DIVISION 1. - PERSONNEL BOARD 

Sec. 2-601. - Personnel board. 
(a)  The mayor pro tem of the city council shall serve as chairman of the personnel board and the mayor shall appoint two (2) other members of the council to serve on the personnel board. 
    The mayor shall fill all vacancies on the board by appointment, subject to approval by a majority of the members of city council. 
    A member appointed to fill an unexpired term shall hold the position on the board for the remainder of the unexpired term of the person who leaves the position vacant. 
    If, during the term for which he or she is appointed to the board, a member of the board is absent from three (3) of its meetings, consecutively the position on the board shall become vacant. A member of the board may be removed from the board for just cause by the council with the approval of two-thirds ( 2/3 )of the members. 
    No person appointed to the board shall be an employee of the city in any capacity other than as a member of the council. 
(b)  All appointed members of the board shall serve one year unless they are no longer a member of the council. 
(c)  The board shall: 
(1)  Establish its own rules of procedure; 
(2)  Advise and make recommendations to the city administrator on matters concerning personnel administration; 
(3)  Upon the request of the city administrator, the council or upon its own initiative, inquire into the administration of the personnel system and, on the basis of the inquiry, make recommendations regarding the system; 
(4)  When requested by the city administrator or the human resources director, or city's legal counsel, assist in investigations; 
(5)  After receiving a petition, hear appeals of decisions of the city administrator pursuant to the applicable discipline or grievance procedure. 
( Ord. No. 5621 , § 5, 7-10-17) 
Secs. 2-602-2-609. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - EQUAL EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITY 

Sec. 2-610. - Equal employment opportunity. 
    The City of Lebanon is an equal opportunity employer and prohibits discrimination against employees or applicants on the basis of race, color, religion, sex, national origin, age, disability, military status, or any factor whose consideration is prohibited by federal, state, or local law. 
( Ord. No. 5621 , § 5, 7-10-17) 
Secs. 2-611-2-619. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - DISCIPLINE AND GRIEVANCES 

Sec. 2-620. - Disciplinary action and offenses. 
    This policy and procedure sets forth guidelines for employee disciplinary actions. Each step builds on the former, thereby providing a progressive approach. Honest, straightforward communications, both verbal and written, is essential to the supervisor-employee relationship. 
    Conduct that interferes with operations, discredits the City of Lebanon, or is offensive or dangerous to others in the work place is grounds for discipline, whether or not such conduct is expressly prohibited by or in violation of any applicable rule, policy or directive. 
    Disciplinary action involving more than a verbal warning or counseling shall not be initiated without first consulting with the human resources department. A progressive discipline approach is the preferred method of resolution, however; certain circumstances may require a more severe resolution. In these circumstances, one or more steps may be bypassed straight to termination of employment. 
    The following are declared to be improper conduct and may be grounds for disciplinary action. This list is intended to serve as a guide to employees and department heads and is not inclusive. 
(1)  Violation of the city's substance abuse policy by the introduction, possession, or use of intoxicating liquors or controlled substances on city property or in city vehicles during working hours. 
(2)  Insubordination: Failure to obey any reasonable work direction made by a supervisor; noncompliance with the city's rules, policies or procedures, or with reasonable work directions/assignments made by supervision shall be insubordination. 
(3)  Incompetency, inefficiency or wastefulness in the line of duty. 
(4)  Theft, attempted theft, misappropriation or willful damage to city property or the property of another person or entity; misappropriation, destruction theft, conversion or falsification of any record, report or information required by the city. 
(5)  Dishonesty, misrepresentation, falsification, exaggeration, or concealment of a material fact in connection with any official document or proceeding; withholding material facts in connection with matters under official investigation. 
(6)  Repeated failure or negligence in the care and handling of city property or equipment which causes damage to the property or equipment. 
(7)  Engaging in profane, lewd or offensive conduct or language toward members of the public, city officials, supervisors or other personnel. 
(8)  Engaging in a violation of the city's workplace harassment policy or EEO Policy which prohibit discrimination on the basis of race, creed, color, marital status, national origin, religion, sex, age, disability, political affiliation, military status, ancestry, or any classification which is protected by federal or state law as it pertains to employees and non-employees on city property, or in conjunction with the employee's assigned duties. 
(9)  Possession of dangerous or unauthorized materials, such as explosives or firearms, in the workplace, unless authorized by the city. 
(10)  Any conduct unbecoming an employee of the city, either on or off duty, provided said conduct relates detrimentally to the employee's ability to perform those job tasks assigned to him. 
(11)  Excessive absenteeism or any absence without permission, proper notice, or satisfactory reason. Any employee who is absent for more than two (2) consecutive work days without proper notice or failure to report for work after an approved absence or leave of absence shall be deemed to have resigned his position. 
(12)  Failure to report an on-the-job accident or personal injury to supervisor immediately after such accident or personal injury occurs. 
(13)  Serious or repeated violations of department or city safety rules. 
(14)  Making false claims or statements against or about the city or its employees. 
(15)  Plea of guilty or conviction of a felony or misdemeanor involving moral turpitude. 
(16)  Unauthorized disclosure of confidential information or business "secrets" offered to the city. 
( Ord. No. 5621 , § 5, 7-10-17) 
Sec. 2-621. - Forms of discipline and procedures of appeals. 
    The City of Lebanon believes that a progressive discipline approach is in the best interest of the employee and the city. The employee progressive discipline procedure can begin at any discipline level, depending upon the nature and severity of the employee's conduct. This listing does not necessarily imply a required sequence. Employee discipline above a warning or counseling shall be initiated by the Human Resources department and any discipline shall become a part of the employee's permanent file. All actions will be kept confidential to the greatest extent as possible. 
(1)  Warning and counseling. A minor infraction of the City of Lebanon's Personnel Policies and Regulations Handbook and departmental policies shall result in the employee receiving a verbal or written warning from the supervisor or department head. The warning or counseling shall include a description of the deficiency and the corrective action taken by the supervisor or department head. If a supervisor or department head issues a warning or counseling, it shall be taken into consideration in the employee's next performance evaluation. The written warning or counseling shall be forwarded to the human resources department and shall become part of the employee's permanent file. Warnings and counseling are considered to be an administrative action and may not be appealed. An employee who receives a warning or counseling may submit a written response which shall accompany the warning or counseling in the permanent file. 
(2)  Written reprimand. A serious infraction of the City of Lebanon's Personnel Policies and Regulations Handbook or departmental policies shall result in the employee receiving a written reprimand from the supervisor or department head. Written reprimands shall only be initiated after the operational supervisor, division leader, or department head has consulted with the Human Resources department. A written reprimand is a written communication from the supervisor or department head to the employee which sets out the offense or deficiency and details the disciplinary action that was taken. An employee who is issued a written reprimand will be required to acknowledge receipt. The written reprimand and acknowledgement shall become part of the employee's permanent file. A copy of the written reprimand will be furnished to the employee. Written reprimands are considered to be an administrative action and may not be appealed. An employee who receives a written reprimand may submit a written response which shall accompany the written reprimand in the permanent file. 
(3)  Probation. Defined as a period of time, not to exceed six (6) months (unless authorized by the city administrator, where up to twelve (12) months' probation can be used), during which the employee is placed under enhanced supervision and regular observation of his or her performance and conduct. An employee is not eligible for pay increases or promotional opportunities during this period. Written notice of the probation shall cite the reasons for the probation and shall be provided to the employee. The employee will be required to acknowledge receipt. The written notice and the acknowledgement shall become part of the employee's permanent file. Department heads who are contemplating probation must consult the human resources department prior to taking action. Department heads contemplating probation exceeding six (6) months must consult the human resources department and obtain authorization from the city administrator prior to taking action. Probation may be appealed in accordance with the disciplinary appeal procedure. 
(4)  Suspension. An employee may be temporarily suspended from work without pay for a period not to exceed thirty (30) consecutive calendar days for any disciplinary offense or offenses, or pending the outcome of an investigation involving the employee. Upon approval of the city administrator, a suspension with pay may be invoked pending the outcome of an investigation. An employee will not be permitted to offset suspension time with accrued leave time. If found innocent or cleared, or if the suspension is overturned upon review or appeal, the employee's wages and benefits shall be retroactive to the date suspension commenced. Written notice of suspension shall cite the reasons for the suspension and the employee will be required to acknowledge receipt. The written notice and the acknowledgement shall become part of the employee's permanent file. Department heads who are contemplating suspension must consult with the human resources department and obtain authorization from the city administrator prior to taking action. Suspensions may be appealed in accordance to the disciplinary appeal procedure. 
(5)  Demotion. A department head, in consultation with the human resources department, may recommend to the city administrator that an employee receive a disciplinary demotion for unsatisfactory performance or conduct, by moving the employee to a position classification which has a lower salary. Written notice of the disciplinary demotion shall cite the reasons for the demotion, shall be provided to the employee and the employee will be required to acknowledge receipt. The written notice and the acknowledgement shall become part of the employee's permanent file. Demotions may be appealed in accordance to the disciplinary appeal procedure. 
(6)  Termination. A department head, in consultation with the Human Resources department, may recommend the termination of an employee. An employee may be terminated for one single serious violation of the City of Lebanon's Personnel Policies and Regulations Handbook or departmental policies or after the employee has failed to improve his work performance or correct his deficiencies. Termination of an employee will only occur after the review and approval of the action by the city administrator. The city administrator shall review all terminations. Written notice of the termination shall cite the reasons for the termination and shall be provided to the employee. The written notice shall become part of the employee's permanent file. Terminations may be appealed in accordance to the disciplinary appeal procedure. 
( Ord. No. 5621 , § 5, 7-10-17) 
Sec. 2-622. - Discipline procedure. 
(a)  Disciplinary action being contemplated. Prior to any regular employee being formally disciplined, a conference between the employee and the department head shall be set up in accordance to the following procedure: 
(1)  Written notice to employee. The human resources department shall issue and cause to be delivered to the employee a written notice of the charges against the employee, the nature of the evidence supporting the charges, the possible disciplinary action being contemplated, and the time and place of a meeting with the department head for the employee to present his side of the story. 
(2)  Nature of meeting. The conference is not a full-scaled hearing, the employee is not entitled to cross examine witnesses, the employee does not have the right to have an attorney participate in the meeting, the meeting will usually be scheduled promptly after the written notice, and the employee shall have the right to present his side of the story either verbally or written. 
(3)  Action before the conference. An employee may be placed on leave upon approval of the city administrator. 
(4)  Action after the conference. After the conference, the department head, with authorization from the city administrator, shall have the authority to direct such disciplinary action as he shall consider appropriate under the circumstances. 
(5)  Notice of disciplinary action. Promptly after taking action, the department head, with authorization of the city administrator, shall issue and deliver to the employee a written notice of the disciplinary action taken against the employee. 
(6)  Permanent file to be maintained. A written notice of all disciplinary action taken by the department head, with the city administrator's approval shall become part of the permanent file and a copy shall be provided to the employee. 
(b)  Right of appeal to the personnel board. Regular employees are granted the right of appeal of a disciplinary action to the personnel board. The personnel board may at that time uphold, modify, or rescind the action of the city administrator. 
(1)  All appeals shall be presented in writing and delivered to the human resources department within ten (10) business days of the receipt of the notice of disciplinary action. 
(2)  The city administrator in conjunction with the human resource director shall call a meeting of the personnel board to arrange a date and time so the appeal can be heard. 
(c)  Right of appeal to the remaining city council. In the event the employee is not satisfied with the decision of the personnel board, regular employees are granted a subsequent appeal to the remaining city council. The city council may at that time uphold, modify, or rescind the action of the personnel board. 
(1)  All subsequent appeals shall be present in writing and delivered to the human resources department within ten (10) business days of the decision rendered by the personnel board. 
(2)  The hearing shall be conducted within forty-five (45) days of the filing of the written notice of appeal by the employee. The parties can agree on a continuance of the appeal hearing not to exceed sixty (60) days. 
(3)  The presentation of evidence at the appeals hearing shall be closed to the public, and the determination and deliberation of the five (5) members of council after the hearing shall be closed to the public. 
(4)  After the appeal hearing is completed, the five (5) members of city council, by majority vote, shall uphold, modify, or rescind the action of the personnel board. 
(5)  The five (5) members of council shall have twenty (20) business days following the close of all proceedings and presentation of evidence on the appeal within which to make a decision. 
(6)  The five (5) members of city council shall issue written findings of fact, conclusions and decisions within the twenty (20) day period they have to make their decision and copies shall be delivered to the employee or his attorney. The decision of the five (5) members of city council on the employee's appeal shall be final and if the decision shall be against the employee, the employee shall have the rights of an aggrieved party pursuant the RSMo 536.100. 
(7)  This appeal procedure is hereby declared to be the policy of the city as placing the final decision regarding personnel disciplinary matters with a majority of the duly elected officials of the municipal government. 
(8)  The appeal of any disciplinary action by employee shall be a contested case as provided and governed by the RSMo Ch. 536. 
( Ord. No. 5621 , § 5, 7-10-17) 
Sec. 2-623. - Grievance policy and procedures. 
    The city desires to resolve employee grievances promptly and fairly. A calm and sensible discussion between the employee and the immediate supervisor will usually resolve most employee problems. This sort of settlement, without bringing in a third party is, of course, the best way to settle most grievances. This can be done readily when both the supervisor and the employee adopt a proper attitude and show willingness to settle differences that may exist, intelligently and on a reasonable basis. 
    Employees are free to seek answers to any questions and adjustments of any grievances without discrimination, coercion, restraint, or reprisal. Supervisors and higher authorities shall see that all questions, complaints, and grievances receive prompt, impartial, and systematic consideration in attempting to reach satisfactory adjustments. 
    If a situation occurs when you believe that a condition of employment or a decision that affects you is not fair, you are encouraged to use the following problem resolution steps. You may stop the procedure at any step. 
    In the event the employee elects to process the facts of the grievance through an alternate process (lawsuit, charge of discrimination, etc.) the city may elect to terminate the processing of the employee's grievance to allow it to be handled in the alternate forum selected by the employee. 
(1)  Step 1-First line of supervision. 
a.  Informal discussion of grievance. An attempt should be made to resolve any alleged grievance in an informal discussion between the employee who is the grievant and the person in the first line of supervision. An informal answer or adjustment of a question or complaint concluded between an employee and the first line supervision shall not establish a precedent in any comparable situation. 
b.  Filing of grievance with the division supervisor. If the grievant is not satisfied with the resolution of the grievance after the informal discussion outlined above, the grievant may file a grievance, in writing, on a form prepared for this purpose, with the division supervisor within ten (10) business days after the date of occurrence of the event giving rise to the grievance or after such date first became known to the grievant. 
1.  The written grievance shall provide a description of the facts that all alleged to give rise to the grievance and shall state the remedy requested. 
2.  Within five (5) business days after the division supervisor receives the written grievance, a meeting shall be held with the grievant and the department supervisor at a mutually agreeable time other than when the employee is engaged in assigned duties, to discuss the grievance and attempt to resolve the same. 
3.  The division supervisor shall render a decision and communicate it in writing to the grievant and the human resource director within five (5) business days following the meeting between that person and the grievant. 
(2)  Step 2-Division supervisor and human resource director. 
a.  Filing a grievance with the division supervisor and human resource director. If the grievant is not satisfied with the resolution of the grievance at Step 1, or if no decision has been rendered, the grievant may present the grievance to the division supervisor and human resource director. The grievance shall be presented in writing within five (5) business days after the decision at Step 1, or ten (10) business days after the meeting between the grievant and the division supervisor if no decision was rendered. 
b.  Meeting with the division supervisor and human resource director. Within five (5) business days after the grievance is filed with the division supervisor and human resource director, a meeting shall be held with the grievant and the division supervisor and human resource director, in an effort to resolve the grievance. 
c.  Decision of the division supervisor and human resource director. The division supervisor and human resource director shall give an answer within five (5) business days of the meeting and communicate it in writing to the grievant and the department supervisor. 
(3)  Step 3-City administrator. 
a.  Filing of grievance with the city administrator. If the grievant is not satisfied with the resolution of the grievance at Step 2, or if no decision has been rendered, the grievant may appeal the grievance to the city administrator. The grievance shall be presented in writing within five (5) business days after the decision at Step 2, or ten (10) business days after the meeting between the grievant and the department head or human resource director if no decision was rendered. 
b.  Meeting with the city administrator. Within five (5) business days after the grievance is filed with the city administrator, a meeting shall be held with the grievant and the city administrator, in an effort to resolve the grievance. 
c.  Decision by the city administrator. The city administrator shall give an answer within five (5) business days of the meeting and communicate it in writing to the grievant, department supervisor, department head, and human resource director. 
(4)  Step 4-Appeal to the personnel board. 
a.  Appeal to the personnel board. In the event the grievant is not satisfied with the resolution of the grievance at Step 3, or if no decision has been rendered by the city administrator, the grievant may appeal to the personnel board. 
b.  The personnel board shall consider and decide the grievant's appeal in closed session and may accept, reject, or modify any previous determination made on the grievance. 
c.  The personnel board may, in its discretion, elect to hear the appeal by receiving written submissions from the grievant and the mayor or city administrator; listening to oral presentations by the grievant and the supervision; or it may decide the appeal on the documents and decisions made at Steps 1 through 3 of this procedure. 
d.  Where the grievance involves discipline or termination, the employee may elect to have a hearing before the personnel board. 
e.  The decision of the personnel board shall be final and binding upon all parties to the grievance procedure. The personnel board shall notify the grievant in writing as to its decision within ten (10) business days after a final vote is taken concerning the appeal of the grievance. 
( Ord. No. 5621 , § 5, 7-10-17) 
Secs. 2-624-2-800. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - INDEMNIFICATION OF OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES 

Sec. 2-801. - City may purchase insurance. 
    To the extent permitted by law, the city may, in its discretion, purchase and maintain insurance on behalf of the city and/or any person who is or was an elected or appointed public official, officer, employee or agent of the city and/or its boards or commissions, or is or was serving on any other public board or commission at the request of the city, against claims or causes of action for damages, property damage or personal injuries including death, caused by such officer, employee or board or commission member while in the exercise of government functions. 
(Ord. No. 3305, Div. 1, 9-26-88) 
Sec. 2-802. - City may indemnify. 
    The city may, in its discretion and in accord with the provisions set forth in this section, indemnify any person who was or is a party or is threatened to be made a party to any action, suit or proceeding, whether civil, criminal, administrative or investigative, other than an action brought by or in the right of the city, by reason of the fact that such person is or was an elected or appointed public official, officer or was serving at the request of the city on any other public board or commission. 
(Ord. No. 3305, Div. 1, 9-26-88) 
Sec. 2-803. - Limits of indemnification. 
    The nature and extent of such indemnification may include expenses, attorney fees, judgments, fines and/or amounts paid in settlement or compromise, and actually and reasonably incurred in connection with such action, suit or proceeding. Provided, however, that the city shall not be obligated to pay any claim, judgment or expense, including attorney fees, unless and until the benefits of any insurance, whether provided by the city or by the person seeking indemnification, have been exhausted and, provided further, in no event in excess of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for any one claimant or an aggregate of one hundred fifty thousand dollars ($150,000.00) for all claims arising out of and upon the same act or an aggregate of one hundred fifty thousand dollars ($150,000.00) during any one calendar year. In addition, the indemnification may also include any deductible amount from any policy of insurance, whether provided by the city or the person seeking indemnification. 
(Ord. No. 3305, Div. 1, 9-26-88) 
Sec. 2-804. - Determination of eligibility. 
    The city may in its discretion provide indemnification if, based upon the information available to the city at the time a determination of indemnification is made, it is found by the city that: 
(1)  The public official, officer, agent, employee or board or commission member acted in good faith; and 
(2)  In a manner he or she reasonably believed to be in or not opposed to the best interest of the city; 
(3)  Such person had no reasonable cause to believe his or her conduct was unlawful or unconstitutional. 
If the city has made a determination to provide indemnification to any public official, officer, agent, employee or board or commission member and thereafter believes that reason may exist to find that such person did not act in accord with one or more of the three (3) criteria set forth above, the city shall notify such person that a hearing shall be conducted at a time and place fixed by the city to determine whether such person shall be further indemnified as provided herein. If, at such hearing and based upon the evidence and information then available to the city, it shall be determined that such person did not act in accord with one or more of the criteria listed above, the city shall terminate further indemnification forthwith and the city shall not thereafter be liable for any expenses or payments for which indemnity would otherwise have been available under this section. Expenses or obligations incurred by the city prior to any such determination of ineligibility as provided herein shall not be affected thereby. 
    The termination of any action, suit or proceeding by judgement, order, settlement, conviction, or upon a plea of nolo contendere or its equivalent, shall not, of itself, create a presumption that the person did not act in good faith or not in a manner which he or she reasonably believed to be in or not opposed to the best interest of the city, or had reasonable cause to believe that his or her conduct was unlawful or unconstitutional. 
(Ord. No. 3305, Div. 1, 9-26-88) 
Sec. 2-805. - Negligence or misconduct; exception. 
    No indemnification shall be made in respect to any claim, or matter as to which such public official shall have been adjudged to be liable for negligence or misconduct in performance of his or her duty to the city. 
(Ord. No. 3305, Div. 1, 9-26-88) 
Secs. 2-806-2-810. - Reserved. 
Sec. 2-811. - Time of indemnification. 
    Expenses incurred in defending a civil or criminal action, suit or proceeding may be paid by the city in advance of the final disposition of the action, suit or proceeding as authorized by the city council in the specific case. 
(Ord. No. 3305, Div. 1, 9-26-88) 
Sec. 2-812. - Notice to city. 
    Any person seeking indemnification from the city shall in the event of any occurrence or upon receipt of notice of any claim, suit, action or proceeding promptly notify in writing the city administrator of the city of the identity of the person seeking indemnification and all reasonably obtainable information with respect to the time, place and circumstances that gave rise to the claim, including the name and address of the injured party and of any witnesses. 
(Ord. No. 3305, Div. 1, 9-26-88) 
Sec. 2-813. - Settlement authority. 
    The person seeking indemnification shall cooperate with the city in any investigation, defense, negotiation or compromise of any claim, suit or action, even if any of the allegations of the suit are groundless, false or fraudulent. The city may make such investigation and settlement of any claim or suit as it deems expedient. 
Sec. 2-814. - City attorney to defend. 
    Any investigation, defense, negotiation or compromise covered by this section shall be conducted by the city counselor or his designees. 
(Ord. No. 3305, Div. 1, 9-26-88) 
Sec. 2-815. - Indemnification not assignable. 
    The indemnification provided herein is intended for the protection and welfare of the city, its public officials whether elected or appointed, its employees or agents as herein set forth and no such person can assign, sell, pledge, hypothecate or in any other manner anticipate or dispose of such right to indemnification. No party recovering any judgment, fines, amounts paid in settlement or compromise of claim or cause of action or expense including attorney fees, against a person eligible for indemnification can sue the city to recover or enforce any claim for indemnification. 
(Ord. No. 3305, Div. 1, 9-26-88) 
Secs. 2-816-2-820. - Reserved. 
Sec. 2-821. - Construction. 
    Nothing herein shall be construed to broaden the liability of the city, its public officials whether elected or appointed, its employees or agents, nor to abolish or waive any defense at law which might otherwise be available to the city, its public officials whether elected or appointed, its employees or agents. 
(Ord. No. 3305, Div. 1, 9-26-88) 
Sec. 2-822. - Public purpose. 
    The payment of such amounts as may be necessary for the benefit of any person covered hereby are deemed necessary and proper public purposes for which funds of this city may be expended. 
(Ord. No. 3305, Div. 1, 9-26-88) 
Secs. 2-823-2-850. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - REGULATION AUTHORITY FOR MINIMUM STANDARDS FOR CONSTRUCTION AND BUILDING OF SEWER, WATER, SIDEWALKS, STREETS, CURBS, GUTTERS, STORM DRAINAGE AND ELECTRICAL FACILITIES[12]

Editor's note- Ord. No. 3321, § 2, adopted January 10, 1989, amended the Code by adding a new Ch. 27, § 27-1. For purposes of classification and in order to maintain Code format, the aforesaid has been redesignated as Art. XI, § 2-851, of Ch. 2. 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6; streets, sidewalks, and other public places, Ch. 22; subdivision regulations, Ch. 23; utilities, Ch. 26. 

Sec. 2-851. - Regulation-making authority. 
    The city council shall have the authority and power to adopt minimum standards for the construction and building of sewer, water, sidewalks, streets, curbs, gutters, storm drainage, and electrical facilities in all areas of the city including, but not limited to, existing subdivisions and new subdivisions. The city council may amend, change or alter the minimum standards from time to time. No building permit shall be issued for the construction, reconstruction, remodeling or refurbishing of any structure or building unless and until all requirements of the minimum standards as adopted by the city council have been satisfied, provided that such minimum standards are already in existence on the lots adjoining the property which is the subject of the permit application.

ARTICLE XII. - PURCHASING POLICY 

Sec. 2-900. - Short title. 
    This article may be known and cited as the "Purchasing Policy of the City of Lebanon, Missouri." 
(Ord. No. 4769, § 2, 9-13-10) 
Sec. 2-901. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of said article is to establish rules and procedures governing the procurement of materials, supplies, equipment and services for the city and to maintain a high ethical standard for all officers and employees of the city in connection herein. It is the intention of the purchasing policy to provide for a system to coordinate the bid process and to consolidate purchases where possible among departments to include city-wide in achieving efficiencies and cost savings. 
(Ord. No. 4769, § 2, 9-13-10) 
Sec. 2-902. - Purchasing agent. 
    The city administrator shall supervise the purchasing for the city and shall see that the purchasing is done in accordance with the purchasing rules and procedures now in effect or later approved by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 4769, § 2, 9-13-10; Ord. No. 4911, § 1, 10-3-11) 
Sec. 2-903. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4911, § 2, adopted October 13, 2011, repealed § 2-903, which pertained to duties-generally and derived from Ord. No. 4769, adopted September 13, 2010. 
Secs. 2-904-2-909. - Reserved. 
Sec. 2-910. - Purchasing and contracting policy. 
    Except as exempt or approved by the city administrator said purchasing policy shall be followed for all purchases by the city. 
(Ord. No. 4769, § 2, 9-13-10) 
Sec. 2-911. - Purchase order issuance and validity subject to availability of funds. 
    A purchase order shall be issued and become valid only when approved by the department head and city administrator or department director who shall have first determined that the purchase is being made in compliance with these regulations and that there is a sufficient unencumbered balance in the appropriate account of the using department to fund such purchase order, except where otherwise provided in the budget. 
(Ord. No. 4769, § 2, 9-13-10) 
Sec. 2-912. - Open market purchases. 
    The department supervisor, or the purchasing department, may acquire in the open market all goods and services with a value of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or less. Such acquisition shall be based upon sound procurement principals. Purchases may be made as open purchases and employees shall take every reasonable effort to ensure that competitive prices are received. No contract or purchase shall be subdivided to avoid open market purchases bidding procedures. Exceptions to said section is for sole source, specialized and non-standard items as referred to in section 2-920. 
(Ord. No. 4769, § 2, 9-13-10; Ord. No. 4911, § 3, 10-3-11) 
Sec. 2-913. - Verbal bids. 
    A minimum of three (3) verbal bids shall be received for all purchase orders over one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) but not exceeding five thousand dollars ($5,000.00). The city administrator or his/her authorized designee shall utilize a "verbal bid" tracking form that shall indicate at a minimum the bid specification, the vendor's name, address, telephone number, the date of the bid, the vendor's agent's name and the vendor's bid. Formal bids shall not be required; a record of the bids will be included within the purchase order notes. Local qualified vendors will be given priority as referred to in section 2-922 of said Code. The city administrator and/or department head approval is required before commitment on purchases between one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) and five thousand dollars ($5,000.00). The procurement of several items of the same type at substantially the same time is a single purchase for the purpose of this section and the total cost of all such items will determine whether a formal competitive bidding procedure must be followed. No contract or purchase shall be subdivided to avoid verbal bidding procedures. Exception to said section is for sole source, specialized and non-standard items as referred to in section 2-920. 
(Ord. No. 4769, § 2, 9-13-10; Ord. No. 4911, § 4, 10-3-11) 
Sec. 2-914. - Written bids. 
    A minimum of three (3) written bids shall be received for all purchase over five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) but not exceeding twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00). All bids must be responsive and attached to the purchase order. Local qualified vendors shall be given priority as referred to in section 2-922. The city administrator shall approve all purchases between five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) and ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) before a purchase commitment is made. The mayor and the city administrator may approve purchases between ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) and twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) before a purchase commitment is made. The procurement of several items of the same type at substantially the same time is a single purchase for the purpose of this section and the total cost of all such items will determine whether a formal written bidding procedure must be followed. No contract or purchase shall be subdivided to avoid written bidding procedures. Exception to said section is for sole source, specialized and non-standard items as referred to in section 2-920. 
(1)  Such notice shall include: 
a.  A general written description of the project name, project number, scope of work and/or items to be purchased; and 
b.  The conditions of such purchase. 
(2)  The city administrator or his/her authorized designee, in conjunction with the department head of said department requesting said bid, shall prepare a written summary of all bids, including a review of the facts. All bids received shall be made available for inspection as a public record. 
(3)  When deemed necessary by the city administrator or his/her authorized designee, bid deposits and/or performance bonds may be required. Such deposits may be required in the form of a certified check or bid bond and may be for the amount of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or ten (10) percent of the bid amount, whichever is greater. All bids not accompanied by required bond shall be rejected. Bid deposits shall be returned to all bidders upon execution of a contract or purchase with the successful bidder. A successful bidder shall forfeit his/her deposit if the contract is not executed within twenty (20) days after the award. 
(4)  The city has the right to reject any/or all bids with or without reason. 
(5)  The city may negotiate with the lowest bidder to reduce the material, equipment or overall project cost. 
(Ord. No. 4769, § 2, 9-13-10; Ord. No. 4911, § 5, 10-3-11) 
Sec. 2-915. - Formal competitive bids. 
    Purchases and contracts over twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) will be advertised in a newspaper of general circulation and on the city's website at least one calendar week prior to the date specified for submission of bids. The city administrator or his/her authorized designee shall prepare information for notice and submit for publication. All formal bids shall be presented to the city council for approval. 
(1)  Such notice shall include: 
a.  A general written description of the project name, project number, scope of work and items to be purchased; 
b.  The conditions of such purchase; 
c.  A statement of bid award to be either lowest or best value, a best value award shall have grading criteria; 
d.  The place where specifications and bid forms may be secured; and 
e.  The date, time and place for bid submittal / opening of bids. 
(2)  All bids shall be sealed, identified on the envelope by company name and address, project name, project number, bid submittal/opening of bids date. 
(3)  All bids shall be submitted to the city clerk on or before the bid submittal date as stated in the public notice inviting bids. The date and time of receipt of each bid shall be entered by the receiving employee on the envelope containing such bid. 
(4)  The city administrator or his/her authorized designee, together with a representative of the city clerk's office, shall publicly open all bids as specified in the notice to bid as "bid opening date" and in conjunction with the department head of said department requesting said bid, shall prepare a written summary of all bids, including a review of the facts. All bids received shall be made available for inspection as a public record. 
(5)  When deemed necessary by the city administrator or his/her authorized designee, bid deposits and/or performance bond and/or payment bond may be required. Such deposits may be required in the form of a certified check or bid bond and may be for the amount of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or ten (10) percent of the bid amount, whichever is greater. All bids not accompanied by required bond shall be rejected. Bid deposits shall be returned to all bidders upon execution of a contract or purchase with the successful bidder. A successful bidder shall forfeit his/her bid deposit if the contract is not executed within twenty (20) days after the award. 
(6)  The city has the right to reject any and/or all bids with or without reason and a provision to this effect shall be included in all notices or advertisements. 
(7)  The city may negotiate with the lowest bidder to reduce the material, equipment or overall project cost. 
(8)  The city clerk shall maintain the original files and records including a copy of the bid notice, specifications and all bid proposals/quotes verifying compliance with the provisions of this policy. 
(9)  It shall be unlawful and a violation of said policy for any employee to subdivide a bid for purposes of evading these bidding requirements. 
(Ord. No. 4769, § 2, 9-13-10; Ord. No. 4911, § 6, 10-3-11) 
Sec. 2-916. - Request for information (RFI). 
    A request for information (RFI) may be used to request information on potential vendor(s) or service provider(s) to determine what products and services are available and to know the capability of the vendor/provider in terms of offerings and strengths of the company for preparing for a request for proposal (RFP) or request for qualifications (RFQ) developing strategy and/or building a database. Request for information procedures to follow shall be set forth by the purchasing agent. 
(Ord. No. 4769, § 2, 9-13-10) 
Sec. 2-916.1. - Capital improvement purchases. 
    All capital equipment and improvements purchases over five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) shall be presented to council for approval. 
(Ord. No. 4911, § 7, 10-3-11) 
Sec, 2-917. - Request for qualifications (RFQ). 
    A request for qualifications (RFQ) may be used to request vendor and/or provider qualifications prior to initiating a request for proposal (RFP) for a specified project scope of work. Request for qualifications procedures to follow shall be set forth by the purchasing agent. 
(Ord. No. 4769, § 2, 9-13-10) 
Sec. 2-918. - Request for proposal (RFP). 
    A request for proposal (RFP) may be used to request proposals from vendors and/or providers requiring expert and/or technical knowledge or skill regarding a specified project scope of work. Request for proposal procedures to follow shall be set forth by the purchasing agent. 
(Ord. No. 4769, § 2, 9-13-10) 
Sec. 2-919. - Emergency clause. 
    In case of an apparent emergency that requires immediate purchase of supplies or contractual services, the city administrator or his/her authorized designee, may authorize the purchase, at the lowest obtainable price, of any supplies or contractual services. A full explanation of the circumstances of an emergency purchase shall be included in the purchase order documentation. 
(Ord. No. 4769, § 2, 9-13-10; Ord. No. 4911, § 8, 10-3-11) 
Sec. 2-920. - Sole source, specialized and non-standard items. 
    The city administrator or his/her authorized designee, may approve negotiated procurement of goods or services without requiring bids if it is determined from all information submitted by the purchasing agent that use of a specific product, manufacturer or vendor is desirable to maintain consistency of equipment, such goods are of such specialized or non-standard nature that can be acquired only from a sole source of supply and that no similar standard goods would reasonably satisfy the city's requirements. 
(Ord. No. 4769, § 2, 9-13-10; Ord. No. 4911, § 9, 10-3-11) 
Sec. 2-921. - Absence or rejection of bids. 
    The city administrator or his/her authorized designee, may approve negotiated procurement of goods or services if there have been no responsive bids or if all bids have been rejected. 
(Ord. No. 4769, § 2, 9-13-10; Ord. No. 4911, § 10, 10-3-11) 
Sec. 2-922. - Buy local. 
    It is the policy and intent of the city in awarding of contracts and the purchase of goods and materials to encourage doing business with suppliers located within the city or Laclede County. The cost difference between the lowest bidder and local bidder shall be no greater than three (3) percent. 
(Ord. No. 4769, § 2, 9-13-10; Ord. No. 4911, § 11, 10-3-11) 
Sec. 2-923. - Inspection and testing. 
    The city, in accordance with and subject to the rules, regulations and procedures in said section and all applicable city ordinances, state and federal laws shall ensure product quality and order accuracy as follows: 
(1)  The city administrator or his/her authorized designee, shall inspect or supervise all deliveries of supplies, materials, equipment or services to determine their conformance with the specifications set forth in the purchase order. 
(2)  The city administrator or his/her authorized designee, may authorize departments to inspect all deliveries made to such department under rules and regulations which the city shall prescribe. 
(3)  The city administrator or his/her authorized designee, shall have the authority to require chemical and physical tests of delivery samples to determine their quality and conformance with the specifications. In the performance of such tests, the city shall have the authority to use laboratory facilities of any outside laboratory. 
(Ord. No. 4769, § 2, 9-13-10; Ord. No. 4911, § 12, 10-3-11) 
Sec. 2-924. - Cooperative purchasing. 
    The city administrator or his/her authorized designee, shall have authority to join with the state, county or any other governmental entity in cooperative purchasing when the best interests of the city would be served by such cooperative purchasing and shall be considered in compliance with the procedures of the purchasing policy. Provided that, the process for seeking such cooperative purchases must be done in accordance with the principles and intent of these regulations. 
(Ord. No. 4769, § 2, 9-13-10; Ord. No. 4911, § 13, 10-3-11) 
Sec. 2-925. - Unauthorized purchases. 
    Except as provided in regulations prescribed by the purchasing agent, it shall be unlawful for any officer or employee of the city other than the purchasing agent to purchase materials, supplies or equipment or to enter into contracts for any goods or services and the city shall not be bound by any purchase order or contract made in violation of the provisions of this policy. 
(Ord. No. 4769, § 2, 9-13-10) 
Sec. 2-926. - Disposition of surplus supplies, material and equipment. 
    City property, equipment, supplies and materials that are no longer required by the city and that have been declared surplus by the city council shall be disposed of in the following manner: 
(1)  Sold to the general public through advertised bid or auction; 
(2)  Traded-in on other equipment or goods; 
(3)  Salvaged; 
(4)  Traded to other governmental entities for equipment and/or material of like value; 
(5)  Destroyed; 
(6)  Special handling, (i.e. hazardous materials); or 
(7)  Provided as an in-kind gift to other governmental or political sub-entities of the state (including volunteer fire departments) or service organizations. 
(Ord. No. 4769, § 2, 9-13-10; Ord. No. 4911, § 14, 10-3-11) 
Sec. 2-927. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4911, § 15, adopted October 13, 2011, repealed § 2-927, which pertained to reimbursement of expenses and derived from Ord. No. 4769, adopted September 13, 2010. 
Sec. 2-928. - Gifts and rebates prohibited. 
    Every officer, agent and employee of the city are hereby prohibited from accepting, directly or indirectly, from any person to whom any purchase order or contract is or might be awarded, any rebate, gift, money or anything of substantial value as defined in the City of Lebanon Personnel Policies and Regulations section 102.11(2). 
(Ord. No. 4769, § 2, 9-13-10; Ord. No. 4911, § 16, 10-3-11) 
Sec. 2-929. - Liability of officer violating provisions. 
    Any officer of the city knowingly violating any provision of this section shall be personally liable to the city and liable under his/her bond, if any, for any damages suffered by the city. 
(Ord. No. 4769, § 2, 9-13-10) 
Sec. 2-930. - Payment of bills. 
    All open invoices shall appear on a "payment schedule-by vendor" list submitted to the city council for review and approval. No bill on said list shall be paid without approval of the city council except as authorized by the city administrator. The city administrator is authorized to approve payment prior to council approval for deposits, all expenditures relating to payroll and utility bills and such other bills for which reasonable discounts can be received from early payment or when holding same for council approval would result in penalties or other cost to the city. 
(Ord. No. 4769, § 2, 9-13-10) 
Sec. 2-931. - Prohibitive acts of the council. 
    No member of the city council of the City of Lebanon, Missouri, shall: 
(1)  Perform any service for the city or any agency of the city for any consideration other than the compensation provided for the performance of his or her official duties, except as otherwise provided in this section; or 
(2)  Sell, rent or lease any property to the city or any agency thereof for consideration in excess of five hundred dollars ($500.00) per transaction or five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) per year, unless the transaction is made pursuant to an award on a bid let or a sale made after public notice and in the case of property other than real property, formal competitive bidding, provided that the bid or offer accepted is the lowest received; or 
(3)  Attempt, for any compensation other than the compensation provided for the performance of his or her official duties, to influence the decision of any agency of the city on any matter; except that, this provision shall not be construed to prohibit such person from participating for compensation in any adversary proceeding or in the preparation or filing of any public document or conference thereon. 
(4)  No sole proprietorship, partnership, joint venture, or corporation in which any member of the city council is the sole proprietor, a partner having more than a ten (10) percent partnership interest, or a co-participant or owner of in excess of ten (10) percent of the outstanding shares of any class of stock, shall: 
a.  Perform any service for the city or any agency thereof for any consideration in excess of five hundred dollars ($500.00) per transaction or five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) per year unless the transaction is made pursuant to an award on a contract let after public notice and formal competitive bidding, provided that the bid or offer accepted is the lowest received; 
b.  Sell, rent or lease any property to the city or any agency thereof where the consideration is in excess of five hundred dollars ($500.00) per transaction or five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) per year unless the transaction is made pursuant to an award on a contract let or a sale made after public notice and in the case of property other than real property, formal competitive bidding, provided that the bid or offer accepted is the lowest received. (Compliance with section 105.458 RSMo) 
(Ord. No. 4769, § 2, 9-13-10) 
Sec. 2-932. - Professional services. 
    It shall be the policy of the City of Lebanon, Missouri, to negotiate contracts for architectural, engineering, land surveying, auditing, legal, and other professional services on the basis of demonstrated competence and qualifications for the type of services required at fair and reasonable prices. 
(Ord. No. 4769, § 2, 9-13-10; Ord. No. 4911, § 17, 10-3-11) 
Chapter 3 - AIRPORT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Ordinances pertaining to rules and regulations for the use of the Floyd W. Jones Lebanon Airport saved from repeal, § 1-6(12). 
State Law reference- Operation of airports by cities, RSMo 305.170; manner of operating airports-fees, RSMo 305.210. 

ARTICLE I. - GENERAL 

Sec. 3-1. - Rules and regulations adopted. 
    The pamphlet entitled "Rules and Regulations for the Use of Airport and Facilities, Lebanon, Missouri, October, 1978," is hereby adopted as the rules and regulations governing the use and operation of the airport and the airport facilities. A copy of this pamphlet shall be kept on file in the city clerk's office. 
(Ord. No. 2058, § 1, 11-27-78) 
Sec. 3-2. - Airport advisory board. 
(a)  That an airport advisory board is hereby created and established. 
(b)  The airport advisory board shall consist of five (5) at-large members, and two (2) members of the city council. The five (5) at-large members shall serve staggered terms ranging from one to three (3) years, to be determined by the mayor. Thereafter, all at-large members shall serve terms of three (3) years until their successors are appointed and qualified. 
(c)  The board is advisory only and provides recommendations to the city council on matters concerning long range planning, land use, and improvements for the Floyd W. Jones Memorial Airport. The airport advisory board and its members shall have no powers or authority to contract, incur any liability or expense on behalf of the City of Lebanon, supervise or direct airport management or operations or to make or enforce any laws or regulations. 
(d)  The airport advisory board shall review and make recommendations to the city council on matters pertaining to the management, operation and development of the airport, including but not limited to: 
(1)  Identifying problems involving airport safety, compliance with FAA regulations and other airport policies and recommending solutions; 
(2)  Reviewing the airport master plan and airport layout plan and making recommendations for the development, improvement and promotion of the airport and for state and federal funding sources; 
(3)  Promoting awareness, utilization, and development of the airport pursuant to, and consistent with, the council's adopted goals and objectives and airport master plan; 
(4)  Presenting an annual report concerning the status of the airport; 
(5)  Reviewing airport fees and lease rates and making recommendations for changes; and 
(6)  Receiving comments from members of the public concerning the airport and communicating the same to the city council. 
(e)  Board members shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the majority of the city council. Appointees to the airport advisory board shall be residents of the City of Lebanon, or an area now within the corporate limits, for at least six (6) months and shall not be in arrears in the payment of any fee for service, lease, or other liability due the city; liability not being defined as a tax. 
(f)  The board shall meet as necessary: but no less frequently than semiannually. 
(Ord. No. 4632, § 1, 4-27-09; Ord. No. 4651, § 1, 8-31-09; Ord. No. 4969, § 1, 5-29-12; Ord. No. 5051, § 1, 1-28-13) 
Secs. 3-3-3-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - AIRPORT ZONING ORDINANCE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Zoning, App. A. 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to regulate airports, RSMo 305.170. 

Sec. 3-36. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the Floyd W. Jones Lebanon Airport Zoning Ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 1734, § I, 4-8-68) 
Sec. 3-37. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, unless the context otherwise requires, the following terms shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
    Airport shall mean the Floyd W. Jones Lebanon Airport. 
    Airport elevation shall mean the established elevation of the highest point on the usable landing area, 1318 feet above mean sea level. 
    Airport hazard shall mean any structure, tree or use of land which obstructs the air space required for, or is otherwise hazardous to, the flight of aircraft in landing or taking off from the city airport. 
    Airport reference point shall mean the point established as the approximate geographical center of the airport landing area and so designated. 
    Board of appeals shall mean the board appointed by the city council as provided for in Appendix A, Section 9. 
    Height shall mean, for the purpose of determining the height limits in all zones set forth in this article and shown on the zoning map, the datum shall be mean sea level elevation unless otherwise specified. 
    Landing area shall mean the area of the airport used for landing, taking off or taxying of aircraft. 
    Nonconforming use shall mean any preexisting structure, tree, natural growth or use of land which is inconsistent with the provisions of this article. 
    Runway shall mean the paved surface of an airport landing strip. 
    Structure shall mean an object constructed or installed by man, including, but without limitation, buildings, towers, smokestacks and overhead transmission lines. 
    Tree shall mean any object of natural growth. 
(Ord. No. 1734, § II, 4-8-68) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 3-38. - Enforcement. 
    It shall be the duty of the building and zoning administrator to administer and enforce the regulations prescribed in this article. Applications for permits and variances shall be made to the building and zoning administrator on forms furnished by him. Applications required by this article to be submitted to the building and zoning administrator shall be promptly considered and granted or denied by him. Applications for action by the board of appeals shall be forthwith transmitted by the building and zoning administrator. 
(Ord. No. 1734, § VIII, 4-8-68; Ord. No. 3253, § 2, 6-22-87) 
Sec. 3-39. - Board of appeals. 
    The board of appeals shall have and exercise the following powers: 
(1)  To hear and decide appeals from any order, requirement, decision or determination made by the building and zoning administrator in the enforcement of this article; 
(2)  To hear and decide special exemptions to the terms of this article upon which the board of adjustment under these regulations may be required to pass; and 
(3)  To hear and decide specific variances. 
(Ord. No. 1734, § IX, 4-8-68; Ord. No. 3253, § 2, 6-22-87) 
Cross reference- Board of appeals generally, App. A, § 9A. 
Sec. 3-40. - Zones. 
    In order to carry out the provisions of this article, there are hereby created and established certain zones which include all of the land lying within the approach zone, horizontal zone, conical zone and transition zones. These areas and zones are shown on the Floyd W. Jones Lebanon Airport zoning map and dated January 3, 1968, a copy of which is on file in city clerk' office. The various zones are hereby established and defined as follows: 
(1)  Approach zone. The approach zone for the east and west runway shall have a width of two hundred fifty (250) feet at a distance of two hundred (200) feet beyond each end of the runway, and the approach zone for the north and south runway shall have a width of four hundred (400) feet at a distance of two hundred (200) feet beyond each end of the runway, both widening thereafter uniformly to a width of twenty-two hundred fifty (2,250) feet a distance of ten thousand two hundred (10,200) feet beyond each end of the runway. 
(2)  North and south clear zones. The north clear zone and the south clear zone shall have a width of four hundred (400) feet at a distance of two hundred (200) feet beyond the end of the runway widening uniformly to a width of eight hundred (800) feet at a distance of two thousand two hundred (2,200) feet beyond the end of the runway. 
(3)  East and west clear zones. The east clear zone and the west clear zone shall have a width of two hundred fifty (250) feet at a distance of two hundred (200) feet beyond the end of the runway widening uniformly to a width of four hundred fifty (450) feet at a distance of one thousand two hundred (1,200) feet from the end of the runway. 
(4)  Horizontal zone. A horizontal zone is hereby established as the area within a circle with its center at the airport reference point and having a radius of five thousand (5,000) feet. 
(5)  Conical zone. A conical zone is hereby established as the area that commences at the periphery of the horizontal zone and extends outward there from a distance of three thousand (3,000) feet. 
(6)  Transition zones. Transition zones are hereby established adjacent to each runway and approach zone as indicated on the zoning map. Transition zones symmetrically located on either side of runways have variable widths as shown on the zoning map. Transition zones extend outward from a line two hundred (200) feet either side of runway 13/36 and one hundred twenty-five (125) feet either side of runway 9/27 for the length of the runway, plus two hundred (200) feet on each end. The transition zones along such runways slope upward and outward one foot vertically for each seven (7) feet horizontally to the point where they intersect the surface of the horizontal zone. Further, transition zones are established adjacent to both runway approach zones for the entire length of the approach zones. These transition zones have variable widths as shown on the zoning map. The transition zones flare symmetrically with either side of the runway approach zones from the base of the zones and slope upward and outward at the rate of one foot vertically for each seven (7) feet horizontally to the point where they intersect the surface of the horizontal and conical zones. 
(Ord. No. 1734, § III, 4-8-68) 
Sec. 3-41. - Height limitations. 
    Except as otherwise provided, no structure or tree shall be erected, altered, allowed to grow or maintained in any zone created by this article to a height in excess of the height limit herein established for that zone. These height limitations are hereby established for each of the zones in question as follows: 
(1)  Approach zones: One foot in height for each forty (40) feet in horizontal distance beginning at a point two hundred (200) feet from and at the center line elevation of the end of the runway and extending to a point ten thousand two hundred (10,200) feet from the end of runway. 
(2)  Horizontal zone: One hundred fifty (150) feet above the airport elevation or a height of one thousand four hundred sixty-eight (1,468) feet above mean sea level. 
(3)  Conical zone: One foot in height for each twenty (20) feet of horizontal distance beginning at the periphery of the horizontal zone, extending to a height of three hundred (300) feet above the airport elevation or a height of one thousand six hundred eighteen (1,618) feet above mean sea level. 
(4)  Excepted height limitations. Nothing in this article shall be construed as prohibiting the growth, construction or maintenance of any tree or structure to a height up to thirty-five (35) feet above the surface of the land. Where an area is covered by more than one height limitation, the more restrictive limitation shall prevail. 
(Ord. No. 1734, § IV, 4-8-68) 
Sec. 3-42. - Use restrictions. 
    Notwithstanding any other provisions of this article, no use may be made of land within any zone established by this article in such a manner as to create electrical interference with radio communication between the airport and aircraft, make it difficult for flyers to distinguish between airport lights and others, result in glare in the eyes of flyers using the airport, impair visibility in the vicinity of the airport or otherwise endanger the landing, taking off or maneuvering of aircraft. 
(Ord. No. 1734, § V, 4-8-68) 
Sec. 3-43. - Nonconforming uses. 
(a)  The regulations prescribed by this article shall not be construed to require the removal, lowering or other changes or alterations of any structure or tree not conforming to the regulations as of the effective date of the ordinance upon which this section is based, or otherwise interfere with the continuance of any nonconforming use. Nothing herein contained shall require any change in construction, alteration or intended use of any structure, the construction or alteration of which was begun prior to the effective date of the ordinance upon which the section is based and is diligently prosecuted. 
(b)  Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (a), the owner of any nonconforming structure or tree is hereby required to permit the installation, operation and maintenance thereon of such markers and lights as shall be deemed necessary by the building inspector to indicate to operators of aircraft in the vicinity of the airport, the presence of these airport hazards. The markers and lights described herein shall be installed, operated and maintained at the expense of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1734, § VI, 4-8-68) 
Sec. 3-44. - Permits-Future uses. 
(a)  Except as specifically provided in subsections (b) and (c), no material change shall be made in the use of land and no structure or tree shall be erected, altered, planted or otherwise established in any zone created by this article unless a permit therefore shall have been applied for and granted. Each application for a permit shall indicate the purpose for which the permit is desired, with sufficient particularity to allow it to be determined whether the resulting use, structure or tree would conform to the regulations herein prescribed. If such determination is in the affirmative, the permit shall be granted. 
(b)  Within the area lying within the limits of the horizontal zone and the conical zone, no permit shall be required for any tree or structure less than seventy-five (75) feet of vertical height above the ground, except where because of terrain, land contour or topographic features the tree or structure would extend above the height limits prescribed for that zone. 
(c)  In the areas lying within the approach zone limits but at a horizontal distance of not less than twenty-two hundred (2,200) feet from each end of the runways, no permit shall be required for any tree or structure less than fifty (50) feet in vertical height above the ground, except when the tree or structure would extend above the height limit set for the approach zone. 
(d)  Nothing contained in any of the foregoing exceptions shall be construed as permitting or intending to permit any construction, alteration or growth of any structure or trees in excess of any of the height limits established by this article, except as set forth in section 3-41. 
(Ord. No. 1734, § VII(1), 4-8-68) 
Sec. 3-45. - Same-Existing uses. 
    No permit shall be granted that would allow the establishment or creation of an airport hazard or permit a nonconforming use, structure or tree to be made or become higher, or become a greater hazard to air navigation, than it was on the effective date of the ordinance upon which this section is based or than it is when the application for permit is made. Except as indicated, all applications for a permit shall be granted. 
(Ord. No. 1734, § VII(2), 4-8-68) 
Sec. 3-46. - Same-Nonconforming uses abandoned or destroyed. 
    Whenever the building and zoning administrator determines that a nonconforming structure or tree has been abandoned or more than eighty (80) percent torn down, physically deteriorated or decayed, no permit shall be granted that would allow the structure or tree to exceed the applicable height limit or otherwise deviate from the zoning regulations. 
(Ord. No. 1734, § VII(3), 4-8-86; Ord. No. 3253, § 2, 6-27-87) 
Sec. 3-47. - Variances. 
    Any person desiring to erect or increase the height of any structure, or desiring to permit the growth of any tree, or to use his property, not in accordance with the regulations prescribed in this article, may apply to the board of appeals for a variance from these regulations. A variance shall be allowed where it is duly found that a literal application or enforcement of the regulations would result in practical difficulty or unnecessary hardship and the relief granted would not be contrary to the public interest but will do substantial justice and be in accordance with the spirit of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1734, § VII(4), 4-8-68) 
Sec. 3-48. - Hazard marking and lighting. 
    Any permit or variance granted may, if such an action is deemed advisable to effectuate the purpose of this article and be reasonable in the circumstances, be so conditioned as to require the owner of the structure or tree in question to permit the city at its own expense, to install, operate, and maintain thereon such markers and lights as may be necessary to indicate to flyers the presence of an airport hazard. 
(Ord. No. 1734, § VII(5), 4-8-68) 
Sec. 3-49. - Appeals. 
(a)  Any person aggrieved, or any taxpayer affected by any decision of the building inspector made in his administration of this article, may appeal to the board of appeals. 
(b)  All appeals must be taken within a reasonable time as provided by the rules of the board of appeals, by filing with the building inspector a notice of appeal specifying the grounds thereof. The building inspector shall forthwith transmit to the board of appeals all the papers constituting the record upon which the action appealed from was taken. 
(c)  An appeal shall stay all proceedings in furtherance of the action appealed from, unless the building inspector certifies to the board of appeals, after the notice of appeal has been filed, that, by reason of the facts stated in the certificate, a stay would in his opinion, cause imminent peril to life and property. In such cases, proceedings shall not be stayed except by order of the board of appeals on notice to the building inspector and on due cause shown. 
(d)  The board of appeals shall fix a reasonable time for hearing appeals, give public notice and due notice to the parties in interest, and decide the same within a reasonable time. Upon the hearing any party may appear in person, by agent or by attorney. 
(e)  The board of appeals may, in conformity with the provisions of this article, reverse or affirm in whole or in part, or modify the order, requirement, decision or determination appealed from and may make any such order, requirement, decision, or determination, as may be appropriate under the circumstances. 
(Ord. No. 1734, § X, 4-8-68) 
Sec. 3-50. - Judicial review. 
    Any person aggrieved, or any taxpayer affected, by any decision of the board of appeals, may appeal to the circuit court. 
(Ord. No. 1734, § XI, 4-6-68) 
Sec. 3-51. - Penalties. 
    Each violation of this article or of any regulation, order or ruling promulgated hereunder shall constitute an offense and be punishable by a fine or imprisonment as provided in section 1-12, and each day a violation continues to exist shall constitute a separate offense, as provided in section 1-12. 
(Ord. No. 1734, § XII, 4-6-68) 
Chapter 4 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1] 
Footnotes:
