(Ord. No. 3228, § C, 8-25-86) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3228, § B, adopted August 25, 1986, repealed former § 4-1, concerning definitions, in its entirety. Former § 4-1 derived from the Code of 1967, § 3-1. Section C of Ord. No. 3228 enacted new provisions which were nonamendatory of the Code and have been included herein as § 4-1 at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 4-2. - Drinking in certain public places prohibited. 
    No person shall consume or drink any intoxicating liquor or non-intoxicating beer in any park, cemetery, public land, public park facility, public parking lot or in any public owned or controlled building, except that consumption or drinking shall be allowed in the Kenneth E. Cowan Civic Center and city parks and around the parking lots directly affiliated with those properties for special events and/or occasions when an approved caterer/concessionaire is being contracted for said events. 
(Ord. No. 3055, § 1, 10-12-81; Ord. No. 4635, § 1, 5-11-09; Ord. No. 5722 , § 1, 2-26-18) 
Cross reference- Parks and recreation, Ch. 15; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 22. 
Sec. 4-3. - Possession in certain public places prohibited. 
(a)  No person shall possess any intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer except in the original package with the seal unbroken in any park, cemetery, public land, public park facility, public parking lot or in any public owned or controlled building, except as provided in section 4-2, where one or more additional persons, excluding police officers, shall be in the immediately adjacent area. 
(b)  For purposes of this article, the term "immediately adjacent area" shall mean within thirty-five (35) feet of the person in question. 
(c)  For purposes of this article, the term "possess any intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer except in the original package with the seal unbroken" shall not include the transportation of any intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer with the seal unbroken or in a package other than the original package, so long as it is in a place which is not immediately accessible to the persons occupying the particular mode of transportation involved. 
(Ord. No. 3055, § 2, 10-12-81; Ord. No. 5722 , § 2, 2-26-18) 
Sec. 4-4. - Drinking and possession in certain semi-public parking lots prohibited. 
(a)  If the owner, tenant or other person lawfully in possession of a semi-public parking lot shall display a sign giving notice that the parking lot shall be governed by the provisions of sections 4-2 to 4-5, then it shall be unlawful for any person to drink or consume any intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer thereupon. Where notice shall be displayed, it shall be unlawful for any person to possess any intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer thereupon, except in the original package with the seal unbroken on any semi-public parking lot where two (2) or more additional persons, excluding police officers, shall be in the immediately adjacent area. 
(b)  For purposes of this article, the term "semi-public parking lot" shall include any area wherein motor vehicles are parked in conjunction with any business, enterprise, commercial establishment, office building, apartment building or church. 
(Ord. No. 3055, § 4, 10-12-81) 
Secs. 4-5-4-35. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3228, § B, adopted August 25, 1986, repealed §§ 4-6-4-10 and §§ 4-12-4-20 in their entirety. Section 4-11 had been reserved. The aforesaid sections were concerned with miscellaneous alcoholic beverage and liquor control provisions and derived from the Code of 1967, §§ 3-23, 3-25, 3-26, 3-30; Ord. No. 1784, adopted October 27, 1969; and Ord. No. 2039, adopted May 22, 1978. Subsequently, Ord. No. 1678, adopted May 24, 1999, repealed § 4-5 which pertained to permits for consumption in Nelson Community Center and was derived from Ord. No. 3055, adopted October 12, 1981. 
ARTICLE II. - LICENSES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- State license required, RSMo 311.050 et seq., 312.040 et seq.; state retail licensing provision, RSMo 311.200. 

Sec. 4-36. - Required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, give away, dispense, or expose for sale in the city any intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer in any quantity without taking out a license as required in this article. 
(b)  It shall also be unlawful to conduct wine tastings on the licensed premises without taking out a special license as required by this article. 
(Ord. No. 3607, § 1, 1-9-95) 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 3607, adopted Jan. 9, 1995 repealed § 4-36 in its entirety. Formerly, § 4-36 pertained to licenses for sale of alcoholic beverages and derived from § 3-5 of the 1967 Code. Section 1 of said ordinance added a new § 4-36 as herein set out. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 311.050; nonintoxicating beer permit necessary, 312.030. 
Sec. 4-37. - Qualifications. 
(a)  No person shall be granted a license under this article unless they are of good moral character and a qualified legal voter and taxpaying citizen of the state, nor shall any corporation be granted a license under this article unless the managing officer of the corporation be of good moral character and a qualified legal voter and taxpaying citizen of the state. 
(b)  No person shall be granted a license under this article whose license as such dealer has been revoked, or who has been convicted, since December 5, 1933, of a violation of the provisions of any law applicable to the manufacture or sale of intoxicating liquor and nonintoxicating beer, or who employs in his business as such dealer, any person whose liquor license has been revoked or who has been convicted of violation of such law since December 5, 1933. 
(c)  No person, partnership or corporation shall be qualified for a license under this article if such person, a partnership member, or any officer, director or shareholder or owns ten (10) percent or more of the stock, directly or indirectly, or otherwise, or ten (10) percent or more of the interest in the business that is licensed, shall have had, or, if any person employed by the business licensed shall have had, a license revoked under state law or shall have been convicted of violating the provisions of any law applicable to the manufacture or sale of intoxicating liquor or non-intoxicating beer since December 5, 1933. 
(Code 1967, § 3-6; Ord. No. 3933, § 2, 5-24-99) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 311.060, 312.040. 
Sec. 4-38. - Applications. 
(a)  All applications for licenses required by this article shall be made to the city clerk and shall be accompanied by a remittance in the amount of the proper license fee and payable to the city clerk, who shall account therefor, and no license shall be issued hereunder until the license fee shall be paid. 
(b)  Application shall be made on forms to be furnished by the city clerk and shall be subscribed and sworn to by the applicant. 
(c)  If the applicant is a corporation, then the requirements as to legal voter and taxpaying citizens shall apply to and must be fulfilled by the managing officer of the corporation. 
(Code 1967, § 3-7; Ord. No. 3228, § D, 8-25-86; Ord. No. 3933, § 3, 5-24-99) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 311.210(1), 312.080. 
Sec. 4-39. - Investigation of applicant. 
(a)  When an application has been filed with the city clerk for a license, as required by section 4-36, it shall be the duty of the city clerk to forthwith transmit the application to the police department of the city and the police department shall investigate the applicant to determine whether the applicant's qualifications comply with section 4-37. In addition, the city clerk shall forthwith transmit a copy of the application to the building and zoning administrator and the building and zoning administrator shall make a determination by inspection that the proposed location of the business to be licensed meets the provision and requirements of section 4-49 of this chapter concerning schools and churches. 
(b)  After the investigation has been conducted by the police department, if the applicant is found to meet the qualifications, and if the proposed location of the business to be licensed is found by the building and zoning administrator to comply with the requirements of section 4-49, then it shall be the duty of the city clerk to issue the license upon payment of the proper license fees; but if the applicant is found not to meet the qualifications, or if the location of the premises falls within the prohibited distances provided by section 4-49, then it shall be the duty of the city clerk to not issue the license and, in such case, the city clerk shall notify the applicant in writing of such action and the reasons therefor. 
(Code 1967, § 3-8; Ord. No. 1765, § A, 3-24-69; Ord. No. 3228, § D, 8-25-86; Ord. No. 3253, § 2, 6-22-87) 
Sec. 4-40. - Issuance; separate licenses; proration of license fees. 
    On approval of the application required by section 4-36, and upon payment of an appropriate license fee, a license shall be issued to the applicant by the city clerk to conduct the business described in the application for a term to expire on the thirtieth day of June next succeeding the date of the license. Licenses shall be signed by the mayor and the city clerk and the city clerk shall affix the city's corporate seal thereto. A separate license shall be required for each place of business. Of the annual license fee required to be paid for any license, the applicant shall pay as many twelfths as there are months (part of a month counted as one month) remaining from the date of the license to, but not including, the next succeeding first day of July. 
(Code 1967, § 3-13; Ord. No. 3228, § D, 8-25-86; Ord. No. 3933, § 4, 5-24-99) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 311.240; 312.110. 
Sec. 4-41. - Special licenses; pro-ration of license fee. 
    Any person possessing the qualifications and meeting the requirements of this article who is licensed to sell intoxicating liquor in the original package at retail under the terms and provisions of this article, shall be entitled upon payment of the appropriate special license fee to be issued a special license to the applicant by the city clerk to sell intoxicating liquor in the original package at retail between the hours of 11:00 o'clock a.m. and midnight on Sundays at the licensed premises described in the application for a term to expire on the 30th day of June next succeeding the date of the special license. Special licenses referred to in this section shall be signed by the mayor and the city clerk and the city clerk shall affix the city's corporate seal thereto. Special licenses referred to in this section shall also be countersigned by the city collector upon payment of the special license fee required. A separate special license shall be required for each place of business. Of the annual special license fee required to be paid for any special license referred to in this section, the applicant shall pay as many twelfths as there are months (part of a month counted as one month) remaining from the date of the special license to but not including the next succeeding first day of July. 
(Ord. No. 3607, § 2, 1-9-95) 
Sec. 4-42. - Special licenses for wine tasting. 
    Any person possessing the qualifications and meeting the requirements of this article who is licensed to sell intoxicating liquor in the original package at retail under the terms and provisions of this article, shall be entitled upon payment of the appropriate special license fee to be issued a special license to the applicant by the city clerk to conduct wine tastings on the licensed premises described in the application for a term to expire on the 30th day of June next succeeding the date of the special license. Special licenses referred to in this section shall be signed by the mayor and the city clerk and the city clerk shall affix the city's corporate seal thereto. The said special licenses shall also be countersigned by the city collector upon payment of the special license fee required. A separate special license shall be required for each place of business. Of the annual special license fee required to be paid for any special license, the applicant shall pay as many twelfths as there are months (part of a month counted as one month) remaining from the date of the special license to but not including the next succeeding first day of July. 
(Ord. No. 3607, § 3, 1-9-95) 
Sec. 4-43. - Display. 
    All licenses issued under this article shall be placed, displayed and kept in a conspicuous place on the premises where the business is carried on, and in view so that all persons visiting the premises may readily see the license. 
(Code 1967, § 3-18) 
Sec. 4-44. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3228, § B, adopted August 25, 1986, repealed § 4-44 in its entirety. Former § 4-44 was concerned with transfer of licenses, and derived from the Code of 1967, § 3-19. 
Sec. 4-45. - Duplicate licenses. 
    The city council may authorize a duplicate license to be issued to a licensee upon proof by affidavit that the license was unavoidably lost or destroyed. No fee shall be charged for a duplicate. 
(Code 1967, § 3-20) 
Secs. 4-46-4-48. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3228, § B, adopted August 25, 1986, repealed §§ 4-46-4-48 in their entirety. Former §§ 4-46-4-48 were concerned with miscellaneous restrictions on licenses, and derived from the Code of 1967, §§ 3-12 and 3-24. 
Sec. 4-49. - Licensing near schools and churches prohibited. 
(a)  The provisions of section 311.080.1 of the Revised Statutes of Michigan are hereby adopted by reference and no license for the sale of intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer shall be issued in violation of the provisions of said statute, and in addition, the local option allowed in section 311.080.2 of the Revised Statutes of Missouri is also adopted by reference as to the consumption of intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer on the premises of the establishment selling such so that no license shall be granted for the sale of intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer for consumption on the premises, within three hundred (300) feet of any school, church or other building regularly used as a place of worship, unless the applicant for the license shall first obtain the consent in writing of the board of directors of the school, or the consent in writing of the majority of the managing board of the church or place of worship: except that when a school, church or place of worship is established within three hundred (300) feet of any place of business licensed to sell intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer for consumption on the premises, the license shall not be denied for lack of consent in writing as herein provided. 
(b)  In determining the distance from the school, church or place of worship, the measurement shall be made from the front door of the building used as a school, church or place of worship on a direct line to the front door of the building to be used for the sale of intoxicating liquor. For the purposes of this subsection, "front door" is defined in the case of a school, church or place of worship as the entrance regularly used by those who attend and participate in activities at the building in question. In the case of the building of the business used to sell intoxicating liquor, front door is defined as the entrance regularly used by customers and patrons of that business. In the event there is more than one front door so used, the measurement shall be from the front doors nearest to each other. 
(Code 1967, § 3-2; Ord. No. 1744, § A(1), 8-26-68; Ord. No. 3228, § D, 8-25-86; Ord. No. 4130, § 1, 7-29-02) 
Case law annotation- Vesting in the governing body of a church the power effectively to veto applications for liquor licenses within a certain radius of the church violates the establishment clause of the First Amendment (by failing to properly separate church and state), Larkin v. Grendel's Den, 103 S. Ct. 505 (1982). 
State Law reference- Sales of intoxicating liquors near churches and schools, RSMo 311.080. 
Secs. 4-50, 4-51. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3228, § B, adopted August 25, 1986, repealed §§ 4-50 and 4-51 in their entirety. Former §§ 4-50 and 4-51 were concerned with licensing and derived from the Code of 1985. 
Sec. 4-52. - License fees. 
(a)  A separate license shall be taken out and fees paid for each of the following classes of sales: 
(1)  For the sale of intoxicating liquor: 
a.  At retail in the original package and not to be consumed or opened on the premises where sold ..... $150.00 
b.  At retail on Sundays between the hours of 11:00 o'clock a.m. and midnight on Sundays in the original package and not to be consumed or opened on the premises where sold ..... 300.00 
c.  Containing alcohol not to excess of twenty-two (22) percent by weight by a wholesaler or distributor to a person duly licensed to sell such intoxicating liquor at retail ..... 300.00 
d.  By a wholesaler or distributor to a person duly licensed to sell such liquor at retail ..... 375.00 
e.  By the drink at retail for consumption on the premises ..... 450.00 
(2)  For the sale of what is commonly known as "set-ups" ..... 90.00 
(3)  For the sale of malt liquor containing alcohol in excess of three and two-tenths (3.2) percent by weight: 
a.  By grocers and other merchants and dealers in the original package direct to consumers not for resale ..... 22.50 
b.  To be sold by the drink at retail for consumption on the premises where sold ..... 25.00 
c.  By a wholesaler or distributor to a person duly licensed to sell such liquor at retail ..... 100.00 
(4)  For the sale of three and two-tenths (3.2) percent nonintoxicating beer: 
a.  By wholesaler or distributor ..... 100.00 
b.  For consumption on the premises where sold ..... 37.50 
c.  By grocers and other merchants and dealers in the original package direct to consumers not for resale ..... 22.50 
(b)  A separate special license to conduct wine tasting on the premises of any person who is licensed to sell intoxicating liquor in the original package at retail shall be taken out and the fee shall be ..... $37.50 
    Nothing in this subsection (b) shall be construed to permit the licensee to sell wine for on-premises consumption. 
(c)  The city shall not increase any occupation tax which it now levies upon any holder of any three and two-tenths (3.2) percent nonintoxicating beer license in excess of the amount of such tax imposed upon merchants and dealers in the same or similar lines of business and not holding any such license. 
(Ord. No. 1967, § 3-22; Ord. No. 1920, 6-24-74; Ord. No. 1981, 8-23-76; Ord. No. 2039, § B, 5-22-78; Ord. No. 3228, § D, 8-25-86; Ord. No. 3607, §§ 4, 5, 1-9-95; Ord. No. 1678, § 5, 5-24-99) 
Editor's note- The license fees as set out in § 4-52 have been incorporated herein at the request of the city. Former § 4-52 read as follows: "A separate license shall be required for each separate license required by the State of Missouri and the applicant shall pay to the city as the fee for each separate license an amount equal to one and one-half times the amount required to be paid to the state for the state license. These fees are charged pursuant to the authority granted in sections 311.220 and 312.140 of the Revised Statutes of Missouri." 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to charge such license fees, RSMo 311.220(2), 312.140. 
Sec. 4-53. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3228, § B, adopted August 25, 1986, repealed § 4-53 in its entirety. Former § 4-53 was concerned with renewal of licenses and derived from the Code of 1967, § 3-15. 
Sec. 4-54. - Expiration of license for nonuse thereof. 
    If, for a period of sixty (60) days, any licensee under this article shall not operate his business, his license shall be deemed to have expired and become null and void; provided; that the license will not be deemed to have expired if the business of the licensee shall be inoperative by reason of an act of God, accident or some other cause beyond the control of the licensee. 
Sec. 4-55. - Refunds. 
    No refund shall be made for the unexpired term of any license issued under this article. 
(Code 1967, § 3-21) 
Sec. 4-56. - Suspension and revocation. 
(a)  Whenever it shall be shown or whenever the mayor or city council has knowledge or is informed that a retail licensee under this article: 
(1)  Has not at all times kept an orderly place or house; 
(2)  Has violated any of the provisions of the state liquor control act; 
(3)  Has violated any of the rules and regulations adopted and in force by the state supervisor of liquor; 
(4)  Has no license issued by the state supervisor of liquor; 
(5)  Who has made any false statement for a city license; or 
(6)  When any other valid grounds or reasons shall be found to exist. 
The council, after a hearing thereon, may suspend or revoke the license of the licensee after giving such person at least ten (10) days notice in writing of the time, place, purpose and grounds of complaint. Notice may be served on the licensee in person or upon any person in charge of the place of business of the licensee. The licensee may be represented by counsel and produce testimony at the hearing. 
(b)  The mayor authorized to issue subpoenas for witnesses or papers, including subpoenas duces tecum, and any police officer of the city is authorized to serve them or the subpoena may be served by any officer authorized to serve subpoenas in civil court actions. The subpoena shall be served in the manner authorized by the laws of this state for service in civil court actions. 
(c)  Nothing in this section shall prevent any witness from voluntarily appearing and testifying in the proceeding. All witnesses before testifying must be sworn, either by the mayor or the city clerk. 
(d)  The testimony submitted will not be transcribed except at the request and at the expense of the party so desiring. 
(e)  When a license has been suspended or revoked as provided in this article the mayor shall issue an order of such suspension or revocation as the case may be and have such order served on the license holder and it shall be unlawful to continue business under such license thereafter until such time as such order is revoked, expired by lapse of time in case of suspension and no appeal is taken, or revoked by a court of competent jurisdiction; provided, that any person desiring to keep such place open for the sale of food or other merchandise may do so by displaying the order of suspension or revocation in a conspicuous place on the premises. 
(f)  Any party aggrieved by any order of suspension or revocation, may, within ten (10) days after written notice thereof filed with the city clerk, take an appeal to the circuit court of Laclede County by the filing of an affidavit to the effect that he is aggrieved by the decision of suspension or revocation. Upon the filing of such request and affidavit it shall be the duty of the city clerk to transmit to the circuit court a certified copy of the record of all proceedings had in such matter in his possession. 
(g)  The taking of an appeal shall not stay the enforcement of the order of suspension or revocation. 
(Code 1967, § 3-28, 3-29) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 311.680, 311.691. 
Chapter 5 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes:

State Law reference- Municipal authority concerning animals, RSMo 77.510. 

ARTICLE I. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 5-1. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter the following terms shall have these prescribed meanings: 
    Abandon: Leaving a dog, cat or other animal in the city and not providing food, water or shelter. This shall include not redeeming a dog, cat or other animal at an animal shelter or kennel. 
    Animal control officer: An officer or agent designated by the City of Lebanon to enforce this chapter and may include a police officer. 
    At large: A dog, cat or other animal shall be deemed to be at large when off the property of the owner and not under restraint. 
    Dangerous animal: Any animal having evidenced a disposition, propensity or tendency to attack or bite any person or other animal without provocation, or any animal which, without provocation, in a vicious or terrorizing manner, approaches any person in apparent attitude of attack upon the streets, sidewalks, or any public grounds or places; or any animal which is wild by nature and of a species which, due to size, vicious nature or other characteristics, constitutes a danger to human life, physical well-being, or property; or any animal which has been found to be vicious, dangerous, or a danger or menace to persons or other animals by a court of law of another jurisdiction after a hearing or upon a plea agreement is hereby deemed to be a dangerous animal. For the purpose of this chapter, where the official records of the animal control office or the police department of this city or any other jurisdiction establish that an animal has bitten any person or other animal on one (1) or more separate occasions without provocation, such evidence shall be prima facie evidence that said animal is a dangerous animal. In making a determination as to whether an animal is dangerous, elements that may be considered, but are not required to be, are provocation, location of the event, reason for the attack, whether the animal is acting protectively, whether the animal was tormented or abused, the seriousness of an attack, and previous attacks. 
    Exposed to rabies: Shall mean bitten by, or fought with, or has come in close contact with an animal showing symptoms of rabies. 
    Humane manner: Care of an animal to include, but not be limited to, adequate heat, ventilation and sanitary shelter, wholesome food and water, consistent with the normal requirements and feeding habits of the animal's size, species and breed. 
    Kennel: An establishment kept for the purpose of breeding, selling, or boarding dogs or cats or engaging in training dogs or cats. 
    Livestock: Shall mean cattle, horses, mules, hogs, sheep, goats, exotic animals, domestic fowl or exotic fowl or other animals commonly associated with farming and agriculture. 
    Neutered: Rendered permanently incapable of reproduction. 
    Owner: The person having the right of property or custody of a dog, cat, or animal or who keeps or harbors a dog, cat, or animal or knowingly permits a dog, cat or animal to remain on or about any premises occupied by that person. 
    Restraint: A dog, cat, or animal is under restraint if it is within a fully enclosed or fenced area or under the handheld leash of owner or agent of the owner, or on a chain or cable confining such dog, cat, or animal to the yard of its owner. 
    Spayed female dog or cat: A female dog or cat certified by a licensed veterinarian to have been spayed. 
    Vicious animal: A dog, cat, or animal that constitutes a physical threat to humans or other domestic animals. 
(Ord. No. 3776, § 1, 2-24-97) 
Sec. 5-2. - Enforcement of provisions. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall be enforced by police and/or animal control officers. 
(Ord. No. 3776, § 1, 2-24-97) 
Sec. 5-3. - Number of animals; residential restriction. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person(s) residing in one household having the right of property or custody of to own, keep or harbor more than four (4) adult canine and four (4) adult feline over the age of four (4) months to remain on or about any premise occupied as a single family dwelling zoned residential neighborhood. 
(Ord. No. 4728, § 1, 6-14-10) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4728, § 1, adopted June 14, 2010, repealed the former § 5-3, and enacted a new § 5-3 as set out herein. The former § 5-3 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 3776, adopted February 24, 1997. 
Sec. 5-4. - Duty of owner to restrain dogs, cats or other animals at all times. 
    A dog or cat or other animal owner shall keep his/her dog, cat, or other animal under restraint at all times. 
(Ord. No. 3776, § 1, 2-24-97) 
Sec. 5-5. - Duties of owner generally. 
    The owner of a dog, cat or other animal shall provide it with humane shelter from heat, cold, rain, wind and snow, and shall give it food and water adequate to keep the animal in good health and comfort. Animal shelters, to include dog houses and kennels, must be soundly constructed, dry and provided in cold weather with clean bedding. All dogs or cats must be given an opportunity for vigorous daily exercise and must be provided by their owners with veterinary care when needed to prevent suffering. No owner shall permit a dog or cat to bark, howl, meow or cry, in such a manner that it annoys or disturbs a reasonable man. No owner shall allow to accumulate excrement or other waste material such that either the odor or smell of the same is offensive to a reasonable man located off the owner's property, or the condition creates a health hazard to man or animal, or unreasonably interferes with the normal enjoyment of another person's property. No owner of a dog, cat or other animal shall abandon his or her dog, cat or animal. 
(Ord. No. 3776, § 1, 2-24-97) 
Sec. 5-6. - Cruelty to animals prohibited. 
(a)  No person shall be cruel or inhumane to any dog or cat by beating, torturing, kicking, or other physical abuse. 
(b)  No person shall torture, torment, wound, maim, mutilate, or cruelly beat, cruelly overwork, cruelly drive or work when unfit for labor, cruelly kill or cruelly abandon to die any domestic animal; provided that nothing contained in this subsection shall be construed to prohibit or interfere with any scientific experiment or investigation. 
(c)  No person shall impound or confine, or cause to be impounded or confined, in any pound or other place, any animal or creature, and fail to supply the animal or creature during such confinement with adequate food and water, or shall unnecessarily fail to provide the animal or creature with adequate food, water, or shelter or shall carry or cause the animal or creature to be carried or moved on any vehicle or otherwise in an unnecessarily cruel or inhumane manner. 
(d)  No person having ownership or custody of an animal shall fail to provide adequate care. 
(e)  Any person found guilty of a violation prescribed in this section shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished as provided in chapter 1, section 1-12 of this Code of Ordinances, and each and every instance of violation shall be a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 3776, § 1, 2-24-97; Ord. No. 5643 , § 1, 8-28-17) 
Sec. 5-7. - Female dogs or cats in heat, confinement by owner required. 
    It shall be the duty of every owner to confine any female dog or cat in heat within a building, in such a manner that the dog or cat will not be accessible to other dogs or cats (except for planned breeding) and will not attract male dogs or cats. 
(Ord. No. 3776, § 1, 2-24-97) 
Sec. 5-8. - Animals that bite humans; animals exposed to rabies; duty of owner; quarantine required. 
(a)  Every animal that has bitten any person or persons shall be immediately confined by the owner, who shall promptly notify a police officer or animal control officer. The owners shall, upon demand by a police officer or animal control officer, surrender any such animal for quarantine in the designated city pound, or a licensed veterinary hospital, and shall be held responsible for all costs incurred during the quarantine period. The animal must, in any event, be quarantined for ten (10) days. The owner shall pay to have his/her animal vaccinated against rabies before release from the kennel and shall pay the fees and costs for the vaccination and all boarding fees and costs, if any. 
(b)  When bitten by a rabid animal, unvaccinated animals should be destroyed immediately. If the owner is unwilling to have this done, the unvaccinated animal shall be placed in strict isolation for six (6) months and shall be vaccinated one (1) month before being released. The owner shall pay the costs of the "strict isolation" and the vaccination. 
(Ord. No. 3776, § 1, 2-24-97) 
Sec. 5-9. - Rabid animals-Unlawful to kill without proper authority. 
    No person shall kill a rabid animal exposed to rabies, nor remove such an animal from the city limits, without permission from the person in charge of animal control, except when it is necessary to kill such animal to prevent it from escaping or from biting any other animal or person. 
(Ord. No. 3776, § 1, 2-24-97) 
Sec. 5-10. - Same-Dead bodies to be surrendered to an animal control officer. 
    The owner of any animal which has died of rabies or has been exposed to rabies prior to death shall notify the animal control officer immediately and the body of the said animal shall be surrendered by the owner upon demand to the said animal control officer. 
(Ord. No. 3776, § 1, 2-24-97) 
Sec. 5-11. - Authority of police; animal control officer to inspect premises; unlawful to interfere. 
    Any police officer or animal control officer is authorized to enter any premises, without a court order, when in pursuit of an animal: (a) that has been running at large; (b) that is reasonably suspected to be a dangerous animal; or (c) that is reasonably suspected to be an animal that has bitten any person or another animal. Otherwise, any police officer or animal control officer shall make application to the judge of the municipal court for an order authorizing him to enter private property in order to inspect, care for or impound neglected or abused animals. Any application for such order shall be accompanied by an affidavit stating the probable cause to believe a violation of this article has occurred. A person acting under the authority of a court order shall not be liable for any necessary damage to property while acting under such order. No person shall hinder, molest or interfere with any police officer or animal control officer in the performance of his/her duties. 
(Ord. No. 3776, § 1, 2-24-97) 
ARTICLE II. - TAGS 

Sec. 5-12. - Required-Veterinarian Tag and Collar. 
(a)  No person shall own, keep or harbor any dog or cat over four (4) months of age within the city limits unless such animal has been vaccinated against rabies within the last twelve (12) months, and has been issued a receipt and tag from a licensed veterinarian. All dogs shall wear the said tag at all times on the collar required in subsection (b). 
(b)  No person shall own, keep or harbor any dog within the city limits without a collar that has the name and address of the owner in clear print thereon or attached thereto. 
(c)  Any person who fails to comply with the provisions of subsection (b) but is able to show that his/her dog has been vaccinated against rabies in compliance with subsection (a), shall, in case it is a first offense, be issued a warning only and shall not be subject to the penalties provided for in this section. In case of any subsequent offense, the offending person will be subject to such penalties. In the event any person shall be in violation of subsection (a), the said person shall be subject to said penalties and shall, in addition, be required to have their dog vaccinated against rabies in compliance with the provisions of subsection (a). 
(Ord. No. 3776, § 1, 2-24-97) 
Sec. 5-13. - Unlawful to use veterinarian tag of another dog or cat. 
    No person shall use for any dog or cat a tag issued for a different dog or cat. 
(Ord. No. 3776, § 1, 2-24-97) 
ARTICLE III. - DANGEROUS ANIMALS 

Sec. 5-14. - Harboring dangerous animal illegal. 
    It is illegal to harbor or keep within the City of Lebanon an animal that is a "dangerous animal" or to own such an animal and allow it to be kept or harbored within the City of Lebanon. 
(Ord. No. 3776, § 1, 2-24-97) 
Sec. 5-15. - Dangerous animals prohibited. 
(a)  Definition of dangerous animal: 
(1)  Any animal, without provocation, having a disposition, propensity or tendency to attack or bite any person or other animal; or 
(2)  Any animal, without provocation, in a vicious or terrorizing manner, approaches any person in apparent attitude of attack upon the streets, sidewalks, any public grounds or places; or 
(3)  Any animal wild in nature and of a species, due to size, vicious nature or other characteristics, constitutes a danger to human life, physical well-being, or property; or 
(4)  Any animal found to be vicious, dangerous, or a menace to persons or other animals by a court of law of another jurisdiction upon conclusion of a hearing or plea agreement; or 
(5)  Any animal where the official records of the animal control office or the police department of this city or any other jurisdiction establishes that said animal has bitten any person or other animal on one or more separate occasions without provocation. 
    In making a determination as to whether an animal is dangerous, elements that may be considered, but are not required to be are: Provocation; location of the event; reason for the attack; the animal acting protectively; the animal was tormented or abused; the seriousness of an attack and previous attacks. 
(b)  The animal control officer or any police officer shall cause the matter to be investigated against any person that owns, or is keeping or harboring, within the city a dangerous animal as defined in section 5-15 (a) and procedures to follow as stated below: 
(1)  Confirm said animal is a dangerous animal as defined in section 5-15(a); 
(2)  Verify said person is the owner or is keeping or harboring said dangerous animal within the city; 
(3)  The animal control officer or police officer shall issue a summons for a violation of section 5-14 to said person owning or keeping or harboring said dangerous animal; and 
(4)  Written notification shall be given to said person owning or keeping or harboring said dangerous animal stating said dangerous animal shall be safely removed from the city within three (3) days of the date of said written notification. 
(c)  Written notification shall be required when such dangerous animal has caused serious harm or death to any person or other animal or has escaped and is at large. In such case, the animal control officer or police officer shall immediately issue a summons to the person who owns or is keeping or harboring the animal for a violation of section 5-14, and cause said animal to be immediately seized and impounded, or killed if seizure or impoundment is not possible without risk of serious physical harm or death to any person. Impoundment may be in any animal shelter so designated by the animal control officer or police officer. Failure to remove said dangerous animal within the three (3) day period is unlawful and shall constitute a violation of section 5-14 for each day thereafter. 
(Ord. No. 3776, § 1, 2-24-97; Ord. No. 4804, § 1, 12-27-10) 
Sec. 5-16. - Failure to comply with notice. 
    The animal control officer or public safety officer shall forthwith cause to be seized and impounded any dangerous animal where the person owning, keeping or harboring such animal has failed to comply with the notice given pursuant to section 5-15 and shall issue to said person a general ordinance summons for a violation of section 5-15. 
(Ord. No. 3776, § 1, 2-24-97) 
Sec. 5-17. - Summons to issue; when. 
    Any time a dangerous animal is seized, impounded, or killed, a general ordinance summons for the violation of either sections 5-14 or 5-15 shall be issued. 
(Ord. No. 3776, § 1, 2-24-97) 
Sec. 5-18. - Penalties. 
    Any person found guilty of violating the provisions of sections 5-14-5-16, shall be punished by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment not exceeding ninety (90) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. The court shall have the power to order the impoundment, release, removal from the city, return to the city, or confinement by an individual of any animal seized, impounded, or the subject of a violation charge under sections 5-14-5-16 after a preliminary or final hearing on the merits. Nothing herein shall in any way restrict the initial seizure or impoundment pursuant to sections 5-14-5-16. Nothing herein confers a right to any preliminary hearing before the court on any issue. The court shall have the power to assess the costs of boarding any dangerous animal boarded by the city upon any conviction and cause said assessment to be paid. 
(Ord. No. 3776, § 1, 2-24-97) 
ARTICLE IV. - IMPOUNDMENT 

Sec. 5-19. - Authority of police officers, animal control officers, person in charge of animal control to designate animal shelters. 
    Dogs or cats which have not been vaccinated against rabies and have not been issued a tag by a licensed veterinarian pursuant to this chapter; or dogs, cats or animals who have allegedly been cruelly treated or been abused by those in whose care they reside; or dogs, cats or animals that are sick or have been injured and require treatment and the owner cannot be located; or dogs, cats or other animals found not under restraint may be seized and impounded by any police or animal control officer and said dog, cat or animal that has been impounded may be treated if necessary. Impoundment may be in any animal shelter so designated by the person in charge of animal control. The owner of the dog, cat or animal shall be responsible for the expenses of impoundment and/or treatment. In the case of a dog, cat or other animal that has allegedly been cruelly treated or been abused and a general ordinance summons for a violation of either sections 5-5 or 5-6 has been issued or the owner is unknown, said impounded dog, cat or other animal may only be released by order of a judge or when an animal control officer believes the release will not result in cruel treatment or abuse. 
(Ord. No. 3776, § 1, 2-24-97) 
Sec. 5-20. - Owner to be notified of impoundment. 
    If a dog or cat wears a veterinarian tag or if an owner of a dog, cat, or other animal can by any other reasonable means be identified and located, the owner shall, if at all possible, be notified that the dog, cat, or other animal has been impounded. If the owner is notified by mail, the deposit of such notice in the U.S. Mail, postage prepaid, shall be deemed delivery of the notice. However, failure of the owner to be notified shall not excuse any violation of this chapter or any expenses for which the person would otherwise be responsible. 
(Ord. No. 3776, § 1, 2-24-97) 
Sec. 5-21. - Disposition of unredeemed dogs, cats, or dangerous animals. 
    If a dog, cat or other animal is not redeemed by the owner within five (5) business days after impoundment, or within three (3) business days after notice of impoundment is given, the dog, cat or other animal may be disposed of in one of the following ways: 
(1)  Euthanasia, under the guidelines and procedures established by rules promulgated by the director and the Department of Agriculture of the State of Missouri; 
(2)  Release for adoption by a new owner who shows evidence of ability and intention to provide the dog, cat, or other animal with an appropriate home and humane care, and who has the dog, cat or other animal vaccinated against rabies by a licensed veterinarian within forty-eight (48) hours. Proof of said vaccination shall be submitted to the animal control office within that time period. 
(3)  Deal with a private organization such as the Humane Society, for the placement and adoption of impounded animals and such private organization shall follow the following procedures on adoption of animals: A person desiring to adopt an animal must have the animal examined by a licensed veterinarian, as required for redemption by an owner, except that a person adopting an animal shall not be required to pay the five dollars ($5.00) per day impounding charge. An owner may not adopt his own animal in order to avoid payment of the impoundment charge, but must redeem his animal. No impoundment fee shall be charged to the Humane Society for any animal presented to it by the city to be held thereby for adoption. 
(Ord. No. 3776, § 1, 2-24-97) 
Sec. 5-22. - Redemption by owners; fees. 
(a)  An owner redeeming a dog or cat from impoundment shall pay, before release, a redemption fee in accordance with the following schedule: 
(1)  First redemption, twenty-five dollars ($25.00); 
(2)  Second redemption and all subsequent redemptions, fifty dollars ($50.00). 
    Before redeeming a dog or cat, the owner shall provide a receipt from a licensed veterinarian that the dog or cat has been vaccinated against rabies, or said dog or cat shall be vaccinated against rabies by a licensed veterinarian within two (2) business days of release and proof of said vaccination shall be submitted to the animal control office within that time period. 
(b)  In addition to any redemption fee for an impounded animal an owner redeeming any animal from impoundment shall pay, before release, the prevailing board fee charged the city for each twenty-four (24) hours, or fraction thereof, that the dog or cat has been impounded. This shall not apply to "dangerous animals" that have been seized or impounded. 
(c)  An owner of an animal impounded under sections 5-14-5-16, or the persons charged with a violation of any of said sections, may redeem the animal at any time after impoundment, but shall not return said animal to the City of Lebanon or allow said animal to remain within the City of Lebanon unless and until said animal is found not to be dangerous by the municipal court of the City of Lebanon or a higher court, or until said court has authorized, by order, its return. 
    Animals not redeemed shall be impounded, until a decision is rendered by the court as to whether the animal is a dangerous animal. If the animal is adjudged a "dangerous animal" by the court, and it is not redeemed within five (5) business days of the court's decision, the animal shall be disposed of in the manner set forth in section 5-21(a). 
    If the animal is not found by the court to be a "dangerous animal," it shall be released immediately to its owner or the person charged with the violation. If it is not claimed or redeemed within five (5) business days thereafter, it shall be disposed of pursuant to either of subsections (a) and (b) of section 5-21. 
(Ord. No. 3776, § 1, 2-24-97) 
Sec. 5-23. - Keeping livestock in the city restricted. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or maintain any livestock in such close proximity to any business or residence as to cause annoyance to the occupants thereof, or in such a place as will render it a nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 3776, § 1, 2-24-97) 
Sec. 5-24. - Sale of certain animals prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer for sale, barter or give away baby chickens, ducklings or other fowl, until fully feathered out, or rabbits or other animals under the age of two (2) months, as pets, toys, premiums or novelties; provided, however, that this section shall not be construed to prohibit the sale or display of baby chickens, ducklings, or other fowl or rabbits or other animals under the age of two (2) months, in proper facilities by breeders or stores engaged in the business of selling them to be raised for commercial purposes. 
(Ord. No. 3776, § 1, 2-24-97) 
Sec. 5-25. - Prohibition of dyeing or artificially coloring. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to dye or artificially color any small animal or fowl or to bring or transport the same into the city except for continuous transport through the city. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to possess, sell, barter or give away within the city limits, any dyed or artificially colored small animal or fowl. 
(c)  Provided, however, subsections (a) and (b) shall not be construed to prohibit breeders or stores engaged in the business of selling them to be raised for commercial purpose, in proper facilities, from dyeing or artificially coloring any small animal or fowl for sales at wholesale for commercial purposes. 
(Ord. No. 3776, § 1, 2-24-97; Ord. No. 4466, § 1, 3-12-07) 
Sec. 5-26. - Poisoning prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to feed or place so as to constitute a direct or obvious hazard to man or animal, or shall offer or tempt any animal with liquid, or meat, or any food which shall: 
(1)  Cause prostration, convulsion, pain or suffering as a prelude to death; 
(2)  Cause death; or 
(3)  Be proven toxic or lethal in the amount present to any man or domestic animal by competent medical or veterinary authority; 
provided this section shall not apply to the poisoning of rodents or other harmful pests if done in such a manner as not to expose poisonous substances to domestic animals. 
(Ord. No. 3776, § 1, 2-24-97) 
Sec. 5-27. - Mistreatment of police dogs prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to taunt, torment, tease, beat, strike, torture, mutilate, injure, disable, poison or kill any police dog, or to interfere with or meddle with any such police dog while in the performance of any duty with a law enforcement officer. 
(Ord. No. 3776, § 1, 2-24-97)

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 6-1. - Reserved.

No. 3058, adopted October 26, 1981; Ord. No. 3253, adopted June 22, 1987; Ord. No. 4477, adopted April 30, 2007; Ord. No. 4562, adopted August 11, 2008 and Ord. No. 4648, adopted August 31, 2009. 
Sec. 6-2. - Office of building commissioner established. 
    The mayor shall, with the approval of the city council, select and appoint some person to the office of building commissioner to serve for an indefinite term unless otherwise specified. The building commissioner shall perform all the duties prescribed for such office by this chapter. During all times when no person is lawfully appointed as building commissioner due to death, resignation or otherwise, the mayor of the City of Lebanon shall perform all the duties prescribed for the office of building commissioner by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 3058, § 14, 10-26-81; Ord. No. 3331, § 1, 6-12-89; Ord. No. 4477, § 2, 4-30-07) 
Cross reference- Officers and employees generally, § 2-61 et seq. 
Sec. 6-3. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4981, § 1, adopted August 13, 2012, repealed § 1, which pertained to a board of appeals and derived from Ord. No. 4168, adopted January 13, 2003. 
Sec. 6-4. - Contractors shall be familiar with codes and ordinances. 
    Every person working as a contractor in the city shall be responsible for familiarizing himself with this Code, all codes adopted by this chapter and all other ordinances of the city pertinent to his operations, and shall obtain the proper permits, as required in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1896, § 2, 5-14-73) 
Sec. 6-5. - Building permits. 
(a)  Before a building permit is issued, any person, firm or corporation desiring to undertake any new construction or major renovation of any building in the City of Lebanon, Missouri, other than those buildings excepted in subsection (b), shall submit to the City of Lebanon design plans and specifications prepared by a professional architect or a professional engineer, or by both. 
(b)  Design plans and specifications shall not be required in the following cases: 
(1)  A single-family dwelling house; or 
(2)  A multiple-family dwelling house, flat or apartment containing not more than two (2) families; or 
(3)  A building or structure used exclusively for farm purposes. 
(c)  As to each of the enumerated exceptions in subsection (b), the construction or renovation of the building shall be subject to inspection and examination at all reasonable times by the building and zoning administrator of the City of Lebanon and all such construction and renovation shall comply with all applicable laws and ordinances, including the BOCA Building and Plumbing Codes, the National Electrical Code and the National Fire Code. 
(d)  The building and zoning administrator shall have authority and power granted by the ordinances, rules and regulations of the City of Lebanon, Missouri (including BOCA Building and Plumbing Codes, the National Electrical Code and the National Fire Code), with regard to the enforcement of the provisions of this chapter. 
(e)  As to the construction or major renovation of all buildings, other than those excepted in subsection (b), the top cover sheet of all design plans and specifications for such construction or renovation shall contain the following statement signed and sealed by the architect or engineer who prepared such plans: 
    To the best of my professional knowledge and belief, these plans have been prepared in accordance with the latest version of the BOCA Building and Plumbing Codes, the National Electrical Code and the National Fire Code. 
In addition, each separate page of the design plans and specifications shall contain, at the end thereof, the signature and seal of the architect or engineer who prepared such plans. 
(f)  Major renovation is hereby defined as any work involving any of the following: 
(1)  The redesign, relocation, removal or alteration of load-bearing walls and/or any other structural component of the building; 
(2)  The redesign, relocation, removal or alteration of a major component and/or a major portion of the electrical, plumbing or mechanical systems of the building; 
(3)  The construction of any addition to an existing building which involves any of the above work; 
(4)  The conversion of a single-family dwelling unit to a multifamily dwelling unit containing more than two (2) families; or 
(5)  The conversion of a residential unit to a commercial unit within a commercial zone. 
(g)  Every application for a building permit for which design plans and specifications are required shall also contain the name and address of the architect or engineer who is to be responsible for issuance of the certificate of construction compliance as set forth in section 6-7 herein. 
(h)  No building permit shall be issued until the owner of the property or the authorized agent of the owner shall have executed and delivered to the city a statement to be called a "memorandum of understanding" reciting that the owner understands that the building permit is granted on the express condition that the construction shall conform to the ordinances of the City of Lebanon, Missouri, in all respects including compliance with the design plans and specifications of the architect or engineer and that the owner understands that the building or construction can not be occupied or used unless or until such compliance is made and that no occupancy permit will be issued until compliance is made. 
(Ord. No. 3225, § 1, 7-14-86; Ord. No. 3253, § 2, 6-22-87; Ord. No. 3301, § 1, 7-11-88) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3225, §§ 1-3, adopted July 14, 1986, did not specifically amend the Code; therefore, inclusion as §§ 6-5-6-7 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Copies of the "memorandum of understanding" referred to in subsection (h) are on file in the office of the city clerk. 
Sec. 6-6. - Site plans. 
    In addition to the design plans and specifications, before a building permit is issued, a site plan for the construction or renovation of any building in the city, other than those buildings excepted in section 6-5(b) must be submitted to the community development division for review. Site plans which pertain to the construction of new improvements or an addition to an existing improvement shall be submitted to the community development division for review and approval before the issuance of a building permit, so long as all other requirements of this section and the other applicable provisions of this Code are complied with. Any site plan in a commercial or industrial district which abuts a residential district must be reviewed and approved by the planning and zoning commission before a building permit is issued. A site plan that is required to be submitted to the commission shall be submitted to the community development division at least two (2) weeks prior to the hearing date set for the planning and zoning commission's consideration of said plan. No site plan can be considered by the planning and zoning commission until the same is in writing approved by the building and zoning administrator or code administrator. The site plan must be prepared by a professional engineer or registered land surveyor and a certificate that such site plan complies with all applicable laws and ordinances must be signed and sealed by such professional engineer or registered land surveyor and attached to the site plan; or if such site plan does not comply with all applicable laws and ordinances, the certificate must include and set forth all variances from such laws and ordinances. No building permit shall be issued unless and until compliance is made with the provisions of this chapter including this section. 
(Ord. No. 3225, § 2, 7-14-86; Ord. No. 3301, § 2, 7-11-88; Ord. No. 3531, § 1, 11-29-93; Ord. No. 3109, § 4, 5-28-96; Ord. No. 5578 , § 8, 3-13-17) 
Sec. 6-7. - Occupancy permits. 
(a)  After completion of construction or renovation of any building in the City of Lebanon, other than those excepted in section 6-5 (b) and before the issuance by the City of Lebanon of the occupancy permit, a certificate of construction compliance must be submitted to the city signed, dated and sealed by the architect or engineer designated on the building permit as the professional to be responsible for such certificate. 
(b)  The certificate of construction compliance must contain the following statement by the architect or engineer: 
    I have personally inspected the structure owned by   (name of owner)   and identified as   (identification of structure)   constructed under Building Permit number ____________ dated ____________ / ____________ / ____________ issued by the City of Lebanon, Missouri, and I have personally reviewed the design plans and specifications submitted to the City of Lebanon in application for the building permit and I do hereby certify that the construction or renovation (state which) of the structure has been completed in substantial compliance with those design plans and specifications. 
(c)  It shall be the responsibility of the owner or his agent to arrange for all necessary inspections by the architect or engineer of the project during construction and before issuance of the occupancy permit. 
(d)  No occupancy permit shall be issued unless and until compliance is made with the provisions of this chapter. 
(e)  When any site plan is required for any construction, after completion of the construction and prior to the issuance of an occupancy permit, the owner or authorized agent for the owner must submit to the city a certificate of compliance from the engineer or surveyor who prepared the site plan. The certificate of compliance must contain the following statement by the engineer or surveyor. 
    I have personally inspected the building site owned by   (name of owner)  , and identified as   (identification of structure)  , constructed under Building Permit Number ____________ and dated ____________ / ____________ / ____________ , issued by the City of Lebanon, Missouri, and I have personally reviewed the site plan submitted to the City of Lebanon in application for the building permit and I do hereby certify that the preparation of the site has been completed in substantial compliance with the site plan. 
It shall be the responsibility of the owner or his agent to arrange for all necessary inspections by the engineer or surveyor. No occupancy permit shall be issued unless and until compliance has been made with this subsection. 
(Ord. No. 3225, § 3, 7-14-86; Ord. No. 3301, § 3, 7-11-88) 
Note- See editor's note to § 6-5. 
Sec. 6-8. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 3531, adopted Nov. 29, 1993, repealed § 6-8 in its entirety. Formerly, § 6-8 pertained to guarantee of completion of improvements and derived from § 1 of Ord. No. 3508, adopted July 12, 1993. 
Secs. 6-9-6-15. - Reserved.

    Except as provided above, all of the terms and provisions of the International Building Code, 2006 edition, shall be in full force and effect. 
(Ord. No. 4169, § 1, 1-13-03; Ord. No. 4553, § 1, 6-30-08; Ord. No. 5578 , § 1, 3-13-17)

No. 4116; § 1, adopted Jan. 28, 2002.

(Ord. No. 3084, § 1, 6-14-82; Ord. No. 3850, § 2, 4-13-98; Ord. No. 4169, § 1, 1-13-03) 
Sec. 6-18. - Marked copies to be filed. 
    There shall not be less than three (3) copies of the building code adopted by this article kept in the office of the city clerk. These copies shall be marked "Official Copy of the City Building Code." 
(Ord. No. 3084, § 2, 6-14-82)

(4)  $1,001.00 to $5,000.00 ..... 4.00 
(5)  $5,001.00 to $10,000.00 ..... 5.00 
(6)  $10,001.00 and over ..... 15.00 
plus for each additional thousand or part thereof ..... 1.50 
(Code 1967, App. A, § 114.1; Ord. No. 1928, Art. II, § 1, 10-28-74)

Sec. 6-21. - Liability. 
    This article shall not be constructed to relieve from responsibility or to lessen the responsibility of any person owning, controlling or constructing buildings, nor shall the city be held as assuming any liability of any nature by reasons of the inspection authority hereby issued to the building inspector for the inspection of buildings. 
(Ord. No. 3084, § 3, 6-14-82) 
Sec. 6-22. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be guilty of an offense and upon conviction thereof shall be punishable as provided in section 1-12. Each day that a violation shall continue shall be deemed a separate offense, as provided in section 1-12. 
(Ord. No. 3084, § 4, 6-14-82)

ARTICLE III. - ONE- AND TWO-FAMILY DWELLING CODE 

Sec. 6-31. - Adoption of International Residential Code-One- and Two-Family Dwellings. 
    The International Residential Code for One- and Two-Family Dwellings, 2006 edition, as published by the International Code Council, is hereby adopted as the one- and two-family dwelling code of the city for the regulations of the fabrication, erection, construction, enlargement, alteration, repair, location, and use of the detached one- and two-family dwellings, their appurtenances and accessory structures within the city with the exception that Section R112, Board of Appeals, found on page 7 thereof, shall be deleted and the provisions of Section 6-3 of the Code of Laws of the city shall be followed. 
    The International Residential Code for One- and Two-Family Dwellings, 2006 edition, appendices A, B, C, D, E, G, H, J, K, M, N, P, and Q are also hereby adopted. 
(Ord. No. 4115, § 1, 1-28-02; Ord. No. 4169, § 2, 1-13-03; Ord. No. 4553, § 2, 6-30-08; Ord. No. 5578 , § 2, 3-13-17) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4115, § 1, adopted Jan. 28, 2002, repealed the former § 6-31, and enacted a new § 6-31 as set out herein. The former § 6-31 pertained to adoption of the CABO one- and two-family dwelling code and derived from Ord. No. 3716, § 1, adopted June 10, 1996. 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to adopt technical codes by reference, RSMo 67.280. 
Sec. 6-32. - Marked copies to be filed. 
    There shall be not less than three (3) copies of the one- and two-family dwelling code adopted by this article kept in the office of the city clerk. These copies shall be marked "Official Copy of the City One- and Two-Family Dwelling Code." 
Sec. 6-33. - Additions, insertions, and changes. 
    That the International Residential Code for One- and Two-Family Dwellings, 2006 edition, is amended and revised in the following respects: 
AP101 Fire Sprinklers. Delete: AP101 Fire Sprinklers. Insert: AP101 Fire Sprinklers, an approved automatic fire sprinkler system if installed in new one- and two-family dwellings and townhouses shall be in accordance with Section 903.3.1 of the International Building Code. In reference to Missouri Revised Statutes (Chapter 67 Section 67.281). 
R104.11 Alternative materials, design, and methods of construction and equipment. Insert after last paragraph: Alternative method commonly known as "storage container", "pole barn" or "laminated pole" type structures shall be limited to commercial buildings and accessory buildings only and not for residential dwelling units. 
R105.2 Work exempt from permit. Delete: 3. Retaining walls that are not over 4 feet in height measured from the bottom of the footing to the top of the wall, unless supporting a structure. 
Table R301.5 Minimum Uniformly Distributed Loads. Delete: 30 psf. Insert: 40 psf. 
R309.3 Floor Surface. Delete: Garage floor surfaces hall be of approved non-combustible material and insert Garage floor surfaces shall be a minimum thickness of 3 1/2" and of approved non-combustible material. 
Chapter 4 Foundations. Insert after the last paragraph: Footing, Foundations, Piers, Columns and Retaining Walls shall be constructed as per the engineered drawings that are on file with the City of Lebanon Community Development Department. The Building Official will have the authority to approve other design standards that are in compliance with the International Residential Codes. 
R502.3.1 Sleeping Areas and Attic Joists, Table R502.3.1(1). Delete: 30 psf and insert: 40 psf.

The overcurrent protection shall not be greater than the rating of the panelboard. The electric service size shall have the equivalent conductors and individual protection (main circuit breakers). 
( Ord. No. 5578 , § 3, 3-13-17)

ARTICLE IV. - MOVING OF BUILDINGS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 22. 

Sec. 6-36. - Building and zoning administrator to regulate. 
    The building and zoning administrator is empowered to regulate and control the moving of any house or building within the city limits or from outside the city limits to a point within the city limits in any manner which he deems necessary for the protection of city streets, alleys and sidewalks and other city property that might be damaged or affected by the moving process. 
(Code 1967, § 5-25; Ord. No. 3253, § 2, 6-22-87) 
Sec. 6-37. - Permit to move building required; contents; fee. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to move, or cause to be moved any house or building in, into, through or from the city without first obtaining a permit therefor from the building and zoning administrator. The permit shall be known as a "house-moving permit," and shall be in writing. 
(b)  Any person desiring such a permit shall file with the building and zoning administrator an application therefor in writing on a form to be provided by the city for that purpose. Such application shall specify the following: The character and size of the house or building to be moved; the reason for moving said structure; the use, purpose and occupancy for which said house or building is to be used; the location from which said house or building is to be moved; a plot plan showing the proposed location of the house or building on the property to which said house or building is to be moved provided said location is in the city; what streets, alleys or sidewalks are to be used in the moving process; and the length of time required for the moving process. 
(c)  If the house or building is to be located within the city limits, a building permit for the remodel/reconstruction of the house or building and utility fees must be obtained at the same time a moving permit is issued. The owner must submit to the building and zoning administrator their schedule to bring the building or residential structure up to minimum housing standards. Work must begin within thirty (30) days after moving and be complete within one hundred twenty (120) days. No permit shall be issued to move any house or building, which, in the opinion of the building and zoning administrator: 
(1)  Is so constructed or in such condition as to be dangerous; 
(2)  Is infested with pests or insanitary; 
(3)  If it is a dwelling or habitation, is unfit for human habitation; 
(4)  Is so dilapidated, defective, unsightly or in such a condition of deterioration or disrepair that its relocation at a proposed site would cause appreciable harm to or be materially detrimental to the property or improvements in the district within a radius of one thousand (1,000) feet from the proposed site; 
(5)  If the proposed use is prohibited by the zoning laws of the city; 
(6)  If the structure is of a type prohibited at the proposed location by any ordinance of the city; or 
(7)  If the moving of the building or structure causes unreasonable damage to the trees, plants and shrubs on and along the public streets. 
Provided, however, that if the condition of the building or structure, in the judgment of the building and zoning administrator, admits of practicable and effective repair, the permit may be used upon the terms and conditions as set forth herein. 
(d)  The minimum permit fee for electrical crews and equipment shall be three hundred dollars ($300.00) for the first one-half day and one hundred dollars ($100.00) per hour thereafter. 
(Code 1967, § 5-26; Ord. No. 1928, Art. II, § 5, 10-28-74; Ord. No. 3253, § 2, 6-22-87; Ord. No. 3709, § 10, 5-28-96; Ord. No. 4297, § 1, 11-29-04) 
Sec. 6-38. - Bond, proof of insurance coverage required. 
(a)  The owner of the structure to be moved shall, before commencing the removal and moving of any house or building, and in addition to complying with the other provisions of this article, secure and present to the city clerk, a good and enforceable bond in the amount of twenty thousand ($20,000.00), which bond shall stipulate and provide for the completion of the remodel/reconstruction of the house to minimum housing standards and ready for occupancy within one hundred twenty (120) days from the date of issuance of the building permit. If work is progressing without unnecessary delays or delays beyond the contractor's control, such as weather or available materials, then an extension may be granted by the building and zoning administrator along with the city administrator. In no wise shall the completion exceed a deadline of a total of two hundred forty (240) days from the start to finish. If the owner defaults, the city shall have the option in lieu of completing the work required to demolish the building or structure and to clear, clean and restore the site or sites where by the structure was to be located; the cost in either case being enforceable against the bond; and; 
(b)  The mover, before commencing the removal and moving of any house or building, and in addition to complying with the other provisions of this article, secure and present to the city clerk, upon issuance of the moving permit by the building and zoning administrator, a good and enforceable bond in the amount of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), which bond shall stipulate and provide that the person to whom the moving permit is issued shall repair any or all damage done to public or private property caused by them in removing houses or buildings, or to pay the actual costs of making the repairs. 
(c)  The permit applicant shall also provide the city clerk with proof of liability insurance coverage in the amount of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00). 
(Code 1967, § 5-27; Ord. No. 3709, § 11, 5-28-96; Ord. No. 4297, § 2, 11-29-04) 
Secs. 6-39-6-50. - Reserved.

State Law reference- Inadequate and deficient housing, RSMo 441.500 et seq.

Sec. 6-52. - Additions, insertions and changes.

The provisions of this code shall apply to all existing residential and nonresidential structures and all existing premises and constitute minimum requirements and standards for premises, structures, equipment and facilities for light, ventilation, space, heating, sanitation, protection from the elements, life safety, safety from fire and other hazards, and for safe and sanitary maintenance; the responsibility of owners, operators and occupants: the occupancy of existing structures and premises and for administration, enforcement and penalties. 
    Section 101.3 Application of other codes. Insert: International Plumbing Code in list of applicable codes. 
    Section 103.1 General. Delete Section 103.1 General and insert: 103.1 General. The department of property maintenance inspection is hereby created and the executive official in charge thereof shall be known as the code official. 
    Section 104.3 Inspections. 104.3 Inspections insert second paragraph: The code official also shall have the right to inspect the structure or premises at any time there is a change of occupancy during the period the premises are vacant and the owner or person responsible shall be required to notify the code official or the city utility department each time a vacancy occurs so that an inspection can be made. The code official shall cause the premises to be inspected within three (3) working days of receiving the aforesaid notice.

Prior to entering into a space not otherwise open to the general public, the code official shall make a reasonable effort to locate the owner or other person having charge or control of the structure or premises, present proper identification and request entry. If requested entry is refused or not obtained, the code official shall pursue recourse as provided by law. 
    Section 104.6 Notices and orders. Insert second paragraph: All necessary notices and orders shall be made in conformance with procedures established by Ordinance 3786 and any subsequent amendment, codified within the Code of Ordinances of the City of Lebanon, Missouri, Chapter 13 Nuisances, Article V. - Abatement and Penalty Procedures. 
    Section 106.1 Unlawful Acts. Delete Section 106.1 and insert: Section 106.1 Unlawful acts. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to erect, construct, alter, extend, repair, remove, demolish, maintain, fail to maintain, provide, fail to provide, occupy, let to another or occupy or permit another person to occupy any structure or equipment regulated by this code, or cause same to be done, contrary to or in conflict with or in violation of any of the provisions of this code, or to fail to obey a lawful order of the code official, or to remove or deface a placard or notice posted under the provisions of this code. 
    The city will not be required to provide utilities to the subject structure until the said alterations or repairs are completed, except that temporary utility services will be provided by the city for a thirty-day period after inspection to enable the owner or other person or persons having charge or control of the structure or premises to make the alterations, repairs or improvements required by this article so long as the subject structure is unoccupied. The period of temporary service may be extended for a longer period if a good faith effort has been made to complete the necessary alterations, repairs or improvements and more time is required to do so. 
    It shall be unlawful for any owner or operator to "let" for occupancy or allow, cause or permit the occupancy of any residential or structural unit unless and until: 
(1)  All utilities, to-wit, water, sewer, and a heat source for heating water and heating the unit, are properly connected and operating; 
(2)  Any electrical deficiencies referred to in Subsection (c) have been added or corrected as per the requirements of Subsection (c). 
(3)  The owner/operator has notified the code official that the unit is vacant and has permitted inspection unless waived by the code official; 
(4)  The unit complies with all other requirements of this code. 
    It shall also be unlawful for any owner or operator to allow, cause or permit occupancy or for any person to occupy any residential unit after any or all utility service is disconnected, terminated or otherwise unavailable for any reason. The owner or operator shall not be considered in violation of this subsection if eviction procedures under state law have been initiated and are being diligently pursued to cause the occupant or occupants to be removed from the premises. 
    It shall also be unlawful for an owner or operator of any residential unit or structure to cause or allow the termination of any or all utility service or services to or for said residential or structural unit to cause or compel the occupant or occupants to abandon the premises for any reason. 
    The occupancy of a residential or structural unit without utilities properly connected and operating is hereby declared to be a nuisance and a safety and health hazard and any person who violates the provisions of subsections (d), (e) or (f) hereof shall upon conviction of any violation thereof, be punished by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00), or by imprisonment in the county jail for a period not exceeding three (3) months or both such fine and imprisonment pursuant to Chapter 1, Section 1-12 of the Code of Ordinance of the City of Lebanon Missouri; provided that in any case wherein the penalty of an offense as fixed by any statute of the state, the statutory penalty and no other, shall be imposed for the punishment of the offense. Each day any violation of this ordinance shall continue shall constitute, except where otherwise provided, a separate offense. Said violator shall also be subject to injunctive relief pursuant to the provisions of Section 106.3.

If the notice of violation is not complied with, the code official shall institute the appropriate proceeding at law or in equity to restrain, correct or abate such violation, or to require the removal or termination of the unlawful occupancy of the structure in violation of the provisions of this code or of the order or direction made pursuant thereto. Any action taken by the authority having jurisdiction on such premises shall be charged against the real estate upon which the structure is located and shall be a lien upon such real estate.

Delete: Section 602.3 and insert: Section 602.3 Heat supply: Every owner and operator of any building who rents, leases or lets one or more dwelling units or sleeping units on terms, either expressed or implied, to furnish heat to the occupants thereof shall supply heat during the period from October l, to April 1, to maintain a temperature of not less than 68°F (20°C) in all habitable rooms, bathrooms, and toilet rooms.
