    As used in this article the term "garage sale" shall include all sales entitled garage sale, lawn sale, rummage sale, patio sale, basement sale, or any similar casual sale of tangible personal property such as normally accumulates in ordinary residential dwelling usage. 
(Ord. No. 5229, § 1, 7-14-14) 
Sec. 14-202. - Limitation on frequency and duration of sales. 
(a)  No person shall conduct more than three (3) garage sales during any one calendar year at a single location unless the ownership of the property at such location changes or unless there is a change in the tenant occupying such location. 
(b)  No person shall conduct a garage sale other than on the days of Thursday, Friday, Saturday, or Sunday, without the permission of the community development director or his or her designee. 
(c)  No person shall conduct a garage sale other than between the hours of 7:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. on the days allowable as established by ordinance. 
(d)  No person shall conduct any garage sale for more than three (3) consecutive calendar days (seventy-two (72) hours) on the days allowable as established by ordinance. 
(e)  No person conducting a garage sale may begin setting up the sale in excess of twelve (12) hours in advance of the commencement of the sale. 
(f)  Any person conducting a garage sale shall ensure that all unsold items are removed from the driveway, yard or outside area no more than twelve (12) hours following the completion of the sale, and no such goods shall thereafter be offered for sale 
(Ord. No. 5229, § 1, 7-14-14) 
Sec. 14-203. - Signs. 
(a)  No person shall place any sign or billboard advertising any garage sale in the right-of-way of any public street, alley, sidewalk, municipal park or property owned by the City of Lebanon nor shall any person allow or permit any such sign or billboard to encroach upon such designated areas. 
(b)  No person shall place, or permit to be placed, any sign or billboard on any traffic-control signs, post or signals or utility poles. 
(c)  The person conducting any garage sale shall cause all signs or billboards advertising such sale to be removed no later than 8:00 p.m. on the last day of such sale. 
(Ord. No. 5229, § 1, 7-14-14) 
Sec. 14-204. - Creating nuisance prohibited. 
(a)  No person shall conduct a garage sale in such a manner as to cause a nuisance or disturbance to the general public by allowing trash or debris to be carried or blown onto property other than the location of the sale, by causing or allowing traffic and/or parking congestion to occur, by allowing; trash or debris to accumulate at the sale location, or by causing or allowing unusual or loud noises to occur at or during the sale. 
(b)  For the purpose of enforcing the provisions of this article, the City of Lebanon, Laclede County, Missouri, its proper nominees, representatives and employees shall have the right of entry to any premises showing evidence of a garage sale and may close the premises from such a sale where any provisions of this article are being violated 
(Ord. No. 5229, § 1, 7-14-14) 
Sec. 14-205. - Exemptions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to or affect the following persons or sales: 
(1)  Persons acting in accordance with their powers or duties as public officials. 
(2)  Persons acting as executor, administrator, personal representative, guardian or conservator of any estate. 
(3)  Any person advertising for sale any items of tangible personal property which are specifically named or described in the advertisement and which separate items do not exceed five (5) in total number. 
(4)  Any auction sale conducted by a licensed auctioneer on behalf of the owner or tenant of a property location which sale is a non-repetitive casual sale. 
(Ord. No. 5229, § 1, 7-14-14) 
Sec. 14-206. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating the provisions of this article, upon conviction of any violation thereof, be punished by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00), or by imprisonment in the county jail for a period not exceeding three (3) months or both such fine and imprisonment pursuant to chapter 1, section 1-12 of the Code of Ordinances of the City or Lebanon Missouri. 
(Ord. No. 5229, § 1, 7-14-14) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5229, § 1, adopted July 14, 2014, set out provisions intended for use as § 14-205. For purposes of classification, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as § 14-206. 
Chapter 15 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Drinking in certain public places prohibited, § 4-2; possession of intoxicating liquors in certain public places prohibited, § 4-3; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 22; design standards for public sites and open spaces in subdivisions, § 23-27. 
State Law reference- Parks and recreation, RSMo Ch. 90; municipal authority to purchase land for parks, RSMo 77.140. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 15-1. - Speed limit. 
    No person shall drive any vehicle within the limits of any park in excess of fifteen (15) miles per hour at any time, day or night. 
(Code 1967, § 18-2) 
Cross reference- Traffic and motor vehicles, Ch. 25. 
Sec. 15-2. - Entering swimming pool after closing hours prohibited. 
    No person shall enter the confines of the city swimming pool after closing hours for swimming or any other purpose. 
(Code 1967, § 18-3) 
Sec. 15-3. - No fishing in Nelson Park Lake; exceptions. 
(a)  Nelson Park Lake shall be closed to fishing under the discretion of the parks superintendent, with the posting of "No Fishing" signs. 
(b)  Nelson Park Lake shall be open to fishing to the general public unless closed by parks superintendent with the following restrictions: 
(1)  Nelson Park Lake is considered a catch and release lake, except as permitted by the Lebanon Park Board for special events, i.e. Kids Fishing Days, etc. Fish taken must be immediately released back to the water unharmed. 
(2)  In the event the park board authorizes the taking of fish from Nelson Park Lake, an individual shall not take fish in excess of the following limits: 
a.  Bluegill: Ten (10) any size. 
b.  Channel catfish: Four (4) any size. 
c.  Largemouth bass: Four (4) fourteen (14) inches or larger. 
d.  Catfish and Bluegill may be taken at any size. Largemouth Bass harvest shall be restricted to those fish fourteen (14) inches in length and larger. 
(Ord. No. 1956, §§ 1-3, 11-10-75; Ord. No. 4317, § 1, 6-27-05) 
Sec. 15-4. - No swimming or boating on Nelson Park Lake; and no presence or activity thereon when the said lake is frozen over. 
(a)  Swimming and the use of all watercraft shall be prohibited at all times on Nelson Park Lake. 
(b)  No person shall be permitted on the ice when Nelson Park Lake is frozen over. 
(Ord. No. 4859, § 1, 5-31-11) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4859, § 1, adopted May 31, 2011, repealed the former § 15-4, and enacted a new § 15-4 as set out herein. The former § 15-4 pertained to no swimming, boating in Nelson Park Lake and derived from Ord. No. 1956, adopted November 10, 1975. 
Sec. 15-5. - Limitation on motor vehicles in parks. 
    No person shall drive or operate any motor vehicle in any park in the City of Lebanon, Missouri, on any area other than roads, streets or parking lots designated for such motor vehicle traffic. No person shall drive or operate any motor vehicle on walking or jogging trails, playgrounds, ball fields or grass areas, or in any other area not designated for such traffic. 
(Ord. No. 3187, § 1, 4-8-85) 
Cross reference- Traffic and motor vehicles, Ch. 25. 
Sec. 15-6. - Definition of motor vehicles. 
    Motor vehicles shall include, but not be limited to, motorcycles, motorized tricycles, motorized four-wheelers, mopeds, automobiles and pickup trucks. Motor vehicles shall not include bicycles. 
(Ord. No. 3187, § 3, 4-8-85) 
Sec. 15-7. - Restriction on camping. 
    No person shall camp out or stay overnight in any park in the City of Lebanon, Missouri, in any tent, camper, trailer or other temporary or movable structure. Provided, however, that the park board of the City of Lebanon shall have the power and authority, upon written application and after review and consideration by the park board, to grant temporary camping rights to educational, charitable or not-for-profit organizations, such as church groups or scout groups, so long as adequate supervision of such groups shall be maintained and sufficient cleanup of the park area shall be provided. The park board shall have the right to establish and require a security deposit from such groups to guarantee the proper cleanup of the park area. 
(Ord. No. 3187, § 4, 4-8-85) 
Sec. 15-8. - Closing time. 
    All city parks shall be closed to the public at 10:30 p.m. on all days of the week except for activities sanctioned and approved in writing by the park board. 
(Ord. No. 3754, § 1, 10-15-96) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3754, § 1, adopted Oct. 15, 1996, repealed former § 15-8 of the Code and added a new § 15-8 to read as herein set out. Former § 15-8 pertained to enforcement and derived from Ord. No. 3187, § 4, adopted April 8, 1985. 
Sec. 15-9. - Enforcement. 
    The park board and the police department of the City of Lebanon shall enforce sections 15-5 through 15-10. 
(Ord. No. 3754, § 1, 10-15-96) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3754, § 1, adopted Oct. 15, 1996, repealed § 15-9 of the Code and added a new § 15-9 to read as herein set out. Former § 15-9 pertained to penalties and derived from Ord. No. 3187, § 5, adopted April 8, 1985. 
Sec. 15-10. - Penalties. 
    Any person who shall violate the provisions of sections 15-5 through 15-9 shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be fined not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense, or such person shall be jailed in the county jail for a period not exceeding thirty (30) days, or by both such fine and jail term. 
(Ord. No. 3754, § 1, 10-15-96) 
Secs. 15-11-15-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PARK BOARD[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Boards, commission and committees, § 2-251 et seq. 
State Law reference- Park boards, RSMo 90.520 et seq. 

Sec. 15-16. - Established. 
    A park board is hereby established. 
(Code 1967, § 18-5) 
Sec. 15-17. - Composition; qualifications and appointment of members. 
    The mayor, with the approval of the city council, is authorized to appoint a board of nine (9) directors for the purpose of forming a park board in the city. The directors shall be known as the park board with jurisdiction, in accordance with this chapter, over the city parks. The park board shall be chosen from the citizens at large with reference to their fitness for office. No member of the city government shall be a member of the park board. 
(Code 1967, § 18-6) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 90.520. 
Sec. 15-18. - Term of office; appointment; removal from office. 
    Annually, the mayor shall, with the approval of the city council, before the first of June each year, appoint three (3) directors, who shall hold office for three (3) years, from the first of June following their appointment and until their successors are appointed and qualify. The mayor, by and with the consent of the city council, may remove any director for misconduct or neglect of duty. 
(Code 1967, § 18-7) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 90.530. 
Sec. 15-19. - Vacancies, compensation. 
    Vacancies in the park board, occasioned by removal, resignation or otherwise, shall be reported to the city council and be filled in like manner as original appointments, and no director shall receive compensation as such, either as an original appointee or when appointed to fill a vacancy. 
(Code 1967, § 18-8) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 90.540. 
Sec. 15-20. - Organization; powers, etc. 
    The park board shall immediately after their appointment meet and organize by electing one of their number president, and by electing any other officers the board deems necessary. They shall make and adopt such bylaws, rules and regulations for their guidance and for the government of the park as may be expedient, not inconsistent with RSMo 90.500 to 90.570. Meetings of the board shall be held at the call of the president and at such other times as the board may determine. All meetings of the board shall be open to the public. All business of the board shall be conducted at such public meeting. A quorum for the transaction of business shall consist of a majority of all of the members of the board and any decision of the board shall require an affirmative vote of a majority of all of the members of the board. The board shall have exclusive control of the expenditures of all money belonging to the park fund, and of the supervision, improvement, care and custody of the park. All money received for park purposes shall be deposited in the city treasury to the sole credit of the park fund and shall be kept separate and apart from other money of the city, and shall be drawn upon by the proper officers of the city upon properly authenticated vouchers of the city park board. The park board shall have power to appoint a suitable person to take care of the park and necessary assistants for that person, and fix their compensation, and shall have power to remove these appointees and shall have general authority to carry out and make effective the spirit and intent of this chapter. 
(Code 1967, § 18-9; Ord. No. 4038, § 1, 11-27-00) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 90.550. 
Sec. 15-21. - Authority of park board to erect signs. 
    The park board shall erect signs setting forth the regulatory measures as provided in this chapter. 
(Code 1967, § 18-1) 
Sec. 15-22. - Annual report. 
(a)  The park board of directors shall make, on or before the second Monday in June, an annual report to the city council stating the condition of their trust on the first day of May of that year, the various sums of money received from the park fund and other sources, and how much money has been expended and for what purpose, with any other statistics, information and suggestions as they may deem of general interest. All portions of the report as relate to the receipt and expenditure of money shall be verified by affidavit. 
(b)  Nothing in this section shall prohibit the city council from calling upon the park board for their report at any time the city council deems it advisable to make a report, and when so called upon, it shall be the duty of the park board to make the report as required. 
(Code 1967, § 18-10) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 90.560. 
Sec. 15-23. - Authority to receive donations. 
    The park board shall have authority to receive by donation or gift money, personal property or real estate for the benefit of the park and shall have the right to vest the title to any such donation or gift in the park board, to be held and controlled by the board when accepted according to the terms of the deed, gift, devise or bequest of the property, and as to this property, the board shall be held and considered to be special trustees. 
(Code 1967, § 18-11) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 90.570. 
Secs. 15-24-15-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - LEBANON AREA VETERANS MEMORIAL BOARD[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5722 , § 3, adopted February 26, 2018, repealed the former article III, §§ 15-41-15-45, and § 5 of Ord. No. 5722 renumbered the existing articles IV and V as articles III and IV. The former article III pertained to the Nelson Community Center and derived from Ord. No. 3332, adopted June 12, 1989.   Ord. No. 4173, § 1, adopted Feb. 10, 2003, set out provisions intended for use as Art. IV, §§ 15-46-15-50. To preserve the style of this Code, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as Art. IV, §§ 15-61-15-65. 

Sec. 15-61. - Established. 
    A veterans memorial board is hereby established which shall be known as the "Lebanon Area Veterans Memorial Board." 
(Ord. No. 4173, § 1, 2-10-03) 
Sec. 15-62. - Appointment; term of office; removal from office. 
(a)  The board shall consist of seven (7) members who shall be appointed by the mayor and approved by a majority of the members of the city council. The membership shall consist of at least four (4) veterans, three (3) of whom shall reside in the City of Lebanon, and one of whom may reside outside the city, but must be a resident of Laclede County. The City Parks Department Director shall serve as an ex-officio member, and shall not have voting rights. 
(b)  Members of the board shall serve without pay and shall serve at the pleasure of the appointing authority. The mayor, with the approval of a majority of the city council, may remove a board member from the board at will, and such board member may also be removed by a three-fourths vote of the city council independently of the mayor's approval or disapproval. 
(c)  The term of office of all members, except the city parks department director, shall be for a two-year term or until a successor is appointed. Each year the terms of two (2) members of the board shall be set to expire. 
(Ord. No. 4173, § 1, 2-10-03; Ord. No. 5006, § 1, 10-9-12) 
Sec. 15-63. - Organization-Powers. 
(a)  The Lebanon Area Veterans Memorial Board shall, immediately after their appointment, meet and organize by electing one of their number president and any other officers as deemed necessary. They shall make and adopt such bylaws, rules and regulations for their guidance and for the government of the Veterans Memorial Park as may be expedient and not inconsistent with Sections 90.500 to 90.570. V.A.M.S. Meetings of the board shall be at the call of the president. All meetings of the board shall be open to the public except meetings that relate to subject matter set forth in Section 610.021. V.A.M.S. Any decisions of the board shall require an affirmative vote of a majority of the members of the board. 
(b)  The board shall be responsible for the supervision, improvement, maintenance, care and operation of all veterans memorials located inside the City of Lebanon, located on city property; however, any major structural changes or improvements shall require approval of the city council. 
(c)  The board shall have authority to receive by donation or gift, money or personal property for the benefit of the memorials and shall have control of the expenditure of such funds that are provided from whatever source for memorial purposes. All funds received for any veterans memorial under the jurisdiction of the board shall be deposited with the Lebanon Area Foundation to the sole credit of the board and shall be maintained in a separate account and drawn upon only by the proper written authorization of the designated officers of the board. 
(Ord. No. 4173, § 1, 2-10-03) 
Sec. 15-64. - Annual report. 
(a)  The board shall make, on or before the second Monday of June, an annual report to the city council which reflects the amount of money contained in the separate account maintained for the board by the Lebanon Area Foundation, the various sums of money received from that source and other sources, and how much money has been expended and for what purpose. All portions of the report as it relates to the receipt and expenditure of money shall be verified by affidavit. 
(b)  Nothing in this section shall prohibit the city council from calling upon the board for their report at any time the city council deems it advisable to make a report, and when so called upon, it shall be the duty of the board to make the report as required. 
(Ord. No. 4173, § 1, 2-10-03) 
Sec. 15-65. - Damages-Penalty. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to write, paint, draw, scratch, or damage by scratching or otherwise defacing any part of any veterans memorial, including but not limited to stone, bricks, flagpoles, flags, walkways, shrubbery, plantings and grounds dedicated to or associated with any veterans memorial. 
(b)  No one shall use any part of the memorial area for skating, roller-blading or riding in any manner except that handicapped wheelchairs or similar handicapped equipment shall be permitted by visitors or by visitors' employees or authorized personnel. 
(c)  Penalty for violation of any of the above listed or any other acts causing damage to the veterans memorial and grounds shall be up to a five-hundred- dollar fine or three (3) months in jail or both. 
(Ord. No. 4173, § 1, 2-10-03) 
Secs. 15-66-15-69. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - ADOPT-A-PARK PROGRAM[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Formerly article V. See editor's note at article III. 

Sec. 15-70. - Adopt-a-park program. 
(a)  The purpose of the adopt-a-park program is to provide volunteer community support for litter prevention and park beautification with the potential for cost savings to the City of Lebanon, Laclede County, Missouri (hereinafter referred to as "city"). 
(b)  The adopt-a-park program is intended to reduce litter, enhance the environment and beautify the city's parks. 
(c)  The adopt-a-park program is not intended to provide an open forum for participants' use to promote personal or political causes. 
(d)  The adopt-a-park rules and regulations are approved by the park board and available by contacting the parks department. 
(e)  An applicant to be known as the adopter or representative thereof shall submit an adopt-a-park program application for approval on a form approved by the park board and distributed by the parks department under the direction of the parks department director. 
(f)  Civic, non-profit, commercial, private enterprise and/or individuals are eligible to submit an adopt-a-park application. 
(g)  Adopter(s) that do not meet the eligibility requirements will be denied participation in the adopt-a-park program. 
(h)  Adopter(s) that fail to meet the eligibility requirements during the term of the approved application shall be removed from the adopt-a-park program. 
(i)  The parks department director has the authority to approve applications of individuals or groups applying to participate in the adopt-a-park program. The parks department director reserves the right to reject, deny or limit the number of adoptions for a single group. 
(j)  A request for participation in the adopt-a-park program may be denied if the applicant has submitted false statement(s) of a material fact or has practiced or attempted to practice any fraud or deception in an application. Material facts include statements regarding convictions of violent criminal activity. 
(Ord. No. 4808, § 1, 1-31-11) 
Chapter 16 - PEDDLERS, SOLICITORS AND ITINERANT MERCHANTS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Secondhand goods, Ch. 19; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 22. 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to license and regulate hawkers, peddlers, etc., RSMo 94.110; merchants; manufacturers', itinerant vendors' and peddlers' licenses and taxes, RSMo Ch. 150. 

ARTICLE I. - BUILDING TRADE OCCUPATIONAL LICENSING CODE 

Sec. 16-1. - Building trade occupational licensing code; enacting authority; title; application; exceptions. 
    This article is hereby established and shall be known as the "building trade occupational licensing code" of the city, and shall apply to all corporations, companies, associations, joint stock associations, partnerships, co-partnerships, and persons and/or their lessees, duly constituted trustees or receivers, heirs, administrators or assigns, who shall engage in any building, trade, vocation, or profession covered by subsection 16-2(a). The intent of this code is to require building trade contractors as defined herein to provide the same information and code compliance commitments mandated by the building trade codes in effect in the city (including the fire code) referred to in subsection 16-2(a). 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 1, 11-26-01) 
Sec. 16-2. - License required; definitions. 
(a)  Any contractor or subcontractor in the construction industry who performs work within the city, which work is governed by any BOCA or international code that is in effect in the city, shall be required to obtain a license therefor whether the business location of such person is within the city limits or not; this subsection is intended to include but is not limited to building contractors (including subcontractors) electricians, plumbers, and heating and cooling contractors. 
(b)  Fees. No fees or taxes shall be required for any license covered by this article. 
(c)  Licensee. Includes any person, as hereinafter defined, who shall apply and obtain a license under the terms and/or provisions of this chapter and in accordance therewith. 
(d)  Person. Shall mean natural person, firm, partnership, co-partnership, corporation, company, association, joint stock association, and/or their lessees, duly constituted trustees or receivers, heirs, administrators or assigns. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 1, 11-26-01) 
Sec. 16-3. - Penalties for various violations of article. 
(a)  Doing business without license. Any person performing building trade work within the city as defined in subsection 16-2(a) without first securing a license therefor, as required by this article, upon conviction thereof, shall be subject to a fine of not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(b)  False statements in application. No person shall knowingly make a false statement in his/her application for a license. 
(c)  Penalty. Any person found to have made a false statement in his/her/its application for a license after the license has been issued shall be subject to the penalties set forth in this section. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 1, 11-26-01) 
Sec. 16-4. - License prerequisite to doing business; fire code inspection; certificate of worker's compensation coverage; code compliance statements. 
(a)  No person shall engage in any building trade activity within the city without first having obtained a license therefor, and registering said business, trade, occupation or profession with the office of the building and zoning administrator on a form provided by the administrator. 
(b)  Any applicant who has a business location in the city as defined in subsection 16-2(a) shall be required to have a fire code inspection of their premises prior to the issuance of a license and prior to the renewal of the same on any anniversary date thereafter. 
(c)  Any applicant who is a contractor or a subcontractor in the construction industry shall be required to produce a certificate of insurance for worker's compensation coverage or an affidavit, signed by the applicant attesting that the contractor is exempt. 
(d)  Any applicant who performs construction work in the city covered by this article shall be required to submit a code compliance statement after completion of the project before an occupancy permit will be issued. This subsection shall cover both residential and commercial projects. 
(e)  The city shall not be responsible for the nature and/or quality of any work performed by any licensee. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 1, 11-26-01) 
Sec. 16-5. - Payment of tax or other obligation. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a building trade occupation or business unless and until all taxes or any other financial obligations due to the city, which are delinquent and owing to the city, have been paid. No license provided for or required under this article, or any other ordinance of the city, shall be issued by any department until compliance with this section shall have been fulfilled. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 1, 11-26-01) 
Sec. 16-6. - License year. 
    The license year for all licenses issued under this article shall begin January 1 and end the last day of December. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 1, 11-26-01) 
Sec. 16-7. - Applications; forms; where filed. 
    All applications for licenses provided for in this article shall be filed with the building and zoning administrator. The building and zoning administrator shall prescribe the form of application and license form. Except as otherwise provided by ordinance, all licenses issued under this article shall be signed by the building and zoning administrator or facsimile and shall be invalid for all purposes unless so signed. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 1, 11-26-01) 
Sec. 16-8. - Separate license for each separate legal business entity. 
    A separate license shall be obtained for each separate legal business entity conducted, operated, maintained, or carried on by every person engaged in any building trade, occupation or profession operation for which a license is required by this article. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 1, 11-26-01) 
Sec. 16-9. - More than one business at the same address. 
    Whenever any person making application for a license under the provisions of this article is engaged in more than one business, which is not operated as a separate legal business entity, at the same address, such person shall combine the information for all businesses conducted at the same address, the same as if all were conducted as a single business operation. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 1, 11-26-01) 
Sec. 16-10. - Record of licenses issued. 
    It shall be the duty of the building and zoning administrator to keep a complete and accurate record of all licenses issued under this article, showing the nature of the license, its date of issuance, and to whom issued. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 1, 11-26-01) 
Sec. 16-11. - Change of business location; change of business ownership. 
(a)  A license may be amended to authorize the conduct of the same building trade, occupation or profession operation at a different location, provided the control of same remains in the same person, upon filing with the building and zoning administrator an amended application, within fifteen (15) days of the change, showing the change of address. 
(b)  A license issued to any person under the provisions of this article shall not be transferable from one person to another person in the event of change of ownership. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 1, 11-26-01) 
Sec. 16-12. - License to be prominently displayed. 
    All business or occupational licenses issued by the city which are located within the city under this article shall be prominently displayed in a conspicuous manner in the place of business authorized to be conducted by said licensee. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 1, 11-26-01) 
Sec. 16-13. - Remedies regarding the operation of a building trade occupation without a license. 
    The continued operation of a building trade occupation or profession without a current and valid license shall be deemed a nuisance, and, as such, shall be actionable under Chapter 13 of the this Code and all of the provisions of Chapter 13 are applicable to the nuisance and its abatement. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 1, 11-26-01) 
Secs. 16-14, 16-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 16-16. - Purpose. 
    This article is designed to: 
(1)  Prevent undue annoyance of city residents by peddlers and solicitors; 
(2)  Maximize the First Amendment rights of peddlers and solicitors, as well as the right of city residents to be secure in their homes; 
(3)  Reduce the opportunity for crime within the city; 
(4)  Attempt to provide some assurance to residents of the city that peddlers and solicitors are not burglars and criminals in disguise; and 
(5)  Attempt to increase the physical safety of peddlers and solicitors who go from place to place within the city. 
(Ord. No. 3152, § 1, 3-1-84) 
Sec. 16-17. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meaning respectively ascribed to them: 
    Peddler shall mean one who, for profit to himself or his principal, sells any good or service or seeks a donation for any cause of a profit-making or commercial character. 
    Solicitor shall mean one who solicits for a charitable, political or religious purpose, even if incidental for such purpose there is the sale of some good or service. 
    For the purpose of this article there shall be no difference to the rights, privileges and duties required of peddlers and solicitors, except for the special restrictions in section 16-55. 
(Ord. No. 3152, § 2, 3-1-84) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Peddler defined, RSMo 150.470. 
Sec. 16-18. - Persons presumed peddlers; exception. 
    It shall be presumed that an individual engaged in activities regulated by this article is a peddler rather than a solicitor. This presumption may be overcome by: 
(1)  A showing that donations to the organization for which one wishes to solicit is exempt from federal income taxation under section 503 of the Internal Revenue Code; or 
(2)  A showing that the organization for which one wishes to solicit is an organization whose primary purpose is to influence public policy. 
(Ord. No. 3152, § 3, 3-1-84) 
Secs. 16-19-16-30. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - IDENTIFICATION CARD 

Sec. 16-31. - Required; fee. 
(a)  No person shall engage in any act as a peddler or solicitor without first obtaining an identification card in accordance with the provisions of this article. Any person who does so shall be guilty of an offense. 
(b)  There shall be no fee for a peddler's identification card. There shall be no fee for a solicitor's identification card. 
(Ord. No. 3152, §§ 4, 5, 3-1-84) 
Sec. 16-32. - Application. 
(a)  Any person or organization, formal or informal, may apply for one or more identification cards by completing an application form at the office of the city clerk. 
(b)  An applicant for an identification card shall provide the following information: 
(1)  The name of applicant; 
(2)  The number of identification cards required; 
(3)  A statement as to the type of cards requested; 
(4)  If one or more solicitors cards is requested, information required to overcome the presumption of section 16-18; 
(5)  If one (1) or more peddlers cards are requested, a state sales license and proof that the applicant is in compliance with all state sales tax laws applicable to his business; 
(6)  The name and physical description, or in lieu thereof, a photograph, of each person for which a card is requested. Instead of providing the physical description or photograph, the applicant may exhibit a valid drivers license or similar identification for each person for whom a card is requested, and a photocopy of such identification shall be attached to such application; 
(7)  The permanent and local address, if any, of the applicant; 
(8)  The permanent and local addresses, if any, of each person for whom a card is requested; 
(9)  A brief description of the proposed activity subject to this identification card requirement; 
(10)  A statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of any crime, and if so, the nature of the offense and the penalty imposed; 
(11)  A statement as to each person for whom a card is requested as to whether that individual has been convicted of any crime, and if so, the nature of the offense and the penalty imposed; 
(12)  The motor vehicle make, model, year, color and registration number of any vehicle which shall be used in the proposed activity; 
(13)  The permanent name and address of the organization or person, with respect to a solicitors card, who can provide a prospective donor with more information about the charity or political or religious organization for which funds are solicited, and from whom information can be obtained as to the deposition of all funds collected, or, with respect to a peddler's card of the individual organization to whom complaints can be made for defective merchandise, who is responsible for any breach or warranty, and from whom additional merchandise can be ordered; 
(14)  The name and address of person to receive donations or profits; and 
(15)  Any other information the applicant may wish to provide. 
(Ord. No. 3152, §§ 6, 7, 3-1-84) 
Sec. 16-33. - Investigation. 
    During the period of time following the application for issuance of one (1) or more identification cards and its issuance, the chief of police shall make diligent investigation, as to him seems necessary, to determine that the applicant is entitled to the identification card sought. The chief of police shall cooperate with the applicant, shall inform the applicant of the progress of his investigation and shall use due diligence in conducting his investigation. In all cases, the chief of police shall work as expeditiously as is reasonably possible to complete his investigation in a minimum amount of time. If the chief of police has not completed his investigation within the working days as provided in section 16-34, the identification card will none the less be issued. 
(Ord. No. 3152, § 9, 3-1-84) 
Sec. 16-34. - Issuance; denial. 
(a)  Three (3) working days after application made pursuant to this division is tendered or sooner if reasonably possible, the requested identification cards shall be issued, unless: 
(1)  The application is incomplete, in which case the city clerk will reject the application at the time of its tender or within thirty (30) minutes thereafter; 
(2)  The applicant has been convicted of a felony; except as provided in RSMo 314.200; 
(3)  With respect to a particular card, if the individual for whom a card is requested has been convicted of a felony; except as provided in RSMo 314.200; 
(4)  If any statement upon the application is false, unless the applicant can demonstrate that the falsehood was the result of excusable neglect; 
(5)  If the application or if the particular individual for whom an identification card is requested has had a previous identification card revoked; or 
(6)  If the applicant or if a particular individual for whom an identification is requested has made any false statement regarding the peddling of merchandise or the solicitation of persons under this article of any other municipality. 
(b)  If the city clerk denies the identification card to one (1) or more persons, the clerk shall prepare promptly, and in no event later than two (2) working days after the denial, a written report of the reason for the denial which shall be immediately made available to the applicant. The applicant shall be entitled to correct in writing any deficiencies so noted in the report, which corrections or changes when filed shall be treated as a new application. 
(Ord. No. 3152, §§ 8, 10, 3-1-84) 
Sec. 16-35. - Applicant's rights upon denial of identification card. 
    If an identification card is denied to an applicant, the applicant shall have the option of an immediate hearing in front of any of three (3) tribunals at the applicant's option. At such a hearing, the city attorney on behalf of the city clerk shall be required to demonstrate by the preponderance of the evidence that the applicant is not entitled to an identification card under this article. The applicant may choose to take his case before any of the following tribunals: 
(1)  The city council at its next regular meeting, or if the next regular meeting is more than twenty (20) days from the denial of the identification card, at a special meeting to be held within that twenty day period; 
(2)  The municipal court, provided that such a hearing will be scheduled within twenty (20) days of the request; or 
(3)  The circuit court within the regularly scheduled procedures of the circuit court, and under the state administrative procedure act. The transcript on such an appeal to the circuit court shall be the written application of the applicant, and the written report of a denial issued by the city clerk as required in the preceding section. 
(Ord. No. 3152, § 11, 3-1-84) 
Sec. 16-36. - Hearing on applicant's denial of identification card; procedure. 
    If an applicant requests a hearing under section 16-35, the hearing shall be held in accordance with the state administrative procedure act, and review from the decision shall be had to the circuit court on the record. Should the applicant decide to forego the administrative hearings, the remedy will be an injunction or declaratory judgment action against the city. 
(Ord. No. 3152, § 12, 3-1-84) 
Sec. 16-37. - Term of validity. 
    An identification card issued under this division shall be valid within the meaning of this article for a period of two (2) months from its date of issuance, thereafter it shall expire. An applicant with an expired identification card shall be considered as having no identification card whatsoever and will be required to apply for a new card if he wished to peddle or solicit within the city. 
(Ord. No. 3152, § 14, 3-1-84) 
Sec. 16-38. - Revocation. 
    Any identification card granted under this division may be revoked by the municipal court after the filing of an Information by the city attorney and a hearing thereon for any of the following causes: 
(1)  Any violation of this article by the applicant or the person for whom the particular card was issued; 
(2)  Fraud, misrepresentation or incorrect statement made in the course of carrying on the activity; 
(3)  Conviction of the cardholder a felony; or 
(4)  Conducting his activity in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or a menace to the health, safety or general welfare of the public. 
(Ord. No. 3152, § 15, 3-1-84) 
Secs. 16-39-16-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - REGULATORY PROVISIONS 

Sec. 16-51. - Permit required; state license prerequisite to permit. 
(a)  No person shall peddle, solicit or operate as peddlers or solicitors in the city without first having obtained a permit to do so from the city clerk. The issuance of the permit shall entitle the holder to peddle and solicit within the city. The holder of the permit shall exhibit his permit to any police officer who may request to see it. 
(b)  No permit shall be issued by the city clerk until the applicant produces a valid state peddler's license and an identification card issued under section 16-34. 
(Code 1967, § 19-2) 
Sec. 16-52. - Display of identification card required. 
    Each identification card shall, when the individual for whom it was issued is acting as a peddler or solicitor, be worn on the outer clothing of such peddler or solicitor, so as to be reasonably visible to any person who might be approached thereby. 
(Ord. No. 3152, § 13, 3-1-84) 
Sec. 16-53. - Certain sales practices declared a nuisance; exemption. 
(a)  The practice of going in and upon private residences in the city by peddlers, solicitors or itinerant vendors of merchandise not having been requested or invited so to do by the owner or occupant of the residence for the purpose of soliciting orders for the sale of goods, wares and merchandise and/or disposing of and/or peddling or soliciting the same is declared to be a nuisance and punishable as such. 
(b)  The provisions of subsection (a) shall not be construed as being applicable to any person who holds a valid solicitors identification card and permit from the city. 
(Ord. No. 1926, §§ 1, 4, 9-23-74) 
Cross reference- Nuisances, Ch. 13. 
Sec. 16-54. - Prohibited acts-Generally. 
    No person having a solicitor's or peddler's identification card shall: 
(1)  Enter or remain on private property where he has reason to believe that the residents thereof have indicated the solicitor or peddler is not welcome; 
(2)  Make an uninvited entry into a resident's home; 
(3)  Refuse to discontinue his message when requested by a hearer to do so, when on private property occupied by the hearer; or 
(4)  Enter upon any private property, knowing or having reason to believe that the owner or occupants do not desire to receive messages from any solicitor or peddler, either by a posted sign or otherwise. 
(Ord. No. 3152, § 16, 3-1-84) 
Sec. 16-55. - Same-Special restrictions on peddlers. 
    No person having a peddler's identification card shall peddle or solicit merchandise: 
(1)  At any place except within the business district of the city as defined by its zoning regulations, or within twenty-five (25) feet to any non-conforming commercial establishment; or 
(2)  Outside of the area provided in subsection (1) unless he has a specific oral or written invitation to approach the dwelling. 
    This article shall not apply to any person who solicits individuals on real estate in which the person has an ownership or leasehold interest. 
(Ord. No. 3152, § 19, 3-1-84) 
Sec. 16-56. - Responsibilities of the city. 
    Any resident of the city may list his property with the city clerk and direct that his property is not to be entered by any solicitor or peddler. This list shall be available for public inspection. Upon the issuance of any solicitor's or peddler's license, a copy of the list shall be provided with each card. No card holder may enter the private property nor contact any person so listed. Such listing shall continue for two (2) years, unless the listee requests sooner removal, at which time the listing shall be removed, unless the listee shall request the same to be continued an additional two (2) years. 
(Ord. No. 3152, § 17, 3-1-84) 
Sec. 16-57. - Time limits. 
(a)  No person shall solicit or peddle within the corporate limits of this city except from 9:00 a.m. until 8:00 p.m. Monday through Friday, and from 10:00 a.m. until 9:00 p.m. on Saturday and Sunday. 
(b)  Notwithstanding subsection (a), no person shall peddle or solicit at any time after sunset on any day unless: 
(1)  He is dressed in light colored or reflective clothing; and 
(2)  He has notified the chief of police of his intention to solicit after dark. 
(Ord. No. 3152, § 18, 3-1-84) 
Secs. 16-58-16-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ITINERANT VENDORS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4108, § 1, adopted Nov. 26, 2001, amended Art. III in its entirety to read as herein set out. The former Art. III, §§ 16-71-16-75, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the original codification and Code 1967, §§ 19-4-19-6, 19-13. 
State Law reference- Itinerant vendors, RSMo 150.380 et seq. 

Sec. 16-71. - Definition and restrictions. 
(a)  The term "itinerant vendor," for the purpose of this article, shall mean and include all persons, both principal and agents, who engage in, or conduct in this city, either in one place or traveling from place to place, a temporary or transient business of selling, exposing or offering for sale, any goods, wares or merchandise and who, for the purpose of carrying on their business shall hire, lease or occupy, either in whole or in part, any vehicle, room, building, street stand or other structure, or commercial parking area, for the exhibition and sale of any goods, wares and merchandise and do not have a permanent place of business in the city. 
(b)  Itinerant vendor's business operation: 
(1)  Shall only be conducted in commercially zoned areas; 
(2)  Shall not be conducted on city property or on any public street, alley or right-of-way with the exemption of the city owned parking lot located between Jefferson Street and Adams Street, south of the BNSF railroad tracks for the express purpose of a farmers type market or vendor under agreement with the City of Lebanon. 
(3)  Shall not be conducted in any parking lot if the operation reduces the number of parking spaces below that required for that property under the zoning ordinance; and 
(4)  Shall not be conducted out of or adjacent to any self-storage facility. 
(Ord. No. 4108, § 1, 11-26-01; Ord. No. 4718, § 1, 4-26-10) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 150.380(1). 
Sec. 16-72. - Applicability of article. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to sales made to dealers by commercial travelers or selling agents in the usual course of business, nor to bona fide sales of goods, wares and merchandise by sample for future delivery, nor to hawkers on the streets, or peddlers from vehicles, nor to any sale of goods, wares and merchandise on the grounds of any agricultural society during the continuance of any annual fair held by the society, nor to auctioneers when selling goods, merchandise or property for customary auction fee or commissions, nor to any person or organization that has secured a permit from the city, or written permission from the downtown Lebanon district or the school district to sell goods, merchandise or food on property owned or controlled by the said entity, nor to any not-for-profit or charitable organization selling goods, merchandise or food for its own benefit on property owned or controlled by that organization, nor to any person conducting a garage sale of his or her own personal property from his or her residence which is located in a commercially zoned area. 
(Ord. No. 4108, § 1, 11-26-01) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 150.380(2). 
Sec. 16-73. - Compliance with article prerequisite to entering business. 
    Itinerant vendors, before engaging in business, shall fully comply with the terms of this article. 
(Ord. No. 4108, § 1, 11-26-01) 
Sec. 16-74. - License required; state retail sales license prerequisite to city license. 
(a)  An itinerant vendor, whether principal or agent, before beginning business, shall apply to the city clerk for an itinerant vendor's license which shall be issued by the city clerk authorizing him to do business in the city in conformity with the provisions of this article and for the number of days specified in the license. The permittee shall exhibit his permit to any police officer who may request to see it. 
(b)  No license shall be issued by the city clerk until the applicant obtains and displays his Missouri Retail Sales License showing that the applicant has authority to engage in business in the city. If the applicant's retail sales license is revoked by the state, this vendor's license shall be automatically revoked and a new application made after reinstatement. 
(c)  The license shall not be transferable, nor allow more than one person to sell goods as an itinerant vendor, either by agent or clerk, or in any other way than in person, but any permittee may have the assistance of one or more persons, who may aid him in conducting his business, but not act for him or without him. 
(Ord. No. 4108, § 1, 11-26-01) 
Sec. 16-75. - Contents of application for license. 
    Applications for licenses required by this article shall disclose the name and address of the itinerant vendor, and the location at which the business operation will be conducted. 
(Ord. No. 4108, § 1, 11-26-01) 
Sec. 16-76. - Violations of article. 
    Itinerant vendors who fail to comply with any of the requirements of this article shall be punished in accordance with section 1-12. 
(Ord. No. 4108, § 1, 11-26-01) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 150.460. 
Chapter 17 - PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6; flood damage prevention, Ch. 11; fair housing, § 12-16 et seq.; parks and recreation, Ch. 15; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 22; subdivision regulations, Ch. 23; zoning, App. A. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 17-1-17-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - URBAN REDEVELOPMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3386, §§ 1-27 and §§ 29, 30, adopted August 13, 1990, did not specifically amend the Code; therefore, inclusion as Art. II, §§ 17-21-17-49, was at the discretion of the editor. This article shall be in full force and effect from and after the time of its passage. 

Sec. 17-21. - Determination of necessity for article. 
    It is hereby determined and declared by the council that in certain portions of the city there are obsolete, decadent, substandard, unsanitary or blighted areas which because of age, obsolescence, inadequate or outmoded design or physical deterioration, as well as inadequate planning, lack of proper light, air or open space and defective building arrangements, have impaired economic value and that these areas have become economic and social liabilities to the city and its citizens. These areas are characterized by depreciated real property values with reduced or negligible income potential and consequent inability to pay reasonable taxes, and are conducive to ill health, transmission of disease, infant mortality, juvenile delinquency and crime. Such obsolete, substandard, unsanitary and blighted areas constitute a menace to the health, safety, morals and welfare of the citizens of the city. These poor conditions occur frequently in areas which are subdivided into small parcels with multiple owners where there is frequent confusion as to who owns individual parcels. The council further determines and declares that individuals would find it difficult and costly to assemble parcels of land for the purpose of clearing, replanning, rehabilitating, reconstructing and redeveloping these areas and that the failure to clear, replan, rehabilitate, reconstruct or redevelop these areas results in progressive deterioration of the city as a whole, continued decline in the city's population, and excessive and wasteful expenditures of public funds for policing, sanitation and other public services. The council further determines and declares that such conditions can be improved but that improvement may require the investment of large amounts of capital so that adequate parcels of land can be acquired at fair prices, such areas can be cleared by demolishing existing old, obsolete, inadequate, unsafe or unsanitary buildings, and such areas can be redeveloped using appropriate land use planning under proper supervision. The large scale redevelopment of these areas is necessary for the public welfare and constitutes public uses and purposes for which the city may acquire private property by purchase or eminent domain. Therefore, the provisions hereby enacted are declared as a matter of legislative determination to be in the public interest. 
(Ord. No. 3386, § 1, 8-13-90) 
Sec. 17-22. - Acceptance of application of state enabling act. 
    The provisions of the "Urban Redevelopment Corporations Law," found at Chapter 353 of the Revised Statutes of Missouri, are hereby accepted and shall apply to all persons and corporations operating under this article. 
(Ord. No. 3386, § 2, 8-13-90) 
Sec. 17-23. - Definitions. 
(a)  The following terms, whenever used or referred to in this article, shall, unless a different intent clearly appears from the context, be construed to have the following meanings: 
    Area shall mean that portion of the city which the council has found or shall find to be blighted, so that the clearance, replanning, rehabilitation or reconstruction thereof is necessary to effectuate the purposes of this article. Any such area may include buildings or improvements not in themselves blighted, and any real property, whether improved or unimproved, the inclusion of which is deemed necessary for the effective clearance, replanning, reconstruction or rehabilitation of the area of which such buildings, improvements or real property form a part. 
    Blighted area shall mean those portions of the city which the council determines that by reason of age, obsolescence, inadequate or outmoded design or physical deterioration, have become economic and social liabilities and that the conditions of such localities are conducive to ill health, transmission of disease, crime or inability to pay reasonable taxes. 
    Commission shall mean the planning and zoning commission of the City of Lebanon. 
    Council shall mean the city council of the City of Lebanon. 
    Development cost shall mean the amount determined by the commission to be the actual cost of redevelopment or of that party thereof for which such determination is made. The term shall include, among other costs, the reasonable expense of planning the redevelopment, including preliminary studies and surveys, neighborhood planning and architectural and engineering services, the reasonable value of the services performed in connection with the development plan, interest during construction, the actual cost of the real property or any part thereof where acquired partly or wholly in exchange for securities, the actual cost of demolishing existing structures, the actual cost of utilities, landscaping and roadways, the actual cost of constructing and furnishing buildings and improvements, including the costs of equipment and architectural, engineering and builder's fees, the actual cost of reconstruction, rehabilitation, redevelopment, remodeling, or initial repair of existing buildings and improvements, reasonable management and operations costs until the redevelopment is ready for use, and the actual cost of improving those portions of the area which are to remain open spaces, together with such additions to development costs as shall equal the actual cost of additions to or changes in the redevelopment in accordance with the original development plan or after approved changes therein or amendments thereto. 
    Development plan shall mean a plan, together with any amendments thereto, for the redevelopment of all or any part of a blighted area. 
    Mortgage shall mean a mortgage, trust indenture, deed of trust, building and loan contract, or other instrument creating a lien on real property, to secure the payment of an indebtedness, and the indebtedness secured by any of them. 
    Person shall mean and include any natural person, firm, partnership, joint venture, association, corporation (except a redevelopment corporation), whether organized for profit or not, estate, trust, business trust, receiver or trustee appointed by any state or federal court, syndicate, or any other group or combination acting as a unit. 
    Real property shall include lands, buildings, improvements, land under water, waterfront property, and any and all easements, franchises and hereditaments, corporeal and incorporeal, and ever estate, interest, privilege, easement, franchise and right therein, or appurtenant thereto, legal or equitable, including restrictions of record, created by plat, covenants, or otherwise, rights-of-way, and terms for years. 
    Redevelopment shall mean the clearance, replanning, reconstruction or rehabilitation of any blighted area and the provision for such industrial, commercial, residential or public structures and spaces as may be appropriate, including recreational and other facilities incident or appurtenant thereto. 
    Redevelopment corporation shall mean an urban redevelopment corporation organized under and pursuant to the provisions of the Urban Redevelopment Corporations Law and shall include any life insurance company organized under the laws of, or admitted to do business in, the State of Missouri, which shall undertake a redevelopment project under the provisions of this article. 
    Redevelopment project shall mean a specific work or improvement to effectuate all or any part of a development plan. 
    Urban Redevelopment Corporations Law shall mean Chapter 353 of the Revised Statutes of Missouri, as it may be amended from time to time hereafter. 
(b)  Words used but not otherwise defined herein shall have their common meanings. Words used in the present tense include the future; the singular number includes the plural and the plural includes the singular, unless the context clearly implies otherwise. 
(Ord. No. 3386, § 3, 8-13-90) 
Sec. 17-24. - Application for approval of development plan. 
    Submission of application form: Any redevelopment corporation proposing to file a development plan for the approval of the commission and the council must first file the development plan with the city clerk. Immediately after receipt of the filing of the development plan, the city clerk shall forward the development plan to the building and zoning administrator. The council shall not act on a development plan until the commission has submitted a report on such plan to the council. 
(Ord. No. 3386, § 4, 8-13-90) 
Sec. 17-25. - Supporting evidence of blight. 
(a)  Blight study. Any application for approval of a development plan shall include evidence that the area is a "blighted area" as defined by Section 353.020(2), RSMo, and section 17-23(a) of this article, which evidence shall include the following: 
(1)  Identification of facts which demonstrate that by reason of age, obsolescence, inadequate or outmoded design or physical deterioration, the area as a whole has become an economic and social liability and is conducive to ill health, transmission of disease, crime or inability to pay reasonable taxes. 
(2)  The existence of those conditions set out in section 17-21 upon which the redevelopment corporation relies. 
(3)  Identification and a factual description of each parcel within the area, including the nature and age of any improvements on the parcel and the physical condition of the parcel and any improvements thereon. 
(b)  Cause of blight. No condition caused by the redevelopment corporation shall be considered evidence of blight. 
(c)  Review by city planning and zoning commission. The commission shall review the blight study along with other evidence submitted to it. 
(d)  Review by city council. The council shall analyze the blight study, along with other evidence, and determine if the area is a blighted area. The council may, at its discretion, request an additional study of the area. 
(Ord. No. 3386, § 5, 8-13-90) 
Sec. 17-26. - Notice to taxing authority. 
(a)  Notification. Prior to the public hearing before the council, the redevelopment corporation shall give written notice to each political subdivision whose boundaries for ad valorem real estate taxation purposes include any portion of the real property to be affected within the area which is the subject of the development plan and shall certify to the council that such notice has been given. 
(b)  Method of notice. Any notice required by this section shall be in writing and mailed by first class mail, postage prepaid. 
(c)  Contents of notice. Any notice required by this section shall state the reason for the notice and, if the notice is a notice of a public hearing, the time, date, and place of the hearing. The notice shall include: 
(1)  A general boundary description of the area within the development plan; 
(2)  The nature of the development; 
(3)  A tax impact analysis indicating the actual and current ad valorem real estate taxes on the property proposed for redevelopment by parcel paid to each political subdivision and the estimated effect the development plan would have on such taxes if it is approved; and 
(4)  An estimate of the amount of ad valorem real estate tax revenues of each political subdivision which would be affected by the proposed tax abatement, based on the estimated assessed valuation of the real property involved as such property would exist before the redevelopment and after it is developed. 
(d)  Comments from taxing authorities. Any affected political subdivision may comment on the proposed development plan either in writing to the commission or the council or through a representative who appears at any hearing before the council. 
(Ord. No. 3386, § 6, 8-13-90) 
Sec. 17-27. - Contents of a development plan. 
    A development plan shall contain the following: 
(a)  Legal description: A legal description of the proposed development area by metes and bounds or other definite designation. 
(b)  Description of the redevelopment project: A description of the redevelopment project, including various stages of development, if any, and the approximate time each stage would begin and be completed, together with a description of the real property to be included in each stage so that each stage can be reasonably identified. The description shall include a time schedule for the commencement and completion of: 
(1)  Acquisition of properties; 
(2)  Demolition of buildings; and 
(3)  New construction and/or building renovation. 
(c)  Property to be demolished immediately: A list of existing buildings or improvements in the development area which would be demolished immediately, if any, and the approximate period of time during which such demolition would take place. 
(d)  Property not to be demolished immediately: A list of existing buildings or improvements in the development area which would not be demolished immediately, if any, and the approximate period of time during which demolition, if any, would take place. 
(e)  Building renovation: A description of the proposed improvements, if any, to each building not to be demolished immediately, any proposed repairs or alterations to such buildings, and the approximate period of time during which such improvements, repairs or alterations are to be made. 
(f)  New construction: A description of the type, number and character of each new residential, commercial and industrial building or other type of improvement to be erected or made in the proposed development area. 
(g)  Amenities: A description of those portions of the blighted area, if any, which shall be determined to be amenities to the redevelopment project, including but not limited to any permanent residential open space for recreation, streetscape, plaza areas and other similar amenities. 
(h)  Property for public agencies: A description of those portions of the blighted area, if any, which are proposed to be sold, donated, exchanged or leased to the board of education, public library board, art commission or other public agency and an outline of the terms of such proposed sale, donation, exchange or lease. 
(i)  Zoning changes: A description of the proposed changes, if any, in zoning ordinances or maps, necessary or desirable for the redevelopment, and protection against blighting influences of these proposed changes. 
(j)  Street changes: A description of the proposed changes, if any, in streets or street levels, alleys, any proposed street closings, and any changes which would have to be made to streets or alleys adjoining or near the redevelopment project including the plan for financing these changes. 
(k)  Financing: A description of the estimated costs and the proposed method of financing the costs of the development plan, including (1) an estimate of the approximate costs of acquisition, demolition, construction and rehabilitation, if any, and (2) the amount of capital required. Evidence shall also be submitted that sufficient funds are available, or will be available upon approval of the development plan, for the acquisition of property within the area, completion of all planned demolition, construction and/or rehabilitation activities of the redevelopment project, and that those funds shall remain available until the redevelopment project is completed. 
(l)  Management: The names of the individuals who are expected to be active in or associated with the management of the redevelopment project during the first year following the date the development plan is approved and the name and address of the registered agent in the State of Missouri for the redevelopment corporation. 
(m)  Eminent domain: A legal description of the real property owned, or proposed to be purchased or acquired by eminent domain by the redevelopment corporation, if any, and the reasons why this property must be acquired by condemnation. 
(n)  Eminent domain on behalf of proponents of plan: The legal description of the real property, if any, proposed to be purchased or acquired by eminent domain by the city on behalf of the proponents of the development plan or by any other body authorized to acquire by eminent domain and the reasons why the aid of the city or other body is sought for that purpose. 
(o)  Assignment of plan: The development plan shall provide appropriate restrictions on the right of assignment of the redevelopment project to any other entity to ensure that the intention and purpose of the redevelopment project will be carried out, provided that the redevelopment corporation may be permitted to assign the redevelopment project in the event such restrictions are available. 
(p)  Certificate of incorporation: The redevelopment corporation shall include a copy of the certificate of incorporation from the secretary of state in its plan. 
(q)  Other information: The development plan, and any application for amendment thereto, shall contain such other descriptions or exhibits as may be deemed relevant. 
(Ord. No. 3386, § 7, 8-13-90) 
Sec. 17-28. - Tax agreements by corporations. 
(a)  Payments in lieu of taxes. In the course of considering any development plan for approval, the commission and the council shall consider any agreement, in writing, on behalf of the redevelopment corporation presenting such redevelopment plan that, notwithstanding the provisions of the Missouri Redevelopment Corporations Law, it will make payments in lieu of real property taxes to the appropriate political subdivisions in such amounts which, together with the real property taxes to be paid on the land for the first ten (10) years, shall, at minimum, equal the total real property taxes on the land and improvements during the tax year immediately preceding purchase of the property by the redevelopment corporation. 
(b)  Distribution. Payments in lieu of taxes shall be distributed to all political subdivisions levying taxes on the area to be redeveloped on the same pro rata basis and in the same manner as the ad valorem real property tax revenues received by each taxing authority from such property in the year such payments are due. 
(c)  Hearing and report. As part of the consideration of any development plan, there shall be a full report on any agreement for payments in lieu of taxes. 
(Ord. No. 3386, § 8, 8-13-90) 
Cross reference- Taxation, Ch. 24. 
Sec. 17-29. - Certification required by corporations. 
(a)  Certification to be made with application and prior to approval. At the time a development plan which provides for the acquisition of property by eminent domain is filed, the redevelopment corporation shall certify, as a consideration for approval of the development plan, that after the plan is approved, (1) it shall make a good faith attempt to purchase such property within one hundred eighty (180) days if the owner of the property indicates in writing to the redevelopment corporation that he desires to proceed with the sale of the property; and (2) it will, if a sale of the property cannot be consummated within such period, proceed forthwith to file a proceeding in condemnation after one hundred eighty (180) days have elapsed. This certification shall be filed with the city clerk. Failure to abide by the terms of the certification shall be grounds for finding of a breach as hereinafter provided. 
(b)  Certifications to be filed after approval. After the council has approved a development plan, the redevelopment corporation shall file an annual report which provides the following information: 
(1)  The availability of equity financing as provided for in section 17-27(k) hereof or some other acceptable alternative financing. 
(2)  A financial statement indicating compliance with section 17-41 hereof. 
(3)  A legal description of an property acquired and the name in which such property was acquired as required pursuant to section 17-32. 
(4)  The addresses of all occupied residential buildings and structures owned or under the control of the redevelopment corporation and the status of compliance of such buildings and structures with the provisions of the city's building codes. 
(5)  The status of the redevelopment project as to any permits applied for or issued, and any certificates of occupancy issued and any other appropriate documentation relevant to the information as part of section 17-27(b) through (f). 
(c)  Additional certifications. The redevelopment corporation shall certify that the notices required by section 17-26 have been given as therein provided. 
(d)  Filing. The certifications required by subsections (b) and (c) of this section shall be filed with the building and zoning administrator. 
(Ord. No. 3386, § 9, 8-13-90) 
Sec. 17-30. - Determinations prior to approval of development plan. 
(a)  Determination of blighted area. As part of its review of an application for approval of a development plan, the commission shall review the evidence provided pursuant to section 17-25(a) concerning the designation of the area as a blighted area and determine whether the declaration of blight is necessary and advisable to effectuate the public purposes set forth in section 17-21 hereof. 
(b)  Determination as to development plan. Regardless of the recommendation of the commission on a determination of blight, the commission shall review the development plan submitted and forward a recommendation on the development plan to the council concerning the following: 
(1)  Compliance with the city's development plan; 
(2)  Necessity of the power of eminent domain to carry out the redevelopment project and to effectuate the purposes set forth in section 17-21 without creating a negative effect on adjacent properties; 
(3)  Sufficiency of size to allow redevelopment of the area in an efficient and economically satisfactory manner; 
(4)  Practicality of the development plan; 
(5)  Adequacy of public facilities for services to be provided concurrent with the redevelopment project, including but not limited to school, fire, water, sewer, police, transportation, park, playground and recreation, considering current facilities and any proposed facilities; 
(6)  Appropriateness of any changes to zoning ordinances or maps, vacating or closing streets and alleys, or the construction of streets and alleys; and 
(7)  Compliance with the provisions of section 17-27 hereof. 
(c)  Determination as to financing. The commission shall review the description of financing provided pursuant to section 17-27(k) and forward a recommendation on the adequacy of the financing based upon the costs proposed in the development plan to the council. 
(d)  Determination as to tax abatement. The commission shall review the proposed redevelopment project and forward a recommendation as to the need for tax abatement considering the estimated cost of the redevelopment project and assessment of the effect of such tax abatement on the political subdivision affected by such abatement to the council. 
(Ord. No. 3386, § 10, 8-13-90) 
Sec. 17-31. - Recommendation by city planning and zoning commission. 
    The commission shall review the development plan and make a recommendation to the council. In arriving at its recommendation, the commission shall consider the blight studies, the development plan and whether the type of development is desirable for the area concerned. After fully considering each development plan, the commission shall forthwith transmit its recommendation thereon to the council. 
(Ord. No. 3386, § 11, 8-13-90) 
Sec. 17-32. - Expiration of development plan. 
(a)  Sunset provision. After a development plan has been approved by the council, the redevelopment corporation shall expeditiously acquire ownership of the property within the blighted area and commence the clearance of blight. Failure to acquire the fee interest and any lesser interest in the name of the redevelopment corporation or on behalf of the redevelopment corporation by a designated person within three (3) years after the date specified in the contract between the city and the redevelopment corporation for phase I, and each phase thereafter, shall result in an automatic loss of the development rights, including the rights of eminent domain and tax abatement, and the development plan and contract shall become null and void as to the respective and all subsequent phases; provided, however, that if such failure is not a result of any fault on the part of the redevelopment corporation, a time extension may be granted pursuant to section 17-34(c) hereof. 
(b)  Certification. Prior to the expiration of the time provided in section 17-32(a), the redevelopment corporation shall notify the mayor of all interest acquired by the redevelopment corporation or on behalf of the redevelopment corporation and identify any person acquiring such interest on behalf of the redevelopment corporation. 
(c)  Condemnation. For purposes of this section, the initiation of condemnation proceedings by the filing of a petition in the appropriate court and the continued pursuance thereof shall be deemed acquisition of the parcels of land under condemnation, provided that the redevelopment corporation has notified the mayor of the condemnation action. 
(d)  Contract provisions. Any contract approved hereafter pursuant to section 17-36(a) shall identify the provisions of this section. 
(e)  Applicability. The provisions set forth in this section 17-32 shall not apply to contractual arrangements entered into now or hereafter concerning termination of an approved redevelopment project, and any amendment thereto shall not be affected by this section. 
(Ord. No. 3386, § 12, 8-13-90) 
Sec. 17-33. - Prerequisites to amendment of plan. 
    The commission shall review any amendments to a development plan previously approved by ordinance, and make its recommendation accordingly to the council. No amendment shall be reviewed by the commission unless and until an application for amendment has been filed with the city clerk by the redevelopment corporation or its assigns which contains any information relevant to the proposed amendment which is required by section 17-27, and unless and until the commission has made all determinations required by section 17-30 which are relevant to the proposed amendment. The notice and hearing requirements of section 17-26 shall also apply. 
(Ord. No. 3386, § 13, 8-13-90) 
Sec. 17-34. - Commission to check compliance, make reports, adopt rules and regulations. 
(a)  Investigation: It shall be the duty of the commission, after a development plan has been approved by the council, to investigate and determine from time to time during construction of the redevelopment project whether the redevelopment corporation undertaking such development plan is fully complying with the provisions thereof, in the manner and at the times fixed therein for the performance of the various stages thereof, if any. 
(b)  Reports: It shall also be the duty of the commission to make reports on each redevelopment project from time to time during the construction of the redevelopment project, and at least once a year to the council, about the performance or compliance with the development plan and the compliance with the provisions of this article by any corporation operating thereunder; provided, however, that no report is required if the plan has been amended within the preceding twelve (12) months. 
(c)  Time extension: The council may, upon the recommendation of the commission and for good cause shown, grant a redevelopment corporation which is operating under an approved development plan an extension of time in which to complete the redevelopment project or any stage thereof.
