(d)  Recommendation of certification: When a redevelopment corporation operating under an approved development plan has completed the redevelopment project in accordance with the provisions of the development plan, in the manner and at the time fixed therein for the performance of the various stages thereof, the commission, upon the written request of such redevelopment corporation, shall conduct an investigation, and if the commission determines that the redevelopment project has been so completed, it shall recommend to the council that a certificate of full compliance be issued to the redevelopment corporation for each stage, and the council may authorize the building and zoning administrator to issue a certificate of compliance which shall be conclusive evidence of such compliance, except upon proof of fraud. The investigation and reports of the commission required by subsections (a) and (b) of this section shall not be required or made subsequent to the date of issuance of such certificate; provided, however, that every redevelopment corporation shall render annually to the mayor, during the existence of the tax relief period provided in section 17-46, three (3) copies of its financial report for the preceding year, which report shall disclose the earnings of the redevelopment corporation and the disposition of any net earnings in excess of those provided for under section 17-41, and the interest rate on income debentures, bonds, notes or other evidences of debt of the redevelopment corporation. The building and zoning administrator shall review the financial report of the redevelopment corporation and thereafter file the financial report, accompanied by his opinion as to compliance by the redevelopment corporation with section 17-41, with the city clerk and the commission. 
(e)  Rules and regulations: The commission shall have power to make and adopt the rules and regulations necessary and proper to effectuate the purposes of this article. 
(Ord. No. 3386, § 14, 8-13-90) 
Sec. 17-35. - Adoption of schedule of fees. 
    The commission may adopt a schedule of fees to be paid by the proponents of any development plan by filing its report on each development plan, any amendments thereto and other instruments in connection therewith, with the council. The amount of these fees shall not exceed the reasonable cost of the examination, inspection and supervisory services required under this article, and shall be subject to the approval of the council. 
(Ord. No. 3386, § 15, 8-13-90) 
Sec. 17-36. - Filing commission report; council action. 
(a)  The commission's report on each development plan shall be filed with the city clerk, along with a copy of the ordinance providing for the approval, disapproval or other action on such plan. If the ordinance provides for the approval of the plan, the council may, if it so desires, authorize the mayor to enter into a contract on behalf of the city with the proposer or proposers of the plan, such contract to contain the provisions embodied in the plan, the approving ordinance, a provision that the applicable provisions of this article shall be incorporated by reference into such contract, and a provision that the terms, conditions or provisions of the contract can be neither modified nor eliminated except by mutual agreement between the city and the proposer or proposers of the plan; provided, however, that no such contract shall be construed as an enlargement of the authority conferred upon the city by the Urban Redevelopment Law. The city clerk shall submit such ordinance, together with such report and plan, to the council at its next regular or special meeting thereafter. At such meeting, a date shall be set for a public hearing thereon. 
(b)  After a public hearing has been held upon the development plan, and after the commission has submitted its report thereon, the council shall: 
(1)  Unconditionally approve the plan; or 
(2)  Approve the plan subject to such conditions, exceptions or restrictions as the council may deem to be in the public interest; or 
(3)  Refer the plan to the commission with recommendations as to changes or amendments to be made therein; or 
(4)  Disapprove the plan. 
The council may, if it desires, in the case of subsection (b), paragraphs (1), (2) or (3) hereof, authorize the mayor on behalf of the city to enter into a contract with the proposer or proposers thereof. 
(Ord. No. 3386, § 16, 8-13-90) 
Sec. 17-37. - Findings and declarations of council. 
    In any ordinance approving a development plan, the council shall make the following findings and declarations: 
(1)  That the area included within a development plan is a blighted area, and that the clearance, redevelopment, replanning, rehabilitation or reconstruction thereof is necessary for the public convenience and necessity. 
(2)  That if a redevelopment corporation seeks to acquire all or any part of the real property within a blighted area by exercise of the power of eminent domain, such acquisition by the power of eminent domain is for the public convenience and necessity. 
(3)  That approval of the development plan and construction of the redevelopment project are necessary for the preservation of the public peace, property, health, safety, morals and welfare. 
(Ord. No. 3386, § 17, 8-13-90) 
Sec. 17-38. - Certificate of public convenience and necessity for corporation to acquire property by eminent domain. 
    If the redevelopment corporation proposing a development plan seeks to acquire by eminent domain in its own name all or any part of the real property described in the development plan, the council shall, by ordinance, determine that the public convenience and necessity will be served by the development plan and redevelopment project, and grant to such redevelopment corporation a certificate of public convenience and necessity authorizing and empowering the redevelopment corporation to acquire by the exercise of eminent domain such real property in fee simple or other estate; provided that such real property shall be devoted to the purposes and used subject to the conditions described in the development plan. Such redevelopment corporation may thereafter exercise the power of eminent domain in the manner provided by any other applicable statutory provision. Property already devoted to a public use may be acquired in like manner, provided that no real property belonging to the city or to the state or any political subdivision thereof may be acquired without its consent. 
(Ord. No. 3386, § 18, 8-13-90) 
Sec. 17-39. - Deposit when city acquires property for corporation. 
(a)  Amount. If the person or redevelopment corporation proposing a development plan seeks to have the city acquire by eminent domain or otherwise, and/or thereafter clear all or any part of the real property described in the development plan, such person or redevelopment corporation shall, at the time hereinafter provided, deposit in escrow with the city, subject to the provisions of this article or any ordinance, a sum of money in cash or negotiable federal or municipal securities of a cash market value equal to the cost estimated by the commission to be incurred by the city in acquiring, or, if the clearance thereof is also sought, in acquiring and clearing such real property, conditioned as hereafter provided that such deposit shall constitute a bid for such real property is offered for sale or lease by the city. Such bid shall equal the actual cost incurred by the city in acquiring or in acquiring and clearing such real property, and shall be applied as hereinafter provided. 
(b)  Return of deposit. If the person or redevelopment corporation making any such deposit is not the successful bidder for such real property, after it has been acquired or acquired and cleared by the city, then such deposit shall be returned by the city to the person or redevelopment corporation making such deposit. 
(c)  "Cost" defined. By the term "cost" as used in this section and section 17-40 is meant all expenditures by the city, including what is paid for such real property and the clearance thereof, appraisal, abstract, title and recording fees, court costs, witness fees, fees of the commission, and all other expenses of acquiring and clearing such property. 
(d)  Custody of securities. All securities deposited in escrow with the city shall be promptly placed in a safety deposit box under the joint control of the mayor and the city's treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 3386, § 19, 8-13-90) 
Sec. 17-40. - Acquisition, resale of property by city. 
(a)  Within ten (10) days after the council shall have approved any development plan calling for the acquisition by the city by the exercise of the power of eminent domain or otherwise of all or any part of the real property described therein, the person or redevelopment corporation submitting such plan shall deposit in escrow with the city the cash amounts or securities required by section 17-39. Thereafter the council shall determine by ordinance whether the real property described in such development plan constitutes a blighted area and should in the public interest be redeveloped, and the council may provide that the city acquire such property and procure the fee simple title thereto by purchase, by the exercise of the power of eminent domain, or by other means. The payment therefor by the city, in whole or in part, may be made out of the general funds of the city, or in whole or in part, by general obligation bonds or the proceeds of general obligation bonds. The city shall then proceed to acquire such real property in accordance with such ordinance. Whenever any real property, land, easement, right-of-way, use or right of any character is taken or damaged by the city for such purpose, just compensation shall be paid to the owner thereof in accordance with the ordinances and applicable state law. 
(b)  After acquiring the title to such real property, the city shall sell such real property and all interest therein for the purpose of redevelopment, as hereinafter provided, subject to such restrictions, exceptions and conditions as may be recommended by the commission, or which the council deems to be in the public interest. 
(c)  No bid shall be considered by the council unless the bidder shall have made the escrow deposit required in section 17-39 within the time required by this section. 
(d)  If there be but one qualified bidder, such real property shall be sold to such bidder at not less than the acquisition of such real property to the city. If there be more than one qualified bidder, such real property shall be sold to the highest and best bidder. If any profit on such sale is realized by the city, such profit shall be credited to the general fund. Each sale shall be approved by the council. The deposit of the successful bidder shall be applied upon the purchase price, and the city shall give due credit therefor. When such deposit is represented by securities, the city shall immediately sell the same at the current market price thereof at private sale for cash and apply the proceeds to the selling price of such real property. If such deposit should prove to be insufficient to equal the actual cost to the city of such real property, when such cost is determined after purchase, or by action of a condemnation jury, or otherwise, as the case may be, then such persons shall make an additional deposit with the city, upon ten (10) days' written notice from the mayor, of a sum of money in cash equal to such additional acquisition cost as so determined, and failing to make such additional deposit, the city may, at its option, thereupon repeal the ordinance providing for the acquisition of such real property and dismiss the pending condemnation proceedings, if any. In such last event, the expenses of such uncompleted acquisition and condemnation proceedings, if any, shall be charged to and paid by the person or redevelopment corporation so making such deposit and the amount thereof shall be withheld by the city from the funds or securities deposited in escrow, and applied to the payment of such expenses, and if more than one deposit has been made, then each person so making a deposit shall be charged equally for his share of such costs. The balance of such funds and securities so deposited in escrow shall then be returned to the owner thereof. Sale of such securities may be made only upon order of the council by resolution or ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 3386, § 20, 8-13-90) 
Sec. 17-41. - Financial restrictions on corporation. 
(a)  Obligations, interest thereon. No redevelopment corporation whose development plan has been approved by the council shall: 
(1)  Issue income debentures, bonds, notes or other evidences of debt bearing or paying an interest rate in excess of that permitted by state law. 
(2)  Pay any interest on its income debentures or dividends on its stock, regardless of class or preference, during any dividend year unless there shall exist at the time of such payment no default under any amortization requirements with respect to its indebtedness, nor unless all accrued interest, taxes and other public charges shall have been duly paid or reserves set up for the payment thereof, and adequate reserves provided for depreciation, obsolescence and other proper reserves. 
(b)  Net earnings. The net earnings of a redevelopment corporation whose development plan has been approved by the council shall be limited to an amount not to exceed eight (8) percent per annum of the cost to the redevelopment corporation of the redevelopment project including the cost of the land or the balance of the total cost of the project as reduced by any amortization payments; provided that the net earnings derived from any redevelopment project shall in no event exceed a sum equal to eight (8) percent per annum upon the entire cost thereof. Such net earnings shall be computed by deducting the following from gross earnings: 
(1)  All reasonable costs and expenses of maintenance and operation; and 
(2)  All amounts paid for taxes, assessments, insurance premiums and other similar charges; and 
(3)  An annual amount sufficient to amortize the cost of the entire project at the end of the period, which shall be not less than twenty (20) years nor more than sixty (60) years from date of completion of the redevelopment project. 
(Ord. No. 3386, § 21, 8-13-90) 
Sec. 17-42. - Disposition of surplus earnings of corporation. 
    The development plan may, upon approval of the council, contain provisions that the surplus earnings provided under section 17-41: 
(1)  May be held by the redevelopment corporation as a reserve for maintenance at such rate of return in the future and may be used by the redevelopment corporation to offset any deficiency in such rate of return which may have occurred in prior years; or 
(2)  May be used to accelerate the amortization payments; or 
(3)  May be used for the enlargement of the redevelopment project; or 
(4)  May be used for reduction in rentals therein; provided, that at the termination of the tax relief granted pursuant to section 17-46, the redevelopment corporation shall make a strict accounting of surplus earnings and shall turn over to the city any excess of such surplus earnings not previously used as provided in subsections (1), (2), (3) or (4) of this section. 
(Ord. No. 3386, § 22, 8-13-90) 
Sec. 17-43. - Insurance companies as redevelopment corporations. 
    Any life insurance company operating under this article shall be limited in its net earnings derived exclusively from the ownership and operation of any redevelopment project, constructed pursuant to a development plan, to an amount not to exceed eight (8) percent per annum upon any sums actually invested in or devoted to such redevelopment project after setting aside the reserves required by section 17-45; provided, however, that any surplus earnings in excess of such rate shall, in the discretion of the council, be held either: 
(1)  As a reserve for future eight (8) percent per annum returns upon its investments; or 
(2)  For use in the maintenance or enlargement of the redevelopment project; or 
(3)  For reduction in rentals charged tenants thereof. 
    In each case, such net earnings shall be computed according to standard accounting practices. 
(Ord. No. 3386, § 23, 8-13-90) 
Sec. 17-44. - Accounting practices. 
    Every redevelopment corporation operating under this article shall establish and maintain obsolescence and other reserves, and surplus and other accounts, including a reserve for the payment of taxes, according to recognized standard accounting practices. 
(Ord. No. 3386, § 24, 8-13-90) 
Sec. 17-45. - Powers of redevelopment corporations. 
(a)  Acquisition of property. A redevelopment corporation may acquire real property or secure options in its own name, or in the name of nominees, and it may acquire real property by gift, grant, lease, purchase or otherwise. 
(b)  Incumbrance of property. A redevelopment corporation may borrow funds and secure the repayment thereof by mortgage, which shall contain reasonable amortization provisions and shall be a lien upon no other real property except property forming the whole or a part of a single development area. Any mortgage on the real property in a development area, or any part thereof, may create a first lien, or a second or junior lien, upon such real property. 
(c)  Disposal of property. A redevelopment corporation may sell or otherwise dispose of any or all of the real property acquired by it for the purpose of a redevelopment project. The ordinance approving any development plan, and any contract entered into pursuant thereto, may provide that in the event of the sale or other disposition of real property of any redevelopment corporation by reason of the foreclosure on any mortgage or other lien through insolvency or bankruptcy proceedings, or by order of any court of competent jurisdiction, or by voluntary transfer or otherwise, the tax relief provided under section 17-46 of this article shall inure to any purchaser of such real property so long as such purchaser shall continue to use, operate and maintain such real property in accordance with the provisions of the development plan. If such ordinance and contract do not so provide and the purchaser of such real property shall continue to use, operate and maintain such real property in accordance with the provisions of the redevelopment plan, the council may grant the tax relief provided in section 17-46. If such real property shall be used for a purpose different than that described in the redevelopment plan, or if the purchaser does not desire the property to continue under the redevelopment plan, or if the ordinance approving the plan does not provide for continuing tax relief and the council shall refuse to grant the purchaser continuing tax relief, the real property shall be assessed for ad valorem taxes upon the full true value of the real property and may be owned and operated free from any of the conditions, restrictions or provisions of this article and the Urban Redevelopment Corporations Law. 
(Ord. No. 3386, § 25, 8-13-90) 
Sec. 17-46. - Tax relief for redevelopment corporations. 
(a)  Full exemption. The real property of a redevelopment corporation which is acquired pursuant to this article shall not be subject to assessment of payment of general and ad valorem taxes imposed by the city or by the state or any political subdivision thereof for a period of ten (10) years after the date upon which such redevelopment corporation became owner of such real property measured solely by the amount of the assessed valuation of the land, exclusive of improvements, acquired pursuant to this article and owned by such redevelopment corporation, as was determined by the assessor of Laclede County, for taxes due and payable thereon during the calendar year during which the redevelopment corporation acquired title to such real property; and the amounts of such tax assessments shall not be increased by the city or by the state or by any political subdivision thereof during such ten-year period so long as the real property is owned by a redevelopment corporation or its permitted successors and assigns and used in accordance with a development plan authorized by the council. 
(b)  Property already exempt. In the event, however, that any such real property was tax exempt immediately prior to ownership by any such redevelopment corporation, the commission shall immediately request such county assessor to promptly assess such land, exclusive of improvements, in accordance with the provisions of Section 110 of the Urban Redevelopment Corporations Law. The amount of such assessed valuation so fixed by the county assessor shall not be increased by the city or by the state or by any political subdivision thereof during the ten-year period next following the date upon which the corporation acquired ownership thereof, so long as such real property is owned by the redevelopment corporation and used in accordance with the development plan authorized and approved by the council. 
(c)  Partial exemption. For the next ensuring period of fifteen (15) years, all ad valorem taxes upon such real property shall be measured by the assessed valuation thereof as determined by the county assessor upon the basis of and not to exceed fifty (50) percent of the true value of such real property, including any improvements thereon, nor shall such valuations be increased over fifty (50) percent of the true value of such real property from year to year during the period of fifteen (15) years, so long as such real property is owned by a redevelopment corporation and used in accordance with an authorized development plan. Notwithstanding the provisions of the Missouri Redevelopment Corporation Law, the redevelopment corporation and the council may agree that such real property may be fully assessed for all or part of the term of partial exemption. 
(d)  Full assessment. After such periods, totaling twenty-five (25) years, such real property shall be subject to assessment by the city and payment of all ad valorem taxes based on the full true value of the real property, and shall be owned and operated by the redevelopment corporation free from the conditions, restrictions and provisions of this article, the approving ordinance and any rule or regulation adopted pursuant to this article; provided that at any time after the completion of the redevelopment project, as authorized by ordinance, the redevelopment corporation may elect to pay to the city a sum equivalent to the amount of the general ad valorem taxes, not including interest or penalties, which would have been levied on the full value of the property from the date of the completion of the project, and from that date such real property shall be owned and operated by the redevelopment corporation free from the conditions, restrictions and provisions of this article, the approving ordinance and any rule or regulation adopted pursuant to this article. 
(Ord. No. 3386, § 26, 8-13-90) 
Sec. 17-47. - Remedies for failure to follow plan. 
(a)  Proceedings. Whenever any person or redevelopment corporation operating under an approved development plan does not substantially comply with the development plan, or any contract entered into pursuant thereto, within the time limits and in the manner for the completion of each stage thereof as therein stated (reasonable delays caused by unforeseen circumstances beyond their control excepted) or shall do, permit to be done, or fail, or omit to do anything contrary to or required of it by this article, or shall be about so to do, permit to be done, or fail or omit to have done, then any such fact shall immediately be certified by the commission to the council, who may authorize the city attorney to commence a proceeding in the circuit court in the name of the city to have such action, failure or omission or threatened action or omission stopped, prevented or rectified by injunction or otherwise, or in the name of the city to bring an action for damages against the redevelopment corporation for breach of any of the provisions of the redevelopment plan; provided that in the event the commission determines that a redevelopment corporation has abandoned construction before completion of the project in accordance with the terms of an approved development plan and the council accepts such determination, a declaration of abandonment shall be filed with the recorder's office in Laclede County and the real property thereafter included in the plan shall be subject that date to assessment and payment of all ad valorem taxes based on the true full value of such real property. 
(b)  Exception. If any person or redevelopment corporation shall propose more than one redevelopment plan and such plans are approved as provided in this article, the failure to comply with one or more such plans within the time limits and in the manner for the completion of each stage thereof as therein stated shall not give the city any right of action with respect to plans which have been fully complied with within the limits and in the manner for the completion of each stage thereof as therein stated; and the real property included in such plans which have been fully complied with shall be entitled to the tax relief provided for in this article. 
(Ord. No. 3386, § 27, 8-13-90) 
Sec. 17-48. - Power of the cit to acquire, clear, develop, sell sites. 
    The city may: 
(1)  Acquire by the exercise of the power of eminent domain, or otherwise, an area designated as a redevelopment area; and 
(2)  Clear any such real property and install, construct and reconstruct streets, utilities and any and all other city improvements necessary for the preparation of such area for use in accordance with the provisions of this article and the Urban Redevelopment Corporations Law; and 
(3)  Sell such real property for use in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 3386, § 29, 8-13-90) 
Sec. 17-49. - Grants, loans from United States Government and the State of Missouri. 
    The city or any person or redevelopment corporation may accept grants or loans of money from the government of the United States or the State of Missouri or any department or agency thereof, to effectuate the purposes of this article. 
(Ord. No. 3386, § 30, 8-13-90) 
Secs. 17-50-17-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - HOUSING REHABILITATION GRANT GUIDELINES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3387, §§ 1-7, adopted August 27, 1990, did not specifically amend the Code; therefore, inclusion as Art. III, §§ 17-61-17-67, was at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 17-61. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of the rehabilitation program is to correct Code violations, overcrowded, or unsanitary conditions, to improve the housing and living environment for persons of low-to-moderate income levels living in the City of Lebanon, Missouri. 
(Ord. No. 3387, § 1, 8-27-90) 
Sec. 17-62. - Scope. 
(a)  This is a voluntary program. All interested persons must make application before any action can be taken. Applicants will not be discriminated against because of race, color, creed, politics or friendship. 
(b)  Applicants who qualify will be taken on a first-come, first-serve basis. Owner-occupied houses where the occupant is low-to-moderate income will be given first priority over renter-occupied houses. An emergency situation will receive priority as determined by the program manager and housing inspector. An appeal can be made to the mayor as to whether an emergency situation is present. 
(c)  After all owner-occupied houses are rehabbed, renter-occupied houses will be considered as follows: 
(1)  Rental houses owned by an LMI person and occupied by an LMI person and/or family will be given first priority. 
(2)  Rental houses owned by persons over income guidelines but occupied by a tenant meeting LMI guidelines will be eligible if the owner signs an agreement as follows: 
a.  The owner must pay one-fourth of the total cost of the improvements. 
b.  The owner must sign a rent freeze agreement between the city, tenant, and owner to be in effect for a period of three (3) years from the date of the agreement. 
c.  Sign a certificate of completion after work completed. 
(3)  Rents charged must be affordable to low-to-moderate income persons based upon the following Fair Market Rents which include an allowance of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for utilities. Rents must be documented with a rental agreement between the landlord and the tenant, receipts or cancelled checks for the previous six (6) months prior to July 1, 1990. Rents being charged as of February 1, 1990, will be the rent that must appear in the rent freeze agreement. 
(4)  The landlord cannot raise the rent because of the rehab work performed except an amount that is not in excess of the Consumer Price Index for one year. Any rents raised must be reported to the city. 
(5)  If the rent charged is over Fair Market Rents, the house will not be rehabbed until the landlord and the tenant have entered into a rent agreement showing the rent will be at or below Fair Market Rent. 
(d)  A complete house inspection will be made by the program housing inspector. A work write-up will be prepared, as well as a cost estimate. All decisions concerning repairs to be made to the structure will be made by the program manager with the right of appeal by the owner to the mayor. 
(e)  All items on the work write-up, as well as other pertinent information, will be discussed with the owner and construction crew. 
(Ord. No. 3387, § 2, 8-27-90) 
Fair Market Rents* 
1 BR 2 BR 3 BR 4 BR Lebanon $247.00 $290.00 $364.00 $407.00  
;adv05; 
Note: Add 15 percent per bedroom for units larger than four (4) bedrooms to the four-bedroom Fair Market Rents. 
;adv05; 
*All Fair Market Rents include utility allowances to be determined by each individual grantee. 
Sec. 17-63. - General objectives. 
(a)  The program is devised to conserve the city's present housing stock. 
(b)  Low-to-moderate income families, as hereinafter defined in section 17-64, will receive rehabilitation work. 
(c)  A quarterly review of the program shall be conducted to determine if changes or refinements are needed. 
(d)  City codes will be followed in all work performed and in the installation of all materials. 
(e)  All work will be done by a qualified construction crew employed by the City of Lebanon. 
(f)  The program will encompass the target area as outlined in the Community Development Application, as noted herein in section 17-64(e). 
(g)  The program manager shall be responsible for the making of all decisions as to the method used in rehabilitating the property with the right of appeal by the owner to the mayor. 
(h)  Competitive bids for materials shall be let on each house and the lowest responsible bidder selected, subject to the approval of the mayor. Minority suppliers may receive negotiated bids, if approved by the mayor. 
(i)  A final inspection of the work shall be made to ensure that it fulfills the terms of the grant and contract agreement. 
(j)  City council members, city employees, and city officers shall not be eligible for grant assistance, contract or subcontract for any work or materials, or have any personal interest, direct or indirect, in any contract under this project. 
(Ord. No. 3387, § 3, 8-27-90) 
Sec. 17-64. - Qualifications. 
(a)  Income limits for applicants. 
Number of Persons/Household Total Annual Gross Income 1 $13,150.00 2 $15,050.00 3 $16,900.00 4 $18,800.00 5 $20,000.00 6 $21,150.00 7 $22,350.00 8 plus $23,500.00  
(b)  The property to be rehabilitated must have been owned by the applicant prior to January 1, 1990. 
(c)  An owner-applicant must not have net assets in excess of thirty thousand dollars ($30,000.00), including equity in property. A renter-applicant must not have net assets in excess of fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00). 
(d)  The owner must have a recorded deed of ownership. A contract for deed properly executed shall not constitute ownership, but shall be considered a rental. The buyer and the seller will be required to make joint application and jointly execute the contract for rehabilitation work. The same applies to renter-applicant, both renter and owner shall be required to jointly apply and execute the contract. 
(e)  Only properties within the target area will be eligible for grant assistance. 
(f)  Properties rehabilitated cannot be sold for a period of three (3) years of completion of rehab work. The owner must sign a contract whereby they agree not to sell the property for a period of three (3) years. If property is sold because of the death of the owner this requirement is waived. If the property is sold for any other reasons, other than death, the total cost of the rehab work must be repaid to the city. This section includes both owner-occupied and renter-occupied properties. 
(g)  Property owners may be paid for material and labor costs, if approved by the housing inspector and program manager, but the property owner cannot be paid for their own labor. 
(h)  No appliances can be purchased other than stove, refrigerator, hot water heater or space heating equipment. This will be solely the decision of the housing inspector and program manager. 
(i)  Premises must be free from rubbish and debris before an applicant will be approved for rehab as instructed by the housing inspector. 
(Ord. No. 3387, § 4, 8-27-90) 
Sec. 17-65. - Application for assistance. 
    Persons wanting to make application for rehab funds must do the following: 
(1)  Fill out an application with the program manager. 
(2)  Submit recorded deed to property. 
(3)  Submit income verification. An income tax return for the year prior to the start of rehab work will be acceptable, or payroll receipts for a period of twelve (12) months preceding the rehab work. 
(Ord. No. 3387, § 5, 8-27-90) 
Sec. 17-66. - Grant amount. 
    The amount of any approved grant will be the total cost of the rehabilitation, not to exceed the sum of seven thousand eight hundred dollars ($7,800.00). In cases where a work write-up exceeds seven thousand eight hundred dollars ($7,800.00), the housing inspector, program manager and mayor will make the decision of whether the work will be performed on the house. 
(Ord. No. 3387, § 6, 8-27-90) 
Sec. 17-67. - Repayment. 
    Recipients do not repay grants, unless a violation of this article, establishing the guidelines, occurs. 
(Ord. No. 3387, § 7, 8-27-90)

ARTICLE II. - POLICE DEPARTMENT[2] 

Footnotes:

Sec. 18-16. - Appointing authority defined. 
    The appointing authority under this division is the mayor with the advice and consent of the city council. 
(Code 1967, § 2-25) 
Sec. 18-17. - Established; commanding officer to be chief of police. 
    A police department for the city is established and the commanding officer thereof shall be the chief of police, who shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of a majority of the members of the city council. The police department shall not be a merit system police department. 
(Code 1967, § 2-26; Ord. No. 3208, §§ 1, 2, 12-9-85) 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to appoint all officers except mayor and councilmen, RSMo 77.370(5).

Chapter 19 - SECONDHAND GOODS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 19-1-19-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PAWNBROKERS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Police, Ch. 18. 
State Law reference- Pawnbrokers, RSMo Ch. 367. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 19-16. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
    Pawnbroker shall mean any person that loans money on goods, wares, articles or merchandise pledged in return therefor. 
    Personal property shall mean and include all tangible personal property of every type and nature including, but not limited to, antiques, junk, secondhand articles, television sets, stereo equipment, radios, gold, silver, platinum, gems jewelry, precious and semiprecious stones, guns, sporting equipment, fishing equipment, hunting equipment, tools, automotive equipment, bicycles, furniture, appliances, and all and any other tangible personal property of every type and nature. 
(Ord. No. 3133, §§ 1, 9, 9-26-83) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 19-17. - Administrative liability. 
    No officer, agent or employee of the city shall render himself personally liable for any damage of whatever nature that may accrue to any person or property as a result of any act required or permitted in the discharge of his duties under this article. 
(Ord. No. 3133, § 17, 9-26-83) 
Sec. 19-18. - Interpretation. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed or interpreted as creating or establishing any business license fees. 
(Ord. No. 3133, § 20, 9-26-83) 
Sec. 19-19. - Violations; penalty for failure to comply. 
(a)  The owner and their agents and employees, who shall operate any pawnbroking business in the city without a license under this article shall be guilty of an offense and punished as provided in section 1-12. Proof of willful or intentional noncompliance shall not be necessary for conviction under this subsection and the person shall be guilty upon proof of failure of compliance. 
(b)  The owner and their agents and employees who shall fail to comply with any provisional or final order of the chief of police, or his delegate, as provided in this article, shall be guilty of an offense and upon conviction thereof shall be punished in section 1-12. Proof of willful or intentional noncompliance shall not be necessary for conviction under this subsection and the person shall be guilty upon proof of failure of compliance. 
(c)  Any owner or his agent or employees who shall be found to have willfully or intentionally violated the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of an offense and upon conviction thereof shall be punished as provided in section 1-12. Proof of delivery to the person affected, of a copy of this article and a notice of the order for compliance or a notice of noncompliance of the article shall establish a rebuttable presumption of the willful and intentional nature of the action or inaction of the person who actually receives the copy of the article and notice. 
(d)  Any person who removes, destroys or obliterates any notice provided for in this article shall be guilty of an offense and upon conviction thereof shall be punished as provided in section 1-12. 
(e)  Any person who shall interfere with, hinder or refuse to allow the chief of police or his delegate, or any of the police officers of the city to enter upon the business premises of a pawnbroking operation for the purpose of inspection, enforcement or carrying out any of the provisions of this article shall be guilty of an offense and upon conviction thereof shall be punished as provided in section 1-12. 
(f)  The city attorney shall institute prosecutions for violations of this article by filing an information of such violation in the municipal court. This remedy shall be in addition to and not in lieu of any and all other remedies available to the city for violations of this article. 
(Ord. No. 3133, § 16, 9-26-83) 
Secs. 19-20-19-30. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 19-31. - Required. 
    All pawnbrokers shall apply for and obtain a license to carry on business as a pawnbroker within the city limits. It shall be unlawful for any pawnbroker to carry on or transact any business or advertise for such business without a license. 
(Ord. No. 3133, § 2, 9-26-83) 
Sec. 19-32. - Chief of police to act as license officer. 
    The chief of police, or some officer of the police department of the city designed by the chief of police, shall act as license officer in the issuance of all pawnbroker licenses. The chief of police, or his delegate as provided, shall: 
(1)  Make and enforce all reasonable rules and regulations necessary to the operation and enforcement of this article; 
(2)  Adopt all forms and prescribe the information to be given therein for all necessary papers; 
(3)  Require applicants to submit all affidavits and oaths necessary to the administration of this article; 
(4)  Submit all applications eligible for approval to the mayor and city clerk for issuance of the license; 
(5)  Investigate and determine the eligibility of any applicant for a license as provided in this division; 
(6)  Examine the books and records of any applicant or licensee when necessary to the enforcement of this article; 
(7)  Notify an applicant of the acceptance or rejection of his application within ten (10) days from the date the written application containing all required information is presented by the applicant and shall, upon the refusal of any application, at the applicant's request, state in writing the reason or reasons therefor; and 
(8)  Maintain all information furnished by any applicant in confidence so that such information shall not be a matter of public record but shall be subject only to the official use of the persons charged with the administration of this article and with the enforcement of the laws of the state. 
(Ord. No. 3133, § 3, 9-26-83) 
Sec. 19-33. - Qualifications of applicants. 
    The chief of police, or his designee shall determine that each applicant for a license to do business in the city as a pawnbroker meet the following requirements: 
(1)  The applicant must be a person of good moral character. In making the determination of this qualification, the chief of police or his delegate shall consider: 
a.  All convictions of criminal offenses, the underlying reason therefor and the conduct of the applicant subsequent to his conviction; 
b.  The license history of the applicant, whether such person, in previously operating as a pawnbroker in this or any other state under a license has had such license revoked or suspended, the reasons therefor, and the conduct of the applicant since such action; and 
c.  The other facts relevant to the general personal history of the applicant as shall be appropriate to a fair determination of the eligibility of the applicant; 
(2)  The applicant must not be indebted to the city in any way other than for current utilities or current taxes; 
(3)  The applicant must have a proposed place of business located within the city; and 
(4)  The applicant must comply with all zoning use regulations, rules and ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 3133, § 4, 9-26-83) 
Sec. 19-34. - Issuance. 
    Every person applying for a license to do business in the city as a pawnbroker shall do the following: 
(1)  Submit an application to the chief of police or his designee, such application to be a written statement upon forms provided by the chief of police or his designee, such form to contain an affidavit to be sworn to by the applicant before a notary public of this state; 
(2)  Disclose the information required by section 19-32 and such additional information as shall be reasonably necessary for the fair administration of this article; and 
(3)  No fee shall be required to be paid to the city by the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 3133, § 5, 9-26-83) 
Sec. 19-35. - Contents. 
    Each license issued under this division shall state upon its face the following: 
(1)  The name of the licensee and any name under which such business is to be conducted; 
(2)  The address of the location of the business; 
(3)  The date of issuance of such license; and 
(4)  Such other information as the chief of police or his delegate shall determine. 
(Ord. No. 3133, § 7, 9-26-83) 
Sec. 19-36. - Denial. 
    When the issuance of the license is denied and any action is instituted by the applicant to compel its issuance, such applicant shall not engage in the business of pawnbroker unless or until a license is ordered issued to such applicant pursuant to a final judgment. 
(Ord. No. 3133, § 6, 9-26-83) 
Secs. 19-37-19-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - REGULATORY PROVISIONS 

Sec. 19-51. - Duties of pawnbrokers-Generally. 
    Every pawnbroker shall permit all reasonable inspection of his business and records by the authorities so authorized by law, avoid all forbidden, improper or unlawful practices or transactions, refrain from operating the business of pawnbroking without a license as required by this article and refrain from operating the business of pawnbroking after revocation or suspension of his license. 
(Ord. No. 3133, § 11, 9-26-83) 
Sec. 19-52. - Posting license required. 
    Every pawnbroker licensed under this article shall post and display the license upon the licensed premises in a place where it may be seen at all times. 
(Ord. No. 3133, § 8A, 9-26-83) 
Sec. 19-53. - Retention of certain property for ten days. 
    Every pawnbroker licensed under this article shall keep and maintain within the city for a period of ten (10) days from the date of receipt of such personal property any and all gold, silver, diamonds or other precious or semiprecious gems, metals, jewelry or coins nor shall any such items be reconstructed, reconstituted, melted or recut within such time period. This provision shall not prohibit the redemption of any such item by the proper owner thereof before the expiration of such period of time. 
(Ord. No. 3133, § 10, 9-26-83) 
Sec. 19-54. - Employment of felons prohibited. 
    No pawnbroker shall hire or employ as an employee or agent any person who shall have been convicted of any felony within the past four (4) years. 
(Ord. No. 3133, § 12, 9-26-83) 
Sec. 19-55. - Records required. 
(a)  Every pawnbroker licensed under this article shall keep and maintain a substantial and well-bound book in which the pawnbroker shall enter, legibly with ink or other permanent marking, a full, accurate and complete description of all personal property purchased, bartered, traded, pledged, loaned or otherwise acquired by the pawnbroker by whatever means, including any identifying number or letters that may be on such personal property. If any of such personal property contains in whole or part a precious gem or metal and such property is difficult to describe, such property shall be photographed and the photograph shall be attached to the record book together with the other data required to be kept with such item. As to each item of personal property acquired by the pawnbroker by whatever means, in addition to the description and photograph of the property, the following information shall be required to be recorded in the book maintained by the pawnbroker: 
(1)  The name, address, date of birth, general description of the person from whom the item of personal property is obtained; 
(2)  The license number of that person's valid motor vehicle driver's license together with the state of issuance of such license and the expiration date thereof; provided, however, that if such person cannot produce such valid motor vehicle drivers license or such license has expired, the pawnbroker shall cause a photograph to be taken of such person from whom such item of personal property is acquired, which photograph shall be attached to the record book together with the other information required; and 
(3)  The amount of money loaned to or paid to or the property traded to or other compensation paid or delivered to the person from whom the item of personal property is acquired. 
(b)  Keep and maintain the records as provided in subsection (a) in such a manner as to not allow them to become defaced, spoiled, erased, lost or misplaced. 
(c)  Keep and maintain the records as provided in subsection (a) above open to any police officer of the city together with the item or article or items or articles acquired provided that the same shall be in the possession of the pawnbroker. 
(Ord. No. 3133, § 8B-D, 9-26-83) 
Sec. 19-56. - Failure to comply with article declared a nuisance; injunction. 
    The maintenance or operation of any pawnbroking business in the city in violation of any provision of this article is hereby declared to endanger the citizens of the city in the comfort and enjoyment of their lives, limbs, health, property and tranquility and is declared to be a nuisance. In addition to all other remedies available to the city, whenever any pawnbroking business in the city is maintained or operated in violation of any provision of this article, the city shall have the right to abate such noncompliance by a temporary or permanent injunction by a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 3133, § 15, 9-26-83) 
Cross reference- Nuisances, Ch. 13. 
Secs. 19-57-19-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2. 

Sec. 19-71. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Inspections. The chief of police or his designee is hereby authorized and empowered to order the inspection of any and all licensed pawnbrokers, their records, business premises and any and all items of personal property therein. 
(b)  Persons authorized to inspect. All police officers of the city shall have the authority to inspect and examine records of licensed pawnbrokers as directed and ordered by the chief of police or his designee. 
(c)  Authority of inspectors. All police officers directed to inspect licensed pawnbrokers shall have the authority to enter, without a search warrant, at all reasonable times, the business premises of a pawnbroker who holds a valid license, the business premises of a pawnbroker who is required to be licensed under this article and who does not hold a current license, and the business premises of a pawnbroker for which the license has been revoked or suspended. 
(d)  Authority of inspectors to confiscate stolen property. All police officers inspecting the business premises of any pawnbroker shall have the authority and right to take possession of, confiscate and remove from the premises any stolen property which the police officer shall discover during his inspection. 
(e)  Reports by inspectors. Police officers inspecting licensed pawnbrokers which should be licensed under this article shall report all and any violations of this article or of other laws, sections of this Code or other ordinances to the chief of police or his designee and submit such other reports as the chief of police or his delegate shall order. 
(f)  Provisional order. When any violation of this article has been reported to the chief of police or his delegate, the chief of police shall issue to the affected person a provisional order to comply. 
(g)  Notice of provisional order. The provisional order, and all other notices issued in compliance with this article, shall be in writing, shall be personally served and shall apprise the person affected of the specific violations. In the absence of the person affected, the notice shall be served on his agent or employee. In the absence of the person affected or his agent or employee, a copy of such notice shall be affixed to some structure on the premises and a separate copy of such notice shall be mailed to the business address of the affected person, if known. 
(h)  Period for compliance with provisional order. The provisional order shall require compliance within not less than ten (10) and not more than twenty (20) days after delivery of the notice as required in subsection (f). 
(i)  Application for hearing. Upon written application by the person affected or his agent or employee before the expiration of the time set for compliance as provided in subsection (h), the chief of police or his delegate shall order a hearing Notice of the hearing shall be given to the person affected as provided in subsection (g). 
(j)  Hearing. Upon the written application by the person affected or upon his own motion, the chief of police shall have the authority to extend the time for compliance, to grant a new hearing date and to change, modify or rescind any provisional order. If, after hearing, any compliance is ordered to be undertaken by the person affected he shall have two (2) days additional time to comply with the order entered at the hearing. 
(k)  Final order. If the person affected does not request a hearing, the provisional order becomes a final order at the expiration of the time set in such order for compliance and the person affected shall comply immediately with the order within the time originally set for compliance. Any order made after hearing shall be a final order. 
(l)  Suspension or revocation of license upon failure to comply with final order. The chief of police or his designee shall order an inspection to be made after the time for compliance with the final order has passed and if the person affected refuses to allow inspection of his business premises or records or if the person affected has failed or refused to comply with the final order, the chief of police or his delegate shall report the refusal to allow inspection or the failure or refusal to comply with the final order to the board of pawnbrokers licensing appeals, as established in section 19-72. The board of pawnbrokers licensing appeals shall have the authority to suspend or revoke the license of the person affected for failure or refusal to comply with the final order or for refusal to allow inspection. 
(m)  Term of suspension of license. If the board of pawnbrokers licensing appeals shall suspend the license of any pawnbroker the suspension shall be for a period of time not less than ten (10) days nor more than thirty (30) days. 
(n)  Term of revocation of license. If the board of pawnbrokers licensing appeals shall revoke the license of any pawnbroker, the revocation shall not be limited by any period of time, but shall be for an indefinite time. 
(o)  Effect of suspension or revocation of license. Upon the suspension or revocation of the license of any pawnbroker, the pawnbroker shall immediately cease all business at any and all places under such license. 
(p)  Effect of repeated violations. When considering the suspension or revocation of the license of the pawnbroker, the Board of Pawnbrokers Licensing Appeals shall take into consideration all past violations of the provisions of this chapter. 
(q)  Right of appeal. Any person aggrieved by any decision of the board of pawnbrokers licensing appeals, after hearing, shall have the right to appeal to the circuit court of appropriate jurisdiction as provided by RSMo Ch. 536. 
(Ord. No. 3133, § 13, 9-26-83) 
Sec. 19-72. - Board of pawnbrokers licensing appeals. 
(a)  Established; membership. There is hereby created a board of pawnbrokers licensing appeals. The board shall consist of the same persons who shall constitute the members of the city's police board. 
(b)  Officers. The board of pawnbrokers licensing appeals shall appoint a chairman and a secretary. The secretary need not be a member of the board. In the absence of the chairman, the board may appoint an acting chairman. 
(c)  Regular meetings; minutes. Meetings of the board of pawnbrokers licensing appeals shall be called by the chairman or acting chairman. The chairman, or in his absence, the acting chairman, shall have the power to administer oaths, compel attendance of witnesses and require production of records and documents. All meetings of the board shall be open to the public and all business of the board shall be conducted at such meeting. The board shall keep minutes of its proceedings, hearings and other official actions, which shall include the vote or failure to vote of the members present, which minutes shall be promptly filed in the office of the city clerk as a public record. 
(d)  Closed meetings. The board of pawnbrokers licensing appeals shall have the right to have a closed meeting after a hearing for the purpose of deliberation among its members and before rendering its decisions. The decision of the board, together with the record of each member's vote or abstinence if not voting, shall be open to the public. For purposes of this article, the hearing and determination by the board shall be deemed a meeting pertaining to a legal action as provided in RSMo 610.025.2 and the term "closed meeting" shall mean a meeting closed to the public and the parties and their attorneys. 
(e)  Appeal of decisions of board. An appeal to the circuit court of the appropriate jurisdiction from any decision of the board of pawnbrokers licensing appeals shall not automatically stay the proceedings or effect of any final order against a pawnbroker. The board shall give notice of the date, time and place of the hearing to the parties not less than ten (10) days before the hearing. The board shall have the power to continue the time of the hearing for good cause or upon the agreement of the parties. The board shall render its decision within a reasonable time after the hearing has been concluded. The board may make rulings regarding and limiting the production of evidence on such hearings. 
(f)  Notice of decisions of board. Notice of the decisions of the board of appeals may be given by ordinary mail or served in person to the parties or to the attorneys of record of the parties. 
(Ord. No. 3133, § 14, 9-26-83) 
Cross reference- Boards, commissions and committees, § 2-251 et seq. 
Chapter 20 - SIGNS AND ADVERTISING[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 3552, adopted April 11, 1994, repealed §§ 20-1 and 20-2. Formerly, § 20-1 pertained to placement of signs on utility poles and derived from § 17-2 of the 1967 Code; § 20-2 pertained to placement of handbills on motor vehicles and derived from § 1 of Ord. No. 1887, adopted March 26, 1973. Section 1 of Ord. No. 3552 provided further for the addition of §§ 20-1-20-6 as set out herein. 
Cross reference- Use of loud speakers for advertising regulated, § 14-98(b)(3); garage sale signs, § 14-207 et seq. 

Sec. 20-1. - Title. 
    This chapter shall hereinafter be known and cited as the "Sign and Advertising Regulations." 
(Ord. No. 3552, § 1, 4-11-94) 
Sec. 20-2. - General sign provisions. 
    The provisions of this section shall apply to all signs in the city. 
(1)  Prohibited signs. The following signs are prohibited, which: 
a.  Concern unlawful activity; 
b.  May be confused with or construed as a traffic control sign, signal, or device, or the light of an emergency or road equipment vehicle by reason of their size, location, movement, content, coloring, or manner of illumination; 
c.  Hide from the view of those to whom the device is directed, any traffic or street sign or signal or similar device; 
d.  Is located in such manner as to obstruct or otherwise physically interfere with the effectiveness of an official traffic sign, signal or device or obstruct or physically interfere with a motor vehicle operator's view of approaching, merging, or intersecting traffic. 
(2)  Sign illumination. Illuminated signs shall be designed, located, and constructed to eliminate or significantly reduce glare and shall not increase the lighting intensity upon adjoining premises not under the same ownership and control. 
(3)  Sign condition. No person shall maintain or allow to be maintained on any premises owned or controlled by that person any dangerous or defective sign. All signs, together with all their supports, braces, connections, or anchors shall be kept in good repair. Unsafe signs, damaged, or deteriorated signs, or signs in danger of breaking apart or falling shall be removed or repaired by their owner. Any fading, chipping, peeling, or flaking of paint, plastic, or glass, or any mechanical, electrical, or structural defect shall be corrected upon written notice by the building and zoning administrator. 
(4)  Compliance with building codes. All signs shall be erected or affixed and maintained in compliance with the building codes. 
(5)  Signs at street/street and street/driveway intersections. Signs may be erected in the street/street or street/driveway intersection sight triangles; however, any sign must be a permanent, detached sign at least six (6) feet above street grade except for supports, which may not exceed eighteen (18) inches in width or diameter, or be spaced less than ten (10) feet apart from any other stationary object; the street sight triangle is hereby defined as the area included within a triangle along the curb or right-of-way from the intersection of each street as projected twenty-five (25) feet to the left and twenty-five (25) to the rear as one faces the intersection from each street or driveway that makes up the intersection, together with an imaginary line from one end of the twenty-five-foot point to the other. A larger sight triangle area may be required by the building and zoning administrator for clear sight if special conditions require the same. Notwithstanding the foregoing, in the event any sign otherwise permitted in subsection (5) or in subsection (6) below, obstructs clear sight due to special conditions by reason of the lay of the land or other reasons, the building and zoning administrator may require the sign to be at a different height than that set forth in the aforesaid subsections or if the adjustment of the height does not permit clear sight, prohibit the sign altogether. The provisions of this subparagraph shall not apply in the C-2 District. 
(6)  Signs located in setback areas. Permanent, detached signs shall be allowed outside the street sight triangle in all commercial and industrial zones within the twenty-five-foot setback zone, however, any sign within twelve and one-half (121/2) feet of the property line must be no more than three (3) feet above street grade and/or at least six (6) feet above street grade except for supports, which may not exceed eighteen (18) inches in width or diameter, or be spaced less than ten (10) feet apart from any other stationary object. No temporary signs, also known as portable signs, shall be allowed within the setback area in any zone. 
(7)  Exempt signs. The following signs shall not require the issuance of a sign permit, but must be in conformance with all other sign regulations and the building code. These signs are allowed in addition to all other signs allowed under this chapter. 
a.  Address numbers and name plates. Address numbers for each residential building and building address numbers not exceeding one square foot in effective area per character, and one name plate not exceeding two (2) square feet in effective area per dwelling unit or business. All address numbers and name plates shall be attached signs, except as follows: 
1.  They may be attached to a mailbox or curb if they do not increase the size of the surface area or alter the shape of the mailbox or curb; and 
2.  If a building is more than one hundred (100) feet from the street, its address numbers may be detached. 
b.  Residential subdivision signs. Residential subdivision signs which display the name of the subdivision may be located in the city street right-of-way so long as the signs do not interfere with traffic flow, create a traffic hazard or interfere with the clear sight of pedestrians, cyclists or motorists who are traveling on the right-of-way. In the case of subdivisions developed after the date of the adoption of this subsection, the preliminary plat shall show the proposed size and location of the subdivision sign and the width of the street right-of-way shall be widened to accommodate the space used for the sign. 
c.  Real estate sale, lease and construction signs. Detached or attached nonilluminated temporary on-premise signs pertaining to the construction, sale, or lease, of that premise, not to exceed thirty-four (34) square feet in effective area in commercial or industrial areas, and not to exceed sixteen (16) square feet in effective area in residential areas. In all areas, such signs shall be located outside the street sight triangle and may have up to thirty-four (34) square feet in effective area if the premises on which they are located either has at least two hundred fifty (250) feet of frontage or contains more than five (5) acres. Such signs shall be removed within fourteen (14) days after the closing of the sale or lease or within thirty (30) days after the issuance of an occupancy permit or erection of a permanent sign, whichever occurs first. 
(8)  Legal nonconforming signs. 
a.  Any sign outside the street sight triangle referred to in section 20-2(5) which was, except for the issuance of a permit, lawfully erected or affixed prior to such time as it came within the purview of this chapter, and which sign complied with all regulations in force at the time it was erected or affixed, but which fails to conform to all applicable regulations and restrictions of this chapter, shall be considered a legal nonconforming sign which may be maintained, however, the sign owner shall apply for and obtain a permit as provided in section 20-3 and the sign shall not be: 
1.  Structurally altered (except to meet safety requirements) so as to prolong the life of the sign. The type of materials used in the construction of the sign shall not be changed after the date the sign becomes a nonconforming sign; 
2.  Altered so as to increase the degree of nonconformity of the sign; 
3.  Expanded in size or effective area; 
4.  Relocated, or repaired by expenditure of more than seventy-five (75) percent of the depreciated value of the sign in place for materials and labor for repair of any deteriorated or damaged nonconforming sign in any continuous twelve-month period. Upon written request, the sign owner must submit to the building and zoning administrator specified substantiating information or documentation sufficient for the administrator to determine the percentage of value expended for repair; 
5.  Abandoned or discontinue. Abandonment or discontinuance occurs whenever: 
(i)  The sign for a continuous period of twelve (12) months or more advertises services or products no longer available to the traveling public because the services or products have been discontinued or cannot be obtained at the destination or by the directions indicated on the sign; or 
(ii)  The sign for a continuous period of twelve (12) months or longer is maintained without an advertising message. The following signs are signs maintained without an advertising message: A sign with a message which is partially obliterated so as to not to identify a particular service or product; a sign which is blank or painted out; or a sign with a message consisting solely of the name of the sign owner on any part of the sign. 
b.  Any sign within the street sight triangle that was erected prior to the effective date of this chapter that does not conform to the provisions of section 20-2(5) and physically interferes with a motor vehicle operator's view of approaching, merging, or intersecting traffic, shall be subject to removal within the time provided in section 20-4(a). 
c.  Any temporary signs within the setback area defined in section 20-2(6) shall be subject to removal within the time provided in section 20-4(a). 
(Ord. No. 3552, § 1, 4-11-94; Ord. No. 3709, § 21, 5-28-96) 
Sec. 20-3. - Sign permits and inspection. 
(a)  Permits required. Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, it shall be unlawful for any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company, or organization of any kind to erect, improve, repair, alter, relocate, or maintain any sign without first obtaining a sign permit from the building and zoning administrator. For the purpose of this chapter, a sign is defined as a billboard, ground sign, wall sign, temporary sign, message board, changeable copy board, or any other structure principally designed to convey a message. 
(b)  Application for permit. Application for a permit shall be made to the building and zoning administrator upon a form provided by the administrator, and shall be accompanied by such information as may be required to insure compliance with all appropriate laws and regulations of the city and state, including, but not limited to: 
(1)  Name, address, and business license number of permit applicant. 
(2)  Name and address of owner of sign. 
(3)  Name and address of the owner and occupant of the premises where the sign is located or to be located. 
(4)  A site plan, which complies with the provisions of section 6-6, and also consists of clear and legible drawings with a description showing the precise location of the sign which is the subject of the permit and all other existing signs on the same premise or as otherwise specified by the administrator. 
(5)  Drawings showing the dimensions, construction supports, sizes, materials of the sign, and method of attachment and character of the structural members to which attachment is to be made. 
(6)  All signs over twenty (20) feet in height shall require a set of plans prepared by a professional engineer and/or architect, and shall comply with all certification requirements set forth in section 6-6 of the Lebanon Code, which must be followed to obtain a building permit. 
(7)  In the event a sign is to be erected and/or maintained on property where improvements are to be constructed, altered, repaired, or removed, the application for sign permit shall accompany the application for permit required pursuant to the provisions of section 9B(2), Appendix A, Zoning, and the location of any proposed or existing sign or signs shall be shown on the required site plan. 
(c)  Denial or revocation. The building and zoning administrator may, in writing, suspend, deny, or revoke a permit issued under provisions of this section whenever the permit is issued on the basis of a misstatement of fact, fraud, or noncompliance with this chapter. 
    When a sign permit is denied by the building and zoning administrator, he shall give written notice of the denial to the applicant, together with a brief written statement of the reason for the denial. Such denials shall have referenced the section of the sign ordinance, or other pertinent code used as a standard for the basis of denial. 
(Ord. No. 3552, § 1, 4-11-94) 
Sec. 20-4. - Enforcement, abatement and penalty. 
(a)  Removal of signs and abatement of violations. Whenever the building and zoning administrator or the code enforcement official identifies, receives a complaint or is otherwise informed and believes that any sign is illegal or endangers the public safety such as an abandoned, dangerous, or materially, electrically, or structurally defective sign or a sign for which no permit has been issued, the code enforcement official shall notify the owner, occupant and person in possession, (if the same is a person different than the owner), of the property that a hearing before the hearing officer shall be held in the council chambers at city hall ten (10) days after notice of the same is personally delivered, mailed or posted as provided below at which hearing, the hearing officer may declare that a violation of this chapter exists and order that the sign be removed or the violation corrected within five (5) days after the hearing. If the sign or the condition constituting the violation is on private property, proof that a person occupies the property or that a person has possession or right of possession of the property shall constitute prima facie evidence for purposes of this chapter that such person has caused, maintained or permitted the violation; and such person and the owner, if different from the occupant or person in possession, shall be responsible for the removal of the sign or correction of the violation. 
    Such notification may be made by any one (1) of the following methods: 
(1)  Delivery of the notice to the owner and the person occupying or having possession of the property if different than the owner; or 
(2)  Depositing in the United States mail, postage prepaid, the notice addressed to the owner and the person occupying or having possession or the right to possession of the property if different than the owner; or 
(3)  If such property is not occupied, the code enforcement official shall notify the owners by posting a notice of his request to abate or remove such violation within a time to be specified in such notice upon such property and shall send a copy of such notice by registered mail to the last known address of the owners; or 
(4)  If such property is not occupied and the owner is unknown or cannot be located, the code enforcement official shall post a notice containing an order to abate the violation on the property where such violation exists; or 
(5)  By delivery of a notice or by depositing in the United States mail, postage prepaid, a notice to the person causing, maintaining or permitting a violation. 
(b)  Order to abate. If, upon a hearing for the violation of this chapter, the hearing officer finds that a violation exists and that proper notice has been given as provided for in this article, and that there has been a failure to remove the sign or correct the violation, the hearing officer shall make an order directing the code enforcement official to remove the sign or correct the violation forthwith. 
(c)  Abatement by city upon failure of owner, occupant or person in possession to comply. If an order to remove the sign or correct the violation is issued as provided above in the previous subsection and the corrective action has not occurred within five (5) days from the date of the order, then the code enforcement official shall effect the corrective action by whatever reasonable means are necessary. 
(d)  Liability for costs; lien. The cost for sign removal or corrective action shall be computed by the code enforcement official, who shall certify all costs of the same to the city clerk who shall cause a special tax bill therefor to be prepared and issued against the real estate involved and to cause the same to be collected by the collector of the County of Laclede, together with other taxes assessed against the said property; each special tax bill shall be issued by the city clerk and delivered to the Collector on or before the first day of June of each year and such tax bills shall bear interest at the rate of eight (8) percent per annum pursuant to the provisions of Section 71.285, R.S.Mo. Said tax bill shall be a first lien on the said real estate until paid and shall be prima facie evidence of the recitals therein and of its validity and no mere clerical error or informality in the same or in the proceedings leading up the issuance shall be a defense thereto. 
(Ord. No. 3806, § 1, 8-25-97) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3806, § 1, adopted Aug. 25, 1997, repealed §§ 20-4-20-6 of the code, and enacted provisions as new §§ 20-4-20-10 to read as herein set out. Former §§ 20-4-20-6, pertained to enforcement and penalty, placement of signs on utility poles, and placement of handbills on motor vehicles, respectively, and derived from Ord. No. 3552, § 1, adopted April 11, 1994. 
Sec. 20-5. - Additional remedies for abatement of violation. 
(a)  Warrants issued by municipal court. The judge of the municipal court, upon application of the city attorney or the code enforcement official and upon a showing that there is probable cause to believe that a violation of any provision of this chapter exists, and that said violation constitutes a threat to public health, welfare or safety and that there is probable cause to believe that evidence of such violation may be found at a specified location, may issue a warrant, which shall be served by the code enforcement official. If the code enforcement official is not a police officer, he shall serve the warrant in the company of a uniformed officer of the city police department. The warrant shall specify what, if any, corrective action may be taken. 
(b)  Injunctive powers. In addition to the penalties set forth in this chapter, the code enforcement official is hereby authorized to file and obtain injunctions on behalf of the city against persons who are violating provisions of this chapter. In the event the city seeks injunctive relief from the circuit court for violations of this chapter, penalty provisions set forth in this chapter shall not apply. The city council finds and declares that the remedies set forth in this chapter may be inadequate to protect the public health, safety and welfare from violations which are continuous or violations that are repeated. 
(Ord. No. 3806, § 1, 8-25-97) 
Note- See editor's note following § 20-4. 
Sec. 20-6. - Assessment of court costs upon finding of violation. 
    Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, if, upon a trial for the violation of this article, the judge of the municipal court shall find that a violation exists and that the defendant has had proper notice, as provided in this chapter, and that the defendant has failed to abate the violation, the judge of the municipal court shall have the right, in addition to the penalty for violating this chapter, to enter an order directing the code enforcement official to abate such violation forthwith, and immediately report the expense thereof to the judge of the municipal court, who shall, as a part of the costs of such prosecution, render judgment against the defendant for the amount of such expense, which shall be collected as other fines and costs. 
(Ord. No. 3806, § 1, 8-25-97) 
Note- See editor's note following § 20-4. 
Sec. 20-7. - Minimum charges to abate violation. 
    Whenever the city is required to abate a violation under the provisions of this chapter, there shall be a minimum charge for the expenses incurred by the city for the abatement of the violation in the amount of seventy dollars ($70.00). In addition to the minimum charge, there shall be a charge of forty-five dollars ($45.00) per hour for each hour or part thereof over one (1) hour that it takes to abate the violation. 
    In the event abnormal abatement procedures are required to abate a violation under the provisions of this chapter, the actual expenses incurred by the city for the abatement of the violation shall be charged to the owner, occupant or person in possession of the parcel of land as set out in this article or assessed against the land as provided in section 20-4. 
    "Abnormal abatement procedures" shall be deemed to mean the required use of heavy construction equipment such as motor graders, crawler-tractors, wheel loaders, and/or track-type loaders. "Actual expenses" shall be deemed to include all administrative costs, including costs incurred in renting such equipment; the cost of fuel, oil, lubrication, filters, and repair or replacement of parts, including tires, when such repair or replacement is not a result of normal wear and tear; the per-mile cost of dump trucks used in hauling away the sign or other materials; and all labor costs. 
(Ord. No. 3806, § 1, 8-25-97) 
Sec. 20-8. - Penalties and procedures cumulative, not exclusive. 
    No proceeding by the city for a violation of any section of this chapter shall prohibit or bar the city from also seeking alternate relief or sanctions available under some other section of this chapter. For example, the city may prosecute a violation of this chapter by seeking the sanctions provided for in section 1-12, may process an abatement proceeding or may seek injunctive relief, proceed under all three or any one or more of the foregoing. 
(Ord. No. 3806, § 1, 8-25-97)
