Sec. 20-9. - Billboard/off-premise signs. 
(a)  Purpose of sign regulations. 
(1)  To preserve and promote the public health, safety, and welfare of the citizens of Lebanon, MO; 
(2)  To maintain and enhance the visual environment, and to preserve the right of citizens to enjoy the City of Lebanon's scenic beauty; 
(3)  To improve pedestrian and traffic safety; 
(4)  To minimize the possible adverse effect of billboards on nearby public and private property. 
(b)  Definitions. 
    Abandoned billboard. A billboard which has carried no message for more than one year or which no longer identifies a bona fide business, lesser, service, owner, product, or activity, date or time of past event, and/or for which no legal owner can be found. The definition shall also include any billboard structure which no longer supports the billboard for which it was designed. 
    Administrator. The designated government official whose responsibility it is to administer the provisions of this ordinance. These activities may include, but are not limited to, reviewing applications for billboard permits, corresponding and/or meeting with applicants, issuing and denying billboard permits, inspecting billboards, and interpreting and enforcing the provisions of this ordinance. For the city the administrator is hereby designated as the community development director. 
    Billboard. A billboard is an off-premises object, device, display, sign, or structure, or part thereof, displayed outdoors or visible from a public way, which is used to advertise, identify, display, direct or attract attention to an object, person, institution, organization, business, product, service, event or location, or to express a point of view, by any means, including words, letters, figures, design, symbols, advertising flags, fixtures, colors, illuminations or projected images. Billboards do not include on-premises commercial or political signage nor small commercial or non-commercial signs temporarily placed in residential lawns by residents, owners, contractors, realtors, or by or on behalf of political candidates or issues. 
    Billboard area. The facing of a billboard, including copy, insignia, background, structural supports, and border and trim. The measurement shall be determined by the smallest rectangle inclusive of all letters and images. The structural supports shall be excluded if they do not constitute a major part of the billboard or if the structure is not used to identify or attract attention to the business or product. 
    Changeable copy. Copy that changes at intervals of more than once every eight (8) seconds. 
    Directional sign. A sign erected and maintained by local officials within the public right-of-way, to indicate to the traveling public the route and distance to public accommodations, facilities, commercial services and points of scenic, historical, cultural, recreational, educational or religious interest. Such signs shall conform to all applicable state regulations regarding the placement of billboards in public rights-of-way. 
    Expressway or freeway. A highway to which access is restricted except by ramps or interchanges. 
    Flashing illumination. A light source which, in whole or in part, physically changes in light intensity or gives the appearance of such change at intervals of less than eight (8) seconds. 
    Height. The vertical distance measured from grade at the edge of the adjacent right-of-way to the highest point of the billboard. 
    Illegal billboard. A billboard that was constructed in violation of regulations that existed at the time it was built. 
    Indirect illumination. A light source not seen directly. 
    Internal illumination. A light source that is concealed or contained within the billboard and becomes visible in darkness through a translucent surface. 
    Movement. Physical movement or revolution up or down, around, or sideways that completes a cycle of change at intervals of less than eight (8) seconds. 
    Non-conforming billboard. A billboard which was lawfully erected and maintained at the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived, or any amendment thereto, that does not conform to the regulations of the district in which it is located. 
    Political billboard. A billboard that advertises a candidate or an issue which is to be voted on in a local, state, or federal election. 
    Premises. The contiguous land in the same ownership or control which is not divided by a street. 
    Spacing. Spacing of billboards shall be the minimum distance between outdoor advertising billboard structures measured along the nearest edge of the pavement between point directly opposite the billboards along each side of the highway and shall apply to outdoor advertising billboard structures located on both sides of the highway involved. 
    Structure. Anything built that requires a permanent location. 
(c)  Billboard regulations-Permitted. 
(1)  New billboards. Off-premise billboards shall comply with the requirements of this section and shall only be permitted upon property having frontage on either Interstate 44, Highway 64, Highway 5, and Highway 32. Land upon which the billboard/off-premise sign will be located must be zoned commercial or industrial. 
(2)  Height and area. All billboards shall be no greater than forty-five (45) feet in height from the highest point on the sign above the natural grade at the base of the sign or the adjacent street grade, whichever is higher. The billboard area must be located at least fifteen (15) feet above the natural grade of the ground at the base of the sign structure or the adjacent street grade, whichever is higher. 
a.  Signs spaced along I-44, Highway 5, and Highway 32 shall be in compliance with MODOT's guidelines and in order to obtain a city permit the applicant must present the permit from MODOT before consideration by the city. 
b.  Maximum surface area of a billboard along Highway 64 shall be two hundred eighty-eight (288) square feet on each side with a maximum sign face height of twelve (12) feet and maximum sign face width of twenty-four (24) feet. The billboard area must be located at least fifteen (15) feet above the natural grade of the ground at the base of the sign structure or the adjacent street grade, whichever is higher. 
c.  Sign spacing along Highway 64 shall be a minimum of one thousand four hundred (1,400) feet from any other billboard sign on the same side of the highway. 
d.  Signs along Highway 64 shall not exceed two sign faces, one surface in each direction. 
e.  Minimum front yard setback for each sign shall be fifteen (15) feet from any public right of way and/or private roadway easement. The maximum setback for each sign shall be two hundred (200) feet to the farthest point on the sign. 
(3)  Lighting. No billboard shall be so illuminated that it: 
a.  Interferes with the safety of aircraft flight in the vicinity of the billboard. 
b.  Interferes with the reasonable use of property of any adjacent landowners. 
c.  Allows the illumination source to be directly visible from any right-of-way or adjoining property. 
d.  No revolving or rotating beam or beacon of light that simulates any emergency light or device shall be permitted as part of any sign. No flashing, intermittent, or moving light or lights will be permitted except for public service information, such as time, date, or temperature. 
e.  External lighting, such as floodlights, thin line and gooseneck reflectors are permitted, provided the light source is directed upon the face of the sign and is effectively shielded so as to prevent beams or rays of light from being directed into any portion of the main traveled way and the lights are not of such intensity so as to cause glare, impair the vision of the driver of a motor vehicle, or otherwise interfere with a driver's operation of a motor vehicle. 
(4)  Spacing. (All measurements shall be made parallel to the roadway between perpendiculars extended from the billboard locations in question.) 
a.  No sign shall be erected within one thousand four hundred (1,400) feet of an existing off-premise sign on the same side of the highway. 
b.  No sign shall be located in such manner as to obstruct or otherwise physically interfere with the effectiveness of an official traffic sign, signal, or device or obstruct or physically interfere with a motor vehicle operator's view of approaching, merging or intersecting traffic, as determined by the administrator. 
(d)  Billboard regulations-Prohibited. The following are expressly prohibited unless specifically stated otherwise in this section: 
(1)  Animated and moving billboards. Off-premise billboards employing movement including, but not limited to, changeable copy signs, pennants, flags, banners, streamers, propellers, discs, and searchlights. No projected image(s) or message(s) shall appear to move or be animated. 
(2)  Flashing billboards. Off-premise billboards that include lights which flash, flicker, blink, or turn on and off intermittently, not including time and temperature signs. 
(3)  Glaring billboards. Off-premise billboards employing direct, indirect, internal, flashing, or other illumination with light sources or reflectivity of such brightness that constitute a hazard to ground or air traffic or a nuisance, as determined by the administrator. 
(4)  Inflatable billboards and objects. Which are in violation of FAA and MODOT's rules and regulations. 
(5)  Roof billboards. Off-premise billboards which are erected on a roof or which extend in height above the roofline of the building on which the sign is erected. 
(6)  Simulated traffic signs and obstructions. Any sign which may be confused with or obstruct the view of any authorized traffic sign or signal, obstruct the sight distance triangle at any street or highway intersection, or extend into the public right-of-way, as determined by the administrator. 
(7)  Vehicular billboards. Off-premise signs displayed on parked or stationary vehicles, where the primary purpose of the vehicle is to advertise a product or business or to direct people to a business or activity. For the purposes of this ordinance, vehicular billboards shall not include business logos, identification, or advertising on vehicles primarily used for other business purposes and such vehicle is legally registered and licensed as a motor vehicle with the State of Missouri. 
(8)  Signs that are not in good repair. Signs that are not in good repair, such as signs with poles, frames, braces, panels or facings which are broken or damaged or not securely affixed to a substantial structure or which are faded, blistered, cracked, peeled, chipped, or torn to the extent the total message is not discernable in the opinion of the administrator. 
(e)  Billboard regulations-Exempted signs. The following signs do not require permits or fee payments but must meet the other requirements of this section: 
(1)  Traffic control signs; 
(2)  Traffic flow informational signs; 
(3)  Directional signs; 
(4)  Safety control signs. 
(f)  General design and construction standards. All billboards shall be designated, constructed, and maintained in accordance with the following standards: 
(1)  All billboards shall comply with applicable provisions of the 2006 International Building Code and the 2005 National Electric Code. 
a.  All detached signs over ten (10) feet high require engineer drawings to be submitted, signed and sealed by a Missouri Registered Engineer. Plans must be certified they comply with the 2006 International Building Codes and 2005 NEC if electric is to be provided to the sign. 
b.  If sign to be illuminated, indicate type of illumination to be used. 
c.  If sign is to replace an existing sign on a pole or to be placed on an existing sign pole, the new sign must be of equal size or smaller or an engineer will be required to evaluate the existing pole and foundation to determine if they are adequate to support the new loads and that engineer must certify the new loads will meet the requirements of the 2006 IBC. 
d.  Site plan showing location of sign and distance from property lines. 
(g)  Non-conforming billboards. 
(1)  Continuance. Each non-conforming billboard and billboard structure shall be allowed to be displayed after the adoption of this section, provided the billboard is maintained in good repair and no structural changes can be made unless the sign is brought into compliance with the new rules and regulations. 
(2)  Removal. Non-conforming billboards and billboard structures shall be removed at the owner's or lessor's expense under the following circumstances: 
a.  The billboard is abandoned. 
b.  The billboard becomes damaged or dilapidated to fifty (50) percent or more of its physical structure. 
(h)  Administration and enforcement. 
(1)  Enforcement officer. All administration and enforcement of this section shall be primarily implemented by the community development director (the "administrator"). The administrator shall have the responsibility and full authority to administer and enforce all provisions of this section, other than those provisions specifically reserved for the authority of Lebanon City Council or the board of zoning appeals. However, other staff in the department will also be prepared to enforce this section. Anyone who wishes to report a billboard that may be in violation of this section should do so to the administrator. 
(2)  Permit procedure. All billboards, except as otherwise provided in this section, shall require a billboard permit prior to being constructed, reconstructed, moved, altered, placed, or repaired. Billboard permits shall be issued by the administrator. 
(3)  Permit application. All applications for billboard permits for billboards to be constructed, reconstructed, moved, altered, placed, or repaired shall be submitted to the administrator and shall contain or have attached at a minimum the following information in either written or graphic form: 
a.  Application date. 
b.  Name, address, and telephone number of the billboard owner and, if different, the owner of the land on which the billboard will be erected. A notarized letter between the owner of the sign and the owner of the property, if different, shall be submitted showing the owner of the property has entered into an agreement for the installation of the sign on their property. 
c.  Address of the property where the billboard or billboard structure will be erected. 
d.  Signature(s) of the billboard owner and, if different, the owner of the land on which the billboard will be displayed. 
e.  Location of the billboard on the property in relation to public rights of way, lot lines, buildings, sidewalks, streets, zoning districts, other existing billboards, and intersections. 
f.  General description of structural design and construction materials of billboard. 
g.  Drawing(s) of the proposed billboard which shall contain specification indicating height, perimeter, and area dimensions, means of support, methods of illumination if any, and any other significant aspect of the proposed billboard. 
h.  A boundary and sign survey showing the property and the proposed sign. 
i.  Certification(s) from licensed professional engineers that the soil surface is capable of sustaining the proposed load and that the electrical and structural strength of the proposed actual sign is satisfactory and complies with the building and electric codes as adopted by the city. 
j.  Wind load calculations must be submitted on all signs based upon the building code as adopted by the city. 
k.  Any other information requested by the administrator in order to carry out the purpose and intent of these regulations. 
(4)  Permit fees. Each application for a billboard permit shall be accompanied by the applicable fees, which shall be established by the Lebanon City Council from time to time. 
(5)  Permit application completeness. Within five (5) working days of receiving an application for a billboard permit, the administrator shall review it for completeness. If the administrator finds that it is complete, the application shall then be processed. If the administrator finds that it is incomplete, s/he shall, within such five (5) day period, send to the applicant a notice of the specific ways in which the application is deficient, with appropriate references to the applicable subsections of this section. 
(6)  Permit issuance/denial action. Within ten (10) working days of the submission of a complete application for a billboard permit, the administrator shall either: 
a.  Issue the billboard permit, if the billboard that is the subject of the application conforms in every respect with the requirement of this section; or 
b.  Deny the billboard permit if the billboard that is subject of the application fails in any way to conform with the requirements of this section. In case of a rejection, the administrator shall specify in the rejection the subsection or subsections of the section or applicable plan with which the billboard is inconsistent. 
(7)  Inspection Upon Completion. Any person installing, structurally altering, or relocating a billboard for which a permit has been issued shall notify the administrator upon completion of the work by submitting a certification of construction compliance by a registered professional engineer if the sign is taller than ten (10) feet, or by the person or company installing the sign if the sign is ten (10) feet tall or less. 
(8)  Violations. The administrator, upon finding that any provision of this section or any condition of a permit issued under this section is being violated, is authorized to institute legal proceedings to enjoin violations of this section. 
(9)  Complaints and revocations. The administrator shall investigate any complaints of violations of this section and may revoke a permit if there is any violation of the provisions of this section or there was misrepresentation of any material facts in either the application or plans. 
(10)  Appeal procedure. Any person applying for a billboard permit who is denied a permit or disagrees with any ruling by the administrator may appeal to the zoning board of appeals. 
(11)  Expiration of billboard permits. If an approved billboard is not erected within a period of twelve (12) months from the date the permit was originally issued, the permit shall expire and become null and void. If during this time the rules and regulations change before a billboard is constructed then the new rules and regulations must be followed for the construction of the billboard. 
(12)  Fines. A person who violates the provisions of this section or the conditions of a permit shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and action may be taken in the municipal court. Each day of the violation constitutes a separate offense subject to a five hundred dollar ($500.00) fine. Such persons shall also be liable for court costs and reasonable attorney fees incurred by the local jurisdiction. 
(i)  Protection of first amendment rights. Any billboard, display, or device allowed under this section may contain, in lieu of any other copy, any otherwise lawful, noncommercial message, including any political message, that does not direct attention to a business operated for profit or to a commodity or service for sale, and that complies with all other requirements of this section. 
(Ord. No. 4797, § 1, 11-29-10) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4797, § 1, adopted November 29, 2010, added § 20-9, which pertains to billboard/off-premise signs. Former §§ 20-9 and 20-10 have been been renumbered as §§ 20-10 and 20-11 respectively. 
Sec. 20-10. - Placement of signs on utility poles prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place any sign or advertisement upon any telegraph, telephone or electric light pole, tree or other public property within the city. 
(Ord. No. 3806, § 1, 8-25-97) 
Editor's note- Formerly § 20-9, was renumbered as § 20-10 at the direction of the city (see editor's note to § 20-9). 
Sec. 20-11. - Placement of handbills on motor vehicles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place handbills on any motor vehicle parked on city streets. 
(Ord. No. 3806, § 1, 8-25-97) 
Editor's note- Formerly § 20-10, was renumbered as § 20-11 at the direction of the city (see editor's note to § 20-9). 
Chapter 21 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6. 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to provide for the disposition of garbage and trash, RSMo 71.680, 71.690; solid waste disposal, RSMo 260.200 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 21-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
    Ashes shall mean the residue from the burning of wood, coal, coke or other combustible materials. 
    Garbage shall mean putrescible animal and vegetable wastes resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food. 
State Law reference- Garbage defined, RSMo 266.410. 
    Licensee shall mean any person licensed to haul garbage, refuse or rubbish. 
    Refuse shall mean all solid wastes. 
    Rubbish shall mean nonputrescible solid wastes, excluding ashes, consisting of both combustible and noncombustible wastes, such as paper, cardboard, tin cans, yard clippings, wood, glass, bedding, crockery and similar materials. 
    Solid waste shall mean garbage, refuse and other discarded materials including, but not limited to, solid and semisolid waste materials resulting from industrial, commercial, agricultural, governmental and domestic activities, but does not include overburden, rock, tailings, matte, slag or other waste material resulting from mining, milling or smelting. 
State Law reference- Solid waste defined, RSMo 260.200(5). 
    Solid waste disposal area shall mean any area used for the disposal of solid waste from residential premises, or from commercial, industrial, manufacturing, recreational or governmental operations and which operates under a permit issued by the state department of natural resources. 
    Solid waste processing facility shall mean any incinerator, compost plant, transfer station or any facility where solid wastes are salvaged and which operates under a permit issued by the state department of natural resources. 
(Code 1967, § 11-1; Ord. No. 3159, § 12, 5-29-84) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 21-2. - Enforcement of chapter. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the building and zoning administrator to enforce the provisions of this chapter. If the city receives a complaint or is otherwise informed and believes that a violation of the provisions of this chapter has occurred or that a nuisance exists, the building and zoning administrator shall have the authority to enter any and all private property at any reasonable time in order to make inspections to obtain evidence in order to aid in the enforcement of this chapter. 
(b)  The building and zoning administrator shall institute all necessary and appropriate enforcement proceedings against any person who shall violate any provisions of this chapter, including but not limited to the notice and abatement procedure outlined in section 13-40 or the filing of an information and complaint in the municipal court. 
(Ord. No. 3159, § 13, 5-29-84; Ord. No. 3253, § 4, 6-22-87; Ord. No. 4357, § 1, 11-28-05) 
Sec. 21-3. - Exceptions from chapter. 
(a)  Cardboard and paper. This chapter shall not prohibit any person engaged in the collection of cardboard, paper and paper products from collecting such materials for resale or reprocessing; provided, however, that the collection, transportation and distribution of such materials shall be conducted in a neat and orderly manner. 
(b)  Aluminum cans. This chapter shall not prohibit any person engaged in the collection of aluminum cans from collecting such for resale or reprocessing; provided, however, that the collection, transportation and distribution of such cans shall be conducted in a neat and orderly manner. 
(c)  Tree trimmers. This chapter shall not prohibit any person engaged in the trimming or removal of trees from engaging in such business; provided, however, that such person shall conduct his business in a neat and orderly manner and shall not allow any limbs, branches or brush to spill onto or be deposited on any public property or any private property other than the property where the business is conducted. 
(d)  Actual producers. This chapter shall not prohibit the actual producer of solid waste, or the owners of premises on which solid waste has accumulated, from personally collecting, transporting, processing or disposing of such solid waste; provided, however, that such producer or owner must comply with all laws applicable to solid waste, including the provisions of this chapter. Any person transporting his own solid waste shall be required, upon request by the health officer or any police officer, to furnish satisfactory proof of the lawful disposal of such solid waste. If such producer or owner collects, transports, processes or disposes of solid waste under this exception on a re-occurring or regular basis, such person file an annual report with the city stating the actual method and procedure of collection, transporting, processing and disposing of such solid waste including the place of ultimate disposal and an accurate estimate of the amount of such solid waste disposed of. This annual report shall be filed no later than June 30 each year. 
(e)  City actions. This chapter shall not prohibit the city from collecting, transporting, processing or disposing of solid waste. 
(Code 1967, § 11-4; Ord. No. 3159, § 1A-E, 5-29-84) 
Sec. 21-4. - License required to haul dead animals. 
    No person may haul or transport over the highways, streets or alleys of the city, the bodies of dead animals, except those that have been slaughtered and intended for human food, without first obtaining and holding a license to transport bodies of dead animals or unless acting for such a licensee. 
(Code 1967, § 14-20; Ord. No. 3016, § 11-2, 8-11-80) 
Cross reference- Animals, Ch. 5. 
State Law reference- License required to transport or operate disposal plant, RSMo 269.030. 
Sec. 21-5. - Penalties, nuisance declared; remedy. 
(a)  Any person who violates any provisions of this chapter or who interferes with the duties of the building and zoning administrator in enforcing this chapter shall be guilty of an offense and upon conviction shall be punished as provided in section 1-12. 
(b)  As an additional remedy, the storage, collection, transportation, processing or disposal of any solid waste in violation of the provisions of this chapter is hereby declared to be a public nuisance against the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the city and shall be subject to abatement by a temporary injunction or permanent injunction by a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(c)  Any person who violates the provisions of section 21-21 shall be notified by the compliance officer and shall have three (3) days to abate the nuisance. If not abated, the building and zoning administrator shall have the option of filing an information and complaint in the municipal court as provided in subsection 21-2(b) and if the allegations are found to be true, the violator shall be subject to the following penalties: 
(1)  If the owner or occupant fails to provide written evidence of the existence of a contract for regular trash collection service: 
a.  First offense: A fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for the nuisance violation and abatement of the nuisance at violator's cost. 
b.  Second offense: A fine of not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00) for the nuisance violation and abatement of the nuisance at violator's cost. 
c.  Third offense: A fine of not less than four hundred dollars ($400.00) for the nuisance violation and abatement of the nuisance at violator's cost. 
(2)  If the owner or occupant provides written evidence of the existence of a contact for regular trash collection service: 
a.  First offense: A fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) for the nuisance violation and abatement of the nuisance at violator's cost. 
b.  Second offense: A fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for the nuisance violation and abatement of the nuisance at violator's cost. 
c.  Third offense: A fine of not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00) for the nuisance violation and abatement of the nuisance at the violator's cost. 
(3)  The court shall not suspend imposition of sentence for any first offense unless the violator is required to perform an appropriate amount of community service. The court shall not suspend imposition of service for any second or subsequent offense. 
(Ord. No. 3159, §§ 14, 15, 5-29-84; Ord. No. 3253, § 4, 6-22-87; Ord. No. 4357, § 2, 11-28-05) 
Secs. 21-6-21-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Collection and disposal of solid waste, RSMo 260.215. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 21-21. - Mandatory garbage and trash disposal; dumping prohibited. 
(a)  Every occupant of a dwelling unit shall dispose of all of his or her garbage, trash and rubbish in a clean and sanitary manner, by placing the same in storage containers required by section 21-22 and shall be required to contract in writing with a licensed collection service authorized to collect, transport and dispose of solid waste in the City of Lebanon or the occupant shall cause the removal of the same to a state approved landfill, at least once per week, and obtain a receipt evidencing the fact that the trash has been disposed of properly. 
(b)  It shall be the responsibility of the owner of a multifamily dwelling containing three (3) or more dwelling units to supply storage containers required by section 21-22. If the multifamily units are less than three (3), each of the occupants shall be responsible for complying with the subsection. 
(c)  No person shall dump or deposit any solid waste or allow any solid waste to be dumped or deposited upon on any lot, street, alley, public or private property within the city. In the event any owner or occupant of property, has trash or rubbish that licensed haulers do not accept, such as old furniture, appliances, tree limbs, etc., it shall be that persons responsibility to remove the same from their property and dispose of it at a state approved landfill within one week and obtain a receipt evidencing the fact that the trash has been disposed of properly. 
(d)  No person shall burn solid waste inside the city limits except that yard waste may be burned, unless burning constitutes a nuisance for the public or for neighbors in the area, in which case, such burning is also prohibited. 
(Code 1967, § 11-3; Ord. No. 3159, § 10, 5-29-84; Ord. No. 4357, § 3, 11-28-05) 
Sec. 21-22. - Solid waste containers. 
(a)  Residential. All solid waste placed outdoors in the city by residential customers shall be deposited and kept in closed containers. Such containers shall be subject to the following rules and regulations: 
(1)  Such containers shall be either corrugated, galvanized metal or durable plastic garbage containers, of a capacity not in excess of thirty (30) gallons, equipped with suitable handles to facilitate simple handling and emptying of the containers; 
(2)  Such containers shall be watertight, equipped with lids which fit with sufficient tightness to prevent the escape of obnoxious odors, and the containers shall be tightly closed; 
(3)  Each customer shall provide his own container, and where there are two (2) or more families residing in a multiple family dwelling, there shall either be a separate container for each family or a commercial or industrial type container of sufficient capacity for the multiple family dwelling; 
(4)  No free water or other liquids shall be placed in the containers except for purpose of cleaning same, and all solid waste shall be drained of water and all other liquids before deposit in the containers; 
(5)  Such containers as are kept outside shall be kept at or near the rear outside area of any dwelling or building of the customer, except that on the assigned pick-up day the containers may be placed at or near the public street to facilitate the collection of their contents; 
(6)  No person shall permit any garbage or refuse other than his own to be deposited within his container, and no person shall deposit and solid waste in any container of another person who shall be a customer of the licensee under section 21-40; 
(7)  The use of industrial strength plastic bags is hereby expressly authorized in lieu of containers, provided that such bags shall be securely fastened or tied and shall be placed outside of the dwelling or building by the customer not more than fourteen (14) hours before the scheduled pick-up; and 
(8)  No person shall allow any solid waste to be carried by wind or other natural cause or by animals or otherwise from his property to the property of any other person or to the public streets. 
(b)  Commercial or industrial. All solid waste placed outdoors in the city by commercial or industrial establishments shall be deposited and kept in closed containers. Such containers shall be subject to the following rules and regulations: 
(1)  Such containers shall be built of a good quality material with a door or cover to tightly enclose the contents thereof and such containers shall be equipped with a latch or closer to prevent vandalism and shall be approved by the health officer; and 
(2)  All of the provisions to residential solid waste containers listed in subsection (a), except subsection (1) thereof, shall also apply to commercial or industrial establishments. 
(Ord. No. 3159, § 7, 5-29-84) 
Sec. 21-23. - Frequency of collection. 
(a)  Residential. Each person operating under a license issued pursuant to this article shall provide at least one (1) solid waste collection each week for residential users of his services. 
(b)  Commercial. Collections for commercial users shall be provided as needed and at least one (1) collection each week. 
(c)  Additional collections. Each person operating under a license issued pursuant to this article shall provide such additional collections to residential or commercial users as shall be reasonably requested for which reasonable charges may be made. 
(Ord. No. 3159, § 5, 5-29-84) 
Sec. 21-24. - Charges for services. 
    Each person operating under a license issued pursuant to this chapter shall charge just and reasonable rates for services, taking into consideration the frequency of service, loading conditions, and the weight, size and nature of solid waste involved. All services to residential users of the same nature shall be uniform and non-discriminatory. 
(Ord. No. 3159, § 6, 5-29-84) 
Secs. 21-25-21-35. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 21-36. - Required. 
    All solid waste accumulated within the city shall be collected, transported, processed and disposed of only by a person who is duly licensed by the city. No person who is not licensed shall collect, transport, process or dispose of any solid waste accumulated within the city. 
(Ord. No. 3159, § 1, 5-29-84) 
Sec. 21-37. - Application. 
    A person seeking a license under this division shall complete an application form for the initial issuance of the license and each renewal thereof which shall state the true name of the person, the business address and telephone of the person, and the location of the place of ultimate disposal of solid waste to be collected by such person. 
(Ord. No. 3159, § 2, 5-29-84) 
Sec. 21-38. - Fee. 
    In order to obtain a license under this division, a person shall pay an annual fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) to the city collector between July 1 and July 15 of each year. This requirement shall apply to persons who collect solid waste from commercial and industrial customers, as well as those who collect from residential customers. 
(Ord. No. 3159, § 2, 5-29-84) 
Sec. 21-39. - Prerequisites to issuance. 
(a)  Inspection of collection vehicles. The building and zoning administrator shall inspect all collection vehicles of the person applying for the issuance or renewal of a license under this division to determine that they comply with the provisions of section 21-57. The building and zoning administrator shall present his written report of inspection to the city clerk indicating compliance or non-compliance, and the reasons for any non-compliance. 
(b)  Insurance. Each person applying for the issuance or renewal of a license under this division shall furnish to the city clerk proof of the following insurance: 
(1)  Worker's compensation insurance on all the employees of such person, unless such person is exempt from the requirements of worker's compensation insurance by the provisions of RSMo Ch. 287; and 
(2)  Public liability and property damage insurance in the minimum amount of five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) combined with single limits for personal injury or property damage covering all vehicles and equipment operated in collection of solid waste. 
Certificate of such insurance shall be presented to the city clerk showing such insurance coverage upon the initial application and each renewal of the license. 
(c)  Performance bond. Each person applying for the issuance or renewal of a license under this division shall furnish to the city clerk a performance bond covering such person's contractual obligations to the citizens of the city, such bond to be in the amount of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00). 
(d)  Indemnification of city. Each person applying for a license under this division or renewal thereof, shall indemnify and hold the city harmless from any and all liability, obligations, claims, demands, actions, suits, causes or action, judgments or damages resulting from the operations of collecting, transporting, processing, or disposing of solid waste by such person. Each person applying for such license or renewal shall execute and deliver a written indemnification as required herein. This written indemnification may be a part of the license application or renewal application. 
(Ord. No. 3159, § 2A-D, 5-29-84; Ord. No. 3253, § 4, 6-22-87) 
Sec. 21-40. - Issuance. 
    Upon receipt of the license fee required in section 21-38 and upon demonstration that the applicant has complied with all the requirements of section 21-39, the city clerk shall issue such applicant a license to collect, transport, process and dispose of solid waste. 
(Ord. No. 3159, § 2, 5-29-84) 
Sec. 21-41. - Licensee must maintain office. 
    Each person operating under a license issued pursuant to this division shall maintain an office or an answering service, within the city equipped with a telephone therein, and staffed with an employee or representative between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. Mondays through Fridays, inclusive, of each week, excluding holidays, for the purpose of providing information and services on behalf of such person. 
(Ord. No. 3159, § 3, 5-29-84) 
Secs. 21-42-21-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - VEHICLES AND EQUIPMENT[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Traffic and motor vehicles, Ch. 25. 

Sec. 21-56. - Parking vehicles with offensive cargoes prohibited; exception. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person driving a motor vehicle carrying livestock, garbage, carrion, fecal matter or any odoriferous cargo, which may be declared a public nuisance detrimental to public health and welfare, to park such vehicle within three hundred (300) feet of any residence or business establishment, except for loading or unloading purposes and then not exceeding thirty (30) minutes, at any area or place in the city. It shall further be unlawful to park any motor vehicle which is empty and which has been hauling or contains the odoriferous matter described herein which may likewise be classed as a nuisance, within three hundred (300) feet of any residence or business establishment in the city, unless the vehicle has been thoroughly cleaned and disinfected according to the orders of the police department. 
(Code 1967, § 14-19; Ord. No. 3016, § 10, 8-11-80) 
Cross reference- Stopping, standing and parking, § 25-256 et seq. 
Sec. 21-57. - Specifications-Generally. 
    Each person operating under a license issued pursuant to this article shall operate and maintain suitable and adequate equipment for rendering the services provided for in this chapter. The motor vehicles used in the collection and transportation of solid waste shall have enclosed, water-tight bodies and covers to prevent leakage and spillage and accumulation of flies. Persons who collect solid waste from residential customers shall use motor vehicles equipped with a mechanical compactor capable of compressing solid waste to a minimum density of five hundred (500) pounds per cubic yard. Persons collecting solid waste from commercial or industrial customers shall not be required to have a compactor. The bodies of all such motor vehicles shall be thoroughly washed and cleaned on a regular basis. The areas of such motor vehicles where the solid wastes are stored shall be completely enclosed to prevent leakage, spillage and fly accumulation. 
(Code 1967, §§ 22-5-22-7; Ord. No. 3159, § 4, 5-29-84) 
State Law reference- Weight limits of vehicles transporting solid wastes, RSMo 260.218. 
Sec. 21-58. - Same-For vehicles transporting dead animals. 
    All vehicles used in the transportation of the bodies of dead animals, under the provisions of section 21-4 shall have a tank or metal lining in the bed of the vehicle, so that no drippings, or seepage from dead bodies shall escape from the vehicle while it is engaged in transportation. Every vehicle shall have a bed of such depth and type of construction and equipment that any dead bodies therein shall be completely hidden from view of persons using the highways, streets or alleys and any public nuisance obviated while being transported. 
(Code 1967, § 14-21; Ord. No. 3016, § 11-1, 8-11-80) 
Cross reference- Animals, Ch. 5. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 269.130. 
Secs. 21-59-21-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - DISPOSAL 

Sec. 21-71. - Site. 
    All solid waste shall be disposed of at either a solid waste processing facility or a solid waste disposal area which has received approval from the state department of natural resources as required by RSMo 260.200 to 260.245. No person, whether or not operating under a license issued pursuant to this article, shall dispose of any solid waste originating from within the city other than at either a solid waste processing facility or a solid waste disposal area. 
(Ord. No. 3159, § 8, 5-29-84) 
Sec. 21-72. - Location of solid waste disposal area. 
    The solid waste originating from within the city may be taken to any solid waste processing facility or solid waste disposal area, provided, that if either the city or the county shall establish a solid waste disposal area, all solid waste collected from within the city shall be disposed of at such solid waste disposal area. 
(Ord. No. 3159, § 9, 5-29-84) 
Chapter 22 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Ordinances naming, re-naming, opening, accepting or vacating streets or alleys in the city saved from repeal, § 1-6(9); regulations making authority for certain minimum standards, § 2-851; drinking in certain public places prohibited, § 4-2; possession of intoxicating liquors in certain public places prohibited, § 4-3; animals prohibited in certain public places, § 5-12; animals running at large prohibited, § 5-7; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6; moving of buildings, § 6-36 et seq.; parks and recreation, Ch. 15; design standards for streets in subdivisions, § 23-22; design standards for public sites and open spaces in subdivisions, § 23-27; improvement to streets in subdivisions, § 23-93; traffic and motor vehicles generally, Ch. 25; placing injurious substances in streets prohibited, § 25-16; signs and devices on city street for traffic control during construction, repairs, etc., § 25-47; authority of city traffic engineer to close streets, § 25-51; driving vehicles on sidewalks, § 25-82; one-way streets and alleys, § 25-216 et seq.; riding bicycles and motorized bicycles on sidewalks, § 25-419; railroad trains not to block streets, § 25-552. 
State Law reference- Municipal control over streets and sidewalks, RSMo 77.520; public works and special assessments therefore, third class cities, 30,000 or less, RSMo 88.497-88.647, 88.863-88.913. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 22-1. - Gutters, drains to be kept free of obstructions. 
    All persons are hereby required to keep the drains or gutters adjacent to their premises free from all obstructions. 
(Code 1967, § 17-24) 
Cross reference- Sewer use, § 26-21 et seq. 
Sec. 22-2. - Adopt-a-street program. 
(a)  The purpose of the adopt-a-street program is to provide volunteer community support for litter prevention and street beautification programs with the potential for a cost savings to the City of Lebanon. 
(b)  This program will reduce litter along the streets, enhance the environment and beautify the City of Lebanon's streets. 
(c)  The program is not intended as a means of providing a public forum for the participants to use in promoting name recognition or political causes. Lebanon right-of-way is not a public forum. 
(d)  The adopter or adopter representative of a group who desires to participate in the program shall submit an application to the department of public works on a form provided by the department. 
    An application completed by an individual on behalf of a group or organization must identify the group or organization for which the application is being submitted and failure to identify the group or organization on the application will result in rejecting the application. 
(e)  Civic and nonprofit organizations, commercial and private enterprises and individuals may be eligible to adopt. Applicants who do not meet the eligibility requirements will be denied participation in the program, and adopters who no longer meet the applicant eligibility requirements may be removed from the program. The public works director reserves the right to limit the number of adoptions for a single group. 
(f)  The public works director has the authority to approve applications of individuals or groups applying to participate in the program. 
    A request for participation in the program may be denied if the applicant does not meet the eligibility requirements or has submitted false statement(s) of a material fact or has practiced or attempted to practice any fraud or deception in an application. Material facts include statements regarding convictions of violent criminal activity. 
(Ord. No. 4622, §§ 1-6, 3-30-09) 
Sec. 22-3. - Sidewalk restaurants. 
(a)  Definitions as used in this section: 
    Adjacent to a restaurant means an area lying between the two (2) property lines of the restaurant when the property lines are extended to the city street. 
    Sidewalk means that portion of the street between the curb lines or the lateral lines of a roadway and the adjacent property lines and which is intended for use of pedestrians. 
    Sidewalk restaurant means a use located on a sidewalk that is associated with the adjacent restaurant where food and beverages are prepared, served, sold, and/or delivered for consumption on the sidewalk. A sidewalk restaurant is characterized by tables and chairs and may be shaded by awnings, canopies, or umbrellas otherwise complying with city ordinances. 
    Sidewalk restaurant items means tables, chairs, umbrellas, planters, trash receptacles, portable railings, lights, and other items associated with the operation of a sidewalk restaurant. 
(b)  A sidewalk restaurant may be operated adjacent to a restaurant and incident to the operation of a restaurant. Sidewalk restaurant items must be arranged in such a manner that an unobstructed path of not less than forty-eight (48) inches, exclusive of the width of the curb, is maintained at all times on the sidewalk or shall comply with the Americans with Disabilities Act requirements and/or United States Access Board guidelines for public rights-of-way, whichever is greater. Awnings, canopies, or umbrellas that extend into the walking area shall be eighty (80) inches in height above the walking area at its lowest point or shall comply with the Americans with Disabilities Act requirements, whichever is greater. 
(c)  Sidewalk restaurant items shall be arranged so that no item obstructs a fire hydrant, non-pedestrian alleyway, pedestrian crosswalk, or accessible curb cut. 
(d)  Sidewalk restaurant items shall be maintained with a clean appearance and shall be in good repair at all times. Each day the owners, managers, or employees of the restaurant shall pick up and collect all trash, debris, and refuse that results from the use of the sidewalk restaurant and said trash, debris, and refuse shall be deposited in the regular solid waste system of the restaurant and shall not be deposited in any public waste can or other public receptacle. 
(e)  If additional liquor licensing is required by law, then the owner of the restaurant adjacent to a sidewalk restaurant shall apply for and obtain appropriate licensing to extend its right to serve or sell alcoholic beverages to the area of the sidewalk restaurant prior to serving or selling any alcoholic beverages. 
(f)  Sections 4-2 and 4-3 of this Code shall not apply to patrons of sidewalk restaurants who are seated at the tables provided and who are not otherwise creating a disturbance. 
(g)  Any person violating this section shall be punished under section 1-12 of this Code. The conviction of any owner, agent, or employee of any restaurant for a violation of this section shall also result in the offending restaurant losing the right to operate a sidewalk restaurant for a period of six (6) months and all sidewalk restaurant items shall be removed from the sidewalk during that period of time. 
( Ord. No. 5723 , § 1, 2-26-18) 
Secs. 22-4-22-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PUBLIC UTILITY RIGHT-OF-WAY MANAGEMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4532, adopted Dec. 17, 2007, amended art. II in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former art. II consisted of §§ 22-16-22-23, pertained to excavations and derived from the 1967 Code; and Ord. No. 4509, adopted Oct. 15, 2007. 

Sec. 22-16. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article the following terms, phrases, words, abbreviations and their derivations shall have the meaning given in this section. Words used in the present tense include the future tense, words in the single number include the plural number, and words in the plural number include the single number. The words "shall" and "will" are mandatory and the word "may" is permissive. Words not defined shall be given their common and ordinary meaning. 
    Abandoned equipment or facilities shall mean any equipment, materials, apparatuses, devices or facilities that are: 
(i)  Declared abandoned by the owner of such equipment, materials, apparatuses, devises or facilities; or 
(ii)  No longer in active use, physically disconnected from a portion of the operating facility or any other facility that is in use or in service, and no longer capable of being used for the same or similar purpose for which the equipment, materials, apparatuses or facilities were installed; or 
(iii)  No longer in active use and the owner of such equipment, materials, apparatuses, devises or facilities fails to respond within thirty (30) days to a written notice sent by the city that the city deems such equipment, materials, apparatuses, devises or facilities abandoned. 
    Applicant shall mean any public utility right-of-way user that applies for a public utility right-of-way permit. 
    Application shall mean the process by which an applicant submits a request to be issued a public utility right-of-way permit. An Application includes all written documentation and representations, in whatever form, made by the applicant to the city regarding the matters pertaining to a requested public utility right-of-way permit. 
    Article shall mean this public utility right-of-way management ordinance, subsections 22-16 through 22-39. 
    Cable communications system or cable system shall have the meaning set forth in applicable ordinances. 
    Cable franchise shall mean a franchise to construct and operate a cable system or provide cable service granted pursuant to the Code. 
    City shall mean the City of Lebanon, Missouri, as now incorporated and including all future annexations. 
    City council shall mean the governing body of the city. 
    Code shall mean the Code of Ordinances of the City of Lebanon, Missouri. 
    Completed application shall mean when an applicant has submitted all documents, plans, specifications and information required by this article has satisfied all other requirements for consideration of the application by the city under this article. 
    Department of public works shall mean the department of public works of the city. 
    Emergency includes, but is not limited to, the following: 
(i)  An unexpected or unplanned outage, cut, rupture, leak or any other failure of a public utility facility that prevents or significantly jeopardizes the ability of a public utility to provide service to customers; or 
(ii)  An unexpected or unplanned outage, cut, rupture, leak or any other failure of a public utility facility that results or could result in danger to the public or a material delay or hindrance to the provision of service to the public if the outage, cut, rupture, leak or any other such failure of public utility facilities is not immediately repaired, controlled, stabilized or rectified; or 
(iii)  Any occurrence involving a public utility facility that a reasonable person could conclude under the circumstances that immediate and undelayed action by the public utility is necessary and warranted. 
    Excavation shall mean any act by which earth, asphalt, concrete, sand, gravel, rock or any other material in or on the ground is cut into, dug, uncovered, removed or otherwise displaced, by means of any tools, equipment or explosives, except that the following shall not be deemed excavation; 
(i)  Any displacement or movement of ground caused by pedestrian or vehicular traffic; or 
(ii)  The replacement of utility poles and related equipment at the existing general location that does not involve either a street or sidewalk cut, or 
(iii)  Any other activity which does not disturb or displace surface conditions of the earth, asphalt, concrete, sand, gravel, rock or any other material in or on the ground. 
    Facilities shall mean any tangible thing located wholly or partially in, above or underneath the public right-of-way, including, but not limited to, lines, pipes, wires, cables, conduit facilities, poles, towers, vaults, pedestals, boxes, appliances, antennas, transmitters, gates, motors, appurtenances or other equipment and systems. 
    Law shall mean all duly enacted and applicable federal, state, county or city laws, ordinances, resolutions, regulations, orders or other enactments now in force or hereafter adopted. 
    Missouri One Call means the procedural requirements for excavation and utility safety established by RSMo 319.010, et seq., as amended, and the terms and conditions of Missouri One Call System, Inc. 
    Person shall mean any natural person and all domestic and foreign corporations, closely-held corporations, limited liability companies, associations, syndicates, joint stock corporations, partnerships of every kind, clubs, businesses, common law trusts, societies and any other legal entity. 
    Public improvement means any project undertaken by the city, or its agents, contractors, or subcontractors, for the construction, reconstruction, maintenance, or repair of any public infrastructure, and including without limitation, streets, alleys, bridges, bikeways, parkways, sidewalks, sewers, drainage facilities, traffic control devices, street lights, public facilities, public buildings or land owned by the city. 
    Public right-of-way shall mean the surface, the air space above the surface (to the extent such air space may be regulated by the city under federal law) and the area below the surface of any public roadway, highway, street, sidewalk or alleyway, in which and to the full extent of the boundaries of the property in which the city has an interest or easement, but not including: 
(i)  The airwaves above a public right-of-way with regard to cellular or other non-wire telecommunications or broadcast service; or 
(ii)  Easements obtained by utilities or private easements in platted subdivisions or tracts, (excluding those dedicated for public use); or 
(iii)  Railroad rights-of-way and ground utilized or acquired for railroad facilities; or 
(iv)  Poles, pipes, cables, conduits, wires, optical cables, or other means of transmission, collection or exchange of communications, information, substances, data, or electronic or electrical current or impulses utilized by a municipally owned or operated utility pursuant to RSMo Chapter 91, or pursuant to a charter form of government. 
    Public utility shall mean every cable television, service provider, every pipeline corporation, gas corporation, electrical corporation rural electric cooperative, telecommunications company, water corporation, heating or refrigerating corporation or sewer corporation under the jurisdiction of the public service commission; every municipally owned or operated utility pursuant to RSMo Chapter 91, or pursuant to a charter form of government or cooperatively owned or operated utility pursuant to RSMo Chapter 394; every street light maintenance district; every privately owned utility; and every other entity, regardless of its form of organization or governance, whether for profit or not, which in providing a public utility type of service for members of the general public, utilizes pipes, cables, conduits, wires, optical cables, facilities, or other means of transmission, collection or exchange of communications, information, substances, data, or electronic or electrical current or impulses, in the collection, exchange or dissemination of its product or services through the public right-of-way. "Public Utility" shall include a public utility provider that does not own facilities in the public right-of-way but uses the public right-of-way by interconnecting with or using the network elements of another public utility utilizing the public right-of-way, and/or by leaving excess capacity from another public utility. 
    Public utility right-of-way user shall mean a public utility owning, controlling, or utilizing a facility located in the public right-of-way. 
    Public works director shall mean the director of the department of public works of the city, or his or her designee. 
    Public utility right-of-way permit shall mean a permit issued by the city authorizing the performance of work in the public right-of-way by a public utility right-of-way user. 
    Trenchless technology shall mean the use of directional boring, horizontal drilling and microtunneling and other techniques in the construction of facilities underground which results in the least amount of disruption and damage to the public right-of-way as possible. 
(Ord. No. 4532, § I, 12-17-07) 
Sec. 22-17. - Permit required. 
(a)  Public utility right-of-way user shall not perform any excavation within a public right-of-way without obtaining a public utility right-of-way permit from the public works director, who shall charge for such permit the sum set by ordinance. Service drops 50 feet or less are exempt from requiring a permit. 
(b)  Any person not a public utility right-of-way user contemplating an excavation within the limits of any street, alley or sidewalk in the city, shall, before making the excavation, apply for a permit from the public works director, who shall charge for such permit the sum set by ordinance. The city may require a cash bond not to exceed the estimated restoration costs. Bond proceeds may be used to restore right-of-way in the event permit holder fails to restore damage in a timely and appropriate manner. 
(Ord. No. 4532, § I, 12-17-07) 
Sec. 22-18. - Permit application and submittal requirement. 
    An application for a public utility right-of-way permit in the form provided by the city must be filed with the director of public works to obtain a public utility right-of-way permit either by a registered public utility right-of-way user or an authorized agent of the public utility right-of-way user who will perform or conduct the excavation. 
(Ord. No. 4532, § I, 12-17-07) 
Sec. 22-19. - Design standards. 
(a)  The public work's director shall assign specific corridors within the public right-of-way, or any particular segment thereof as may be necessary, for facilities, that are or pursuant to current technology the public works director expects will someday be located in public right-of-way. All facilities shall be designed and constructed in the proper corridor as designated by the public works director pursuant to the authority contained in this section. All persons whose facilities are located in public right-of-way in a position at variance with the corridors established by the public works director shall no later than at the time of the next reconstruction or excavation of the area where its facilities are located, move the facilities to the proper corridor designated by the public works director. 
(b)  All construction or maintenance of facilities shall be accomplished in the manner resulting in the least amount of damage and disruption of the public right-of-way. Specifically, every applicant shall utilize trenchless technology and specify the use of trenchless technology in the design of projects located below or under pavements or other locations that will require cutting or patching of public right-of-way. If and when the city requires a public utility right-of-way user to cease using existing poles, all other public utility right-of-way users utilizing the same poles shall also relocate their facilities underground at the same time. The cost of such relocations shall be borne in accordance with this article and approved applicable tariffs governing that public utility right-of-way user. The design of each project shall be the design that will result in the least amount of disruptions to the public right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 4532, § I, 12-17-07) 
Sec. 22-20. - Processing of applications and approval. 
(a)  The public works director shall promptly, but not longer than ten (10) days after the application is filed, process each completed application for a public utility right-of-way permit. The public works director may require an applicant to separate proposed work into individual or distinct applications due to the complexity of a proposed project or for other reasonable reasons. 
(b)  If the public works director determines that an applicant has complied with the requirements of this article, the public works director shall issue a public utility right-of-way permit. 
(c)  Issued public utility right-of-way permits are not transferable without prior written consent of the public works director. The public works director shall not unreasonably withhold consent for transfer of a public utility right-of-way permit. 
(d)  A public utility right-of-way permit shall only be valid for the area of the public right-of-way specified within the public utility right-of-way permit. No public utility right-of-way user may cause any excavation to be done outside the area specified in the public utility right-of-way permit. Any public utility right-of-way user who determines that an area greater than that which is specified in the public utility right-of-way permit must be excavated must make an application for a public utility right-of-way permit amendment describing the area in which the excavation will occur prior to the commencement of excavation in that greater area. 
(e)  Public utility right-of-way permits issued shall be available by the public utility right-of-way user at all times at the indicated work site and shall be available for inspection by the public works director, other city employees and the public. 
(Ord. No. 4532, § I, 12-17-07) 
Sec. 22-21. - Construction. 
(a)  Before the start date of any excavation, each public utility right-of-way user who has facilities located in the area to be excavated shall mark the horizontal and approximate vertical placement of all its facilities in accordance with Missouri One Call System. A public utility right-of-way user shall be solely liable for any damages caused by its mismarks. Any public utility right-of-way user whose facilities are less than twenty (20) inches below a concrete or asphalt surface, shall notify and work closely with the person performing excavation in an effort to establish the exact location of its facilities and the best procedure for excavation. 
(b)  The public utility right-of-way user shall provide the director of public works forty-eight (48) hours' written notice before commencing any excavation. 
(c)  The public utility right-of-way user shall provide each occupant of premises adjacent to the project forty-eight (48) hours' written notice before commencing any excavation. 
(d)  The Public utility right-of-way user shall provide the public works director forty-eight (48) hours' prior written notice before the closure of any roadway, highway or street or interruption in traffic flow. 
(e)  All work permitted by the public utility right-of-way permit shall be in accordance with the approved plans and specifications, the terms of the public utility right-of-way permit, and all applicable law. 
(f)  All work allowed under the public utility right-of-way permit shall be completed by the time required in the public utility right-of-way permit and user shall submit a letter of completion. 
(Ord. No. 4532, § I, 12-17-07) 
Sec. 22-22. - Restoration. 
(a)  In the event that the city does not exercise its right to perform restoration work under subsection (b) below, each permittee shall provide for the restoration of the public right-of-way and surrounding areas in accordance with the following requirements: 
(i)  Any public right-of-way within the city which are disturbed or damaged during the work under a public utility right-of-way permit shall be repaired and restored by the public utility right-of-way user; the terms of the public utility right-of-way permit and in all events the public right-of-way shall be repaired and restored to a condition as good as that previously existed before such work was commenced; and 
(ii)  If the public utility right-of-way user fails to restore the public right-of-way as required by this section, the city may restore the public right-of-way itself and the public utility right-of-way user shall reimburse the city for the cost of restoration. 
(b)  The city shall have the option to perform or cause to be performed street restoration work, in which case the public utility right-of-way user shall reimburse city any reasonable and actual restoration work costs within thirty (30) days from a public utility right-of-way user's receipt of a statement from the city for such costs. 
(Ord. No. 4532, § I, 12-17-07) 
Sec. 22-23. - Abandonment of equipment or facilities. 
(a)  Unless otherwise permitted by the city in writing, a public utility right-of-way user shall remove all abandoned equipment or facilities which prevents or significantly impairs the public right-of-way use, repair, excavation or construction, upon receipt of written notice from the city and shall restore any affected public right-of-way in accordance with the standards set forth in this article. In the event a public utility right-of-way user fails to remove such abandoned equipment or facilities, the city may do so at such public utility right-of-way user's cost and expense. 
(b)  The city, upon such terms as it may impose, may give a public utility right-of-way user permission to abandon, without removing, any equipment or facilities, so long as such equipment or facilities abandoned in place does not materially interfere with the use of the public right-of-way, or with the use of the public right-of-way by any public utility right-of-way user. 
(c)  If required by the city, a public utility right-of-way user shall submit to the city an accurate map of all abandoned equipment and facilities. 
(Ord. No. 4532, § I, 12-17-07) 
Sec. 22-24. - Facilities relocation. 
(a)  The public works director may order a public utility right-of-way user, at the public utility right-of-way user's own cost, to permanently or temporarily remove, relocate, protect, support or disconnect its facilities, in the public right-of-way for the following reasons: 
(i)  To prevent interference with a public improvement undertaken by the city; 
(ii)  When necessary, because of traffic conditions, street vacations, freeway grading, sewer, drainage, or tract installation or to otherwise prevent interference with the safety and convenience of ordinary travel over the public right-of-way; or 
(iii)  When required to protect the public health, safety or welfare. 
(Ord. No. 4532, § I, 12-17-07) 
Sec. 22-25. - Damage to property. 
    Each public utility right-of-way user shall be responsible for the cost of repairing any property owned by other persons in the public right-of-way damaged by the public utility right-of-way user or its facilities. Each public utility right-of-way user shall be responsible for the cost of repairing any damage to the property of another person caused during the city's response to an emergency caused by a public utility right-of-way user or its facilities, except for damage caused by the city's gross negligence or willful misconduct. 
(Ord. No. 4532, § I, 12-17-07) 
Sec. 22-26. - Public right-of-way vacation. 
    If the city vacates a public right-of-way, the city shall reserve, for itself and all public utility right-of-way users having facilities in the vacated public right-of-way, the right to install, maintain and operate the facilities in the vacated public right-of-way and to enter upon such public right-of-way at anytime for the purpose of reconstructing, inspecting, maintaining, repairing or restoring the same. The city shall retain all necessary easements in the vacated public right-of-way in existence at the time of vacation. 
(Ord. No. 4532, § I, 12-17-07) 
Sec. 22-27. - Extensions and inspection. 
(a)  Any construction excavation, or restoration work required under this article shall be completed in the time set forth in the public utility right-of-way permit, unless extended. If a public utility right-of-way user is unable to complete the construction, excavation or restoration work within the time set forth in the public utility right-of-way permit due to reasons beyond the public utility right-of-way user's control, upon application to the public works director, the time required for such work shall be extended to the extent of the delay caused by the reason beyond public utility right-of-way user's control. Upon completion of such work, the public utility right-of-way user shall immediately notify the public works director. The public utility right-of-way user shall make the work site available to the public works director and to all others as authorized by law for inspection at any reasonable times during the execution and upon completion of the work. 
(b)  At the time of inspection, the public works director may order the immediate cessation of any work which poses a serious threat to the public health, safety or welfare. 
(c)  The public works director may order a public utility right-of-way user to perform or redo any work which does not conform to this article, or other applicable standards, conditions or the Code. An order issued pursuant to this section shall state that failure to correct the violation will be cause for revocation of the public utility right-of-way permit. Within ten (10) days after issuance of the order, the public utility right-of-way user shall present proof to the public works director that the violations have been corrected. If such proof has not been presented within the required time, the public works director may revoke the public utility right-of-way permit. 
(Ord. No. 4532, § I, 12-17-07) 
Sec. 22-28. - Other obligations. 
(a)  Obtaining a public utility right-of-way permit does not relieve the public utility right-of-way user of its duty to obtain all other necessary permits, licenses and authority and to pay all fees required by any other law. 
(b)  A public utility right-of-way user shall comply with all requirements of law, including Missouri One Call System. 
(c)  A public utility right-of-way user shall perform all work in conformance with all law, and is responsible for all work done in the public right-of-way pursuant to the public utility right-of-way permit, regardless of who performs the work. 
(d)  A public utility right-of-way user shall not obstruct a public right-of-way to the extent that the obstruction interferes with the natural free and clear passage of water through gutters or other waterways. 
(Ord. No. 4532, § I, 12-17-07) 
Sec. 22-29. - Trimming of trees. 
    A public utility right-of-way user shall have the authority to trim trees, in accordance with the city tree ordinance and all easement restrictions, upon and above public right-of-way so as to prevent the branches of such trees from coming in contact with facilities. City representatives shall have the authority to supervise and direct all trimming of trees conducted by a public utility right-of-way user. 
(Ord. No. 4532, § I, 12-17-07) 
Sec. 22-30. - Indemnification. 
(a)  Each public utility right-of-way user: shall indemnify, hold harmless, release and defend the city, its municipal officials, elected officials, boards, commissions, agents, attorneys and employees, from and against any and all lawsuits, claims, causes of action, liability, contractual damages and losses, economic damages and losses, all other damages and losses, and expenses, including reasonable attorneys' fees, resulting or in any manner arising from the action or inaction of a public utility right-of-way user, its agents, representatives, employees, contractors, subcontractors or any other person for whose acts such public utility right-of-way user may be liable, in constructing, operating, maintaining, repairing, restoring or removing facilities, or in carrying on a public utility right-of-way user's business or operations in the city. This indemnity shall apply without limitation, to any claim or cause, of action for invasion of privacy, defamation, antitrust, negligence, theft, fire, violation or infringement of any copyright, trademark, trade name, service mark or patent or intellectual property right of any person, whether or not any act or omission complained of is authorized, allowed or prohibited by this article; and 
(b)  The city shall notify a public utility right-of-way user of any claims subject to indemnification by a public utility right-of-way user and shall cooperate with all reasonable requests by a public utility right-of-way user for information, documents, testimony or other assistance appropriate to a resolution of such claims. A public utility right-of-way user shall have full responsibility for and control of any action or undertaking directed at the resolution of such claims. 
(Ord. No. 4532, § I, 12-17-07) 
Sec. 22-31. - Violation. 
(a)  No public utility right-of-way user shall excavate in the public right-of-way in violation of its permit or this article. Any violation of section 22-353 of this article shall result in the immediate issuance of a citation to the public utility right-of-way user and enforcement action pursuant to subsection 22-374(d) hereof. 
(b)  Except as provided in subsection (a) of this section, if the public works director determines that a public utility right-of-way user has committed a violation of this article, any law, or a condition of the public utility right-of-way permit, the public works director shall make written demand upon the public utility right-of-way user to remedy such violation, which may include the issuance of a stop work order. 
(c)  The public utility right-of-way user shall, within seven (7) calendar days of receiving a notification of a violation, propose a plan to promptly correct such violation. The public utility right-of-way user shall promptly correct such violation in accordance with an approved plan. If the violation creates a threat to public safety, the public utility right-of-way user upon verbal or written notice from the public works director shall immediately correct such violation. A public utility right-of-way user's failure to submit an acceptable plan or to promptly cure a violation shall in addition to all other remedies provided by law because for immediate revocation of the public utility right-of-way permit. 
(d)  Any public utility right-of-way user violating any provision of this article is guilty of a public offense, and upon conviction thereof shall be fined in a sum of not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) every day that this article is violated. Each day's violation shall constitute a separate offense. The city shall have the authority to maintain civil suits or actions in any court of competent jurisdiction for the purpose of enforcing the provisions of this article. In addition to any other remedies, the city attorney may institute injunction, mandamus or other appropriate actions or proceedings to prevent violations of this article. 
(Ord. No. 4532, § I, 12-17-07) 
Sec. 22-32. - Appeals. 
    A public utility right-of-way user that has been denied a public utility right-of-way permit, has had its public utility right-of-way permit revoked, believes that the fees imposed upon it by the city do not conform to the requirements of RSMo 67.1840 or asserts any other issues related to the use of the public right-of-way shall be entitled to have its disputes reviewed in accordance with the City of Lebanon Code Board of Appeals, provided, however, that a decision affirming the denial, revocation, fee imposition or dispute resolution shall be in writing and supported by written findings of fact and conclusions of law, establishing the reasonableness of the decision. 
(Ord. No. 4532, § I, 12-17-07) 
Sec. 22-33. - Separability.
