    If any provision of this article is held by any federal, state or local court, or by any federal or state agency of competent jurisdiction, to be invalid as conflicting with any law, or is held by such court or agency to be modified in any way in order to conform to the requirements of any such law or regulation, such provision shall be considered a separate, distinct and independent part of this article and such holding shall not affect the validity and enforceability of all other provisions hereof. In the event that such law or regulation is subsequently repealed, rescinded, amended or otherwise changed so that the provision which had been held invalid or modified is no longer in conflict with such law, said provision shall return to full force and effect and shall again be binding on the city and each public utility right-of-way user, provided that the city shall give the public utility right-of-way user thirty (30) days, or, a longer period of time as may be reasonably required for the public utility right-of-way user to comply with such a rejuvenated provision, if written notice of the change before requiring compliance with such provision has been given. 
(Ord. No. 4532, § I, 12-17-07) 
Sec. 22-34. - Exceptions. 
(a)  Regardless of any contrary provisions of this article, nothing contained in this article shall relieve the city of any obligations under an existing franchise agreement. 
(b)  Regardless of any contrary provisions of this article, nothing contained in this article shall relieve a public utility right-of-way user of the provisions of an existing franchise, franchise fees, license or other agreement or permit in effect. 
(c)  Regardless of any contrary provisions of this article, nothing contained in this article shall prohibit the city or a public utility right-of-way user from renewing or entering into a new franchise in compliance with applicable law. 
(d)  Regardless of any contrary provisions of this article, nothing contained in this article shall prohibit the city from enacting, renewing or enforcing ordinance articles allowed by the provisions of RSMo 67.1846. 
(e)  Regardless of any contrary provisions of this article, nothing contained in this article shall prevent the city from imposing a franchise fee and other terms and conditions permitted by law in connection with the city granting or renewing a cable franchise. 
(f)  The permitting and other requirements for towers and other structures or equipment for wireless communications facilities in the public right-of-way shall not be governed by this article and shall be governed by other provisions of the Code. 
(Ord. No. 4532, § I, 12-17-07) 
Sec. 22-35. - Unpaved areas-Excavation procedures; barricades erected; inspection; by persons other than public utility right-of-way users. 
    When an excavation is made by persons other than a public utility right-of-way user, in an unpaved portion of any street, alley or sidewalk in the city, the person making the excavation shall provide sufficient barricades and warning signs and lights as are necessary to adequately protect the public until such time as the street, alley or sidewalk shall be restored to its original condition. When the work for which the excavation is made shall have been completed, the person making the excavation shall properly backfill the excavation, shall allow the backfill to settle sufficiently so as to permit final repair. The person making the excavation shall then immediately notify the public works director, who shall inspect the excavation, and upon being satisfied that the requirements of this section have been met, shall relieve the person making the excavation from further liability in connection therewith. 
(Ord. No. 4532, § I, 12-17-07) 
Sec. 22-36. - Paved areas-Excavation procedures; barricades erected; inspection, backfilling; by persons other than a public utility right-of-way user. 
    When an excavation is made by persons other than a public utility right-of-way user, in the paved portion of any street, alley or sidewalk, the person making the excavation shall perform proper street cut methods to assure minimal damage and provide sufficient barricades, warning signs, and lights as are necessary to adequately protect the public until the work shall have been completed. Upon completion, the person making the excavation shall immediately notify the public works director who shall immediately inspect the same, and shall relieve the person making the excavation from further liability in connection therewith. 
(Ord. No. 4532, § I, 12-17-07) 
Sec. 22-37. - Unlawful digging or excavating; authority of city to remove, alter or reconstruct existing obstructions in streets and alleys. 
(a)  No person shall unlawfully dig any ditch, or make any excavation in or upon the streets, sidewalks, gutters, alleys or highways in the city so as to endanger the safety of persons or animals, or so as to obstruct travel. 
(b)  The city shall have the right and authority to remove, alter or reconstruct any existing obstructions of the streets and alleys of the city and that the same shall be accomplished at no cost to the property owner. 
(Ord. No. 4532, § I, 12-17-07) 
Sec. 22-38. - Permit required for construction of driveways, curbs, etc. 
    Unless an access permit is first obtained from the building and zoning administrator, the construction of driveways, curbs, sidewalks or other obstructions which obstruct the streets or alleys of the city is prohibited, unless a permit is first obtained from the public works director and the construction performed in a manner as approved by the public works director as to line and grade. No charge shall be made by the city for the issuance of such permits. 
(Ord. No. 4532, § I, 12-17-07) 
Sec. 22-39. - Reservation of rights; city's failure to enforce. 
(a)  In addition to any rights specifically reserved to the city by this article, the city reserves unto itself every right and power which is required to be reserved by a provision of any ordinance under any registration, permit or other authorization granted under this article. 
(b)  The city may grant a special exception to the requirements of this article if an applicant, upon application, demonstrates with written evidence that the exception will not create any threat to the public health, safety or welfare, and: 
(i)  The applicant demonstrates that the increased economic burden and the potential adverse impact on the applicant's construction schedule resulting from the strict enforcement of the requirement actually or effectively prohibits the ability of the applicant to provide public utility services in the city; or 
(ii)  The applicant demonstrates that the requirement unreasonably discriminates against the applicant in favor of another public utility right-of-way user. 
(c)  A grant of special exception to the requirements of this section pursuant to subsection 22-34(b) shall not be deemed to be a waiver of any other requirement of this section or this article or constitute a waiver of any requirement with respect to a new or separate public utility right-of-way permit. 
(d)  The city's failure to enforce or remedy any noncompliance of the terms and conditions of this article or of any public utility right-of-way permit granted hereunder shall not constitute a waiver of the city's rights nor a waiver of any public utility right-of-way user's obligations as herein provided. 
(Ord. No. 4532, § I, 12-17-07) 
Sec. 22-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CONSTRUCTION AND MAINTENANCE OF STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal control over sidewalks in cities of 30,000 or less, RSMo 88.883 et seq.; municipal authority to construct and maintain streets and sidewalks in third class cities, RSMo 88.507. 

Sec. 22-41. - Approval of plan. 
    No street or sidewalk shall be constructed on public property or public streets until the city council has been presented with a complete plan of proposed improvement and has approved it by a five-eighths majority. 
Sec. 22-42. - Functional classification of streets. 
    For the purpose of planning the orderly extension and improvement of the streets in the city, the public streets are as classified in the comprehensive plan of the city and access guidelines are as set forth in Appendix B of the Code. 
(Ord. No. 4509, § 2, 10-15-07) 
Sec. 22-43. - Street dedication. 
    Any proposition to dedicate any public right-of-way for street purposes shall be first referred to the zoning and planning commission to assure compliance and orderly extension of the comprehensive plan, and the other requirements of this article and other applicable city ordinances. 
Sec. 22-44. - New building construction limitations. 
    No building permit shall be issued for, and no building shall be erected on any lot, which is shown on the comprehensive plan as future right-of-way acquisition for major or collector streets. 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6. 
Sec. 22-45. - Street construction policy. 
(a)  The cost of bringing new streets to grade and the cost of the constructing curbs and gutters appurtenant thereto shall be borne by the subdivider developing the property containing the new streets and the appurtenances thereto. The city shall pay for the paving of the streets graded by the subdivider, as provided in this article. 
(b)  If a new street is constructed by the city in an area which is not part of a new subdivision, the city will bear the entire cost of its construction and paving. 
Sec. 22-46. - Street maintenance policy. 
(a)  The city will maintain and repair without charge to abutting property, all streets, upon recommendation of the city engineer, and which are in existence or under contract for construction at the time of passage of this Code. 
(b)  If, in the course of the maintenance and repair of existing streets, existing sidewalks, curbs or gutters are damaged or removed by the city, the city will restore without charge to abutting property, all sidewalks, curbs or gutters so damaged or removed. 
Sec. 22-47. - Street specifications. 
    Streets constructed, repaired or maintained in the city shall conform to the requirements of specifications on file in the office of the city engineer. 
Sec. 22-48. - Condemnation of sidewalks. 
    The city council may, by ordinance, condemn any sidewalk which they deem to be in a dangerous or defective condition or out of repair, or any sidewalk which is not located upon the established grade and line for sidewalks (on the street on which it is located, as provided by the ordinances of the city), or any sidewalk which does not conform to the specifications and requirements for sidewalks in the city, as provided by the ordinances of the city, and to provide for the removal of any sidewalk so condemned. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 88.873. 
Sec. 22-49. - Duty of property owners regarding sidewalks, approaches, etc. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the owner of any lot, tract or parcel of ground abutting upon, or lying adjacent to any public street or avenue within the city, to construct, maintain and keep in good repair suitable sidewalks of the kind and dimensions described in this article for the use of the public, along the sides, ends or other boundaries of any such lot, tract or parcel of ground where it abuts upon or lies adjacent to any such public street or avenue. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the owner of any lot, tract or parcel of ground lying, abutting or being adjacent to the intersection of any street or avenue within the city, and being what is commonly termed a corner lot, to build approaches to the sidewalks along, abutting or adjacent to the property of any such owner. Approaches shall be constructed of the same material and the same width as the sidewalks with which the approaches shall connect and shall extend from the ends of the sidewalks and slope or decline to the top of the curb of the streets or avenues. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of the owner of any lot, tract or parcel of ground abutting upon or lying adjacent to any public street or avenue within the city which is paved, to level or fill the space between the curbstone of any such payment and the sidewalk along any such street or avenue with suitable soil or dirt to grow grass in, and the same shall be leveled or filled so as to make a smooth surface over any such space, and to be level with the sidewalk of any such street or avenue, and slope or decline to the top of the curbstone of any such pavement. 
(Code 1967, § 22-21; Ord. No. 1780, § 1, 8-25-69) 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to require sidewalk, approach etc., maintenance by abutting property owners, RSMo 88.877. 
Sec. 22-50. - Notice to abutting property owners; violation, penalty for failure to comply. 
(a)  Whenever the city engineer shall, upon inspection, find a sidewalk or area thereof in need of construction, repair or maintenance, he shall notify in writing the record owner of the property abutting any such sidewalk, directing him to construct, repair or maintain such sidewalk, as the case may be within thirty (30) days from the date the notice is given. Notice provided for in this section may be given by certified mail addressed to the last known address of the owner of record or by personal service upon the owner of record, and if there should be more than one owner of record, then by mail or personal service to any one of the owners. If the owner of the abutting property shall be unknown or his whereabouts unknown, notice shall be given by posting the same upon the property. 
(b)  No abutting property owner shall be given a permit to repair or reconstruct any sidewalk abutting his property if the thirty (30) days provided in this section shall have passed and if the city shall have in any way begun to cause any such sidewalk to be constructed, repaired or maintained. 
(c)  If the owner of the property abutting the sidewalk to be constructed, repaired or maintained shall fail to so construct, repair or maintain within thirty (30) days from the date notice is given to do so, the city, paying the cost thereof out of the fund available therefor, shall cause the sidewalk to be constructed, repaired or maintained either by city forces or by a contractor retained by the city, and the cost thereof, assessed against the abutting property owner as a special tax bill and made a lien on his property. 
(d)  Failure by any abutting property owner to comply with the requirements set forth in the notice authorized by this section is an offense, and upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by the assessment of a fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(Code 1967, § 22-20; Ord. No. 1780, § 1, 8-25-69) 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to cause notice to be given abutting property owners, to create violation and penalty for failure to comply, RSMo 88.877; assessment of cost of maintenance against abutting property owners, RSMo 88.883, 88.893. 
Sec. 22-51. - Construction, rebuilding, reconstruction of sidewalks by the city. 
(a)  The city council may, by ordinance, provide for the building of any sidewalk or for the rebuilding and reconstruction thereof, including grading and filling therefor, including the removal of any obstructions, including approaches at corner lots and including the grading or parking of that portion of the street lying between the property line and the street curb line, by contract, and levy a special assessment against each lot or tract along which such work is done, for the cost thereof. No contract shall be let until the plans and specifications for the work have been adopted by ordinance (provided, the adoption may be by reference to general plans and specifications, which have already been adopted by ordinance by the city). 
(b)  No contract shall be let until an advertisement for bids for the doing of the work has been published in at least one issue of a weekly newspaper or at least two (2) consecutive issues of a daily newspaper, published in the city. The date for the opening of the bids shall be at least ten (10) days after the date of the first publication of the advertisement for bids. Before the bids are opened, the city engineer, or other proper person designated by ordinance by the city council, shall prepare and file an estimate showing the estimated quantities of grading, filling and of the various materials required for the sidewalk in front of each separate lot, tract or parcel of ground, and an estimate of the cost of the work per cubic yard or per square yard, as the case may be, and an estimate of the cost of the removal of any obstruction. No contract shall be let for a price in excess of the estimate of the cost. 
(c)  After the bids are opened by the city council, the city council shall let the contract for the work to the lowest and best responsible bidder, and in case there are no bids received, or that all bids are rejected for any reason, the city council may readvertise for bids for the work, or may, by ordinance, order and require the city engineer or other proper person to build and construct the sidewalk or do the other work as herein contemplated, according to the specifications adopted therefor (provided, however, that the cost of the work shall not exceed the estimate of the city engineer previously filed), keeping an accurate account of the cost of the separate items thereof. The city council shall pay for the labor and material and all other costs of the work out of any funds which they may have on hand available for such a purpose. At the completion of the work (either by contract or by the city) the city council shall levy the cost thereof as a special assessment against the lot, tract or parcel of ground along which each of the sidewalks or other improvements is made. 
(Code 1967, §§ 22-16, 22-19, 22-22, 22-24; Ord. No. 1780, § 1, 8-25-69) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 88.880. 
Sec. 22-52. - Construction of sidewalks by subdividers. 
    Where a new sidewalk is to be built in an area located within a new subdivision, the entire cost of the construction thereof shall be borne by the subdivider thereof. 
Cross reference- Subdivision regulations, Ch. 23. 
Sec. 22-53. - Sidewalk districts. 
(a)  The city council may, when deemed necessary or expedient, divide the city or any portion thereof into sidewalk districts, by ordinance, and may adopt plans and specifications for the building of all sidewalks within the district. The city council may advertise for bids and award a contract to the lowest and best responsible bidder for the building and construction of all sidewalks which it may order be built within the district for the next ensuing year. The advertisement for bids shall be published in at least one issue of a weekly newspaper or in at least two (2) consecutive issues of a daily newspaper published in the city. 
(b)  And before the bids are opened or any contract let, the city engineer or other proper person designated by the city council by ordinance, shall prepare and submit to the city council as estimate of the cost of the sidewalk, including approaches, grading and parking, material, etc. The estimate shall be the price per cubic yard or square yard, as the case may be, for the finished improvement, and no contract shall be let for a price in excess of the estimate. The cost of all sidewalks, approaches, parking or other improvement herein contemplated shall be, on their completion, levied as a special assessment against the lot, tract or parcel of ground along and in front of which the improvement is made. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 88.887. 
Sec. 22-54. - Sidewalk specifications. 
    Sidewalks constructed, repaired or maintained in the city shall conform to the requirements of specifications on file in the office of the city engineer. 
(Code 1967, § 22-25) 
Sec. 22-55. - Construction, rebuilding, reconstruction and repair of sidewalks, sewers and streets and special assessments for said improvements. 
(a)  The city council may, by ordinance, provide for construction and repairing sidewalks and sidewalk curbing, and for sewers, and for construction and/or reconstruction, grading, paving, excavating and macadamizing, curbing and guttering of any street, avenue, alley, square or other highway, or part thereof, and repairing the same and levy a special assessment against each lot or tract along which such work is done, for the cost thereof. At the time the council determines that a public improvement provided for in this subsection should be made, the council shall cause plans and specifications for any project, together with an estimate of the total cost for the project, including construction, construction contingency and fees and other expenses and an estimate of the portion of the total cost to be assessed against each property to be benefited by the project, to be prepared by the city engineer or other proper officer, and filed with the city, subject to inspection by the public, and shall schedule a public hearing on the proposed public improvement, which notice shall set forth the costs, expenses and fee estimate of the improvement. The notice shall be published in a newspaper for seven (7) consecutive insertions in a daily newspaper. 
(b)  The notice shall set forth the day, time and location of the said hearing, which shall be held no less than ten (10) days and no more than twenty-one (21) days after the last insertion of the notice in the daily newspaper mentioned above. At the time of the hearing, the citizens of the community and affected landowners may express their assent or objection to the project. 
(c)  After the hearing is conducted, the council shall determine by majority vote whether or not the project shall proceed and if the project is approved, the council shall determine whether the project shall be constructed by the city or whether a contract shall be let to a contractor who will be responsible for completion of the project. 
(d)  In the event the council determines that a contract shall be let, then the bid procedure outlined in the first two (2) sentences of subsections 22-51(b) and 22-51(c) shall be followed. 
(e)  After the completion of the work, the city council shall pay for the labor and material and all other costs of the work out of the funds which they may have on hand available for such purpose. At the completion of the work (either by contract or by the city) the council shall levy the cost thereof as a special assessment against the lot, tract or parcel of ground along which each of the improvement or improvements are made. 
(f)  These special tax bills may include a reasonable construction contingency and an amount not to exceed twenty (20) percent of the total cost of the improvement to be used for payment of fees and other expenses and tax bills may bear interest not to exceed the rate on ten-year United States treasury notes as established at the most recent auction; all tax bills shall be due and payable sixty (60) days after the date of the issue thereof, except in the case of tax bills payable as provided in subsection (g); every special tax bill shall be a lien against the lot or tract or parcel of land described in said special tax bill for a period of ten (10) years after date of issue or the due date whichever is sooner, unless sooner paid, except in cases of special tax bills payable as provided in subsection (g), the lien of which shall not expire until one year after the date of maturity of the last installment or one year after the maturity date set forth in any separate agreement that may have been entered into with the city, and except in any case where it becomes necessary to bring suit to enforce the lien of any special tax bill, the lien shall continue until the expiration of the litigation. 
(g)  The special tax bills may be paid in ten (10) annual installments. In such case the tax bills shall be payable in annual installments as follows: One-tenth ( 1/10 ) in one year, one-tenth ( 1/10 ) in two (2) years, one-tenth ( 1/10 ) in three (3) years, one-tenth ( 1/10 ) in four (4) years, one-tenth ( 1/10 ) in five (5) years, one-tenth ( 1/10 ) in six (6) years, one-tenth ( 1/10 ) in seven (7) years, one-tenth ( 1/10 ) in eight (8) years, one-tenth ( 1/10 ) in nine (9) years and one-tenth ( 1/10 ) in ten (10) years after the date of their issue, and tax bills may bear interest not to exceed the rate on ten-year United States treasury notes as established at the most recent auction, payable annually, from sixty (60) days after the date of issue until paid, and shall provide that if any annual installment, or the interest thereon, is not paid when due, then all of the remaining installments shall, at the option of the holder of the tax bill, become immediately due and payable; provided, that the owner of property charged with the payment of the tax bill, or the owner of any interest therein, shall have the privilege of paying the whole of any tax bill in full at any time, or on any annual installment payment date of paying in full one or more of the remaining installments not of maturity date. The council may also agree, in special circumstances, by separate written agreement with any landowner to an alternate plan for payment of the special tax bills, which agreement shall be recorded in the real estate records with the Laclede County, Missouri, Recorder of Deeds. 
(Ord. No. 4027, § 1, 10-10-00) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4027, § 1, adopted Oct. 10, 2000, repealed § 22-55 and enacted a new section as set out herein. The former § 22-55 pertained to enforcement of sidewalk assessments and derived from Code 1967, § 22-24; and Ord. No. 1780, § 1, adopted Aug. 25, 1969. 
Sec. 22-56. - Enforcement of sidewalk, sewer and street special assessments. 
    If any assessment for sidewalk construction, repair or maintenance, or for the construction of sewers or for the construction and/or reconstruction, grading, paving, excavating and macadamizing, curbing and guttering of any street, avenue, alley, square or other highway, or part thereof, is not paid by the due date, the city attorney shall cause proceedings to be taken in a court of competent jurisdiction to foreclose the lien of the assessment. Proof of the entry of the assessment upon the assessment of tax record shall be prima facie evidence in any such proceedings of the validity of the assessment and the lien thereof; no lien for any such assessment, or the assessment itself, shall be invalid for failure to give any notice set forth in this article, for mistake in description of land assessed, for error in ownership, or for error in the assessment amount to the extent of the amount shown correct. 
(Ord. No. 4027, § 1, 10-10-00) 
State Law reference- Special tax bills prima facie evidence, RSMo 88.903; suit to enforce collection of special tax bill, RSMo 88.913. 
Chapter 23 - SUBDIVISION REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- The Exhibit A referred to herein, approved by Ord. No. 3157, adopted April 23, 1984, was replaced by a new Exhibit A which was adopted by reference. The aforesaid Exhibit A, as approved by Ord. No. 3321, § 10, adopted January 10, 1989, is on file with the city clerk and not reproduced herein. 
Cross reference- Regulation-making authority, § 2-851; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6; flood control standards for subdivision proposals, § 11-42; planning and development, Ch. 17; construction of sidewalks by subdividers, § 22-52. 
State Law reference- Regulations governing subdivision of land, RSMo 89.410. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 23-1. - Interpretation; purpose. 
    In its interpretation and application, the provisions of this chapter shall be held to be the minimum requirements adopted for the protection of the public health, safety and welfare. To protect the public, among other purposes, such provisions are intended to provide for permanently wholesome community environment, adequate municipal services and safe streets. 
(Ord. No. 3157, § 2, 4-23-84) 
Sec. 23-2. - Scope. 
    This chapter shall not apply to any lot or lots forming a part of a subdivision created and recorded prior to April 23, 1984. Nor is it intended by this chapter to repeal, abrogate, annul or in any way impair or interfere with existing provisions of other laws or ordinances, except those specifically repealed by the ordinance from which this chapter was derived, or with private or with restrictive covenants running with the land to which the city is a party. Where this chapter imposes a greater restriction upon land than is imposed or required by such existing provisions of law, ordinance, contract or deed, the provisions of this chapter shall control. 
(Ord. No. 3157, § 3, 4-23-84) 
Sec. 23-3. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
    Alley shall mean a minor way which is used primarily for vehicular service access to the back of the side of properties otherwise abutting on a street. 
    Arterial street shall mean a fast or heavy traffic street of considerable continuity and used primarily as a traffic artery for intercommunication among large areas. 
    Collector street shall mean a street which carries traffic from minor streets to arterial streets, including the principal entrance streets of a residential development and streets for circulation within such a development. 
    Comprehensive plan and zoning regulations shall mean the comprehensive plan and zoning regulations prepared by the zoning and planning commission which indicates the general locations recommended for the various functional classes of public works, places and structures and for the general physical development of the city, and includes any unit or part of such plan separately adopted and any amendment to such plan or parts thereof. It also includes the map established by the city council showing the streets, highways and parks theretofore laid out, adopted and established by law, and any amendments thereto adopted by the city council or additions thereto resulting from the approval of subdivision plats by the planning commission and the subsequent filing of such approved plats. 
    Cul-de-sac or dead-end street shall mean a minor street with only one outlet. 
    Final plat shall mean the final map, drawing or chart on which the subdivider's plan of subdivision is presented to the zoning and planning commission for approval, and which, if approved, will be submitted to the city council for its approval before recording. 
    Lot shall mean a parcel or portion of land in a subdivision or plat of land, separated from other parcels or portions by description as on a subdivision or record of survey map or by metes and bounds, for the purpose of sale or lease to, or separate use of, another. 
    Marginal access street shall mean a minor street which is parallel and adjacent to arterial streets which provides access to abutting properties and protection from through traffic. 
    Minor street shall mean a street used primarily for access to the abutting properties. 
    Monument shall mean an iron pin or surveyor marker. 
    Owner shall mean any individual, firm, association, syndicate, co-partnership, corporation, trust or any other legal entity having sufficient proprietary interest in the land sought to be subdivided to commend and maintain proceedings to subdivide the same under this chapter. 
    Preliminary plat shall mean the preliminary map, drawing or chart indicating the proposed layout of the subdivision to be submitted to the zoning and planning commission for its consideration. 
    Street shall mean a way for vehicular traffic, whether designated as a street, highway, thoroughfare, parkway, throughway, road, avenue, boulevard, lane, place, or however otherwise designated. 
    Street width shall mean the shortest distance between the lines delineating the right-of-way of a street. 
    Subdivider shall mean any individual, firm, association, syndicate, co-partnership, corporation, trust, or any other legal entity commencing proceedings under this chapter to effect a subdivision of land hereunder for himself or for another. 
    Subdivision shall mean the division of a parcel of land into two or more lots or parcels for the purpose of transfer of ownership or building development, or, if a new street is involved, any division of a parcel of land; provided that a division of land which may be ordered or approved by a court or effected by testamentary or interstate provisions, or a division of land for agricultural purposes into lots or parcels of acres or more and not involving a new street shall not be deemed a subdivision. The term includes resubdivision and, when appropriate to the context, shall relate to the process of subdividing or to the land subdivided. 
(Ord. No. 3157, § 4, 4-23-84) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Streets, subdivision defined, RSMo 89.300(2), (3). 
Sec. 23-4. - Conformance with chapter required. 
    No person shall subdivide any tract of land which is located within the city except in conformity with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 3157, § 5, 4-23-84) 
Sec. 23-5. - Public improvements to be withheld from unapproved subdivisions. 
    The city hereby defines its policy to be that the city shall withhold all public improvements of whatsoever nature, including the maintenance of streets and the furnishing of sewerage facilities and water service from all subdivisions which have not been approved, and from all areas dedicated to the public which have not been accepted by the city council, in the manner prescribed in this chapter. The city also reserves the right to determine in which areas of the city it is feasible to extend water, sewer and electrical service and the city reserves the right to deny service to any and all areas determined to be too far from existing facilities. 
(Ord. No. 3157, § 6(4), 4-23-84; Ord. No. 3321, § 4, 1-10-89) 
Sec. 23-6. - Variances. 
(a)  Generally. The board of appeals may authorize a variance from the regulations of this chapter and the additional provisions set forth in Appendix B of this Code when, in its opinion, undue hardship may result from strict compliance therewith. In granting any variance, the board of appeals shall prescribe only conditions that it deems necessary to or desirable for the public interest. In making its findings, as required herein, the board of appeals shall take into account the nature of the proposed use of land and the existing use of land in the vicinity, the number of persons to reside or work in the proposed subdivision and the probable effect of the proposed use of land and the existing use of land in the vicinity, the number of persons to reside or work in the proposed subdivision and the probable effect of the proposed subdivision upon traffic conditions in the vicinity. No variance shall be granted unless the board of appeals shall find that: 
(1)  There are special circumstances or conditions affecting the property such that the strict application of the provisions of this chapter would deprive the applicant of the reasonable use of his/her land; 
(2)  The variance is necessary for the preservation and enjoyment of a substantial property right of the petitioner; and 
(3)  The granting of the variance will not be detrimental to the public welfare or injurious to other property in the territory in which the property is situated. 
(b)  Complete neighborhood. The board of appeals may authorize a variance from the regulations of this chapter in case of a plan for a complete community, or neighborhood which, in the judgment of the board of appeals, provides adequate public spaces and includes provisions for the efficient circulation, light and air and other needs. In making its findings, as require herein the board of appeals shall take into account the nature of the proposed use of land and the existing use of the land in the vicinity, the number of persons to reside or work in the proposed subdivision and the probable effect of the proposed subdivision upon traffic conditions in the vicinity. No variance shall be granted unless the board of appeals shall find that: 
(1)  The proposed project will constitute a desirable and stable community development; 
(2)  The proposed project will be in harmony with adjacent areas. 
(c)  Applications required. Application for variance to be heard by the board of appeals under subsection (a) shall be submitted in writing by the subdivider at the time when the preliminary plat is filed for consideration of the board of appeals. The petition shall state fully the grounds for the application and all the facts relied upon by the petitioner. Application for variance under subsection (b) shall be made in writing by the subdivider at the time when the preliminary plat is filed for the consideration of the board of appeals, stating fully and clearly all facts relied upon by the petitioner and shall be supplemented with maps, plans and other additional data which may aid the board of appeals in the analysis of the proposed project. The plans for such development shall include such covenants, restrictions or other legal provisions necessary to guarantee the full achievement of the plan. 
(Ord. No. 3157, § 12, 4-23-84; Ord. No. 4509, § 3, 10-15-07; Ord. No. 4921, § 1, 10-17-11) 
Secs. 23-7-23-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DESIGN STANDARDS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to regulate size, location and use of buildings, etc., to promote health, safety, morals or general welfare of the community, RSMo 89.020. 

Sec. 23-21. - Conformity with comprehensive plan, zoning regulations and minimum construction and building standards required. 
    All proposed subdivisions shall conform to the city's comprehensive plan, to all zoning regulations of the city, and with the minimum construction and building standards for sewer, water, sidewalks, streets, curbs, gutters, storm drainage and electrical facilities as adopted by the city council pursuant to section 2-851 hereof. 
(Ord. No. 3157, § 8(A), 4-23-84; Ord. No. 3321, § 3, 1-10-89) 
Sec. 23-22. - Streets. 
(a)  Conformity. The arrangement, character, extend, width, grade and location of all streets shall conform to the city's comprehensive plan and zoning regulations and access management guidelines as set forth in Appendix B of the Code, and shall be considered in their relationship to existing and planned streets, to topographical conditions, to public convenience and safety, and in their appropriate relation to the proposed uses of the land to be served by such streets. Where not shown on the comprehensive plan and zoning regulations, the arrangement and other design standards of streets shall conform to the provisions found in this section and access management guidelines as set forth in Appendix B of the Code. 
(b)  Relation to adjoining street system. The arrangement of streets in new subdivisions shall make provision for the continuation of the existing streets in adjoining areas. 
(c)  Projection of streets. Where adjoining areas are not subdivided, the arrangement of streets in new subdivisions shall make provision for the proper projection of streets. 
(d)  Streets to be carried to property lines. When a new subdivision adjoins unsubdivided land susceptible of being subdivided, then the new streets shall be carried to the boundaries of the tract proposed to be subdivided. 
(e)  Street jogs prohibited. Street jogs with centerline offset of less than one hundred (100) feet shall be avoided. 
(f)  Dead-end street or cul-de-sac. Dead-end streets or cul-de-sacs designed to be so permanently, shall not be longer than eight hundred (800) feet and shall be provided at the closed end with a turn-around having an outside roadway diameter of at least sixty (60) feet, and a street property line diameter of at least one hundred (100) feet. If a dead-end street is of a temporary nature, a similar turn-around shall be provided and provision made for future extension of the street into adjoining properties. (See Exhibit A at the end of this chapter). 
(g)  Marginal access streets. Where a subdivision abuts or contains an existing arterial street, the zoning and planning commission may require marginal access streets or other such treatment as may be necessary for adequate protection of residential properties and to afford separation of through and local traffic. 
(h)  Minor streets. Minor streets shall be so laid out that their use by through traffic will be discouraged. 
(i)  Street widths. Street widths shall not be less than as follows: 
  Width,
Street type     in feet 
Arterial ..... 66 
Collector ..... 60 
Minor, for row houses and apartments ..... 60 
Minor, for other residences ..... 60 
Marginal access ..... 60 
(See Exhibit A). 
In front of areas designed and zoned or where a petition for a change in zoning is contemplated for commercial use, to permit such use, the street width shall be increased by such amount on each side as may be deemed necessary by the zoning and planning commission to assure the free flow of through traffic without interference by parked or parking vehicles and to provide safe parking space for such commercial and business district. 
(j)  Intersection. The intersection of more than two (2) streets at one point shall be avoided except where it is impracticable to secure a proper street system otherwise. Streets shall intersect one another at an angle as near to a right angle as possible, and no intersections of streets at angles less than sixty (60) degrees shall be approved. 
(k)  Street deflections. When connecting street lines deflect from each other at any one point by more than ten (10) degrees, they shall be connected by a curve with a radius adequate to insure a slight distance of not less than one hundred (100) feet for minor and collector streets, and of such greater radii as the zoning and planning commission shall determine for special cases. 
(l)  Reverse curves. A tangent at least fifty (50) feet long shall be introduced between reverse curves on arterial and collector streets. 
(m)  Subdivision into tracts larger than ordinary building lots. Where a tract is subdivided into larger parcels than ordinary building lots, such parcels shall be arranged so as to allow the opening of future streets and logical further resubdivision. 
(n)  Reserve strips. Reserve strips controlling access to streets shall be prohibited except under conditions approved by the zoning and planning commission. 
(o)  Street grades. No street grade shall be less than four percent and shall not exceed the following, with due allowance for reasonable vertical curves: 
Percent grade,
 Street type       in percent 
Arterial ..... 10 
Collector ..... 15 
Minor ..... 15 
Marginal Access ..... 15 
(See Exhibit A). 
(p)  Railroad on or abutting subdivision. Where a subdivision borders on or contains a railroad right-of-way or limited access highway right-of-way, the zoning and planning commission may require a street approximately parallel to and on each side of such right-of-way, at a distance suitable for the appropriate use of the intervening land, as for park purposes in residential districts, or for commercial or industrial purposes in appropriate districts. Such distances shall also be determined with due regard for the requirements of approach grades and future grade separations. 
(q)  Half-streets prohibited. Half-streets shall be prohibited, except where essential to the reasonable development of the subdivision in conformity with the other requirements of these regulations and where the zoning and planning commission finds it will be practicable to require the dedication of the other half when the adjoining property is subdivided. Wherever a half-street is adjacent to a tract to be subdivided, the other half of the street shall be platted within such tract. 
(r)  Street names and numbers. Names and new streets shall not duplicate existing or platted street names unless a new street is a continuation of, or in alignment with the existing or platted street. All new streets shall be named in coordination with the building inspector. 
(s)  Access to streets across ditches. The subdivider shall provide access to all proposed streets, across all ditches, in a standard method approved by the city engineer. 
(t)  Vacation of streets. The zoning and planning commission shall not recommend the vacation of any street or part of a street dedicated for public use, if such vacation interferes with the uniformity of the existing street pattern of any future street plans prepared for the area. 
(u)  Private streets. Private streets shall not be approved nor shall public improvements be approved for any private street. 
(v)  Hardship to owners of adjoining property avoided. The street arrangements shall not be such as to cause hardship to owners of adjoining property in platting their own land and providing convenient access to it. 
(w)  Street interval. In general, provisions should be made for through streets at intervals not exceeding six hundred sixty (660) feet, except as provided for in Appendix B of the Code. 
(Ord. No. 3157, § 8(B), 4-23-84; Ord. No. 4434, §§ 1, 2, 10-30-06; Ord. No. 4509, § 4, 10-15-07) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 22. 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to coordinate streets in subdivisions with existing streets to provide adequate space for traffic, recreation, light and air, RSMo 89.410(1); municipal authority to regulate grading and improving streets, RSMo 89.410(2). 
Sec. 23-23. - Alleys. 
(a)  Residential areas. Alleys shall not be permitted in residential areas. 
(b)  Commercial and industrial districts. Alleys shall be provided in commercial and industrial districts, except that the zoning and planning commission may waive this requirement where other definite and assured provision is made for service access, such as off-street loading, unloading, and parking consistent with and adequate for the uses proposed. 
(c)  Width. The right-of-way width of an alley shall be twenty-five (25) feet. 
(d)  Dead-end. Dead-end alleys shall not be permitted, except that the zoning and planning commission may waive this requirement where such dead-end alley is unavoidable and where adequate turn-around facilities have been provided. 
(e)  See Exhibit A at the end of this chapter for further alley design standards. 
(Ord. No. 3157, § 8(C), 4-23-84) 
Sec. 23-24. - Easements. 
(a)  Provided for utilities. Easements with a right-of-way width of five (5) feet shall be provided on the front of each lot line and other easements as required by the City of Lebanon. 
(b)  Provided for drainage. Where a subdivision is traversed by a water course, drainageway, channel, or stream, there shall be provided a storm water easement or drainage right-of-way conforming substantially with the lines of such water course, and such further width or construction, or both, as will be adequate for the purpose. 
(c)  See Exhibit A at the end of this chapter for further easement design standards. 
(Ord. No. 3157, § 8(D), 4-23-84; Ord. No. 4434, §§ 3, 4, 10-30-06) 
Cross reference- Utilities, Ch. 26. 
Sec. 23-25. - Blocks. 
(a)  Factors governing dimensions. Block length and width or acreage within bounding roads shall be such as to accommodate the size of lot required in the area by the city's zoning ordinance and to provide for convenient access circulation control and safety of street traffic. 
(b)  Lengths. Block lengths shall not exceed eight hundred (800) feet or be less than four hundred (400) feet. 
(c)  Arrangements. A block shall be so designed as to provide two (2) tiers of lots. 
(d)  Cross-walks. In blocks over six hundred (600) feet long, pedestrian cross-walks may be required by the zoning and planning commission in locations deemed necessary to public health, convenience and necessity. Such cross-walks shall be ten (10) feet wide and be straight from street to street. 
(e)  See Exhibit A at the end of this chapter for further block design standards. 
(f)  See Appendix B of the Code for further access management guidelines. 
(Ord. No. 3157, § 8(E), 4-23-84; Ord. No. 4509, § 5, 10-15-07) 
Sec. 23-26. - Lots. 
(a)  Dimensions. Lot dimensions and area shall not be less than the requirements of the city's zoning ordinance. 
(b)  Location. All lots shall abut by their full frontage on a publicly dedicated street or a street that has received the legal status as such. 
(c)  Lines. Side lot lines shall be substantially at right angles to straight lines or radial to curved street lines. 
(d)  Corner lots. Corner lots for residential use shall have extra width to permit appropriate building setback from orientation to both streets. Lots abutting on a pedestrian walkway shall not be treated as a corner lot. 
(e)  Uninhabitable lots. Lots subject to flooding and lots deemed by the zoning and planning commission to be uninhabitable shall not be platted for residential occupancy, nor for such other uses as may increase danger to health, life or property or aggravate the flood hazard, but such land within the plat shall be set aside for such uses as shall not be endangered by periodic or occasional inundation or shall not produce unsatisfactory living conditions. 
(f)  Lot remnants. All remnants of lots below minimum size left over after subdividing of a larger tract must be added to adjacent lots, rather than allowed to remain as unusable parcels. 
(g)  See Exhibit A at the end of this chapter for further lot design standards. 
(Ord. No. 3157, § 8(F), 4-23-84) 
Sec. 23-27. - Public sites and open spaces. 
(a)  Shown on comprehensive plan. Where a proposed park, playground, school or other public use shown in a comprehensive plan is located in whole or in part within a subdivision, the subdivision shall dedicate or reserve adequate space for such purpose in such area within the subdivision when the zoning and planning commission finds the requirement to be reasonably necessary to the public health and welfare. 
(b)  Action not constituting acceptance. The requiring of the dedication of public spaces as provided in subsection (a) above shall not constitute an acceptance of the dedication by the city. 
(Ord. No. 3157, § 8(G), 4-23-84) 
Cross reference- Parks and recreation, Ch. 15; streets, sidewalks and other public spaces, Ch. 22. 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to provide for the dedication, reservation or acquisition of lands and open spaces necessary for public uses indicated on city plan, RSMo 89.410(1). 
Sec. 23-28. - Access management guidelines. 
    The access management guidelines set forth in Appendix B are hereby incorporated herein by reference. 
(Ord. No. 4509, § 6, 10-15-07) 
Secs. 23-29-23-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PLAT PREPARATION AND APPROVAL PROCEDURES[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Plats, RSMo Ch. 445. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 23-41. - Use of unapproved plat in sale of land prohibited. 
    No owner or agent of the owner of any land located within a subdivision shall transfer, sell, agree to sell, or negotiate to sell any land by reference to exhibition of, or by the use of a plan or plat of a subdivision before such plan or plat has been approved and recorded in the manner prescribed herein. The description of such lot or parcel by metes and bounds in the instrument of transfer or other documents used in the process of selling or transferring shall not exempt the transaction from the provision of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 3157, § 6(2), 4-23-84) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 89.450. 
Sec. 23-42. - Issuance of certain permits prohibited absent plat approval. 
    The building and zoning administrator shall not issue building or repair permits for any structure on a lot in a subdivision for which a plat has not been approved and recorded in the manner prescribed herein. 
(Ord. No. 3157, § 6(3), 4-23-84; Ord. No. 3253, § 2, 6-22-87) 
Sec. 23-43. - Revision of plat after approval. 
    No changes, erasures, modifications, or revisions shall be made in any plat of a subdivision after approval has been given by the zoning and planning commission, and endorsed in writing on the plat, unless the plat is first resubmitted to the commission. 
(Ord. No. 3157, § 6(5), 4-23-84) 
Secs. 23-44-23-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PRELIMINARY PLAT 

Sec. 23-56. - Filing; filing fee. 
(a)  A subdivider desiring approval of a preliminary plat shall, at least ten (10) working days prior to the meeting of the zoning and planning commission at which consideration is desired, file an application for preliminary approval with the commission and twenty (20) copies of the preliminary plat, according to the standards and other provisions of this division. The preliminary plat shall be considered officially filed after it is examined by the building and zoning administrator and is found to be in full compliance with the formal provisions of these regulations. 
(b)  There is hereby assessed a filing fee of sixty-five dollars ($65.00) for every preliminary plat submitted by a subdivider to the zoning and planning commission for approval. 
(Ord. No. 3157, § 7(A)(3), 4-23-84; Ord. No. 3253, § 2, 6-22-87) 
Sec. 23-57. - Requirements. 
(a)  Generally. A preliminary plat shall show, on a map, all the facts needed to enable the zoning and planning commission to determine whether the proposed layout of the land in a subdivision is satisfactory from the standpoint of public interest. 
(b)  Preparation. The preliminary plat shall be prepared by a registered surveyor. 
(c)  Form. A preliminary plat shall be clearly and legibly drawn. The size of the map shall not be less than eighteen (18) inches by twenty-four (24) inches. Subdivisions shall be drawn at a scale of one inch equals one hundred (100) feet, unless otherwise required by the zoning and planning commission. 
(d)  Map contents. A preliminary plat shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The proposed name of the subdivision, which shall not duplicate, be the same in spelling or alike in pronunciation with any other recorded subdivision; 
(2)  The names of adjacent subdivisions and owners of adjoining parcels of unsubdivided land; 
(3)  The names and addresses of the subdivider, owner and engineer; 
(4)  The location by section, town, range, township, county, state; 
(5)  The names of streets within the adjoining plat; 
(6)  The boundaries of the subdivision indicated by a heavy line and the approximate acreage; 
(7)  The location, widths, and names of existing or platted streets, railroad rights-of-way, easements, parks, permanent buildings, section and corporation lines; 
(8)  The applicable zoning districts, if any; 
(9)  The existing contours with intervals of not more than two (2) feet shall be shown on the entire preliminary plat. Elevations are to be based on sea level data. 
(10)  All drainage channels, wooded areas, power transmission poles and lines, and any other significant items; 
(11)  A vicinity sketch; 
(12)  The date of preparation, scale of map, North point; and 
(13)  The location and principal dimensions for all proposed streets, alleys, easements, lot lines and areas to be reserved for public use. 
(14)  Survey data shall be shown on the preliminary plat with existing contours with intervals of not more than two (2) feet. 
(e)  Other information. The following information is also required on preliminary plats: 
(1)  A statement of the proposed use of lots stating type of residential buildings with number of proposed dwelling units; 
(2)  The type of business or industry, so as to reveal the effect of the development on traffic, fire hazards or congestions of population; 
(3)  All proposed covenants and restrictions; 
(4)  The source of water supply; 
(5)  Provisions for sewage disposal, drainage and flood control; and 
(6)  If any zoning changes are contemplated, the proposed zoning plan. 
(Ord. No. 3157, §§ 7(A)(1), (2), 10, 4-23-84; Ord. No. 4434, § 5, 10-30-06; Ord. No. 4498, § 1, 8-13-07) 
State Law reference- Plat, how drawn, shall show what, RSMo 445.020. 
Sec. 23-58. - Approval. 
(a)  Official recommendation. The building and zoning administrator shall, within five (5) days after the filing of a preliminary plat, transmit copies of the plat for their study and recommendation to: 
(1)  The city attorney; 
(2)  The city engineer; 
(3)  The park board; 
(4)  The fire department; 
(5)  The zoning and planning commission members; and 
(6)  Such other official, body, company or agency as may be directed by the zoning and planning commission. 
(b)  Notice and hearing. The zoning and planning commission shall provide for an adequate hearing on a preliminary plat, and shall notify by mail at least seven (7) days prior to the hearing all property owners abutting the subdivision as their names appear on the municipal tax record. Such notice shall state the time and place of hearing, a brief description of the subdivision and that a copy of the preliminary plat of said subdivision is on file with the commission for public inspection. The commission shall also cause notice of the hearing to be published in the official newspaper, or a newspaper of general circulation, in the city, at least seven (7) days prior to the hearing. 
(c)  Time requirement. The zoning and planning commission shall grant its approval or disapproval on a preliminary plat within sixty (60) days after review at the first regularly scheduled meeting, during which period it shall receive a written report with their recommendations from each city official, body, company or agency enumerated in subsection (a). If no action is taken by the commission within sixty (60) days after review at the first regularly scheduled meeting, the preliminary plat as filed shall be considered approved. 
(d)  Notice of action taken. The zoning and planning commission shall determine whether a preliminary plat shall be approved, approved with modifications or disapproved and shall give notice to the subdivider in the following manner: 
(1)  If approved, the building and zoning administrator shall affix his signature to the plat and attach thereto a notation that it has received preliminary approval and return it to the subdivider for compliance with the final approval requirements; or 
(2)  If approved with modifications or disapproved, the building and zoning administrator shall attach to the plat a statement of the reasons for such action and return it to the subdivider. 
In any case, a notation of the action taken, and requisite reasons therefore, shall be entered in the records of the zoning and planning commission. 
(e)  Effect of approval. Approval of a preliminary plat by the zoning and planning commission shall not constitute final acceptance of the subdivision by the commission. 
(Ord. No. 3157, § 7(A)(4), 4-23-84; Ord. No. 3253, § 2, 6-22-87) 
State Law reference- Approval of plats, RSMo 89.420, 89.430. 
Secs. 23-59-23-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - FINAL PLAT 

Sec. 23-71. - Scope. 
    A final plat will have incorporated all changes or modifications required by the zoning and planning commission, otherwise it shall conform to the preliminary plat that preceded it, and it may constitute only that portion of the approved preliminary plat which the subdivider proposes to record and develop at the time, provided that such portion conforms with all the requirements of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 3157, § 7(B)(1), 4-23-84) 
Sec. 23-72. - Filing. 
(a)  Required matter. After receiving notice of the action of the zoning and planning commission approving a preliminary plat, the subdivider shall proceed to file with the commission: 
(1)  Copies of the final plat in the amount required by the commission; 
(2)  A written application for final approval; and 
(3)  Cross-sections and profiles of sewer, water, sidewalk, street, curbing, guttering and storm drainage facilities, and other construction drawings related to the improvements to be constructed in the subdivision. 
(b)  Time limits. Within ninety (90) days after the approval of the preliminary plat by the commission, the final plat (whether for a phase development or the entire subdivision) shall be filed with the commission for approval. If approved by the commission, it shall be submitted to the city council for acceptance as a subdivision. Upon acceptance of the final plat by the city council, the accepted plat shall be duly recorded in the office of the Recorder of Deeds of Laclede County, Missouri, prior to its issuance of any building permit and if not recorded within ninety (90) days after acceptance by the city council, then such plat will be considered null and void and all ordinances of the city approving the final plat shall be deemed conditioned on the proper recording of the plat within ninety (90) days in the office of the Recorder of Deeds of Laclede County, Missouri. The final approved plat shall be filed with the commission at least ten (10) working days prior to the meeting at which it is to be considered. The final plat shall be considered officially filed after it is examined by the building and zoning administrator and found to be in full compliance with the formal provisions of the ordinances of the city. 
(Ord. No. 3157, § 7(B)(3), 4-23-84; Ord. No. 3253, § 2, 6-22-87; Ord. No. 3321, §§ 8, 9, 1-10-89) 
Sec. 23-73. - Requirements. 
(a)  Preparation. A final plat shall be prepared by a registered land surveyor in accordance with the land survey standards as required by the Department of Natural Resources of the State of Missouri, and in accordance with all applicable Missouri state statutes. The surveyor shall certify on the written survey that the survey meets all the requirements for land surveys. 
(b)  Form. The final plat shall be clearly and legibly drawn in Indian ink on tracing cloth or mylar. The size of the map shall not be less than eighteen (18) inches by twenty-four (24) inches. All subdivisions shall be drawn at a scale of one inch equals one hundred (100) feet, unless otherwise required by the zoning and planning commission. 
(c)  Map contents. The following items shall be contained in the map of a final plat: 
(1)  The name of the subdivision; 
(2)  The names of adjacent subdivisions and owners of adjoining parcels of unsubdivided land; 
(3)  The names and addresses of the subdivider, owner and engineer; 
(4)  The location by section, town, range, township, county, state; 
(5)  The names of streets within the adjoining plat; 
(6)  All plat boundaries; 
(7)  The bearings and distances to the nearest established street lines, section corners or other recognized permanent monuments which shall be accurately described on the plat; 
(8)  The municipal, township, county or section lines accurately tied to the lines of the subdivision by distance and bearings; 
(9)  The accurate location of all monuments; 
(10)  The length of all arcs, radii, internal angles, points of curvature and tangent bearings; 
(11)  When lots are located on a curve or when side lot lines are at angles other than ninety (90) degrees, the width at the building line; 
(12)  The date of preparation, scale of map, North points; 
(13)  All easements for right-of-way provided for public services or utilities, and any limitations of such easements; 
(14)  All lot numbers and lines, with accurate dimensions in feet and hundredths, and with bearings or angles to street and alley or crosswalk-way lines; 
(15)  Accurate outlines of any areas to be dedicated or temporarily reserved for public use with the purpose indicated thereon; and 
(16)  Building setback lines, with dimensions. 
(d)  Other information. The following items shall also be required for final plats: 
(1)  All protective covenants shall be shown or attached to the plat; 
(2)  Certification shall be furnished from the city collector that all taxes and assessments have been paid on the land within the proposed subdivision; 
(3)  If a zoning change is involved, certification from the planning commission shall be furnished indicating that the change requested has been approved and is in effect; 
(4)  Certifications by a registered surveyor to the effect that the plat represents a survey made by him and that all monuments shown thereon actually exist, and that their location is correctly shown; and 
(5)  An acknowledgement by the owner or owners, of his or their adoption of the plat, and of the dedication of streets and other public areas. 
(Ord. No. 3157, §§ 7(B)(2), 11, 4-23-84; Ord. No. 3321, § 10, 1-10-89) 
State Law reference- Plat, how drawn, shall show what, RSMo 445.020. 
Sec. 23-74. - Approval. 
(a)  Official recommendation. Cross-sections, profiles and other construction drawings shall be forwarded by the zoning and planning commission to the city engineer for his study and recommendations. The commission shall, within five (5) days after the filing of the final plat, transmit copies of the plat for their study and recommendation to: 
(1)  The city attorney; 
(2)  The city engineer; 
(3)  The park board; 
(4)  The fire department; 
(5)  The zoning and planning commission members; and 
(6)  Such other official, body, company or agency as may be directed by the commission. 
(b)  Final tracing. After receiving a written report from each city official, body, company or agency enumerated in subsection (a), the zoning and planning commission shall notify the subdivider of any recommended changes or suggestions so that the subdivider may correct the final tracing and submit same for final approval. 
(c)  Time requirement. The zoning and planning commission shall grant its approval or disapproval on a final plat within sixty (60) days after review at the first regularly scheduled meeting, during which period it shall receive a written report with their recommendations from each city official, body, company or agency enumerated in subsection (a). If no action is taken by the commission within sixty (60) days after review at the first regularly scheduled meeting, the plat as filed shall be considered pending and commission approval or disapproval shall be required no later than the next regularly scheduled meeting, and shall not require resubmission by the applicant. 
(d)  Notice of action taken. The zoning and planning commission shall determine whether the final plat shall be approved or disapproved and shall give notice to the subdivider in the following manner: 
(1)  If approved, the building and zoning administrator shall affix his signature to the plat with a notation that it has received final approval and forward it to the city council for approval at the next scheduled council meeting; or 
(2)  If disapproved, the building and zoning administrator shall attach to the plat a statement of the reasons for such action and return it to the subdivider. 
    In any case, a notation of the action taken, and requisite reasons therefore, shall be entered in the records of the commission. 
(e)  Recording. The subdivider shall record the final plat in the office the county recorder within fourteen (14) days after the date of approval by the city council, and furnish the building and zoning administrator with four (4) certified copies of the recorded plat, otherwise the final plat shall be considered void. 
(Ord. No. 3157, § 7(B), 4-23-84; Ord. No. 3253, § 2, 6-22-87) 
State Law reference- Commission to make recommendations to council on plat, RSMo 89.400; commission to approve plats, RSMo 89.420; commission approval does not constitute acceptance by municipality or public, RSMo 89.430; plat to be accepted by council, acknowledged and recorded, RSMo 445.030. 
Sec. 23-75. - Recording unapproved plat prohibited. 
    No plat of any subdivision shall be entitled to record in the county recorder's office or have any validity until it shall have been approved in the manner prescribed in this article. In the event any such unapproved plat is recorded, it shall be considered invalid and the zoning and planning commission shall institute proceedings to have the plat stricken from the county's records. 
(Ord. No. 3157, § 6(1), 4-23-84) 
State Law reference- Approval of plats required for recording, RSMo 89.440. 
Secs. 23-76-23-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - IMPROVEMENTS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Provisions relating to improvements, RSMo 89.380, 89. 460 et seq. 

Sec. 23-91. - Requirements for residential and commercial subdivision improvements. 
(a)  The following requirements shall apply to all residential and commercial subdivision improvements if the developer elects to have the city construct the infrastructure in the subdivision. 
(1)  Prior to the granting of final approval of a proposed subdivision, the subdivider thereof shall dedicate to the city, or have entered into a written agreement with the city for the ultimate dedication to the city the necessary easements, rights-of-way and improvements installed or to be installed pursuant to the provisions of this article. 
(2)  After the final plat has been approved and recorded pursuant to the provisions of this article, the subdivider shall be eligible to participate in the City of Lebanon's subdivision improvement program provided for in this article. The subdivision improvement program available under this subsection shall consist of the city's construction of the infrastructure in the subdivision, including streets, curbs, sidewalks, utility and stormwater piping and water retention ponds. In order to participate the subdivider shall notify the community development director in writing that participation is desired and pay an earnest money deposit in the amount of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). The subdivider's subdivision will then be placed on a list and any and all subdividers' participation in the program shall be in the same order that the subdivisions are placed on the list. 
(3)  When the subdivider is notified that the city is ready to proceed with the project, the subdivider shall enter into a written contract of development with the city committing to develop the subdivision in conformity with the Lebanon Code including this section and shall also pay the City of Lebanon a sum equal to forty-two dollars and fifty cents ($42.50) per running front foot along all platted lots in the subdivision on both sides of each proposed street for a total of eighty-five dollars ($85.00) per foot, which will constitute one-half of the total project cost and which must be paid before the city will be required to commence construction of the improvements. The balance of the sum due, to-wit, eighty-five dollars ($85.00) per running foot shall be due when the city has completed all improvements in the subdivision less the one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) earnest money payment. The payment referred to above includes the water connection fee provided for in section 26-83 of the Code and the sewer connection fee provided for in section 26-41 of the Code but does not include electrical deposits and fees required by sections 26-121 through 26-123, does not include building permits fees provided for in section 6-19 of the Code, does not include water facility impact fees required by subsection 26-83(c), and does not include waste water impact fees required by subsection 26-41(d), which amounts shall be paid in addition to the said fee. In the case of corner lots the front footage shall be measured along the longest side of the lot which is adjacent to the proposed street. 
(4)  In the event the subdivider desires to develop an additional subdivision phase, the requirements and the provisions of subsection (2) shall apply, however, the subdivider shall not be permitted to put the additional subdivision phase on the list unless and until all fees required under subsection (3) have been paid for the previous phase. 
(5)  In the event the city is not required to engineer, construct and install all the facilities referred to in subsection (2) because the subdivision is located adjacent to an existing street and/or facilities are already in place in the subdivision that meet the requirements of the standard specifications as adopted by the city council pursuant to the provisions of section 28-51, the fee referred to in subsection (3) shall be adjusted in accordance with the standard charge made for those facilities as approved by the city council. 
(6)  Each front foot segment on which facilities are constructed shall be contiguous and must be in the same subdivision or an adjoining extension thereof owned by the same owner if the plat thereof has been approved and recorded as provided in subsection (2). 
(7)  In the event construction costs of the facilities referred to in this article will significantly exceed the usual and standard costs of the construction and installation of the facilities, the subdivider shall be responsible for such excess costs per the schedule listed in the City of Lebanon Policy Manual, with the schedule being reviewed and amended from time to time by the city council and as recommended by the public works director and which amount shall be paid prior to the time construction commences. 
(8)  In the event the proposed subdivision, development, project or improvement requiring city water and/or sewage utility service(s) is located within the established municipal boundaries prior to the passage of this article, and is situated more than five hundred (500) feet, as measured along the most efficient route as determined by the city from the current location of any city water and/or sewage service(s), then the developer shall be required to participate in the expense of planning, easement procurement, engineering and installation, including labor and material of such utilities attributable to costs involved beyond five hundred (500) feet. In the event the proposed subdivision, development, project or improvement is situated five hundred (500) feet or less from the current location of any city water and/or sewage service(s), then the developer shall not be required to participate in the expenses outlined above. 
The developer's cost of the utility extension per linear foot is hereby established at thirty dollars ($30.00) per linear foot beyond the first five hundred (500) feet for each utility that is required or requested. In the event the improvement is a subdivision, the developer's cost shall be paid at the time the project commences. In the case of any other type of project, the developer's cost shall be paid at the time of building permit issuance. The contact or hook-up point, the route to be used and the point of contact with the developer's property shall be determined at the sole discretion of the city. The city shall also be solely in charge of the planning, engineering and construction of each project. Any project extension is subject to prior approval of the city. 
Any proposed subdivision, development, project or improvement requiring city water and/or sewage service(s) as a part of an annexation project that is initiated after June 30, 2006, that is not compact to existing utility service(s), shall be charged on a per-foot basis per each utility as calculated and certified by the public works director for each specific project. The contact or hook-up point, the route to be used and the point of contact with the developer's property shall be determined at the sole discretion of the city. The city shall also be solely in charge of the planning, engineering and construction of each project. 
(b)  The following requirements shall apply to all residential and commercial subdivision improvements if the developer elects to construct the infrastructure in the subdivision: 
(1)  Developers of residential and commercial subdivisions shall have the option to construct the infrastructure in the subdivision, including streets, curbs, sidewalks, utility and stormwater piping and water retention ponds, at their own expense, in which case the city electrical department will pull all wiring, set all sectional boxes, transformers and make all terminations. 
(2)  The developer shall be responsible for obtaining the services of a registered professional engineer subject to approval by the city, after the engineer demonstrates his experience and expertise by listing projects satisfactorily completed that were of similar size, scope and complexity. 
(3)  The engineer shall prepare plans and specifications for streets, curbs, sidewalks, utility and stormwater piping, which shall conform to all City Code requirements and which must be approved by the city. The developer shall be responsible for submitting plans and specifications to all state and local offices for approval and to obtain all necessary permits. 
(4)  The plans and specifications of the infrastructure including watersheds for stormwater, storm sewers and utilities, shall be designed to accommodate the development of adjacent property, not owned in whole or in part by the developer. The city will only be responsible for material cost differences required for water, sewer and electricity to adequately serve or protect adjacent properties. 
(5)  Any and all contractors proposed to perform work on the project shall be subject to approval of the city after review of at least three (3) references and review of at least three (3) projects of similar size, scope and complexity. 
(6)  Prior to the final city approval of the proposed infrastructure, the developer shall consent in writing to grant the city all improvements to be constructed and/or installed, pursuant to the plans and specifications. 
(7)  The developer will be responsible to supply a performance bond of one hundred (100) percent of the contracted cost for construction and materials, or one hundred (100) percent of the cost of construction based on city subdivision improvement fees, whichever is greater. The developer shall provide the city with lien waivers for all labor, materials and contract expenditures for development before acceptance of the improvements by the city. 
(8)  The developer will be responsible for any defects in materials and workmanship for a 12-month period after the acceptance of the project by the city. 
(9)  The work schedule for laborers working on the project shall be from 7:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m., Monday through Friday, unless a schedule change is otherwise approved by the city. The developer will be responsible for city inspection costs at a rate of thirty dollars ($30.00) per hour, per inspector, for any work performed outside regular business hours. The regular city business hours are from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., Monday through Friday. 
(10)  The developer shall certify compliance with the Missouri Department of Labor guidelines and shall submit certified timesheets of all employees who are entitled to receive the prevailing wage. 
(11)  The city inspection fees shall be paid to the city by the developer before any work has commenced to assure compliance with city construction specifications at a rate as follows: 
Water, per lineal foot ..... $1.00 
Sewer, per lineal foot ..... 1.00 
Electric, per lineal foot ..... 1.00
