Storm, per lineal foot ..... 1.00 
Street, per lineal foot ..... 1.00 
Administration, per lineal foot ..... 2.00 
(12)  The developer shall provide the name and contact information of their project manager or representative who is responsible for assuring compliance of city construction specifications at the time inspections fees are paid. All compliance issues will be directed to this representative to be corrected or resolved promptly. 
(13)  The developer shall provide a final geotechnical engineering report by a State of Missouri-registered professional engineer for streets constructed with excessive fill or in marginal soils. The developer shall also provide certification of compliance of material specifications from suppliers of both concrete and asphalt to assure material quality. The paid invoices for both concrete and asphalt shall be submitted by the developer to the city to certify material volumes. 
(14)  The developer will be responsible for all costs associated with concrete testing for the project. The city may request sampling and testing of concrete at the city inspector's discretion but not to exceed three (3) samples per twenty (20) cubic yards of concrete. 
(15)  In the event the developer requests and is denied a variance by the public works director, or if any other dispute or disputes should arise, the developer shall have the right to appeal to the code board of appeals. 
(Ord. No. 4673, § 1, 11-16-09) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4673, § 1, adopted November 16, 2009, in effect repealed the former § 23-91, and enacted a new § 23-91 as set out herein. The former § 23-91 pertained to requirements for subdivision improvements and derived from Ord. No. 3157, adopted April 23, 1984; Ord. No. 3321, adopted January 10, 1989; Ord. No. 3501, adopted May 10, 1993; Ord. No. 3635, adopted May 30, 1995; Ord. No. 3840, adopted March 9, 1998; Ord. No. 4028, adopted October 10, 2000; Ord. No. 4332, adopted August 29, 2005; Ord. No. 4414, adopted July 17, 2006; Ord. No. 4434, adopted October 30, 2006; Ord. No. 4498, adopted August 13, 2007 and Ord. No. 4602, adopted November 24, 2008. 
Sec. 23-92. - Monuments. 
    Monuments shall be placed at all block corners, angle points, points of curves in streets, and at intermediate points as shall be required by the city engineer. Such monuments shall be of such material, size and length as may be approved by the city engineer. 
(Ord. No. 3157, § 9(A), 4-23-84) 
Sec. 23-93. - Subdivision improvements. 
(a)  The construction of all improvements in any subdivision including, but not limited to, sewer, water, sidewalk, street, curbs, gutters, storm drainage and electrical facilities, shall be in accordance with standard specifications as adopted by the city council pursuant to section 2-851 of this Code of Ordinances. 
(b)  The minimum standard specifications adopted for subdivision improvements are set forth in Exhibit A to this chapter and access management guidelines are set forth in Appendix B of the Code. 
(Ord. No. 3157, § 9(B), 4-23-84; Ord. No. 3321, § 7, 1-10-89; Ord. No. 4509, § 7, 10-15-07) 
Chapter 24 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Ordinances levying annual taxes saved from repeal, § 1-6(2); finance, § 2-466 et seq. 
State Law reference- Grant of taxing power to municipalities, Mo. Const, art. X, sec. 1; limitations on municipal taxing power, Mo. Const. art. X, secs. 11(b), 11(c); requirement of local referendum for increases in municipal taxes, licenses or fees, Mo. Const. art. X, sec. 22; municipal taxing powers, RSMo 71.610 et seq.; taxation in third class cities, RSMo 94.010 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 24-1. - Tax exemptions prohibited. 
    The city council shall have no power to relieve any person from the payment of any tax or exempt any person from any burden imposed by law. 
(Code 1967, § 23-2) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 94.050. 
Sec. 24-2. - When delinquency occurs. 
    Upon the first day of January of each year all unpaid city taxes shall become delinquent, and the taxes upon real property are hereby made a perpetual lien thereon against all persons in favor of the city. 
(Code 1967, § 23-5) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 94.160. 
Sec. 24-3. - City collector to make delinquent tax lists; collection. 
(a)  The city council shall require the city collector, at the first meeting of the city council in April of each year, or as soon thereafter as may be, to make out, under oath, lists of delinquent taxes remaining due and uncollected for each year, to be known as "the land and lot delinquent list" and "the personal delinquent list." 
(b)  At the meeting at which the delinquent lists are returned, or as soon as may be thereafter, the city council shall examine carefully the delinquent lists, and if it appears that all property and taxes contained in the lists are properly returned as delinquent, the city council shall approve the lists and cause a record thereof to be entered on the journal, and shall cause the amount thereof to be credited to the account of the city collector. 
(c)  The city council shall return the delinquent lists to the city collector, charging him therewith, and he shall proceed to collect the same in the manner provided for the collection of delinquent lists of real and personal taxes for state and county purposes in RSMo Ch. 140. 
(Code 1967, § 23-7) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 94.170; collection of delinquent taxes generally, RSMo Ch. 140. 
Sec. 24-4. - City collector to make monthly reports of collections of delinquent taxes. 
    The city collector shall report to the city council, at the regular meetings in each month, all taxes collected on the real and personal delinquent lists; and he shall pay the same to the city treasurer, and receive credit therefor. He shall turn over to his successor all uncollected delinquent lists, receiving credit therefor, and his successor shall be charged therewith; provided, that the city council may declare worthless any and all personal delinquent taxes which the council may deem uncollectible. 
(Code 1967, § 23-8) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 94.180. 
Secs. 24-5-24-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MERCHANT'S AD VALOREM TAX[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to impose merchant's ad valorem tax, RSMo 94.080. 

Sec. 24-21. - "Merchant" defined. 
    For the purpose of this article, the word "merchant" shall mean any person who engages in the business of selling goods, wares or merchandise in any store, stand or place occupied for that purpose within the city. 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Merchant defined, RSMo 150.010. 
Sec. 24-22. - Tax levied; when and to whom tax payable. 
    There shall be collected and there is hereby levied on the value of the goods, wares and merchandise possessed by any merchant, an annual ad valorem tax equal to that which is levied upon real estate, and the amount of which shall be determined and ascertained in the same way as the state and county tax is determined and ascertained on the value of all such goods, wares and merchandise, situate within the city for municipal purposes. This tax shall be paid to the city collector, and shall be due on the first day of November of each year. The city collector shall have the authority to enforce the payment of the tax by seizure and sale as in the collection of other taxes. 
(Code 1967, § 23-3) 
Sec. 24-23. - Delinquency penalty; when imposed. 
    No person subject to the tax imposed by section 24-22, who shall pay his tax on or before sixty (60) days from the date it is due, shall be subject to a penalty for delinquency. 
(Code 1967, § 23-3) 
Secs. 24-24-24-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - TAXATION AND REGULATION OF OCCUPATIONS AND FRANCHISES[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Alcoholic beverage licenses, § 4-36 et seq.; pawnbroker licenses, § 19-31 et seq.; solid waste collection license, § 21-36 et seq.; taxicab vehicle license, § 28-61 et seq. 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to levy taxes and licenses, RSMo 94.020; license taxes on certain businesses, RSMo 94.110. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 24-41. - Regulation of businesses. 
    The council shall have power by ordinance to license, tax, and regulate all businesses, occupations, professions, vocations, activities, or things whatsoever set forth and enumerated by the statutes of this state now or hereafter applicable to cities of the third class and which are now or may hereafter be permitted by law to license, tax and regulate. 
(Ord. No. 3729, § 1, 8-12-96) 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ordinance No. 3729, adopted Aug. 12, 1996, repealed §§ 24-41 and 24-42 in their entirety. Formerly, said sections pertained to the closing hours of barbershops and beauty shops, respectively. Section 24-41 was derived from § 17-7 of the 1967 Code and § 24-42 was derived from § 17-12 of the 1967 Code. Section 1 of Ordinance No. 3729 also provided for the addition of a new § 24-41 as herein set out. 
Sec. 24-42. - Reserved. 
Note- See editor's note following § 24-41. 
Secs. 24-43-24-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CLOSED CIRCUIT ELECTRONIC SERVICE 

Sec. 24-56. - "Gross receipts" defined. 
    As used in this division, the term "gross receipts" shall not include revenue from sale to the United States or to the state or to any agency or political subdivision thereof, or for any use which cannot be classified as residential or domestic, such as commercial, industrial and educational uses and sales to churches and charitable institutions, as such uses and sales have been construed by the United States Department of Internal Revenue under the Revenue Act of 1932, as amended. 
(Code 1967, § 12-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 24-57. - License fee. 
    Persons engaged in the business of supplying closed circuit electronic service for compensation, to residential and domestic users within the city, shall pay to the city as a license fee a sum equal to three (3) percent of the gross receipts, exclusive of any federal, state or local sales or excise taxes thereon, derived by such persons from the sale of such service within the present or any future boundaries of the city for residential and domestic purposes. 
(Code 1967, § 12-2) 
Sec. 24-58. - Filing reports of gross receipts; payment of license tax; inspection of records. 
    Persons required by section 24-59 so to do shall file with the treasurer of the city on or before the last day of February and August, each year, a statement of the gross receipts of such persons from the sale of closed circuit, electronic service for residential and domestic purposes, based on their business done during the preceding period of six (6) months ending respectively on the last day of June and December, and at the time of filing these statements shall pay to the treasurer a sum equal to three (3) percent of the amount shown by the statements, respectively. Any duly designated representative of the city, shall at all reasonable times, have the right to investigate the correctness of these statements and shall, at all reasonable times, have access to the books and records of such persons for that purpose. 
(Code 1967, § 12-3) 
Sec. 24-59. - Tax required by article in lieu of certain other taxes. 
    The tax required by this article shall be paid in lieu of any other occupation, license or merchandise tax, but shall not be in lieu of any ad valorem tax. 
(Code 1967, § 12-4) 
Sec. 24-60. - Additional penalty for violation of article. 
    Persons who fail to file a statement or pay the tax as required by section 24-58 shall, for such failure, for the first thirty (30) days or any part thereof, pay in addition to such tax a penalty of ten (10) percent of the tax due and unpaid, and, for each succeeding thirty (30) days or any part thereof, shall pay, as a penalty one percent of such tax as long as the same shall remain unpaid. 
(Code 1967, § 12-5) 
DIVISION 3. - TATTOO PARLORS 

Sec. 24-61. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Director. "Director" shall include the environmental/sanitation director, the director of county health department or his or her designee of the County Health Department of the County of Laclede. 
    City clerk. "City clerk" shall mean clerk of the City of Lebanon, Missouri. 
    Operator. "Operator" shall mean a person who practices the art of tattooing. 
    Person. "Person" shall mean any individual, firm or corporation, owner or operator of a tattooing establishment. 
    Tattooing. "Tattooing" shall mean any method of placing designs, letters, scrolls, figures, symbols or any other marks upon or under the skin with ink or colors, by the aid of needles or instruments. The placement of any "permanent cosmetics" shall be considered tattooing. 
    Tattooing establishment. "Tattooing establishment" shall mean any place or facility where the art of tattooing is performed. 
(Ord. No. 3729, § 2, 8-12-96; Ord. No. 4174, § 1, 2-10-03) 
Sec. 24-62. - Permit required; location of establishment. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation owning, controlling or leasing, acting as agent for, conducting, managing or operating any establishment to practice the art of tattooing or to engage in the practice of tattooing without first applying for and receiving a permit from the city clerk in the manner herein provided and without first complying with the rules and regulations regarding minimum health and sanitary standards as promulgated by the Laclede County Health Department and by the terms and conditions of this ordinance. Rules and regulations regarding the operation of a tattooing establishment may be changed or upgraded at any time as deemed necessary by the county health department to better protect the health of patrons of any tattooing establishment. 
(b)  No tattooing establishment shall be located within five hundred (500) feet of a school. 
(c)  No tattooing establishment shall be promoted, advertised, conducted, managed or operated in any city facility or on any city property. 
(Ord. No. 3729, § 2, 8-12-96; Ord. No. 4174, § 2, 2-10-03) 
Sec. 24-63. - Permit-Reinstatement. 
    Any tattoo establishment, the permit of which has been suspended, may at any time make application to the city clerk for the reinstatement of the permit. The application shall be delivered to the director for processing and within one week after the receipt of a satisfactory application, accompanied by a statement signed by the applicant to the effect that the violated provision of this article has been conformed with, the director shall make a reinspection, and thereafter as many additional reinspections as he may deem necessary, to assure himself that the applicant is again complying with the requirements of this article, and if in case the findings indicate compliance, shall report to the city clerk who shall reinstate the permit. 
(Ord. No. 3729, § 2, 8-12-96) 
Sec. 24-64. - Same-Issuance. 
(a)  Upon approval of an application for a permit to engage in the practice of tattooing by the director who shall report the approval to the city clerk who then, upon payment of a license fee hereinafter provided, shall issue the permit to the designated permittee. 
(b)  Every person engaged in the business of conducting, managing or operating an establishment for the practice of the art of tattooing shall pay a permit fee of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) per year or for any portion of the year payable annually in advance to the city clerk. The director shall cause an inspection to be made of all tattooing establishments with a minimum of two (2) times each year. 
(Ord. No. 3729, § 2, 8-12-96) 
Sec. 24-65. - Operator's card. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to employ an operator in the practice of tattooing without such operator's having first secured an operator's card, and it shall be unlawful for any person or operator to perform a tattoo procedure who does not possess a valid operator's card. 
(b)  The issuance of the operator's card herein provided shall be subject to the compliance with the regulations and passage of the physical examination required by the rules and regulations of the director of the county health department. An operator's card shall be granted only on the express condition that it shall be subject to suspension or revocation by the director upon showing satisfactory to the director of a violation by the holder of the said operator's card of any rule of the director or provision of this article or of applicable state law, or upon a satisfactory public hearing. 
(c)  The operator's card shall be issued by the city clerk after the director has confirmed that all of the aforesaid rules and regulations have been complied with and that the aforesaid physical examination has been successfully passed. 
(Ord. No. 3729, § 2, 8-12-96) 
Sec. 24-66. - Permit expiration. 
    A permit for a tattooing establishment or an operator's card under the provisions of this article may be granted at any time during the year, but all permits and operator's cards issued hereinunder shall expire on the thirty-first day of the next succeeding December. Said permit or operator's card shall not be transferable. 
(Ord. No. 3729, § 2, 8-12-96) 
Sec. 24-67. - Posting of permits; operational regulations. 
(a)  All permits, operator's cards and regulations of the director of the county health department shall be posted at all times in a conspicuous place in the establishment. 
(b)  Any person maintaining, conducting, operating or managing any tattooing establishment must comply with the following regulations: 
(1)  General regulations 
a.  No tattoo may be administered by any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years. No tattoo may be administered to any person less than eighteen (18) years of age. The tattooist shall obtain proof of age before the tattoo procedure is done by checking the patron's driver's license or other identification which contains a photograph of the patron requesting the tattoo procedure. 
b.  Before administering a tattoo, the patron must be required to provide his or her medical history on a form approved by the director which history shall confirm that the patron has no history of active Hepatitis A, B or C; AIDS; herpes simplex virus infection; tuberculosis or other infectious disease. If the said medical history indicates that the patron has a history of one or more of the aforesaid diseases, no tattoo shall be administered. The said medical history form produced as a result of this procedure shall be retained on file at the establishment. 
c.  Before administering a tattoo, the patron must also be advised that the tattoo should be considered permanent; that it can be removed only with a surgical procedure; and that any effective removal may leave permanent scarring and disfigurement. A written cautionary notice to that effect shall be furnished to and signed by the patron and retained on file at the establishment. 
d.  The skin surface to be tattooed must be free of rash, pimples, infection or recent scar tissue. The patron must be in apparent good health, and the skin to be tattooed generally free of all appearances of pathological conditions. 
e.  Tattoos may not be administered to any person under the influence of drugs or alcohol, and the tattooist is charged with the responsibility of making reasonable observation and inquiry to assure himself that the patron is, in fact, sober, and not under the influence of drugs or alcohol. 
f.  Written instructions approved by the director of health, regarding the proper care of the tattooed skin as a precaution against infections shall be provided to each patron following the tattoo procedure. The patron shall be required to confirm in writing that the written instructions have been provided. 
g.  The regulations herein provided shall in no way be construed to allow nor permit the removal of any tattoo nor shall the tattoo operator perform or attempt to perform any procedure which is intended to remove any tattoo. 
Any attempt known by the director of health by a tattoo operator to perform a tattoo removal procedure, shall result in the immediate suspension of the tattoo operator's health permit and a show cause hearing as to why the operator's permit should not be revoked. The above procedure shall not preclude prosecution of the tattoo operator during the same period of permit suspension. 
h.  Prior to receiving an operator's card, the operator shall furnish the inspector of health with a written statement from a licensed physician that he/she is free of communicable disease and that the operator has been properly immunized against all types of Hepatitis, as vaccines are available. 
i.  Any person who owns or operates a tattooing establishment shall at any time disclose the records of all tattoos administered and said records shall disclose the age and the medical history of the patron, including name, sex, residence, and phone number. 
(2)  Premises. 
a.  Premises and equipment must be maintained in a sanitary manner. This includes physical cleanliness as well as antiseptic precautions. 
b.  All tattoo parlors shall be equipped with hot and cold running water. Adequate toilet facilities with soap and disposal paper towels properly installed and in compliance with applicable ordinance of the city and the rules and regulations of the director shall be provided. Each tattooing establishment shall be equipped with hand-washing facilities for its personnel with unobstructed access to the tattoo area such that operators can return to the area without having to touch anything with their hands. Hand-washing facilities shall be equipped with hot and cold or tempered running water under pressure, liquid germicidal soap, single-use towels, and a covered refuse container. Such facilities shall be kept clean and in good repair. 
c.  All tattoo parlors shall be well lit with no less than fifty (50) foot candles in all cleaning and working areas. 
d.  All tattoo parlors shall have ventilation as required by applicable ordinances/rules and regulations of the City of Lebanon. With the exception of service animals, no animals shall be allowed on the premises. 
e.  All tattoo parlors shall be of sufficient size to accommodate required equipment and business done therein. 
f.  Floors, walls and ceilings shall be clean and in good repair and maintained in a clean condition. 
g.  Adequate equipment and facilities shall be provided for the disposition of cigarette butts and other disposal items. 
h.  All tables and chairs used in the tattooing process shall be constructed of a material allowing easy and thorough cleaning and shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition. 
i.  The director shall be permitted access to all areas of the premises and records at any reasonable time and shall inspect the tattoo parlor at least every six (6) months and the director shall make as many additional inspections as are necessary for enforcement of this ordinance. At any time the director of health performs an inspection that does not meet the minimum health standards, the information shall be relayed to city officials at which time the city may pull the permit. 
(3)  Equipment. 
a.  Individual single-use cups of ink or colors shall be used for each patron and be discarded after use. All ink used in tattooing shall be sterile and of a type recommended for tattooing. 
b.  Needles shall be of single use and disposed of properly after each use in administering the tattoo. Other instruments used in administering the tattoo, including hand pieces, needle bars and razor blade holders must be thoroughly disinfected, cleaned with soap and water and thoroughly rinsed again after each person and before sterilization. 
c.  Sterilization of equipment must be by: 
1.  Steam pressure sterilization (autoclave), for a minimum of thirty (30) minutes at 250°F (121°C), followed by a drying time of not less than fifteen (15) minutes. 
(i)  To prepare for steam pressure sterilization, each piece of equipment shall be flushed with distilled water and left distinctly moist, just before the sterilization process is initiated. The tubes containing the needles should rest on their sides in the sterilizer to facilitate air removal and steam contact to each tube and needle. 
(ii)  When an autoclave procedure is used, indicator tape or other acceptable test method shall be used to check the effectiveness of sterilization. 
(iii)  The records shall include the date of sterilization, quantity and type of instruments to be sterilized, and the name or initials of the individual sterilizing the instruments. Sterilized instruments stored in an approved manner and not used within thirty (30) days after sterilization shall no longer be considered sterile and shall be re-sterilized before use, unless the studio utilizes pre-sterilized instruments sterilized by the manufacturer. If pre-sterilized instruments are used, the operator shall obtain documentation from the manufacturer that describes the method of sterilization utilized by the manufacturer and the manufacturer's recommendations for storage and maintenance of sterility. This documentation shall be available for inspection by the director. The operator shall follow the manufacturer's instructions for storage and maintenance of sterility. The records shall include a third party spore test ran on the steam pressure sterilization machine at least quarterly. 
(iv)  All instruments and needles shall be stored in a closed metal or glass container. 
(v)  All acetate tattoo stencils shall be cleaned with seventy (70) percent isopropyl alcohol between customers or individual transfers of tattoo designs shall be used once and discarded. 
(4)  Minimum acceptable aseptic technique. 
a.  Neither the patron or tattoo operator shall consume or bring food or drink into the tattooing area and shall not smoke during the procedure or in the room(s) where the tattooing takes place. 
b.  The tattoo operator must be free from communicable disease while administering tattoos and present no pustular lesions of the hands or arms. 
c.  Immediately before administering a tattoo, the operator must thoroughly wash his/her hands in hot water with soap, using a short-bristled brush and then dry the hands with a disposable paper towel and use disposable medical grade gloves while administering the tattoo. The gloves shall be changed after each tattoo is administered and disposed of in a proper manner in accordance with the laws and regulations, and hands shall be washed after each tattoo is administered or at any time during the tattoo process in which a break in activity causes hands to become contaminated. 
d.  The tattoo operator, while administering a tattoo shall also wear an effective hair restraint, must have clean fingernails and shall in general pay particular attention to his/her personal hygiene. 
e.  The tattoo operator shall wear a clean and easily cleanable smock while administering the tattoo procedure. 
f.  The skin surrounding the area where the tattoo is to be placed shall first be washed with a germicidal soap and then shaved with a disposable blade. Following shaving, the skin must be gently scrubbed with seventy (70) percent isopropyl alcohol, using a sterile gauze pad which shall be disposed of after use. 
g.  Individual razor blades shall be used when customer is shaved and razor then disinfected and prepared as in subsections (3)b. and c. above, between each use. 
h.  During any phase of the tattoo procedure, should the tattoo operator be interrupted for other duties, i.e., answering phone, etc., the tattoo operator shall remove the used medical gloves and wash his/her hands as in subsection (4)c. and put on new gloves before resuming the tattoo procedure. 
i.  The tattoo shall be bandaged with a sterile non-stick type bandage when tattoo is finished. 
j.  Contaminated waste that may release liquid blood or bodily fluids when handled must be placed in an approved "red" bag that is marked with the international "biohazard" symbol. Sharps ready for disposal shall be disposed of in an approved sharps container. It must then be disposed of through an approved biological hazardous waste company. Proof of proper disposal of all biological hazardous waste will be provided to the director in the form of receipts and/or records from the disposal company. Contaminated waste which cannot release liquid blood or bodily fluids when handled may be placed in a covered receptacle and disposed of through normal approved disposal methods pursuant to all applicable laws and regulations. 
k.  All infections resulting from the practice of tattooing shall be reported to the director by the person owning or operating the tattooing establishment. 
(Ord. No. 3729, § 2, 8-12-96; Ord. No. 4174, § 3, 2-10-03) 
Sec. 24-68. - Penalty for violation of division. 
    Any person, firm or corporation who shall violate any of the provisions of this division or fail to comply with any order or regulation made thereunder shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be punished for each violation by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or by imprisonment in the city jail for not more than three (3) months or both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. No. 3729, § 2, 8-12-96) 
Secs. 24-69-24-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - CIGARETTE TAX.[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3748, §§ 1-10, adopted Sept. 30, 1996, enacted new provisions which in effect superseded provisions formerly set out as Ch. 24, Art. IV, Divs. 1, 2, of the Code. Former Ch. 24, Art. IV, Div. 1, 2, §§ 24-76, 24-77, 24-91-24-97, pertained to the cigarette tax and derived from Ord. No. 1758, §§ 2-12, adopted Jan. 27, 1969; and Ord. No. 1759, Art. I, adopted Jan. 27, 1969. At the discretion of the editor, the provisions of Ord. No. 3748, §§ 1-10, have been included herein as a new Ch. 24, Art. IV, §§ 24-76-24-85. 
State Law reference- Cigarette tax, RSMo Ch. 149. 

Sec. 24-76. - Definitions. 
    When used in this article the following words shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
    Cigarette means a roll of tobacco or any substitute thereof wrapped in paper and used for smoking. 
    Consumer means a person who comes into possession of tobacco for the purpose of consuming it, giving it away or disposing of it in any way. 
    Dealer means any person dealing directly with the manufacturer of cigarettes in their purchase and in the business of selling cigarettes as a first seller. 
    First seller means and includes all persons who make the initial or first sale or distribution of cigarettes within the City of Lebanon. 
    Package means the individual package, box or other container from which sales of cigarettes are normally made or intended to be made. 
    Person means any individual, partnership, society, association, joint stock company, corporation, estate, receiver, trustee, assignee, referee or other person acting in a fiduciary or representative capacity, whether appointed by a court or otherwise, or any combination of individuals. 
    Retailer includes persons other than a dealer or wholesaler as defined in this section, who is engaged in the business of selling cigarettes at retail, who shall sell or offer for sale cigarettes, irrespective of quantity, number of sales, giving the same away or exposing the same where it may be taken, or purchased, or otherwise acquired. 
    Sale means any transfer of title or possession or both, exchange or barter, conditional or otherwise, in any manner or by any means whatsoever, for a consideration, or any agreement therefor. 
    Vending machine operator includes all persons engaged in the distribution or sale of cigarettes by means of coin-operated vending machines. 
    Wholesaler includes persons whose principal business is that of a wholesale jobber and who is known to the trade as such, who sells cigarettes for only the purpose of resale or giving them away, or exposing the same where they may be taken or purchased or otherwise acquired by the retailer. 
(Ord. No. 3748, § 1, 9-30-96) 
Sec. 24-77. - Intent. 
    This is the one and only license or other tax that cigarette dealers or wholesalers shall pay. 
(Ord. No. 3748, § 2, 9-30-96) 
Sec. 24-78. - Payment of tax required. 
    This tax shall be paid by the dealer or wholesaler, as defined in section 24-76, selling cigarettes or offering them for sale. 
(Ord. No. 3748, § 3, 9-30-96) 
Sec. 24-79. - Tax levy. 
    Every dealer or wholesaler engaged in the business of selling cigarettes or offering or displaying the same for sale within the city shall pay an occupation tax at the rate of $.001 per cigarette for all cigarettes sold or offered or displayed for sale. This tax shall be paid but once, as provided for in section 24-81, and only by the dealer selling cigarettes or displaying or offering them for sale. The intent and meaning of this ordinance is that the same shall levy an occupation tax based upon and pursuant to the methods provided for by RSMo 92.040, and pursuant to the powers therein granted and the powers contained in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 3748, § 4, 9-30-96; Ord. No. 4645, § 1, 8-17-09) 
Sec. 24-80. - Payment, discount. 
    The tax provided for in section 24-79 shall be paid to the city clerk, and in the collection of such tax, the city clerk shall allow a discount of five percent of the face value thereof. 
(Ord. No. 3748, § 5, 9-30-96) 
Sec. 24-81. - Monthly payment. 
    It shall be the duty of every dealer or wholesaler, as defined in section 24-76, selling, offering or displaying for sale any package of cigarettes, to remit the monthly cigarette tax reporting form and full payment by the 15th day of each following month. The cancelled check, accompanied by the monthly cigarette tax reporting form, shall be proof of payment. 
(Ord. No. 3748, § 6, 9-30-96) 
Sec. 24-82. - Rules and regulations, records. 
    For the purpose of enabling the city clerk to enforce the terms of this article, the following provisions are enacted: 
(1)  Each dealer in the city and those wholesalers and retailers as defined in section 24-76 shall procure and retain invoices showing the amount and value of the shipment of cigarettes received by him, the date thereof, and the name of the shipper, and shall retain this invoice for a period of three (3) years subject to the use and inspection of the city clerk. 
(2)  All dealers, wholesalers and retailers as defined in section 24-76 within the City of Lebanon shall maintain and keep for a period of three (3) years such other records of cigarettes received, sold or delivered within the city as may be required by the city clerk. 
(3)  The city clerk or his or her duly authorized representatives, are authorized to examine the books, papers, invoices and other records, stock of cigarettes in and upon any premises where they are placed, stored or sold, and equipment of any such dealer, wholesaler, or retailer pertaining to the sale and delivery of cigarettes taxable under this article. 
(4)  To verify the accuracy of the occupation tax imposed and assessed by this article, each person, as defined in section 24-76, is directed and required to give to the city clerk or his or her duly authorized representatives, the means, facilities and opportunity for such examinations as are herein provided for and required. 
(5)  In addition to the powers herein granted to the city clerk, he or she is authorized and empowered to prescribe, adopt, promulgate and enforce rules and regulations relating to the delegation of his powers to a deputy or other employee of his or her office and any other matter or thing pertaining to the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this article. 
(6)  Cigarette tax reporting information received from the State of Missouri shall be held in confidence and used solely for verifying cigarette tax payments. 
(Ord. No. 3748, § 7, 9-30-96) 
Sec. 24-83. - Refunds. 
    The city clerk is authorized to adopt, prescribe and promulgate rules and regulations including a monthly cigarette tax reporting form with regard to the presentation and proof of claim for refunds and credits as he or she may deem advisable. 
(Ord. No. 3748, § 8, 9-30-96) 
Sec. 24-84. - Oaths and subpoenas. 
    The city clerk or his or her employees or agents duly designated and authorized by him shall have power to administer oaths and take affidavits in relation to any matter or proceedings in the exercise of their powers and duties under this article. The city clerk shall have power to subpoena and require the attendance of witnesses and the production of books, papers and documents to secure information pertinent to the enforcement of this article and to examine them in relation thereto. 
(Ord. No. 3748, § 9, 9-30-96) 
Sec. 24-85. - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person violating this article by failing to file the report and make the payment provided for in section 24-81 hereof shall be punished by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned for not more than ninety (90) days or be punished by both such fine and imprisonment. Failure to file each monthly report and make each monthly payment shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 3748, § 10, 9-30-96) 
Secs. 24-86-24-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - GENERAL SALES AND UTILITY SERVICE SALES TAXES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Utilities, Ch. 26. 

Sec. 24-111. - Levy of general sales tax. 
(a)  Pursuant to the authority granted by and subject to the provisions of RSMo 94.500 to 94.570, a tax for general revenue purposes is hereby imposed upon all sellers for the privilege of engaging in the business of selling tangible personal property or rendering taxable services at retail to the extent and in the manner provided in RSMo 144.010 to 144.510 and the rules and regulations of the state director of revenue issued pursuant thereto. The rate of the tax shall be one percent on the receipts from the sale at retail of all tangible personal property or taxable services at retail within the city, if such property and taxable services are subject to taxation by the State of Missouri under the provisions of RSMo 144.010 to 144.510. The tax shall become effective as provided in RSMo 94.510(4) and shall be collected pursuant to the provisions of RSMo 94.500 to 94. 570. 
(b)  Each person making domestic use purchases of services who uses any portion of services for nondomestic use shall be responsible for the payment of sales tax on that portion of the bill representing nondomestic purchases. Each person making nondomestic purchases of services who uses any portion of services for domestic use and each person making domestic purchases on behalf of occupants of residential apartments or condominiums through a single or master meter, including service for common areas and facilities and vacant units, shall be entitled to file a residential utility exemption certificate which shall entitle such person to an exemption for that portion of the bill for services that pertains to domestic use. The necessary form to be used for said exemption shall be provided by the city. 
(Ord. No. 2004, § 1, 6-27-77, Ord. No. 3755, § 22, 10-15-96) 
State Law reference- City sales tax, RSMo 94.500 et seq.; sales and use tax generally, RSMo Ch. 144. 
Sec. 24-112. - Levy of utility service tax. 
    A municipal sales tax of one percent is hereby imposed on all sales of metered water service, electricity, electrical current, natural, artificial or propane gas, wood, coal or home heating oil, used for nonbusiness, noncommercial or nonindustrial purposes within the city. 
(Ord. No. 2095, § 1, 11-12-79) 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to impose sales tax on utilities, RSMo 144.032. 
Secs. 24-113-24-125. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - TRANSPORTATION SALES TAX[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance Number 3132, from which this article is derived, was approved by the qualified voters of the city on November 8, 1983, in a special election held for that purpose, in accordance with constitution and laws of the state. 
Cross reference- Traffic and motor vehicles, Ch. 25. 
State Law reference- Transportation sales tax, RSMo 94.600 et seq. 

Sec. 24-126. - Levied; term. 
(a)  Pursuant to the authority granted by and subject to the provisions of RSMo 94.600 to 94.655 and any amendments, additions or repeals thereof, a tax for transportation revenue purposes is hereby imposed upon all sellers for the privilege of engaging in the business of selling tangible personal property or rendering taxable services at retail to the extent and in the manner provided in RSMo 144.010 to 144.510 and the rules and regulations of the state director of revenue issued pursuant thereto. 
(b)  The tax imposed in subsection (a) shall be for a period of five (5) years, from January 1, 1984 to January 1, 1989. 
(Ord. No. 3132, § 1, 9-19-83) 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to impose tax, RSMo 94.605(1). 
Sec. 24-127. - Rate. 
    The tax imposed in section 24-126 shall be at a rate of one-half of one (1) percent on the receipts from the sale at retail of all tangible personal property or taxable services at retail within the city, if such property and taxable services are subject to taxation by the state under the provisions of RSMo 144.010 to 144.510. 
(Ord. No. 3132, § 1, 9-19-83) 
State Law reference- Maximum rate of tax prescribed, RSMo 94.605(4). 
Sec. 24-128. - Tax use. 
    The proceeds from the tax imposed in section 24-126 shall be used solely for the renovation, reconstruction and/or maintenance of existing city streets, unless specific authority for other uses is granted by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 3634, § 1, 5-15-95) 
Secs. 24-129-24-140. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - SPECIAL BUSINESS DISTRICT AD VALOREM TAX[7] 
Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- Special business districts, RSMo 71.790 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 24-141. - Establishment of district; boundaries. 
    A special business district, be and the same is hereby established under the provisions of RSMo 71.790 to 71.808, within that part of the first railroad addition to the city, described as beginning at the south corner of block 24 of the first railroad addition; thence northwest along the southwest boundaries of blocks 24 and 16 and crossing commercial street to the west corner of lot 19 of block 16; thence northeast along the northwest boundaries of lots 19 and 28 of block 16 and crossing Monroe Avenue to the southwest boundary of block 17; thence northwest along the southwest boundary of block 17 to the west corner thereof; thence northeast along the northwest boundaries of blocks 17 and 18 and crossing Madison Avenue to the west corner of lot 20 of block 18; thence northwest crossing Second Street and along the southwest boundaries of lots 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5 of block 13 to the west corner of lot 5; thence northeast along the northwest boundary of lot 5 to the north corner thereof; thence southeast along the northeast boundaries of lots 5, 4, 3, 2 and 1 of block 13 and crossing Second Street to the north corner of block 18; thence northeast crossing Jefferson Avenue and along the northwest boundaries of blocks 19 and 20 and crossing Adams Avenue to the west corner of lot 24 of block 20; thence southeast along the southwest boundaries of lots 24, 25, 26 and 27 to the west corner of lot 28; thence northeast along the northwest boundary of lot 28 to the north corner thereof; thence southeast along the northeast boundaries of blocks 20 and 21 and crossing Commercial Street to the east corner of block 21; thence southwest along the southeast boundaries of blocks 21, 22, 23 and 24 and crossing Adams Avenue, Jefferson Avenue, Madison Avenue and Monroe Avenue to the point of beginning, and shall be a body corporate and politic and a political subdivision of the state, and shall be known and described as the Downtown Lebanon Business District. 
(Ord. No. 1979, § 1, 7-26-76) 
Sec. 24-142. - Levy, amount of tax. 
(a)  The property in the area within the boundaries of the special business district shall be subject to the provisions of additional tax as provided in RSMo 71.790 to 71.808. The initial rate of levy of such tax upon the owners of real property lying within the boundaries of the special business district shall be eighty-five cents ($0.85) on the one hundred dollars ($100.00) assessed valuation. 
(b)  All occupations, vocations and businesses operated by an entity or individual within the district not exempt by statute shall be subject to a business license tax of fifty dollars ($50.00) per business. The license tax herein provided shall be an annual tax and shall become due and payable January 1 each year, commencing with the year 1996, and each license issued hereunder shall expire on December 31 each year. Applicants for new businesses shall be required to pay the annual tax for that business for the first taxable year of said business, or part thereof. Upon payment of said tax, the city collector shall issue to applicant a business license. No individual or business subject to said tax shall do business within the district without first having obtained a business license. The tax herein provided shall be collected and accounted for by the city collector as other city taxes are collected and accounted for. Said tax shall become delinquent on February 1 of each year. The city collector shall charge and collect and the applicant shall be required to pay a penalty of one (1) percent per month on delinquent taxes. 
(Ord. No. 2026, § 2(a), (b), 12-12-77; Ord. No. 3683, § 1, 12-26-95) 
Sec. 24-143. - When license taxes due. 
    The license tax provided in section 24-142 shall be an annual tax and shall become due and payable on the first day of January of each year and each license issued hereunder shall expire on the thirty-first day of December of each year. Applicants for new businesses shall be required to pay the minimum annual tax applicable to that business for the first taxable year of their business, or part thereof. 
(Ord. No. 2026, § 2, 12-12-77) 
Sec. 24-144. - License to be issued; doing business without license prohibited. 
    Upon payment of a license tax, the city collector shall issue to the applicant a business license. No individual or business subject to this tax shall do business within the special business district without first having obtained a business license. The license tax herein provided shall be collected and accounted for by the city collector in the same manner as are other city taxes. 
(Ord. No. 2026, § 2, 12-12-77) 
Sec. 24-145. - Delinquent taxes; penalty. 
    License taxes shall become delinquent on the first day of February of each year. The city collector shall charge and collect and the applicant shall be required to pay a penalty on delinquent taxes in the same manner as other city taxes. 
(Ord. No. 1979, § 2, 7-26-76; Ord. No. 2026, § 2, 12-12-77) 
Sec. 24-146. - Businesses and individuals encouraged to voluntarily contribute. 
    The following businesses and individuals, who are members of firms of offices with more than one individual, are hereby encouraged to voluntarily contribute to the special business district: 
(1)  Lawyers; 
(2)  Certified Public Accountants; 
(3)  Dentists; 
(4)  Chiropractors; 
(5)  Optometrists; 
(6)  Chiropodists; 
(7)  Physicians; and 
(8)  Surgeons. 
Sec. 24-147. - Use of funds; improvements. 
    The revenue from the special business district may be used for any of the following purposes: 
(1)  To close existing streets or alleys or to open new streets and alleys or to widen or narrow existing streets and alleys in whole or in part; 
(2)  To construct or install pedestrian or shopping malls, plazas, sidewalks or moving sidewalks, parks, meeting and display facilities, convention centers, arenas, bus stop shelters, lighting, benches or other seating furniture, sculptures, telephone booths, traffic signs, fire hydrants, kiosks, trash receptacles, marquees, awnings, canopies, walls and barriers, paintings, murals, alleys, shelters, display cases, fountains, rest rooms, information booths, aquariums, aviaries, tunnels and ramps, pedestrian and vehicular overpasses and underpasses and each and every other useful or necessary or desired improvement; 
(3)  To landscape and plant trees, bushes and shrubbery, flowers and every other kind of decorative planting; 
(4)  To install and operate, or to lease, public music and news facilities; 
(5)  To purchase and operate buses, minibuses, mobile benches and other modes of transportation; 
(6)  To construct and operate child-care facilities; 
(7)  To lease space within the special business district for sidewalk cafe tables and chairs; 
(8)  To construct lakes, dams, and waterways of whatever size; 
(9)  To provide special police or cleaning facilities and personnel for the protection and enjoyment of the property owners and the general public using the facilities of the special business district; 
(10)  To maintain all city owned streets, alleys, malls, bridges, ramps, tunnels, lawns, trees and decorative plantings of each and every nature, and every structure or object of any nature whatsoever constructed or operated by the city; 
(11)  To grant permits for newsstands, sidewalk cafes and each and every other useful or necessary or desired private usage of public or private property; 
(12)  To prohibit or restrict vehicular traffic on those streets within the business district as the city council may deem necessary and to provide the means for access by emergency vehicles to or in these areas; 
(13)  To lease, acquire, construct, reconstruct, extend, maintain or repair parking lots or parking garages, both above and below ground, or other facilities for the parking of vehicles, including the power to install these facilities in public areas, whether the areas are owned in fee or by easement; and 
(14)  To promote business activity in the special business district by, but not limited to, advertising, decoration of any public place in the area, promotion of public events which are to take place on or in public places, furnishing of music in any public place and the general promotion of trade activities in the special business district. 
(Ord. No. 1979, § 3, 7-26-76) 
Secs. 24-148-24-160. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ADVISORY BOARD[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Cross reference- Boards, commissions and committees, § 2-251 et seq. 

Sec. 24-161. - Created. 
    An advisory board is hereby created to make recommendations to the city council as to the use of the revenue from the special business district consisting of nine (9) members to be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1979, § 4, 7-26-76) 
Sec. 24-162. - Qualifications for membership. 
    Members of the advisory board shall be at least eighteen (18) years of age and either owners of real property or owners or managers of businesses within the special business district. 
(Ord. No. 1979, § 4(a), 7-26-76) 
Sec. 24-163. - Forfeiture, removal of membership. 
    Membership on the advisory board shall be automatically forfeited in the event a member is absent without leave for four (4) consecutive regular meetings and his office shall thereupon become vacant. The city council may remove any member of the advisory board for misconduct or neglect of duty. 
(Ord. No. 1979, § 4(b), 7-26-76) 
Sec. 24-164. - Term of membership; compensation. 
    The term of membership of members of the advisory board shall be three (3) years. No member of the advisory board shall receive compensation for his duties. 
(Ord. No. 1979, § 4(c), (d), 9-26-76) 
Sec. 24-165. - Nepotism prohibited. 
    No person shall be employed by the special business district who is related to a member of the advisory board either by blood or marriage, and no business shall be conducted with firms which are owned in whole or part by a person related to a member of the advisory board either by blood or marriage. 
(Ord. No. 1979, § 4(e), 9-26-76) 
Sec. 24-166. - Duties. 
    The advisory board has the responsibility of performing the primary administrative functions of the special business district. These functions include, but are not limited to: 
(1)  Election of officers. Elections among the members of the advisory board for all officer positions shall occur annually during the month of August. A Chairman, Vice Chairman, and Secretary-Treasurer of the advisory board shall be elected and shall function as an executive committee. The members of the advisory board may create such other committees as they deem necessary. 
(2)  Rule and regulations. The advisory board shall make and adopt such bylaws, rules and regulations for their own guidance and for the administration of the special business district as may be appropriate, but not inconsistent with this Code or any other ordinances of the city or with state law. 
(3)  Development of plan. The advisory board shall be responsible for the development and maintenance of an overall plan of action for the district. The advisory board shall hold at least one meeting a year to which all persons owning property or owning or managing businesses within the boundaries of the district may attend with the purpose of reviewing and updating the plan. Meetings of the board shall be held at the call of the chairman, and at such other times as the board may determine. All meetings of the board shall be open to the public. All business of the board shall be conducted at such public meeting. A quorum for the transaction of business shall consist of a majority of all of the members of the board and any decision of the board shall require an affirmative vote of a majority of the members in attendance at the meeting. 
(4)  Budget. The advisory board shall create and maintain a budget for any existing revenue and the anticipated revenue of the special business district for the year following the date of the last budget. The budget shall be submitted to the city council for approval by the first day of March of each year. The advisory board may make recommendations for the modification or elaboration of the budget to the city council at any time. 
(5)  Annual report. The advisory board shall submit an annual report of its activities to the city council by the first day of March of each year. Upon receipt of the annual report, the city council shall place the report on file with the city clerk and note that it is available for public inspection. 
(Ord. No. 1979, § 4(f), 9-26-76; Ord. No. 4035, § 1, 11-13-00) 
Secs. 24-167-24-180. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - LODGING TAX[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3954, § 1, adopted Sept. 13, 1999, enacted provisions intended for use as Art. V, §§ 24-113-24-119; however, as this subject matter differs significantly from what is currently found in Art. V, it has been added as a new Art. VIII, §§ 24-181-24-187, at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 24-181. - Definitions. 
    The terms used in this article shall have the meaning ascribed to them in this section and shall be construed as indicated in this section. 
    Tax rate. The term tax rate or "lodging tax" is that amount of tax levied on a hotel, motel, lodge, bed and breakfast inn or campground based on charges made by the hotel, motel, lodge, bed and breakfast inn or campground for sleeping accommodations. 
    Gross receipts is based upon the applicable revenue received by the hotel, motel, lodge, bed and breakfast inn or campground for rental of guest rooms, lodgings or campsites. 
    Hotel, motel, lodge, bed and breakfast inn and campground means any structure, or building, which contains rooms or any campsite, under one management, furnished for the accommodation or lodging of guests kept, used, maintained, advertised or held out to the public as a place where sleeping accommodations are sought for pay or compensation to transient guests. 
    Transient guest means any person who occupies a room in a hotel, motel or campsite for thirty-one (31) days or less. 
(Ord. No. 3954, § 1, 9-13-99) 
Sec. 24-182. - Levy of tax. 
    There is hereby levied a license tax on hotels, motels and campgrounds in an amount equal to two and one-half (21/2) percent of gross receipts derived from transient guests for sleeping accommodations. This tax shall be in addition to all other taxes which are applicable to hotels, motels and campgrounds. 
(Ord. No. 3954, § 1, 9-13-99) 
Sec. 24-183. - Convention, visitors and tourist promotion funding. 
    All revenues received from the two and one-half (21/2) percent lodging tax shall be utilized by the city for promoting the city as a convention, visitor and tourist center. 
(Ord. No. 3954, § 1, 9-13-99) 
Sec. 24-184. - Use of fund. 
    The lodging tax funds shall be used exclusively to promote tourism, conventions and other related activities. 
(Ord. No. 3954, § 1, 9-13-99) 
Sec. 24-185. - Reports required. 
    Every person engaged in the business of operating a hotel, motel, lodge, bed and breakfast inn or campground shall file with the city clerk prescribed forms, giving such information as may be necessary to determine the amounts to which the license tax shall apply for the monthly period, to be submitted with monthly payments. Such report and payment shall be due on the 30th day of the following month. 
(Ord. No. 3954, § 1, 9-13-99) 
Sec. 24-186. - Examination of books, records. 
    The city administrator or an authorized representative shall have the right at all reasonable times during business hours to make such examination and inspection of the books and records of the licensee as may be necessary to determine the correctness of the reports required by this article. 
(Ord. No. 3954, § 1, 9-13-99) 
Sec. 24-187. - Penalties for nonpayment. 
    For each month, or part thereof, any lodging tax provided for under this article remains unpaid after the same shall be due and payable, there shall be added to such lodging tax as a penalty and interest, three (3) percent of the amount of such lodging tax for the first month or part thereof the same is unpaid, and for each and every month thereafter three (3) percent of the amount of such lodging tax and penalty shall be added until the same is fully paid. In addition to the penalties provided herein, any person subject to the provisions of this article who fails to pay the lodging tax or files a false or fraudulent statement, required by this article or within the time required by this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) or by imprisonment not exceeding three (3) months, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. No. 3954, § 1, 9-13-99) 
Sec. 24-188. - Established. 
    An advisory committee is hereby established to advise the director of tourism and governing body and make recommendations regarding lodging tax as enacted in chapter 24, article VIII, section 24-182 of the Code of Ordinances and other tourism revenues which may be generated, tourism and marketing committee membership, programs and expenditures for promotion of convention and tourism related activities, which shall be known as the Lebanon Tourism and Marketing Advisory Committee. 
(Ord. No. 5105, § 1, 7-22-13) 
Sec. 24-189. - Appointment: term of office, removal from office. 
(a)  The advisory committee shall consist of nine (9) members who shall be appointed by the mayor and approved by a majority of the members of city council. The members shall consist of a community leader or a representative of a business in the City of Lebanon, one from each sector: an hotelier, a retailer, a restaurateur, an operator from the Bennett Spring area, a Route 66 Society member, a member of the city council, two (2) at-large representatives residing in the City of Lebanon with working tourism/marketing knowledge, and a citizen at-large from within Laclede County, not within the incorporated limits of the city, with working tourism/marketing knowledge. The mayor shall appoint an alternate council member for a term no longer than one year. The alternate council member shall only participate and vote in the event the regular council member is absent. The city administrator, the President of the Lebanon Regional Economic Development Incorporated and the executive director of the Lebanon Area Chamber of Commerce will sit on the committee as non-voting members. 
(b)  Members of the advisory committee shall serve without pay and shall serve at the pleasure of the appointing authority. The mayor, with the approval of a majority of the city council, may remove a committee member from the committee at will, and such committee member may also be removed by a three-fourths vote of the city council independently of the mayor's approval or disapproval. Failure to attend three (3) consecutive meetings shall constitute grounds for dismissal. 
(c)  The term of office of all regular members shall be for a two (2) year period. The governing body shall provide for the appointments and two-year terms of service for such members. Terms of members shall be staggered so that no more than three (3) members are appointed in any one year. Any vacancies in the membership of the committee shall be filled by the appointment of a new member to fill the unexpired term of the member whose office is vacant. 
(Ord. No. 5105, § 1, 7-22-13) 
Sec. 24-190. - Organization-Powers. 
(a)  The advisory committee shall meet and organize by electing one of their members as president and any other officers as deemed necessary. Meetings of the committee shall be at the call of the president or the director of tourism. The advisory committee shall set their annual meeting schedule. All meetings of the advisory committee shall be open to the public. Any decisions of the advisory committee shall require an affirmative vote of a majority of the advisory committee. 
(b)  It is the duty of the advisory committee to prepare a proposed budget to present to the city administrator for consideration, on or by the 31 st day of May. The committee shall not bind the City of Lebanon or its agents to any contract, agreement or any other obligation. The advisory committee shall not have the authority to supervise nor direct any employee, agent or vendor of the City of Lebanon. 
(c)  An annual report should be presented to the city council, on or before the 30 st day of June. Nothing shall prohibit the city council from calling upon the advisory committee for a report at any time the city council deems it advisable to make a report, and when so called upon, it shall be the duty of the president of the advisory committee or the director of tourism to make the report as required. 
(Ord. No. 5105, § 1, 7-22-13) 
Chapter 25 - TRAFFIC AND MOTOR VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Ordinances establishing any speed limit, one-way street, traffic device, signal or marking, any parking regulation, or any limitation placed upon the use of specific streets for vehicles or pedestrians saved from repeal, § 1-6(13); authority of municipal judge to create traffic violations bureau, § 8-27; abandoned, wrecked and dismantled vehicles, § 13-30 et seq.; offenses generally, Ch. 14; motor vehicle noise regulated, § 14-98(b)(1), (8); speed limits in parks, § 15-1; police, Ch. 18; placement of handbills on motor vehicles restricted, § 20-10; vehicles for collection of solid waste, § 21-56 et seq.; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 22; transportation sales tax, § 24-126 et seq.; vehicles for hire, Ch. 28; taxicabs, § 28-16 et seq. 
State Law reference- Motor vehicles, RSMo Ch. 300 et seq.; municipal regulation of traffic, RSMo 304.120. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 25-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
    Alley or alleyway shall mean any street with a roadway of less than twenty (20) feet in width. 
    Authorized emergency vehicle shall mean a vehicle publicly owned and operated as an ambulance or a vehicle publicly owned and operated by the state highway patrol, police or fire department, sheriff or constable or deputy sheriff; traffic officer or any privately owned vehicle operated as an ambulance when responding to emergency calls. 
    Bicycle shall mean every vehicle propelled solely by human power upon which any person may ride, having two (2) tandem wheels, except scooters and similar devices. 
    Bus shall mean any vehicle or motor car designed and used for the purpose of carrying more than seven (7) persons. 
    Business district shall mean the territory contiguous to and including a highway when within any six hundred (600) feet along the highway there are buildings in use for business or industrial purposes, including but not limited to hotels, banks or office buildings, railroad stations and public buildings which occupy at least three hundred (300) feet of frontage on one side or three hundred (300) feet collectively on both sides of the highway. 
    Central business (or traffic) district shall mean all streets and portions of streets within the area described by city ordinance as such. 
    Commercial vehicle shall mean every vehicle designed, maintained, or used primarily for the transportation of property. 
    Controlled access highway shall mean every highway, street or roadway in respect to which owners or occupants of abutting lands and other persons have no legal right of access to or from the same except at such points only and in such manner as may be determined by the public authority having jurisdiction over the highway, street or roadway. 
    Crosswalk shall mean: 
(1)  That part of a roadway at an intersection included within the connections of the lateral lines of the sidewalks on opposite sides of the highway measured from the curbs, or in the absence of curbs from the edges of the traversable roadway. 
(2)  Any portion of a roadway at an intersection or elsewhere distinctly indicated for pedestrian crossing by lines or other markings on the surface. 
    Curb shall mean the lateral boundaries of that portion of a street designated for the use of vehicles, whether marked with curbstones or not. 
    Curb loading zone shall mean a space adjacent to a curb reserved for the exclusive use of vehicles during the loading or unloading of passengers or materials. 
    Driver shall mean every person who drives or is in actual physical control of a vehicle. 
    Freight curb loading zone shall mean a space adjacent to a curb for the exclusive use of vehicles during the loading or unloading of freight (or passengers). 
    Highway shall mean the entire width between the boundary lines of every way publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular travel. 
    Improved street or highway shall mean a street or highway which has been paved with gravel, macadam, concrete, brick or asphalt, or improved in any manner by adding material or substances so as to present a surface other than the original earth surface. 
    Intersection shall mean: 
(1)  The area embraced within the prolongation or connection of the lateral curb lines, or, if none, then the lateral boundary lines of the roadways of two (2) highways which join one another at, or approximately at, right angles, or the area within which vehicles traveling upon different highways joining at any other angle may come in conflict. 
(2)  Where a highway includes two (2) roadways thirty (30) feet or more apart, then every crossing of each roadway of the divided highway by an intersecting highway shall be regarded as a separate intersection. In the event the intersecting highway also includes two (2) roadways thirty (30) feet or more apart, then every crossing of two (2) roadways of the highways shall be regarded as a separate intersection. 
    Laned roadway shall mean a roadway which is divided into two (2) or more clearly marked lanes for vehicular traffic. 
    Live load shall mean the weight of the cargo of a commercial vehicle, in addition to that of the chassis and body of the vehicle. 
    Motor bus shall mean a motor vehicle designed or regularly used for carrying more than eight (8) passengers. 
    Motor vehicle shall mean any self-propelled vehicle not operated exclusively upon tracks, except farm tractors and motorized bicycles. 
    Motorcycle shall mean every motor vehicle having a seat or saddle for the use of the rider and designed to travel on not more than three (3) wheels in contact with the ground, but excluding a tractor. 
    Motorized bicycle shall mean any two-wheeled or three-wheeled device having fully operative pedals capable of propulsion by human power, and automatic transmission and a motor with a cylinder capacity of not more than fifty (50) cubic centimeters, which produces less than two (2) gross brake horsepower, and is capable of propelling the device at a maximum speed of not more than thirty (30) miles per hour on level ground. 
    Official time standard shall mean that whenever certain hours are named herein, they shall mean standard time or daylight-saving time as may be in current use in the city. 
    Official traffic-control devices shall mean all signs, signals, markings and devices not inconsistent with this chapter placed or erected by authority of a public body or official having jurisdiction, for the purpose of regulating, warning or guiding traffic. 
    One-way street shall mean a street where vehicles are required to move in one direction only. 
    Operator shall mean any person who is in actual physical control of a vehicle. 
    Park or parking shall mean the standing of a vehicle, whether occupied or not, otherwise than temporarily for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading merchandise or passengers. 
    Passenger curb loading zone shall mean a place adjacent to a curb reserved for the exclusive use of vehicles during the loading or unloading of passengers. 
    Pedestrian shall mean any person afoot. 
    Pneumatic tires shall mean tires of rubber or other substance and fabric, inflated with air. 
    Police officer shall mean every officer of the municipal police department or any officer authorized to direct or regulate traffic or to make arrests for violations of traffic regulations. 
    Private road or driveway shall mean every way or place in private ownership and used for vehicular travel by the owner and those having express or implied permission from the owner, but not by other persons. 
    Railroad shall mean a carrier of persons or property upon cars, other than streetcars, operated upon stationary rails. 
    Railroad train shall mean a steam engine, electric or other motor, with or without cars coupled thereto, operated upon rails, except streetcars. 
    Residence district shall mean the territory contiguous to and including a highway not comprising a business district when the property on such highway for a distance of three hundred (300) feet or more is in the main improved with residences or residences and buildings in use for business. 
    Right-of-way shall mean the right of one vehicle or pedestrian to proceed in a lawful manner in preference to another vehicle or pedestrian approaching under such circumstances of direction, speed and proximity as to give rise to danger of collision unless one grants precedence to the other. 
    Roadway shall mean that portion of a highway improved, designed or ordinarily used for vehicular travel, exclusive of the berm or shoulder. In the event a highway includes two (2) or more separate roadways the term "roadway" as used herein shall refer to any such roadway separately but not to all such roadways collectively. 
    Safety zone shall mean the area or space officially set apart within a roadway for the exclusive use of pedestrians and which is protected or is so marked or indicated by adequate signs as to be plainly visible at all times while set apart as a safety zone. 
    School zone shall mean a space in any street lawfully designated by ordinance for the safety of persons going to and returning from public, private or parochial schools. 
    Service car shall mean a motor vehicle other than a motor bus, offered for or engaged in carrying passengers for hire over a designated route for a fixed fare and over the route of which the passenger has not control. 
    Sidewalk shall mean that portion of a street between the curb lines, or the lateral lines of a roadway, and the adjacent property lines, intended for use of pedestrians. 
    Solid tires shall mean tires of rubber or other resilient material, other than pneumatic tires. 
    State highway shall mean a highway maintained by the state as a part of the state highway system. 
    Stand or standing shall mean the halting of a vehicle, whether occupied or not, otherwise than for the purpose of and while actually engaged in receiving or discharging passengers. 
    Stop shall mean when required, complete cessation from movement. 
    Stop or stopping shall mean when prohibited, any halting even momentarily of a vehicle, whether occupied or not, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or traffic control sign or signal. 
    Street or highway shall mean the entire width between the lines of every way publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the uses of the public for purposes of vehicular travel. 
    Taxicab shall mean a motor vehicle other than a motor bus or service car offered for or engaged in carrying passengers for hire. 
    Through highway shall mean every highway or portion thereof on which vehicular traffic is given preferential right-of-way, and at the entrances to which vehicular traffic from intersecting highways is required by law to yield the right-of-way to vehicles on the through highway in obedience to either a stop sign or a yield sign, when such signs are erected as provided in this chapter. 
    Tractor shall mean any motor vehicle designed primarily for agricultural use of used as a traveling power plant or for drawing other vehicles or farm or road-building implements and having no provision for carrying loads independently. 
    Traffic shall mean pedestrians, ridden or herded animals, vehicles, streetcars and other conveyances either singly or together while using any highway for purposes of travel. 
    Traffic-control signal shall mean any device, whether manually, electrically or mechanically operated, by which traffic is alternately directed to stop and to proceed. 
    Traffic division shall mean the traffic division of the police department of the city, or in the event a traffic division is not established, then the term whenever used herein shall be deemed to refer to the police department of the city. 
    Trailer shall mean any vehicle without motive power designed for carrying passengers or property on its own structure for being drawn by any vehicle, except those running exclusively on tracks, including a semitrailer or vehicle of the trailer. 
    Truck shall mean any vehicle, machine, tractor, trailer or semitrailer, or any combination thereof, propelled or drawn by mechanical power and designed or used in the transportation of property upon the highways. 
    Vehicle shall mean every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway, excepting motorized bicycles and devices moved by human power or used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
(Code 1967, §§ 14-1, 14-129) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Similar definitions, RSMo 300.010, 304.044, 307.180. 
Sec. 25-2. - Certain traffic regulations continued in effect. 
    Each ordinance which is in effect immediately prior to the effective date of this Code and which is for the purpose of regulating the speed of motor vehicles upon the public streets, establishing one-way streets and alleys, establishing stop signs and signals for the purpose of regulating and stopping motor vehicle traffic upon the public streets, prohibiting the parking of motor vehicles upon the public streets at all times or at specified times, and designating public streets upon which commercial vehicles may not operate shall continue in full force and effect from and after the effective date of this Code and not be repealed until such time as additional ordinances shall be adopted and become effective in accordance with this chapter. 
Sec. 25-3. - Official traffic-control devices continued in effect. 
    All official traffic-control devices, as such term is defined herein, which are lawfully in place immediately prior to the effective date of this Code are hereby redesignated as official traffic-control devices, and each shall continue to be such until changed, replaced or removed pursuant to ordinance of the city council or directive of the city traffic engineer. 
Sec. 25-4. - Applicability of chapter to public employees. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall apply to the driver of any vehicle owned by or used in the service of the United States government, this state, county or city, and it shall be unlawful for any such driver to violate any of the provisions of this chapter, except as otherwise permitted in this chapter. 
(Code 1967, § 14-5; Ord. No. 3015, § 4, 8-11-80) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.095. 
Sec. 25-5. - Applicability of chapter to persons riding bicycles or animals, propelling pushcarts. 
    Every person propelling any pushcart or riding a bicycle or an animal upon a roadway, and every person driving any animal-drawn vehicle, shall be subject to the provisions of this chapter applicable to the driver of any vehicle, except those provisions of this chapter which by their very nature can have no application. 
(Code 1967, § 14-6) 
Cross reference- Animals, Ch. 5. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.085. 
Sec. 25-6. - Obedience to police and fire department officials. 
    No person shall willfully fail or refuse to comply with any lawful order or direction of a police officer or fire department official. 
(Code 1967, § 14-4) 
Cross reference- Fire department, § 10-16 et seq.; merit system police department, § 18-16 et seq. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.080. 
Sec. 25-7. - Commercial vehicles prohibited from using certain streets. 
    In cases where an equally direct and convenient alternate route is provided, an ordinance may describe and signs may be erected giving notice thereof, that no persons shall operate any commercial vehicle upon streets or parts of streets so described except those commercial vehicles making deliveries thereon.
