Sec. 26-45. - Review of user charge system; notice of rate to be charged. 
(a)  The city will review the user charge system annually and revise user charge rates as necessary to ensure the system generates adequate revenues to pay the costs of operation and maintenance, including replacement, and continues to provide for the proportional distribution of operation and maintenance, including replacement costs, among users. 
(b)  The city will notify each user at least annually, in conjunction with a regular bill, of the rate being charged for operation and maintenance, including replacement, of the treatment works. 
(Ord. No. 3027, art. VI, §§ 1, 2, 10-27-80) 
Sec. 26-46. - Owner and occupant both responsible for sums due for sewerage services. 
    Sewerage services shall be deemed to be furnished to both the occupant and owner of the premises receiving the service and the city shall sue the occupant or owner, or both, of the real estate in a civil action to recover any sums due for sewerage services, plus a reasonable attorney's fee to be fixed by the court hearing the case. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 250.140. 
Secs. 26-47-26-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - INFILTRATION AND INFLOW 

Sec. 26-51. - Definitions. 
    The definitions set forth in this section shall be applicable to this division and shall not supersede, amend or alter other codes or enactments of the city. 
    Access. Entry into or upon any real estate or structure including any part thereof. 
    Accessible. Capable of being reached without excavation. 
    Administration. The City of Lebanon is hereby designated as responsible for administering the provisions of this division. 
    Domestic wastewater. Liquid and waterborne waste derived principally from dwellings, business buildings, institutions and the like; free from industrial wastes, and of such character as to permit sanitary disposal without special treatment into the public sewer or by means of a private sewage disposal system. 
    Infiltration. Water, as herein defined, entering the sanitary sewer system, including private sewer service connections, from the ground, through such means as, but not limited to, defective pipes, pipe joints, connections, or manhole walls. Infiltration does not include, and is distinguished from, inflow. 
    Infiltration/inflow. A combination of infiltration and inflow water entering the sanitary sewer lines, with no way of distinguishing the basic source, and which tends to cause an overloading of the capacities of the sanitary sewer system. 
    Inflow. Water discharged into the sanitary sewer system, including service connections, from such means as, but not limited to, roof downspouts or leaders; cellar, yard, and area drains; sump pumps; foundation drains; cleanouts; cooling water discharge; drains from springs and swampy areas; manhole covers; cross connections from storm sewers; combined sewers; catch basins; storm waters; surface runoff; street washwaters; or drainage. Inflow does not include, and is distinguished from, infiltration. 
    Industrial wastes. Liquid wastes from industrial processes as distinct from domestic. 
    Lessee. A person, firm or corporation who has possession and control of property and/or a structure and who has responsibility, pursuant to a written agreement with the owner, to maintain, repair or replace sanitary sewer lines and/or discharges which cause infiltration and/or inflow as herein defined. 
    Person. Any individual, firm, partnership, corporation, estate, governmental agency, or any other legal entity and/or assigns. 
    Sanitary sewer system. All lines, pipes, tanks, conduits, structures or other devices designed for the collection, transportation, storage, treatment or disposal of sewage, whether owned by the city or other persons, and to which storm, surface, and ground waters are not intentionally admitted. 
    Schedule of compliance. A schedule of remedial measures and times including an enforceable sequence of actions or operations leading to compliance with this division. 
    Sewage. A combination of domestic or industrial wastewater which may include chemical, house wastes, laundry wastes, human excreta, animal or vegetable matter in suspension or solution, and other solids in suspension or solution, and which is discharged from a dwelling, building, or other structure and permitted to enter the sanitary sewer system for the purpose of treatment and disposal. 
    Wastewater treatment facility. The system or facility for treating, neutralizing, stabilizing, or disposing of sewage. The term "wastewater treatment facility" also includes appurtenances such as interceptors, collection lines, outfall and outlet sewers, pumping stations, and related equipment. 
(Ord. No. 4181, § 1, 3-31-03) 
Sec. 26-52. - Prohibited connections. 
    No person shall henceforth make or allow the continued connection of roof downspouts or leaders, interior or exterior foundation drains, cleanouts, sump pumps, cellar, yard, and area drains, cooling water discharges, drains from springs or swampy areas, or other sources of surface, storm or ground water to a structure sewer or structure drain which is connected, either directly or indirectly, to the sanitary sewer system, even though such connection may have been permitted when installed under the existing ordinances, rules, regulations, or standards in force at the time of installation. Provided, however, that interior or exterior perimeter building foundation drains connected directly into the sanitary sewer system will be exempt from the provisions of this Ordinance if the connect point is not accessible and the drainage system was installed prior to 1971. Otherwise, the connection is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 4181, § 2, 3-31-03) 
Sec. 26-53. - Inspection; access and entry. 
(a)  Access. Representatives of the City of Lebanon shall have the right to make an inspection of any parcel of real estate and/or structure for the purpose of determining compliance with this division. Inspections shall be done at a reasonable hour of the day. 
(b)  Owner/occupant contact. If the structure or real estate to be inspected is occupied, the representative shall first present proper credentials and request entry. If the structure or real estate is unoccupied, he shall first make a reasonable effort to locate the owner or other person(s) having charge or control of the structure or real estate and request entry. 
(c)  Search warrants. If, after proper request, entry or access is refused, the City of Lebanon may compel such access by application to a court of competent jurisdiction for a search warrant in compliance with the provisions of Article I, Section 15 of the Missouri Constitution and the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution relating to unreasonable searches and seizures. 
(Ord. No. 4181, § 3, 3-31-03) 
Sec. 26-54. - Nuisance declared; notice of violation; abatement of nuisance. 
(a)  Nuisance declared. The existence of a private infiltration or inflow source is hereby declared to be a nuisance adversely affecting the health and welfare of citizens and the wastewater treatment facility. 
(b)  Notice of disconnect order. If the inspection discloses that a private infiltration or inflow source exists, the director of public works or his designee, "director," shall notify the owner(s), lessee and occupant(s) (the person responsible for compliance, hereinafter sometimes referred to as "owner") in possession of the property that a nuisance exists by reason of the inability of the waste treatment facilities to properly treat sewage and ordering that the private infiltration or inflow connection which is discharging prohibited liquid from real estate or structure(s) must be disconnected. Such notification shall be made by any one of the following methods: 
(1)  Delivery of the notice to the owner(s) and the person occupying or having possession of the property if different than the owner; or 
(2)  Depositing in the United States mail, postage prepaid, the notice addressed to the owner(s) and the person occupying or having possession or the right to possession of the property if different than the owner; or 
(3)  If such property is not occupied, the "director" shall notify the owner(s) by posting a notice of his order to abate or remove such nuisance within a time to be specified in such notice upon such property and shall send a copy of such notice by registered return receipt mail to the last known address of the owners; or 
(4)  If such property is not occupied and the owner(s) is unknown or cannot be located, then the code enforcement official shall post a notice containing an order to abate the nuisance on the property where such nuisance exists; or 
(5)  By delivery of a notice or by depositing in the United States registered return receipt mail, postage prepaid, a notice to the person causing, maintaining or permitting the nuisance. 
(6)  Compliance work must commence within sixty (60) days of issuance and must be complete no later than ninety (90) days after the date of issuance. 
(7)  If the owner(s) disagrees with the order, the owner(s) shall, within thirty (30) days of service request a hearing before the code board of appeals of the City of Lebanon, Missouri, by filing an appeal in writing, which request shall be delivered to the building and zoning administrator. 
(8)  Thereafter, the building and zoning administrator shall deliver the request to the chairman of the code of the board of appeals who shall schedule a hearing to be held within thirty (30) days of the receipt of the request and shall notify the owner at the owner(s)' address (which must be set forth in the request) of the date, time and location of the hearing. 
(9)  The filing of the request shall act as a stay of the order. 
(10)  The board, after hearing the evidence, may affirm, set aside or modify the order but does not have the authority to do so if the board finds that no private infiltration or inflow exists, in which case the order shall be dismissed. 
(11)  In the event the board determines that infiltration and/or inflow does exist, the owner(s) shall have the right to appeal the decision to the Laclede County Circuit Court within ten (10) days and thereafter the State Administrative rules of procedure, Chapter 536, R.S.Mo., shall apply. 
(12)  In the event the board's decision is not appealed or the appeal is upheld by the court, the "owner(s)" shall: 
a.  Comply with the order by either performing the work or having the work done by a registered plumbing or sewer contractor. 
b.  All work shall be done in a workmanlike manner and shall be performed in compliance with adopted codes and regulations and city standards. 
c.  After completion of the work, the City of Lebanon shall reinspect the premises to verify compliance with the disconnect order and also confirm that there are no other private infiltration or inflow sources on the property. 
(Ord. No. 4181, § 4, 3-31-03) 
Sec. 26-55. - Grant applications; guidelines. 
(a)  If a low income owner(s) who has completed compliance with this Code needs financial assistance, rehab funds may be available if the applicant meets the following qualifications: 
(1)  Grant qualifications. 
a.  Income limits for applications. 
Number of persons/ 
household annual

b.  The property to be rehabilitated must have been owned by the applicant prior to April 1, 2003. 
c.  An applicant must not have net assets in excess of thirty thousand ($30,000.00), including equity in property, other than the residence where the applicant resides. 
d.  The applicant must have a recorded proof of ownership. A lease or contract for deed properly executed shall not constitute ownership, but shall be considered a rental. The buyer and the seller or the owner and lessee will be required to make joint application and jointly execute the contract for rehabilitation work. 
e.  The applicant must be under age sixty-two (62) at the time of application. 
(2)  Application-Procedure requirements. Applicants wishing to make application for rehab funds must do the following: 
a.  Fill out an application with the city clerk. 
b.  Submit a recorded deed to the property. 
c.  Submit income verification. An income tax return for the year prior to the start of rehab work will be acceptable, or payroll receipts for a period of twelve (12) months preceding the rehab work. 
(3)  Reimbursements. If an applicant qualifies for a grant and has complied with the procedural requirements outlined above, the city will reimburse the applicants an amount equal to one hundred (100) percent of the owner(s)' cash expenditure for contract labor and material; but in no case shall the reimbursement exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per structure or parcel of real estate even though there are a multitude of sources; and, in no event shall the reimbursement exceed the following maximum amounts per source: 
Source description Maximum amount 1. Directly connected storm sump pump $500.00 per sump pump 2. Combination sanitary/storm sump $1,000.00 per sump pump 3. Cellar, yard, foundation, and area drains (driveway, patio, basement entry, etc.) $500.00 each 4. Downspout or leader $100.00 each 5. Cleanout $50.00 each 6. Unusual circumstance $1,000.00 each  
(4)  Requests for partial reimbursements; requirements. It is the responsibility of the owner(s) requesting partial reimbursement to submit a "certification of cost" to the City of Lebanon which shall include an itemization of the work performed, including man hours of contract labor and material used. A receipt for the material, from the store or supplier where purchased, showing the price and quantities shall be attached to the certification of costs. If the work has been performed by a registered plumber, the owner(s) shall, in addition, submit a personally endorsed statement from the plumber or sewer contractor which shall be attached to the certification, verifying that the charges for the labor and material are true and correct. Acceptance of reimbursement shall constitute a consent by the person accepting such payment to a reinspection of the premises by the city within five (5) years following payment for the sole purpose of verifying continued compliance with this division. Such inspection shall be done at a reasonable time of day. 
(b)  Applicants who meet low income guidelines and who are over the age of sixty-two (62) may receive grants through the USDA Rural Development Sec. 504 Home Repair Loans and Grants Program. Grant information will be provided to prospective applicants by the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 4181, § 5, 3-31-03) 
Sec. 26-56. - Appeals. 
    In the event the administrative appeal is upheld in the city's favor or if the owner(s) do not appeal and fails and refuses to comply with the requirements of this ordinance, the city may proceed to abate the nuisance at the owner(s)' expense in which case the following provisions shall apply: 
(1)  Liability for costs; lien. The cost for abating the said nuisance shall be computed by the director, who shall certify all costs of the same to the city clerk who shall cause a special tax bill therefor to be prepared and issued against the real estate involved and to cause the same to be collected by the collector of the County of Laclede, together with other taxes assessed against the said property; each special tax bill shall be issued by the city clerk and delivered to the collector on or before the first day of June of each year and such tax bill shall bear interest at the rate of eight (8) percent per annum pursuant to the provisions of Section 71.285, R.S.Mo. Said tax bill shall be a first lien on the said real estate until paid and shall be prima facie evidence of the recitals therein and of its validity and no mere clerical error or informality in the same or in the proceedings leading up the issuance shall be a defense thereto. 
(2)  Termination of service. The city shall also have the option to terminate sanitary sewer service to any real estate or structure if the owner(s) or lessee has refused to allow access and entry for inspection or has failed or refused to comply with the disconnect order requiring that the private infiltration or inflow waters be prohibited from entering the sanitary sewer system. The termination shall be effective thirty (30) days after notice is served upon the owner(s) or lessee. 
Within fifteen (15) days after receipt of the termination order, the owner or lessee may request a hearing by filing written request therefore with the code board of appeals. The filing of such request shall act as a stay of the termination. After the hearing, the code board of appeals may affirm, set aside or modify the terms of the order. The decision of the code board of appeals entered after such a review hearing may be appealed to the Laclede County Circuit Court within ten (10) days, after notice of the decision is served, and thereafter the State Administrative rules of procedure, Chapter 536, R.S.Mo., shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 4181, § 6, 3-31-03) 
Sec. 26-57. - Additional remedies for abatement of nuisances. 
(a)  Injunctive powers. In addition to the remedies and/or penalties set forth in this chapter, the director is hereby authorized to file and obtain injunctions on behalf of the city against persons who are violating provisions of this chapter. In the event the city seeks injunctive relief from the circuit court for violations of this chapter, penalty provisions set forth in this chapter shall not apply. The city council finds and declares that the remedies set forth in this chapter may be inadequate to protect the public health, safety and welfare from violations which are continuous or violations that are repeated. 
(b)  Assessment of court costs upon finding of violation. Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, if, upon a trial for the violation of this article, the judge of the municipal court shall find that a violation exists and that the defendant has had proper notice, as provided in this chapter, and the defendant has failed to abate the nuisance, the judge of the municipal court shall have the right, in addition to the penalty for violating this chapter, to enter an order directing the director to abate such nuisance forthwith, and immediately report the expense thereof to the judge of the municipal court, who shall, as a part of the costs of such prosecution, render judgment against the owner(s) for the amount of such expense, which shall be collected as other fines and costs. 
(c)  Penalties and procedures cumulative, not exclusive. No proceeding in municipal court for prosecution of a violation of any section of this chapter shall prohibit or be any bar to a proceeding by the city under any other of the proceedings available in this chapter. For example, the city may prosecute a violation of this chapter by seeking the sanctions provided for in section 1-12, may process an abatement proceeding, may terminate utility service or may seek injunctive relief or a combination of any one or more of the foregoing. 
(Ord. No. 4181, § 7, 3-31-03) 
Sec. 26-58. - Disclaimer of liability. 
    This division shall not be construed or interpreted as imposing upon the city or its officials or employees (1) any liability or responsibility for damages to any property; or (2) any representation or warranty that any system, installation or portion thereof that is constructed or repaired under orders and inspections required by this division will function properly. In addition, neither the city nor any of its officials and employees charged with the enforcement of this Ordinance, if acting in good faith and without malice in the discharge of their duties, shall be personally liable for any damage that may occur to persons or property as a result of performing or not performing any act required by this division. 
(Ord. No. 4181, § 9, 3-31-03) 
ARTICLE III. - WATER SERVICE[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6; plumbing code, § 6-161 et seq.; flood plain management, Ch. 11. 
State Law reference- Regulations concerning municipal water works in third class cities, RSMo 91.090 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 26-61. - Unauthorized construction of water lines prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person or the agent thereof to construct any water line over and across the street, alley or public property within the city limits unless first getting approval from the mayor and city council. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person or the agent thereof to construct a water line over and across any private property upon which the city has a utility easement. This section applies to the construction of lines over and across any easement, but not private property adjacent thereto. Any exceptions hereto shall first have the approval of the mayor and city council. 
(Ord. No. 1715, §§ 2, 3, 9-28-67) 
Sec. 26-62. - Scope of prohibition on unauthorized lines. 
    The provisions of section 26-61 shall extend to the property designated therein even though the street or alley has not been dedicated or conveyed by recorded legal instrument. These provisions shall not affect existing water lines. 
(Ord. No. 1715, §§ 4, 5, 9-28-67) 
Sec. 26-63. - City will provide water. 
    The city will provide water to all consumers presently receiving service from its water system and in addition will serve all new customers within the city limits where water is required, provided the requirements of section 26-83 are met. 
(Ord. No. 3009, § 2, 5-28-80; Ord. No. 3070, § 2, 1-25-82) 
Sec. 26-64. - Terms for receipt of water service. 
(a)  The city will supply water through meters furnished and owned thereby, and delivery of water is considered completed at the point of installation of the meters. No city employee shall be permitted to do any work beyond the location of water metering equipment. 
(b)  The register of the meter shall be prima facie evidence of the amount of water used by the consumer, and he shall be held and shall pay for water in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(c)  In the event a customer should experience a water leak which causes water bill charges to exceed normal usage the city shall have a right to adjust the bill based on the following formula. After having provided proof of repair, the customer's normal usage for the same month one year prior to the month in question shall be determined and that amount deducted from the current bill and the customer then would be responsible for one-half of the charge for the excess usage after the deduction has been made. In the event the customer has not used city water for a full one-year period, then the city will select a month that would be closely comparable to the normal use for the present month and utilize the formula outlined above based on that month's bill. Only one credit will be available to any customer for any twelve-month period. 
(d)  In case of interference with or unnecessary injury to metering equipment or other property belonging to the city, the city may remove the same and refuse further service until the damage is paid. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person to tap into any water line ahead of the metering equipment. 
(f)  If the city finds, at any time, that a tap has been made ahead of the metering equipment, it shall estimate as nearly as possible the amount of water service illegally used and the consumer shall be billed for an amount equal to three (3) times the amount of the estimate. Any consumer violating this provision shall also be subject to the penalties set forth in section 26-149. 
(g)  Service under this section shall be furnished for the sole use of the consumer and shall not be re-sold or sub-metered. 
(Ord. No. 3009, § 6, 5-28-80; Ord. No. 3070, § 6, 1-25-82; Ord. No. 3755, § 21, 10-15-96; Ord. No. 4858, § 5-31-11) 
Sec. 26-65. - Water meters. 
(a)  The city shall have power to ascertain by meter the quantity of water used in any case and a meter shall be affixed whenever deemed expedient. 
(b)  Meters required herein shall be of a recognized standard make and shall be approved by the city water superintendent. 
(Code 1967, §§ 15-19, 15-20) 
Secs. 26-66-26-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CHARGES 

Sec. 26-81. - Security deposit for water service. 
(a)  The city will require a security deposit at installation of water service from all new customers or those who have been disconnected for violation of any of the provisions of this chapter, or for nonpayment of bills, equal to two (2) times the estimated monthly bill, and not less than twenty dollars ($20.00), unless the customer shall qualify under subsection (d) of this section for a reduced deposit, and the city shall give receipt for such deposit. 
(b)  All new large commercial and all new industrial users without established credit shall make payment to the city a sum equal to the estimated cost of two (2) months' service. 
(c)  At the termination of service, the city will refund the deposit upon full payment of all bills for service due to the city and the surrender of the deposit receipt. Any deposit may be applied by the city to the payment of any or all bills due the city at the time of termination of service to the consumer, either for electric or water service, or may be applied on any outstanding tax or license fee due to the city, and may be so applied with or without permission or consent of the consumer. Any deposit receipt given by the city for a security deposit shall not be transferable or assignable. 
(d)  Any new customer who shall present to the city satisfactory proof that they have paid their last twelve (12) months' utility bills to their previous supplier of electric and water utilities on a timely basis shall be required to pay a utility deposit of ten dollars ($10.00) for the installation of water service. If the customer shall have originally made the full deposit required herein and shall later present to the city satisfactory proof that they have paid their last twelve (12) months' utility bills to their previous supplier of electric and water utilities, then such customer may request and receive a refund of one-half of the original security deposit paid. The city collector shall have the right to adopt reasonable requirements and guidelines for the form of proof to be furnished by each new customer. In those instances in which the post of assignment of any new customer who is on active duty with the armed forces of the United States of America shall require proof of payment of final utility charges before installation clearance is given upon relocation or separation of service, and when such new customer signs a utility deposit agreement in which such customer waives his or her right to privacy for disclosure of current and future unit of assignment and home address, then such new customer shall be required to pay a utility deposit of ten dollars ($10.00) for the installation of water service. 
(e)  Any customer who shall have originally made a deposit of twenty dollars ($20.00) for the installation of water services, who shall have made timely payment of at least the past immediate twelve (12) months' utility bills shall, upon request by such customer, be refunded ten dollars ($10.00) of their water service deposit. 
(Code 1967, §§ 15-4-15-8, 15-10, 15-11; Ord. No. 2041, § 1(13-34), 6-26-78; Ord. No. 3009, §§ 3, 7, 5-28-80; Ord. No. 3070, § 3, 1-25-82; Ord. No. 3282, §§ 1-3, 2-8-88) 
Sec. 26-82. - Charge for temporary service. 
    Any service for less than twelve (12) months shall be considered temporary service. The cost of all labor, equipment, and material in installing temporary service shall be borne by the consumer. In addition to the regular security deposit required, a consumer requesting temporary service, shall deposit with the city a sum equal to the estimated cost of installing and connecting temporary service. After the termination of temporary service, materials and equipment shall be salvaged and consumer given credit for that portion which is fit for reuse. 
(Ord. No. 3009, § 5, 5-28-80; Ord. No. 3070, § 5, 1-25-82) 
Sec. 26-83. - Water connection and water facility impact fees. 
(a)  In all connections to the city water system the city will furnish appropriate service connections five-eighths-inch, one-inch, one and one-half-inch, two-inch or three-inch water meter installation listed herein. In all connections to the water system, the customer will bear the actual additional cost over and above the standard installation charge of extra water meters, special water meters, larger service lines or mains larger than the six (6) inches required for the service. 
(b)  The fees charged for water connection shall be: 
(1)  For connection to a five-eighths-inch water meter ..... $750.00 
a.  Multiple dwelling (two (2) or more residential dwellings) for connecting to additional five-eighths-inch water meter ..... $150.00 
(2)  For connection to a one-inch water meter ..... 900.00 
(3)  For connection to a one and one-half-inch water meter ..... 1,200.00 
(4)  For connection to a two-inch water meter ..... 1,500.00 
(5)  For connection to a three-inch water meter ..... 3,525.00 
There shall be no water connection fee charge for customers who live in a residence being served by a public water supply district. 
(c)  In addition to the fees set forth in subsection (a), a one-time water facility impact fee schedule is hereby established which shall apply only to newly constructed improvements in order to provide funds to the water department for expansion, modifications and repairs of the water system to accommodate the increase in demand generated by new connections. That fee schedule is as follows: 
(1)  For connection to an improvement served by a five-eighths-inch city water meter ..... $750.00 
(2)  For connection to an improvement served by a one-inch water meter ..... $1,875.00 
(3)  For connection to an improvement served by a one and one-half-inch water meter ..... $4,500.00 
(4)  For connection to an improvement served by a two-inch water meter ..... $6,000.00 
(5)  For connection to an improvement served by a water meter larger than two (2) inches the impact fee will be determined by the City of Lebanon. 
(6)  The fees referred to in this subsection (d) shall be due at the time the building permit for the improvement(s) to be served is issued. 
(7)  The water flows for improvements that vary from amounts normally used for customer facilities utilizing the water meter sizes referred to in subsection (b) shall be subject to rate adjustments as determined by the city and approved by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 2037, § 3, 5-22-78; Ord. No. 3755, § 11, 10-15-96; Ord. No. 3883, § 3, 9-28-98; Ord. No. 3887, § 3, 11-16-98; Ord. No. 4333, § 1, 8-29-05; Ord. No. 4433, §§ 3, 4, 10-30-06)

Secs. 26-85-26-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - ELECTRIC SERVICE[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6; electric code, § 6-121 et seq.; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 10. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 26-101. - Unauthorized construction of electric, power lines prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person or the agent thereof to construct electric service lines or power lines on the surface, underground, above ground, over and across any street or alley or public property within the city limits unless first getting approval from the mayor and city council. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person or the agent thereof to construct an electric service line or power line over and across any private property upon which the city has a utility easement. This section applies to construction of lines over and across any easement, but not private property adjacent thereto. Any exceptions hereto shall first have the approval of the mayor and city council. 
(Ord. No. 1715, §§ 1, 3, 9-28-67) 
Sec. 26-102. - Scope of prohibition on unauthorized lines. 
    The provisions of section 26-101, shall extend to the property designated therein even though the street or alley has not been dedicated or conveyed by recorded legal instrument. These provisions shall not affect existing electrical lines. 
(Ord. No. 1715, §§ 4, 5, 9-28-67) 
Sec. 26-103. - City will provide service. 
    The city will provide electric service to all consumers presently receiving service from its electric system and in addition will serve all new consumers within the city limits where electric service requires the use of streets, avenues, alleys, etc., to construct the distributing lines. 
(Ord. No. 1879, § 2, 1-22-73; Ord. No. 1941, § 2, 5-27-75; Ord. No. 1962, § 2, 1-12-76; Ord. No. 2028, § 2, 12-12-77; Ord. No. 2062, § 2, 12-26-78; Ord. No. 2098, § 2, 12-26-79; Ord. No. 3038, § 2, 2-23-81; Ord. No. 3069, § 2, 1-25-82; Ord. No. 3447, § 2, 1-30-92) 
Sec. 26-104. - Terms for receipt of electric service. 
(a)  The city will supply electricity through meters furnished and owned by it, and delivery of electric current is considered completed at the service point. No city employee shall be permitted to do any work beyond the load terminals of such service point. 
(b)  The register of the meter shall be prima facie evidence of amount of electricity used by the consumer, and the consumer shall be held responsible for and shall pay for electricity in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(c)  In case of interference with or unnecessary damage to metering equipment or other property belonging to the city, the city may remove the equipment or property and refuse further service until such damage is paid. 
(d)  If the city finds, at any time, that a tap has been made ahead of the metering equipment, it shall estimate as nearly as possible the amount of electric service illegally used, and the consumer shall be billed for an amount equal to three (3) times the amount of the estimate. Any consumer violating this provision shall also be subject to the penalties set forth in section 26-149. 
(e)  The city shall, at all times, have the right to inspect any and all wiring, equipment, installations and appliances upon the premises of a consumer; and should such inspection disclose dangerous or defective conditions of service or defective conditions likely to interfere with proper service to and use of electric facilities to and by other consumers, the city shall have the right to require correction or removal of such defective wiring, installation, equipment and appliances by the consumer upon reasonable notice; and upon his failure or refusal to do so, shall discontinue service to such consumer until such condition shall be corrected. 
(Ord. No. 1879, § 8, 1-22-73; Ord. No. 1941, § 8, 5-27-75; Ord. No. 1962, § 8, 1-12-76; Ord. No. 2028, § 8, 12-12-77; Ord. No. 2062, § 8, 12-26-78; Ord. No. 2098, § 8, 12-26-79; Ord. No. 3038, § 8, 2-23-81; Ord. 3069, § 8, 1-25-82; Ord. No. 3477, § 8, 1-30-92; Ord. No. 3924, § 1, 5-10-99) 
Sec. 26-105. - Wiring regulations. 
    The following regulations are hereby adopted and prescribed for the wiring of consumer's installations in the city: 
(1)  All new wiring must be done in accordance with the National Electrical Codes, and any further specifications set up from time to time by the city. 
(2)  The consumer will be required to furnish, install and maintain at all times in good condition all interior wiring, apparatus and equipment, including all fixtures, appliances, and everything pertaining to the use of electric service on their premises. When wiring is to be done before wires of the city are extended to the consumer's premises, the city shall be notified and it shall specify the point of service for the consumer. 
(Ord. No. 1879, § 4, 1-22-73; Ord. No. 1941, § 4, 5-27-75; Ord. No. 1962, § 4, 1-12-76; Ord. No. 2028, § 4, 12-12-77; Ord. No. 2062, § 4, 12-26-78; Ord. No. 2098, § 4, 12-26-79; Ord. No. 3038, § 4, 2-23-81; Ord. No. 3069, § 4, 1-25-82; Ord. No. 3447, § 4, 1-30-92) 
Sec. 26-106. - Adoption of "City of Lebanon, Terms and Standards for Electrical Service" and service restrictions. 
(a)  That certain booklet entitled "City of Lebanon, Terms and Standards for Electrical Service" is hereby adopted and incorporated by reference as the article setting forth the minimum terms and standards for electrical service for the city. 
(b)  The city may refuse to connect or supply motors or other apparatus of such a type or of such an installation as may impose low voltage or an insufficient power factor, or such as may otherwise impair service to other consumers. 
(Ord. No. 1879, § 7, 1-22-73; Ord. No. 1941, § 7, 5-27-75; Ord. No. 1962, § 7, 1-12-76; Ord. No. 2028, § 7, 12-12-77; Ord. No. 2062, § 7, 12-26-78; Ord. No. 2098, § 7, 12-26-79; Ord. No. 3038, § 7, 2-23-81; Ord. No. 3069, § 7, 1-25-82; Ord. No. 3447, § 7, 1-30-92; Ord. No. 3924, § 2, 5-10-99) 
Sec. 26-107. - Services. 
(a)  Overhead. All electrical services provided by the city shall be on the basis of overhead primary and secondary facilities with secondary service being brought to the consumer's service entrance head. The consumer shall provide the attachment member with the necessary strength to support the overhead service. The consumer shall furnish and install an approved meter base, and shall furnish and install all other materials required for the service, except for the overhead service wire and meter which will be furnished and installed by the city. 
(b)  Underground. Underground single phase services to residential and commercial consumers will be furnished by the city. The consumer shall furnish and install an approved meter base on his structure and shall furnish and install Schedule 40 PVC of code size for the required service conductors from the meter base to the secondary pedestal or transformer. The city will furnish secondary service conductors to be installed by the consumer. All primary will be installed by the city. Three (3) phase pad mounted transformers will be furnished for commercial and industrial consumers if three (3) phase underground service can be made available. Three (3) phase service utilizing pad mounted transformers will be furnished for 208Y/120-volt or 480Y/277-volt services only. Three (3) phase four (4) wire delta secondary services will not be available from pad mounted transformers. The city will furnish three (3) phase, four (4) wire delta secondary service from "transclosure" type assemblies. 
(c)  Net meter service. 
(1)  Availability of service. 
a.  Net meter service is available to any City of Lebanon Electric Utility consumer that owns and operates a qualified electric generation unit as meeting the conditions established in sub-section (d) of this section, which is powered by the following renewable energy resources: solar, wind, biomass, or hydrogen fuel cell with a capacity of not more than one hundred (100) kilowatts which is located on the consumers property, interconnected and operates in parallel with City of Lebanon transmission and distribution facilities. This service is intended primarily to offset part or all of the consumer own electrical power requirements. 
b.  This service is available within the incorporated limits of the city at any point on the existing facilities that have adequate capacity and suitable voltage for delivery of service as determined by the city. A request for service is required prior to connection to any facilities. The request must be approved and connection to city facilities must be coordinated with the city. 
c.  The request for service and agreements established for service will govern the terms and conditions of service. Consumers using this service shall be classified as "consumer-generator." All agreements hereunder are between the "consumer-generator" and the city, and shall not include a third party. 
(2)  Monthly billing. 
a.  The electric service charge shall be calculated in accordance with the monthly rate under the consumer effective standard rate schedule. 
b.  If metered electricity by the city exceeds the electricity generated by the "consumer-generator" during a billing period, the consumer-generator shall be charged for the actual kWh units delivered by city facilities. 
c.  If the electricity supplied by the consumer-generator exceeds the electricity delivered by the city, the "consumer-generator" shall be credited for each kWh unit of the energy delivered to the city system during a billing period. This credit will be established by code. 
d.  The credit per kWh shall be based on avoided cost as defined in this chapter. 
e.  Avoided cost shall be the average cost per kilowatt-hour (kWh) of energy received by the city electric utility during the previous calendar year multiplied by the number of kWh registered at the consumer-generator's meter. 
(3)  Transfer of ownership. 
a.  Upon transfer of ownership of the qualified unit and of the property on which the unit is located, a new request for service shall be submitted for consideration. 
(4)  Conditions of service. 
a.  The "consumer-generator" must have a signed standard interconnection agreement with the city. 
b.  The "consumer-generator" is responsible for all cost associated with the generating facility, in addition to being responsible for all cost related to any modifications to the facilities that may be required by the city for purposes of safety and reliability. 
c.  All "consumer-generator" facilities shall meet applicable safety and performance standards established by the National Electric Safety Code, the Institute of Electrical and Electronic Engineers, and Underwriters Laboratory. 
d.  The "consumer-generator" is responsible for all requirements established for this service. 
(Ord. No. 1879, § 9, 1-22-73; Ord. 1941, § 9, 5-27-75; Ord. No. 1962, § 9, 1-12-76; Ord. No. 2028, § 9, 12-12-77, Ord. No. 2062, § 9, 12-26-78; Ord. No. 2098, § 9, 12-26-79; Ord. No. 3038, § 9, 2-23-81; Ord. No. 3069, § 9, 1-25-82; Ord. No. 3447, § 9, 1-30-92; Ord. No. 3755, § 12, 10-15-96; Ord. No. 3924, § 3, 5-10-99; Ord. No. 5392, § 1, 9-28-15) 
Secs. 26-108-26-120. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CHARGES 

Sec. 26-121. - Security deposit for electric service. 
(a)  The city will require a security deposit from residential customers in the amount of eighty dollars ($80.00) at each location, which deposit will be reduced to forty dollars ($40.00) with a letter of credit from the last provider confirming that no late payments were made for a twelve-month period prior to termination of service. In the event any customer has previously been disconnected for violation of the provisions of this chapter, or for nonpayment of bills, the deposit shall be one hundred sixty dollars ($160.00). 
(b)  All commercial users without established credit shall make payment to the city a sum equal to the estimated cost of two (2) months' service. However, if that amount exceeds fifteen hundred dollars ($1,500.00), the deposit will be reduced to fifteen hundred dollars ($1,500.00) with a letter of credit from the last provider confirming that no late payments were made for a twelve-month period prior to termination of service. 
(c)  At the termination of service, the city will refund the deposit upon full payment of all bills for service due to the city and the surrender of the deposit receipt. Any such deposit may be applied by the city to the payment of any or all bills due the city at the time of termination of service to the consumer, either for electric or water service. 
(d)  Any customer obtaining electrical service for a facility that will service more than one residential family from a single meter shall be required to make the required security deposit for said service and shall be responsible for payment of the entire utility bill. 
(Ord. No. 1879, § 3, 1-22-73; Ord. No. 1941, § 3, 5-27-75; Ord. No. 1962, § 3, 1-12-76; Ord. No. 2028, § 3, 12-12-77; Ord. No. 2062, § 3, 12-26-78; Ord. No. 2098, § 3, 12-26-79; Ord. No. 3038, § 3, 2-23-81; Ord. No. 3069, § 3, 1-25-82; Ord. No. 3282, §§ 4-6, 2-8-88; Ord. No. 3447, § 3, 1-30-92; Ord. No. 3755, § 13, 10-15-96; Ord. No. 3924, § 4, 5-10-99) 
Sec. 26-122. - Charge for temporary service. 
(a)  Charge for temporary special event service. Any service for less than twelve (12) months shall be considered temporary service and the cost of all labor, equipment and materials in installing temporary service shall be borne by the consumer. In addition to the regular security deposit required, a consumer requesting temporary service, shall deposit with the city a sum equal to the estimated cost of installing and connecting temporary service. 
(b)  Construction temporary service. A fee will be charged for construction temporary services in the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for a one hundred (100) amp service. A two hundred (200) amp temporary service will have a one hundred fifty dollar ($150.00) connect fee. If the customer requests a temporary to be disconnected and reconnected at a different location, a new connect fee will be charged. 
(Ord. No. 1879, § 6, 1-22-73; Ord. No. 1941, § 6, 5-27-75; Ord. No. 1962, § 6, 1-12-76; Ord. No. 2028, § 6, 12-12-77; Ord. No. 2062, § 6, 12-26-78; Ord. No. 2098, § 6, 12-26-79; Ord. No. 3038, § 6, 2-23-81; Ord. No. 3069, § 6, 1-25-82; Ord. No. 3447, § 6, 1-30-92; Ord. No. 3924, § 5, 5-10-99)

(a)  The fees for installation of electric meters shall be:

(Ord. No. 1879, § 10, 1-22-73; Ord. No. 1941, § 10, 5-27-75; Ord. No. 1962 § 10, 1-12-76; Ord. No. 2028, § 10, 12-12-77; Ord. No. 2062, § 10, 12-26-78; Ord. No. 2098, § 10, 12-26-79; Ord. No. 3924, § 6, 5-10-99) 
Sec. 26-124. - Rate schedule adjustment. 
(a)  The city shall supply electric service to consumers in accordance with the schedules contained in sections 26-125 through 26-129, except that all schedules shall be subject to upward or downward adjustment due to changes in the wholesale power cost from Sho-Me Power Cooperative, Inc. 
(b)  All demand and energy rates set forth in each rate schedule shall be increased by a factor of one and two-tenths (1.2) times the increase or decrease in demand and energy costs made by Sho-Me Power Cooperative, Inc., to the city. 
(Ord. No. 1879, § 11, 1-22-73; Ord. No. 1941, § 11, 5-27-75; Ord. No. 1962, § 11, 1-12-76; Ord. No. 2028, § 11, 12-12-77; Ord. No. 2062, § 11, 12-26-78; Ord. No. 2098, § 11, 12-26-79; Ord. No. 3038, § 1, 2-23-81; Ord. No. 3069, § 11, 1-25-82; Ord. No. 3447, § 11, 1-30-92; Ord. No. 3924, § 7, 5-10-99) 
Sec. 26-125. - Residential service schedule-Rate residential. 
(a)  Availability. This service is available at secondary voltage for general residential use to any individually metered private or apartment dwelling unit located within the urban area of the city, or served from a common low tension network serving that area. 
(b)  Character of service. The type of service rendered under this subsection shall be alternating current sixty (60) Hertz, single phase, at a voltage of approximately 120/240 Volts. 
(c)  Monthly rate. 
Service Availability Charge: $0.00 Energy Charge: First 15 .6215 KWH Next 85 .1738 KWH Next 150 .1045 KWH Next 750 .0902 KWH Remaining .0803 KWH Winter Rate: Effective from the first billing cycle in October through the last billing cycle in April Next 1,000 .0803 KWH Remaining .0671 KWH  
(d)  Minimum monthly charge. The minimum monthly charge for this rate shall be nine dollars and twenty-five cents ($9.25). 
(e)  Payment. The above rate and minimum apply only in case a bill is paid on or before the due date. If not so paid, the gross rate, which is the net rate plus ten (10) percent, then applies. 
(f)  Conditions of service. 
(1)  Voltage, phase and frequency of energy supplied under this section shall be as specified by the city. 
(2)  Service under this section shall be furnished for the sole use of the consumer and shall not be resold or sub metered. 
(3)  Service shall be supplied through a single meter unless authorized by the city. At the request of the consumer, separate meters may be retained, in which case each meter shall be billed as a separate consumer. 
(4)  Welding, x-ray, or other equipment characterized by severe or fluctuating demands, shall not be served under this section. 
(5)  All motor driven devices of one and one-half horsepower capacity or larger must be operated on a nominal voltage of two hundred eight (208) volts or higher. 
(Ord. No. 5362, § 1, 7-13-15) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5362, §§ 1-11, adopted July 13, 2015, repealed the former §§ 26-125-26-131, and enacted new §§ 26-125-26-133 as set out herein. The former §§ 26-125-26-131 pertained to: Residential service schedules-rate RE; small commercial service schedules-rate CE; large commercial service schedules-rates L1; industrial service schedules-rates I1 and I2; large industrial, high load factor service schedule-rate I3; private outdoor lighting service schedule-rate VL; special service-rate SS and monthly electric user charge, respectively. See the Code Comparative Table for the sections history. 
Sec. 26-126. - Commercial service schedule-Rate commercial 1. 
(a)  Availability. The schedule contained in this section is available for service within the urban area of the city, or from a common law tension network serving that area, delivered through a single point to commercial establishments, rooming houses, multiple-family dwellings, or for combined usage up to ten thousand (10,000) kilowatt hours per month, or demand of twenty-five (25) kilowatts. When the consumer's monthly average usage exceeds twenty five (25) kilowatts or ten thousand (10,000) kilowatt hours during the preceding 12 months, the consumer shall be placed on the applicable power rate schedule. 
(b)  Character of service. The type of service rendered under this subsection shall be alternating current, sixty (60) Hertz, single- or multi-phase, at a standard secondary voltage (e.g., 120/240, 120/208, 277/480 Volts), or at another secondary voltage as mutually agreed upon in writing. 
(c)  Monthly rate. 
Service Availability Charge: $0.00 Energy Charge: First 20 .6215 KWH Next 80 .1738 KWH Next 150 .1045 KWH Remaining .0957 KWH Winter Rate: Effective from the first billing cycle in October through the last billing cycle in April First 100 .4972 KWH Remaining .0825 KWH  
(d)  Minimum monthly charge. The minimum monthly charge for this rate shall be eleven dollars and twenty cents ($11.20). During the winter rate months, the charge shall be forty-four dollars and forty cents ($44.40). 
(e)  Payment. The above rate and minimum apply only in case a bill is paid on or before the due date. If not so paid, the gross rate, which is the net rate plus ten (10) percent, then applies. 
(f)  Determination of demand. The consumer's demand will be determined by the maximum fifteen (15) minute measured demand; the load shall be as indicated or recorded by suitable recording instruments provided by the electric utility. 
(g)  Conditions of service. 
(1)  Voltage, phase and frequency of energy supplied under this section shall be specified by the rules and regulations of the utility. 
(2)  The electric utility shall furnish and maintain at its expense the facilities (including poles, conductors, meters, protective equipment, and transformers) for a single delivery point. The electric utility shall place its meters at the delivery point, unless otherwise determined by the electric utility. All facilities beyond the delivery point are the responsibility of the consumer. 
(3)  Service under this section shall be furnished for the sole use of the consumer and shall not be resold or sub metered. 
(4)  Service shall be supplied through a single meter unless otherwise provided by the rules and regulations of the utility. At the request of the consumer, separate meters may be retained, in which case each meter shall be considered a separate consumer. Polyphase service, metered separately, shall be considered a separate consumer 
(Ord. No. 5362, § 2, 7-13-15)

Sec. 26-130. - Industrial service schedule-Rate industrial 2. 
(a)  Availability. The schedule contained in this section is available for service within the urban area of the city, delivered through a single point to consumer with a monthly demand of one thousand five hundred (1,500) kilowatts or greater. 
(b)  Character of service. The type of service rendered under this subsection shall be alternating current, sixty (60) Hertz, single- or multi-phase, at a standard secondary voltage (e.g., 120/240, 120/208, 277/480 Volts), or at another secondary voltage as mutually agreed upon in writing. 
(c)  Monthly rate. 
Service Availability Charge: $0.00 Demand Charge First 400 KWD $9.63 Remaining KWD $7.79 Energy Charge: 3500 KWD x 400=KWh .0715 KWH Next 5500 KWD x 400=KWh .0561 KWH Remaining KWh .0484 KWH  
(d)  Minimum monthly charge. The minimum monthly charge for this rate shall be fourteen thousand four hundred forty-five dollars ($14,445.00). 
(e)  Payment. The above rate and minimum apply only in case a bill is paid on or before the due date. If not so paid, the gross rate, which is the net rate plus ten (10) percent, then applies. 
(f)  Determination of demand. The consumer's demand will be determined by the maximum fifteen (15) minute measured demand; the load shall be as indicated or recorded by suitable recording instruments provided by the electric utility. 
(g)  Conditions of service. 
(1)  Voltage, phase and frequency of energy supplied under this section shall be specified by the rules and regulations of the utility. 
(2)  The electric utility shall furnish and maintain at its expense the facilities (including poles, conductors, meters, protective equipment, and transformers) for a single delivery point. The electric utility shall place its meters at the delivery point, unless otherwise determined by the electric utility. All facilities beyond the delivery point are the responsibility of the consumer. 
(3)  Service under this section shall be furnished for the sole use of the consumer and shall not be resold or sub metered. 
(4)  Service shall be supplied through a single meter unless otherwise provided by the rules and regulations of the utility. At the request of the consumer, separate meters may be retained, in which case each meter shall be considered a separate consumer. Polyphase service, metered separately, shall be considered a separate consumer 
(5)  All polyphase motors of twenty-five (25) horsepower and larger shall be controlled by reduced voltage starters. Reduced voltage starters shall be of the auto transformer, resistor, part winding or solid state type. 
(Ord. No. 5362, § 6, 7-13-15)

Sec. 26-131. - Private outdoor lighting service schedule-Rate VL. 
(a)  Availability. This section is available for overhead outdoor lighting service to any consumer located on the lines of the city and limited to one light to a residential customer. However, the city will make available the use of its existing power poles for lighting of industrial/commercial parking lots and grounds provided each light will consist of separate installation and monthly charges. 
(b)  Rate VL-private outdoor light services. Charge for installation of standard one hundred-watt or equivalent lamp is one hundred dollars ($100.00). Charge for electrical service is eight dollars ($8.00) per month per lamp. Additional charge for installations requiring additions to or rearrangement of existing facilities shall be at actual cost. This cost to be paid prior to commencement of service. 
(c)  Conditions of service. 
(1)  Standard construction shall consist of a lighting unit with refractor, bracket, control device, wire and hardware mounted on existing poles and on existing secondary circuits. 
(2)  All lamps shall burn every night from dusk to dawn, subject to a time allowance of three (3) work days after notice is given by the consumer to the city for maintenance and lamp renewals. 
(3)  The facilities installed by the city under this section shall remain the property of the city. 
(4)  The above net rate applies only in case a bill is paid on or before the due date. If not so paid, the gross rate, which is the net rate, plus ten (10) percent, then applies. 
(5)  The term of service under this section shall be not less than one year. 
(Ord. No. 5362, § 7, 7-13-15)

Sec. 26-132. - Electric user charge. 
    The monthly electric user charge for the City of Lebanon, Missouri, accounts and purposes shall be at the rate of eight cents ($0.08) per kilowatt hour of electric usage reading measured by electric meters acceptable to the city. No additional charges shall be assessed to the City of Lebanon, Missouri, for any other established electric service fees. 
(Ord. No. 5362, § 9, 7-13-15) 
Editor's note- See the editor's note at § 26-125. 
Sec. 26-133. - Other condition of services. 
(a)  Power factor adjustment. The consumer shall maintain a power factor of not less than ninety (90) percent lagging. The average power factor during the month used for billing purposes shall be obtained from the measured kilowatt hours and the measured reactive kilovolt-ampere hours taken during the month. The meter for measurement of reactive kilovolt-ampere hours will be ratcheted to prevent reverse registration. If the average power factor during the month is less than ninety (90) percent lagging, the total bill for the month shall be increased two (2) percent for each one percent or major function thereof by which the average power factor during the month is less than ninety (90) percent lagging. 
(b)  Primary metering discount. The rates imposed in this division apply to service metered at secondary voltage. Where service is metered at the primary line feeding to these locations, adjustment for billing shall be made by decreasing the metered kilowatt-hours by three (3) percent if only one transformer bank is installed. 
(c)  More than one character of service, as to voltage, phase and frequency of delivery, shall not be combined for billing under this division except that a consumer with existing multiple services may retain such services. Billing will be accomplished by adding demand and kilowatt hour readings of all meters numerically. Credit for delivery will not be granted. 
(d)  The utility, at its discretion, shall define the type of service provided. The utility will furnish and install the service and the consumer shall pay the city for all expenses incurred over and above the normal installed services. 
(e)  Lighting will be served hereunder, subject to the provisions of determination of billing demand. Lighting service incidental to power may be rendered hereunder if combined lighting and power is served through one point of delivery, and the consumer furnishes all additional equipment necessary for further transformation or regulation of energy for lighting service. Should service to an incidental single phase load result in phase unbalance, whereby the average of the separate loads on the three (3) phases is less than eighty (80) percent of the load of maximum phase, the consumer shall correct the phase unbalance to meet the above limitation. Should the consumer tail to correct the phase unbalance, the demand, as determined, shall be increased in due proportion to the phase unbalance, or the single phase service shall be rendered separately and billed under the appropriate rate covering such service. 
(f)  Starting with the 1st billing cycle in October through the last cycle in April but prior to the first cycle in May, the rate schedules of residential, commercial 1, commercial 2, and commercial-industrial shall receive a reduced rate for KWh consumed as determined by Code. This rate shall be referred to as Winter Rate, and be in effect for the months of October, November, December, January, February, March, and April consumption. 
(Ord. No. 5362, § 10, 7-13-15) 
Editor's note- See the editor's note at § 26-125. 
Sec. 26-134. - Annual increase and bi-annual review by council. 
(a)  Annually, a proposal for rates of not less one percent increase shall be submitted to the city council for action. 
(b)  Every two (2) years the city council shall review the charges for services against the operational expenses to ensure no operational deficit is present. 
(Ord. No. 5362, § 11, 7-13-15)

ARTICLE V. - BILLING 

Sec. 26-146. - Responsibility for payment of water and electric bills. 
(a)  When city water and/or electricity service is supplied or to be supplied to any property occupied, or, to be occupied by a tenant, the owner, his manager or agent renting the property to the tenant, or, the tenant(s) shall sign an application therefore, and the applicant shall be responsible for the payment of the water and/or electricity supplied by the city on a monthly basis. 
(b)  The responsibility for payment of sewer shall be governed by section 26-46. 
(Code 1967, § 15-22; Ord. No. 4607, § 1, 2-9-09) 
Sec. 26-147. - Reading of meters and payment of bills. 
(a)  Meters will be read on a cycle basis using three (3) cycles per month. Each customer will be assigned to one of the three (3) cycles. Meters will be read and bills will be mailed to consumers on or before the date in accordance with following schedule: 
Cycle No. 1. Ninth day of the month. 
Cycle No. 2. Nineteenth day of the month. 
Cycle No. 3. Twenty-eighth day of the month. 
(b)  Bills for service will be due upon presentation of the bill and shall be payable not later than the date set forth on the following schedule: 
Cycle No. 1. Twentieth day of the month. 
Cycle No. 2. Thirtieth day of the month. 
Cycle No. 3. Tenth day of the month. 
(c)  In case a meter does not record, is incorrectly recording, or, is not read, the bill for that period will be based upon an average of the preceding three (3) months. If the bill for service remains unpaid on the sixth day after the due date, the consumer will be notified that service will be disconnected. If the bill remains unpaid on the fifteenth day after the due date, then the service shall be disconnected. If the bill for service is disputed by the customer or there is a complaint about service, the customer may contact the city clerk during regular business hours to resolve any complaints about the bill. Customer contact and discussion of the problem must occur before fifteen (15) days after the due date. If the clerk determines that the bill is correct or the complaint is denied and the customer does not appeal to the council, and if the bill for service remains unpaid on the fifteenth day after the due date, the consumer shall be required to make payment in full for the delinquent bill, plus the penalty set forth in section 26-149. If payment in full of all amounts due the city has not been made before the fifteen day after the due date, then service shall be disconnected for nonpayment and a charge of fifteen dollars ($15.00) for reconnection for each service shall be assessed at the time the disconnect order is issued to cover the cost of disconnecting and reconnecting the service, which sum shall be added to the bill and collected therewith before service is restored. If services are disconnected for nonpayment, the city shall have the right to require the consumer to pay the delinquent bill, plus the penalty set forth in section 26-149. The city reserves the right to collect in addition thereto a security deposit as set out in this article. 
(d)  The date of disconnection of utility service for nonpayment by an industrial customer shall be by direction of the city administrator but in no case shall disconnection be later than sixty (60) days from the date of the delinquency. In the event of disconnection, the industrial customer shall be required to pay the full amount of the bill for service plus the actual cost of reconnection. 
(e)  The city administrator may establish policies regarding special circumstances that would justify payment agreements to pay delinquent accounts on an installment basis. Such policies shall be applicable to all customers, shall be in written form, and shall be available at the clerk's office. 
(Code 1967, §§ 15-13, 15-16, 15-25; Ord. No. 1879, § 5, 1-22-73; Ord. No. 1941, § 5, 5-27-75; Ord. No. 1962, § 5, 1-12-76; Ord. No. 2028, § 5, 12-12-77; Ord. No. 2062, § 5, 12-26-78; Ord. No. 2098, § 5, 12-26-79; Ord. No. 3009, § 4, 5-28-80; Ord. No. 3021, § 1, 10-27-80; Ord. No. 3038, § 5, 2-23-81; Ord. No. 3069, § 5, 1-25-82; Ord. No. 3070, § 4, 1-25-82; Ord. No. 3212, § 5, 12-23-85; Ord. No. 3477, § 5, 1-30-92; Ord. No. 3755, § 17, 10-15-96; Ord. No. 4607, § 2, 2-9-09) 
Sec. 26-148. - Percentage of funds shall be contributed to city's general fund. 
(a)  Five (5) percent of each monthly billing for utility service, excluding wastewater utility, shall be contributed to the general fund of the city. 
(b)  The city council shall also have the authority to transfer, to the economic development fund, up to one percent of the income from each utility fund, monthly, plus, any additional amount deemed appropriate by the council, from the general fund. 
(c)  The city council shall also have the authority to loan money to the economic development fund, for the purpose of acquisition of real estate and construction of improvements, in an amount deemed appropriate by the council. Any such loan must be repaid within fifteen (15) years and shall bear interest at the rate of five (5) percent per annum. 
(Code 1967, § 15-18; Ord. No. 4601, § 1, 11-24-08) 
Sec. 26-148.1. - Percentage of funds shall be contributed to city's general fund. 
(a)  Five (5) percent of each monthly billing for utility service shall be contributed to the general fund of the city. 
(b)  The city council shall also have the authority to transfer, to the economic development fund, up to one (1) percent of the income from each utility fund, monthly, plus, any additional amount deemed appropriate by the council, from the general fund. 
(c)  The city council shall also have the authority to loan money to the economic development fund, for the purpose of acquisition of real estate and construction of improvements, in an amount deemed appropriate by the council. Any such loan must be repaid within fifteen (15) years and shall bear interest at the rate of five (5) percent per annum. 
(Ord. No. 4607, § 3, 2-9-09) 
Sec. 26-148.2. - Utility reserve fund accounts established. 
(a)  Two (2) utility reserve fund accounts for water and electric are hereby established. 
(b)  Contributions to each fund shall be made from customer payments for each utility service and the reserve fund shall be established and maintained at no less than thirty (30) percent of the annual income of each utility and each fund shall not exceed fifty (50) percent of that utility's annual income; except that in the event of an emergency or a special need as determined by the mayor and city council, the council may by ordinance authorize the use of money from either fund for any reason deemed appropriate and necessary by the mayor and city council. 
(Ord. No. 4607, § 3, 2-9-09) 
Sec. 26-149. - Penalty for delinquency. 
    The bills under the rates set out in this chapter are net, and if they are not paid on or before the due date, then the city shall add a ten (10) percent service charge to the monthly amount of the bill due. This penalty shall be assessed at the close of business the day following the due date, and payable for each thirty (30) days of delinquency. If the bill is not paid on or before the fifteenth day after the due date, the service shall be disconnected. 
(Code 1967, §§ 15-17, 15-34; Ord. No. 2041, § 1(15-34), 6-26-78; Ord. No. 3009, § 7, 5-28-80; Ord. No. 3027, art. V, § 2, 10-27-80; Ord. No. 3070, § 7, 1-25-82; Ord. No. 3755, § 19, 10-15-96; Ord. No. 3976, § 1, 11-29-99; Ord. No. 4607, § 4, 2-9-09; Ord. No. 5114, § 1, 8-12-13) 
Sec. 26-150. - Lien for unpaid utility bills. 
    The city may have a lien for unpaid utility bills, which may be enforced in any court of competent jurisdiction. Liened property may be sold under proper judgement to enforce the payment of all such claims, and the owners of liened property consent to the lien by contracting with the city for utility service, or either under the terms and conditions provided in this chapter. 
(Code 1967, § 15-23) 
Sec. 26-151. - Service charge for returned checks. 
    The city shall add a service charge of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) to the bill of any utility customer upon the return of that customer's check unpaid for insufficient funds or any other reason and the customer shall pay such service charge in addition to the unpaid bill and any other service charges. In the event a customer submits a check for insufficient funds three (3) times during a twenty-four-month period, the city clerk shall direct such customer to be placed on a cash only basis for a period of no less than one (1) year. 
(Ord. No. 3282, § 7, 2-8-88; Ord. No. 3755, § 18, 10-15-96; Ord. No. 4607, § 5, 2-9-09) 
Secs. 26-152-26-159. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - WASTEWATER TREATMENT[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- At the editor's discretion, Ord. No. 3183, §§ 1-6, adopted Nov. 13, 1984, being nonamendatory of the Code, has been included herein as Art. VI, §§ 26-160-26-165. 
Cross reference- Sewer use generally, § 26-21 et seq. 

Sec. 26-160. - General provisions. 
(a)  Purpose and policy. The objectives of this article are: 
(1)  To prevent the introduction of pollutants into the municipality wastewater system which will interfere with the operation of the system or contaminate the resulting sludge; 
(2)  To prevent the introduction of pollutants into the municipal wastewater system which will pass through the system, inadequately treated, into receiving waters or the atmosphere or otherwise be incompatible with the system; 
(3)  To improve the opportunity to recycle and reclaim wastewaters and sludges from the system; and 
(4)  To provide for equitable distribution of the cost of the municipal wastewater system. 
This article provides for the regulation of direct and indirect contributors to the municipal wastewater system through the issuance of permits to certain nondomestic users and through enforcement of general requirements for the other users, authorizes monitoring and enforcement activities, requires user reporting, assumes that existing customer's capacity will not be preempted, and provides for the setting of fees for the equitable distribution of costs resulting from the program established herein. 
This article shall apply to the City of Lebanon and to persons outside the city who are, by contract or agreement with the city, users of the city POTW. This article is a supplement to Ordinance No. 1833 (Code sections 26-21 through 26-28) as amended. Except as otherwise provided herein, the superintendent of the Lebanon POTW shall administer, implement and enforce the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Definitions. Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the following terms and phrases, as used in this article, shall have the meanings hereinafter designated: 
    Act or "the Act" shall mean the Federal Water Pollution Control Act, also known as the Clean Water Act, as amended, 33 U.S.C. 1251 et seq. 
    Approval authority shall mean the director in an NPDES state with an approved state pretreatment program and the administrator of the EPA in a non-NPDES state or NPDES state without an approved state pretreatment program. 
    Authorized representative of industrial user. An authorized representative of an industrial user may be: (1) A principal executive officer of at least the level of vice-president, if the industrial user is a corporation; (2) A general partner or proprietor, if the industrial user is a partnership or proprietorship, respectively; (3) A duly authorized representative of the individual designated above, if such representative is responsible for the overall operation of the facilities from which the indirect discharge originates. 
    Biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) shall mean the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure, five (5) days at twenty (20) degrees centigrade, expressed in terms of weight and concentration (milligrams per liter (mg/l)). 
    Building sewer shall mean a sewer conveying wastewater from the premises of a user to the POTW. 
    Categorical standards shall mean national categorical pretreatment standards or pretreatment standard. 
    City shall mean the City of Lebanon, or the city council of Lebanon. 
    Control authority. The term "control authority" shall refer to the "approval authority," defined hereinabove; or the superintendent, if the city has an approved pretreatment program under the provisions of 40 CFR, Section 403.11. 
    Cooling water shall mean the water discharged from any use such as air conditioning, cooling or refrigeration, or to which the only pollutant added is heat. 
    Direct discharge shall mean the discharge of treated or untreated wastewater directly to the waters of the State of Missouri. 
    Environmental Protection Agency, or EPA shall mean the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, or where appropriate the term may also be used as a designation for the administrator or other duly authorized official of time. 
    Grab sample shall mean a sample which is taken from a waste stream on a one-time basis with no regard to the flow in the waste stream and without consideration of time. 
    Holding tank waste shall mean any waste from holding tanks such as vessels, chemical toilets, campers, trailers, septic tanks, and vacuum-pump tank trucks. 
    Indirect discharge shall mean the discharge or the introduction of nondomestic pollutants from any source regulated under Section 307(b) or (c) of the Act (33 U.S.C. 1317) into the POTW (including holding tank waste discharged into the system). 
    Industrial user shall mean a source of indirect discharge which does not constitute a "discharge of pollutants" under regulations issued pursuant to Section 402, of the Act (U.S.C. 1342). 
    Interference shall mean the inhibition or disruption of the POTW treatment processes or operations which contributes to a violation of any requirement of the city's NPDES permit. The term includes prevention of sewage sludge use or disposal by the POTW in accordance with Section 405 of the Act (33 U.S.C. 1345), or any criteria, guidelines, or regulations developed pursuant to the Solid Waste Disposal Act (SWDA), the Clean Air Act, the Toxic Substances Control Act, or more stringent state criteria (including those contained in any state sludge management plan prepared pursuant to Title IV of SWDA) applicable to the method of disposal or use employed by the POTW. 
    National categorical pretreatment standard shall mean any regulation containing pollutant discharge limits promulgated by the EPA in accordance with Section 307(b) and (c) of the Act (33 U.S.C. 1317) and with 40 CFR Chapter I, subchapter M, parts 405-471 which applies to a specific category of industrial users. 
    National pollution discharge elimination system or NPDES permit shall mean a permit issued pursuant to Section 402 of the Act (33 U.S.C. 1342). 
    National prohibitive discharge standard or prohibitive discharge standard shall mean any regulation developed under the authority of Section 307(b) of the Act and 40 CFR, Section 403.5. 
    New source is defined in 40 CFR 403.3(k) as a facility from which there is, or may be, a discharge of pollutants, construction of which began after the publication of the proposed pretreatment standards pursuant to Section 307(c) of the Clean Water Act (CWA), which will apply to the facility if the standards are promulgated, provided certain location and construction criteria are met. 
    Person shall mean any individual, partnership, copartnership, firm, company, corporation, association, joint stock company, trust, estate, governmental entity or any other legal entity, or their legal representatives, agents or assigns. The masculine gender shall include the feminine, the singular shall include the plural where indicated by the context. 
    pH shall mean the logarithm (base 10) of the reciprocal of the concentration of hydrogen ions expressed in grams per liter of solution. 
    Pollutant shall mean any dredged spoil, solid waste, incinerator residue, sewage, garbage, sewage sludge, munitions, chemical wastes, biological materials, radioactive materials, heat, wrecked or discharged equipment, rock, sand, cellar dirt and industrial, municipal and agricultural waste discharged into water. 
    Pollution shall mean the man-made or man-induced alteration of the chemical, physical, biological and radiological integrity of water. 
    POTW treatment plant shall mean that portion of the POTW designed to provide treatment to wastewater. 
    Pretreatment or treatment shall mean the reduction of the amount of pollutants, the elimination of pollutants, or the alteration of the nature of pollutant properties in wastewater to a less harmful state prior to or in lieu of discharging or otherwise introducing such pollutants into a POTW. The reduction or alteration can be obtained by physical, chemical or biological processes, or process changes by other means, except as prohibited by 40 CFR, Section 403.6(d). 
    Pretreatment requirements shall mean any substantive or procedural requirement related to pretreatment, other than a national pretreatment standard, imposed on an industrial user. 
    Pretreatment standards or standards. Pretreatment standards shall mean prohibitive discharge standards, categorical pretreatment standards, and local limits. 
    Publicly owned treatment works (POTW) shall mean a treatment works as defined by Section 212 of the Act (33 U.S.C. 1292) which is owned in this instance by the city. This definition includes any sewers that convey wastewater to the POTW treatment plant, but does not include pipes, sewers or other conveyances not connected to a facility providing treatment. For the purposes of this article "POTW" shall also include any sewers that convey wastewaters to the POTW from persons outside the city, who are by contract or agreement, with the city, users of the city's POTW. 
    Shall is mandatory; may is permissive. 
    Significant industrial user shall mean the following: 
Any categorical industrial user (CIU) 
Any other IU which: 
(1)  Discharged twenty-five thousand (25,000) gallons or more of process wastewater per day. 
(2)  Contributes a process wastewater which makes up five (5) percent or more of the dry weather average hydraulic or organic capacity of the POTW. 
(3)  Is designated as such by the control authority on the basis that it has a reasonable potential for adversely affecting the POTW's operation or for violating a pretreatment standard or requirement. 
    Standard industrial classification (SIC) shall mean a classification pursuant to the Standard Industrial Classification Manual issued by the Executive Office of the President, Office of Management and Budget, 1972. 
    State shall mean the State of Missouri. 
    Storm water shall mean any flow occurring during or following any form of natural precipitation and resulting therefrom.
