ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 28-1-28-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TAXICABS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 3721, adopted June 24, 1996, amended Art. II to read as herein set out. Formerly, Art. II consisted of §§ 28-16-28-28, 28-41-28-47, 28-61-28-70, and 28-86-28-99, which pertained to taxicabs and derived from §§ 24-1-24-29, 24-31, 24-32, 24-34-24-38, and 24-40-24-50 of the 1967 Code; § 1 of Ord. No. 1792, adopted Jan. 12, 1970; § 1 of Ord. No. 1797, adopted Feb. 9, 1970; § 1 of Ord. No. 1901, adopted Oct. 22, 1973; § 1 of Ord. No. 1935, adopted Dec. 10, 1974; § 1 of Ord. No. 2072, adopted April 9, 1979; § 1 of Ord. No. 3004, adopted Feb. 25, 1980; and §§ 1 and 2 of Ord. No. 3067, adopted Nov. 30, 1981. 
Cross reference- Traffic and motor vehicles generally, Ch. 25; stopping, standing and parking of taxicabs, § 25-281; use of taxicab stands, § 25-282. 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to license and regulate taxicabs, RSMo 94.110. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 28-16. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
    Driver shall mean every person in actual charge of the operation of a taxicab, whether as owner or agent, servant or employee of an owner. 
    Owner shall mean every person having the use or control of one or more taxicabs. 
    Taxicab shall mean any vehicle driven by mechanical power used for the carriage of persons for hire except those vehicles commonly known as busses. 
(Ord. No. 3721, § 1, 6-24-96) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 28-17. - Insurance. 
    Every holder of a license to conduct the operations of a taxicab business within this city shall at all times during the course of his operations have on file with the city clerk and approved by the city council a certificate of public liability and property damage insurance covering each motor vehicle being operated in the taxicab business by the holder of the certificate of convenience and necessity in the minimum amounts of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for injury or death to any one person, three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for injuries or deaths from any one accident and one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) property damage for any one accident. 
(Ord. No. 3721, § 1, 6-24-96) 
Sec. 28-18. - Daily taxicab service required. 
    Every licensee, under the provisions of this article, shall regularly and daily operate his licensed taxicabs from 6:00 a.m. to 12:00 p.m. midnight during each day of the licensed year to the extent reasonably necessary to meet the public demand for taxicab service. Every licensee shall also maintain an eighteen-hour telephone service during those hours stated herein. 
(Ord. No. 3721, § 1, 6-24-96) 
Sec. 28-19. - Effect of abandonment of taxi service for failure to furnish telephone service. 
    Upon complete abandonment of taxicab service, or failure to furnish the telephone service required by section 28-18, the chief of police shall thereupon recommend to the mayor that the license of the offending owner or operator be presented to the mayor and city council for revocation. 
(Ord. No. 3721, § 1, 6-24-96) 
Sec. 28-20. - Appearance and condition of taxicabs. 
    All taxicabs shall be kept in a thoroughly and mechanically safe operating condition, complying with all of the safety requirements of this Code and other ordinances of the city, and state statutes regulating motor vehicles of a capacity of seven (7) passengers or less. All taxicabs shall be kept clean, properly painted and identifiable as a taxicab by appropriate signs printed on each side of the door. 
(Ord. No. 3721, § 1, 6-24-96) 
Sec. 28-21. - Marking on taxicabs. 
    Each vehicle operated as a taxicab shall be marked clearly on the outside of both sides in letters not less than three (3) inches high and lines not less than three-quarter (3/4) inches wide with the full name of the taxicab company in a color contrasting with the color of the vehicle. Each vehicle shall bear its number in color contrasting to the color of the vehicle, not less than three (3) inches high and lines not less than three-quarter (3/4) inches wide in clear view on the outside of each side and on the rear thereof. Each vehicle shall have installed on the top thereof a sign bearing the word "taxi." 
(Ord. No. 3721, § 1, 6-24-96) 
Sec. 28-22. - Registry of taxicab owners or operators; contents. 
    The city clerk and chief of police shall keep a register of the name and address of each person owning or operating a vehicle licensed under the provisions of this chapter, together with the license number and the description, make and necessary dimensions of the vehicle and the date and a complete record of inspections made of the vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 3721, § 1, 6-24-96) 
Sec. 28-23. - Public inspection of registry. 
    The records required to be kept by section 28-22 shall be open to the inspection of the public at all reasonable times and shall be public records, extracts of which may be certified for use as evidence by the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 3721, § 1, 6-24-96) 
Sec. 28-24. - Police to oversee, inspect taxicabs. 
    The chief of police and the police officers of the city shall maintain constant vigilance over all taxicabs and see that they are kept in a condition of continued fitness for public use and that the terms of this chapter are enforced. To this end, the chief of police, or his inspectors, shall inspect all taxicabs from time to time on the complaint of any person or as often as they deem necessary. At least twice in each year the chief of police shall make a written report of all taxicab inspections to the mayor. 
(Ord. No. 3721, § 1, 6-24-96) 
Secs. 28-25-28-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - VEHICLE LICENSE 

Sec. 28-61. - Required. 
    No taxicab business shall be operated upon the streets of the city without first obtaining a license therefor from the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 3721, § 1, 6-24-96) 
Sec. 28-62. - Application; contents. 
    Applications for licenses for taxicabs shall be made on blanks furnished by the city clerk. They shall contain the full name of the operator and the class of the vehicle for which the license is desired. 
(Ord. No. 3721, § 1, 6-24-96) 
Sec. 28-63. - Inspections and examinations required to receive license. 
(a)  No vehicle shall be licensed under the provisions of this division until it has been thoroughly and carefully inspected and examined by the chief of police and his inspectors and found to be in a thoroughly safe condition for the transportation of passengers, clean, fit, [in] a good appearance and well painted. 
(b)  The chief of police shall make, or have his inspectors make, the examination and inspection required by subsection (a) before a license shall be issued under the provisions stated in this division. 
(Ord. No. 3721, § 1, 6-24-96) 
Sec. 28-64. - Similar corporate names, colors prohibited among taxicab operators. 
    No license shall be issued to any person having the same corporate name or whose taxicabs are colored similar to that of any other person already licensed to operate taxicabs within the limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 3721, § 1, 6-24-96) 
Sec. 28-65. - Approval of applications by chief of police. 
    Upon approval of the application by the chief of police, he shall endorse and file the application with the city clerk, who shall deliver the application to the mayor for action in granting or denying the application. 
(Ord. No. 3721, § 1, 6-24-96) 
Sec. 28-66. - Issuance; fee; proration. 
(a)  Every person holding a license for the operation of a taxicab business within the city shall pay the city clerk an annual license fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for each taxicab they operate in the city. 
(b)  In case of licenses issued as required by this division, on or after July first in each year, one-half (1/2) only of the license fees shall be paid. 
(Ord. No. 3721, § 1, 6-24-96) 
Sec. 28-67. - Term of license. 
    The license required by section 28-61 shall be issued as of the calendar year and shall be effective for that period of time unless sooner suspended or revoked. 
(Ord. No. 3721, § 1, 6-24-96) 
Sec. 28-68. - License specifications. 
    The license number assigned to license cards issued under this division shall in each case be the same as that issued to the vehicle for that year pursuant to law. 
(Ord. No. 3721, § 1, 6-24-96) 
Sec. 28-69-28-85. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - DRIVER'S PERMIT 

Sec. 28-86. - Required; state commercial driver's license. 
    No person shall drive a taxicab within the city unless he has in his possession a currently effective and valid taxicab driver's permit which has been issued as hereinafter provided, and has issued to him a state commercial driver's license. 
(Ord. No. 3721, § 1, 6-24-96) 
Sec. 28-87. - Application. 
(a)  Any person desiring to secure a taxicab driver's permit shall make application therefor in writing to the chief of police, upon a form provided by the police department. 
(b)  The application form shall require applicant to furnish his name, residence, sex, age, race, height, color of eyes and hair, place of birth, citizenship and nationality, places of previous employment, whether previously issued a state commercial driver's license, and if so, whether such license has ever been revoked, and if so, for what reason, and the applicant shall both sign and swear to the truth of the contents of the application. 
(Ord. No. 3721, § 1, 6-24-96) 
Sec. 28-88. - Fees. 
    The following license application fees shall be paid for taxicab operators' licenses: 
(1)  Original license ..... $ 5.00 
(2)  License renewal ..... 1.00 
(Ord. No. 3721, § 1, 6-24-96) 
Sec. 28-89. - Qualification of applicants. 
(a)  Each applicant for a taxicab operating license shall be: 
(1)  Eighteen (18) years of age or over; 
(2)  Of sound physical condition; and 
(3)  Clean in dress and person and not be addicted to the use of drugs or alcoholic beverages. 
(b)  No applicant shall be eligible for a taxicab driver's permit who has been convicted of any of the following felonies: 
(1)  Arson in the first degree; 
(2)  Assault in the first degree; 
(3)  Sexual assault, including forcible rape and forcible sodomy; 
(4)  Child molestation or abuse; 
(5)  First degree domestic assault; 
(6)  First degree elder abuse; 
(7)  First and second degree murder; 
(8)  First degree robbery; 
(9)  Armed criminal action; 
(10)  Unlawful use of a weapon; 
(11)  Felonious restraint; 
(12)  Manslaughter; and 
(13)  Vehicular manslaughter. 
(Ord. No. 4653, § 1, 9-28-09) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4653, § 1, adopted September 28, 2009, repealed the former § 28-89, and enacted a new § 28-89 as set out herein. The former § 28-89 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 3721, adopted June 24, 1996. 
Sec. 28-90. - Issuance. 
    If the chief of police shall approve the application as meeting the requirements of section 28-89, he shall endorse his approval and return the application to the city clerk who shall issue the permit. 
(Ord. No. 3721, § 1, 6-24-96) 
Secs. 28-91, 28-92. - Reserved. 
Sec. 28-93. - Destruction of entries on permit. 
    Any permittee who defaces, removes or obliterates any official entry made upon his permit issued under this division shall be subject to revocation upon recommendation of the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 3721, § 1, 6-24-96) 
Sec. 28-94. - Term. 
    Taxicab driver's permits shall be issued as of January first of each year, and shall be valid to and including the thirty-first day of December next succeeding. 
(Ord. No. 3721, § 1, 6-24-96) 
Sec. 28-95. - Reserved. 
Sec. 28-96. - Renewal. 
    The mayor may renew a taxicab driver's permit issued pursuant to this division from year to year upon recommendation of the chief of police by appropriate endorsement thereon. 
(Ord. No. 3721, § 1, 6-24-96) 
Sec. 28-97. - Records. 
(a)  There shall be kept in the offices of the city clerk and the police department a complete record of each permit issued to taxicab drivers and of all the renewals, suspensions or revocations thereof. 
(b)  The chief of police's records shall be kept on file with the original application of the taxicab driver for a permit. 
(Ord. No. 3721, § 1, 6-24-96) 
Sec. 28-98. - Suspension; revocation; restoration-Authorized; grounds. 
    A taxicab driver's permit may be suspended or revoked upon recommendation of the chief of police or by the mayor and city council for cause. Any suspensions shall be noted on the permit, together with a statement of the reason therefor. No driver whose permit has been revoked shall again be permitted as a taxicab driver in the city, unless upon presentation of reasons satisfactory to the chief of police and acceptable by the mayor and council. The approval of the mayor and city council shall be necessary before the restoration of the permit. 
(Ord. No. 3721, § 1, 6-24-96) 
Sec. 28-99. - Same-Hearing. 
(a)  Upon conviction of the holder of a taxicab driver's permit for the reason stated in section 28-98, or, if a complaint shall be filed with the city council against the holder of a taxicab driver's permit alleging that the holder of the permit is either mentally, physically or morally unsafe or unfit to operate a taxicab within this city, the city council shall set a day for the hearing on the suspension or revocation of the permit of the taxicab driver, and cause the holder of the permit to be served a written notice stating the time when and the place of the hearing, the offense or offenses charged against the holder of the permit, and ordering the holder of the permit to appear at the hearing to show cause why his permit to operate a taxicab within the city should not be suspended or revoked. If at the hearing it should be proven that the holder of the taxicab driver's permit has been convicted of any offense mentioned in section 28-98, or, if it shall be proven by competent evidence that the holder of the permit is mentally, physically or morally unfit or unsafe to operate a taxicab within the city, taking into consideration generally the health, safety and welfare of the residents of the city, the city council may either revoke and cancel the permit or suspend same for a period of time not to exceed ninety (90) days. 
(b)  Failure of the holder of the permit to appear at the hearing shall be deemed an admission of the validity and truthfulness of any charge contained in the notice of hearing. 
(c)  The council may suspend a permit, pending a hearing on revocation, if the holder is charged with conviction of any ordinance specified in section 28-98. 
(Ord. No. 3721, § 1, 6-24-96) 
APPENDIX A - ZONING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Printed herein are the city's zoning regulations as enacted in Ordinance Number 3156, adopted on April 23, 1984. All amending ordinances adopted subsequent to April 23, 1984 are indicated by the presence of history notes in parentheses (), following the section amended. The absence of such a note indicates that a section has remained unchanged since April 23, 1984. The original arrangement, catchlines and subcatchlines of Ordinance Number 3156 have been retained. Ordinances zoning or rezoning specific properties are not included herein, but have been saved from repeal and are on file in the office of the city clerk. Material which has been added by the editor for clarity is indicated by brackets [ ]. Obvious errors in spelling and punctuation have been corrected without notation. 
Code references- Ordinances pertaining to zoning or to the re-zoning of specific property saved from repeal, § 1-6(14); airport zoning ordinance, § 3-36 et seq.; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6; planning and development, Ch. 17. 
State Law reference- Zoning and planning in cities, RSMo Ch. 89. 

SECTION 1. - TITLE, INTENT AND PURPOSE 

A. - Title. 
    These regulations may be referred to as the "ZONING ORDINANCE" of the City of Lebanon, Missouri. 
B. - Intent and Purpose. 
(1)  These regulations have been based upon the comprehensive plan for the City of Lebanon, Missouri. Said comprehensive plan included estimates of population growth, land use surveys, a land use plan, plans for major thoroughfares, other transportation facilities, community facilities, public services and utilities, and a public works program. 
(2)  Need for public services and facilities in both size and location depends upon the character and intensity of land use. Regulation of the use of land is thus fundamental to a coordinated optimum physical development of the community. The land use regulations are intended to be the foundation of the entire process of improvement of the physical environment. 
(3)  The regulations are intended to preserve and protect existing property uses and values against adverse or unharmonious adjacent uses. 
(4)  The land use regulations divide the area into a number of zoning districts. 
(a)  The comprehensive plan included careful estimates of the land area requirements for the various land uses such as commerce, residence, industry, transportation, and public uses. These urban uses should be directed into that land area where they may be most efficiently served by public services and facilities such as sewers, water, schools, parks and the like. Remaining lands should be reserved for rural uses. Consequently, the regulations include a Rural District for non-urban land uses. 
(b)  In the past, residential neighborhoods have deteriorated because they were invaded by small isolated commercial uses and by more intensive residential uses such as duplexes or apartment buildings. The great majority of our population desire to, and do, live in single-family homes which they own and which are located on fairly large lots. The regulations establish residential districts particularly designed to provide maximum protection for single-family homes. 
(c)  Two-family and multiple-family uses are permitted as conditional uses in residential and commercial districts. Density, yard, and parking regulations would insure good living conditions in these areas. Much of present day building is by large projects instead of lot by lot. The regulations provide for planned unit developments which may be located in any district with approval of the site plan. This introduces an important measure of flexibility into the regulations. 
(d)  Commercial districts recognize the different types of commercial areas that will be needed by the future growth of the community. There is a central commercial district for the downtown area and a district for commercial areas along major streets and highways. 
(e)  For industry there are two districts-a "light" industrial district for nonobnoxious manufacturing and a "general" or unrestricted industrial district. 
(f)  The regulations are reasonable in relation to existing conditions. Yard dimensions are adjusted to peculiarities of existing lots. Lots that are now too small may be used. Nonconforming uses are permitted to continue for adequate time periods. 
(g)  All uses are required to provide their own off-street parking (with a few exceptions). Over a period of years, enforcement of this requirement will enable streets to be used primarily for traffic movement. 
(h)  Each of the regulations has been designed to work harmoniously with the others with the totality providing that minimum degree of land use control essential to the realization of the optimum urban environment. 
SECTION 2. - DISTRICTS AND BOUNDARIES 

A. - Districts. 
    The City of Lebanon, Missouri, is hereby divided into three types of districts: 
R Districts-Residential 
C Districts-Commercial 
M Districts-Industrial 
    The three types of districts are further divided into the following specific districts: 
RU-1 Rural RU-2 Cemetery RS-1 Residential RS-2 Residential RS-3 Residential RS-4 Residential NC Neighborhood Commercial C-1 General Commercial C-2 Downtown Commercial C-L Limited Commercial M-1 Light Industrial M-2 General Industrial  
(Ord. No. 3626, § 1, 4-10-95; Ord. No. 3830, § 1, 1-26-98; Ord. No. 4453, § 1, 12-11-06) 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to divide city into zoning districts, RSMo 89.030. 
B. - District Boundaries. 
(1)  The boundaries of the districts are shown upon the map attached hereto and made a part hereof, which map is designated as the "District Map." The district map and all notations, references and other information shown thereon are a part of this ordinance and have the same force and effect as if the district map and all the notations, references and other information shown thereon were all fully set forth or described herein, the original of which district map is properly attested and is on file with the City Clerk of the City of Lebanon, Missouri. 
(2)  Whenever any street, alley or other public way is vacated by official action of the City Council of the City of Lebanon, the zoning district adjoining each side of such street, alley, or public way shall be automatically extended to the center of such vacation, and all area included in the vacation shall then and henceforth be subject to all appropriate regulations of the extended districts. 
(3)  All territory which may hereafter be annexed to the City of Lebanon shall automatically be placed in the most restrictive RS Residential District until otherwise changed by ordinance. 
SECTION 3. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

A. - Except as hereinafter provided: 
(1)  No building shall be erected, converted, enlarged, reconstructed or structurally altered, nor shall any building or land be used except for a purpose permitted in the district in which the building or land is located. 
(2)  No building shall be erected, converted, enlarged, reconstructed or structurally altered to exceed the height limit herein established for the district in which the building is located. 
(3)  No building shall be erected, converted, enlarged, reconstructed or structurally altered except in conformity with the area regulations of the district in which the building is located. 
(4)  The density and yard regulations of this ordinance are minimum regulations for each and every building existing at the effective date of this ordinance and for any building hereafter erected or structurally altered. No land required for yards or other open spaces about an existing building or any building hereafter or structurally altered shall be considered a yard or lot area for more than one building. 
(5)  Every building hereafter erected or structurally altered shall be located on a lot as herein defined and in no case shall there be more than one main building on a lot except as otherwise provided in this ordinance. 
(6)  No building shall be erected or structurally altered to the extent specifically provided hereinafter except in conformity with the off-street parking and loading regulations of this ordinance. 
(7)  Cooperation, condominiums and all other forms of property ownership do not affect the provisions of these regulations and all requirements shall be observed as though the property were under single ownership. 
(8)  All inhabited mobile homes and trailers shall be located in a mobile home park (trailer court) that has received a conditional use permit. No trailer outside an approved trailer court shall be connected to utilities except those trailers being offered for sale and not inhabited or being temporarily used. 
SECTION 4. - USE REGULATIONS 

A. - District Regulations. 
    In the following established districts, a building or premise shall be used only for the following purposes. 
(1)  RU-1 Rural District 
Permissive Uses: 
(a)  Farm or agricultural activity. 
(b)  Single-family dwelling. 
(c)  Public park or recreational facility. 
(d)  Church. 
(e)  Public school, elementary and high, or private school having a curriculum equivalent to a public elementary or public high school and having no rooms regularly used for housing or sleeping purposes. 
(f)  Golf course except miniature course or driving range. 
(g)  Kennels. 
(h)  Commercial greenhouse or plant nursery. 
Conditional Uses: 
(a)  Day care center. 
(b)  Day care home. 
(c)  Commercial feed lot. 
(d)  Extraction of minerals. 
(e)  Hospital, nursing home and educational, religious and charitable institution on sites of not less than five acres. 
(f)  Modular home on single lot or lots. 
(Ord. No. 3626, § 2, 4-10-95; Ord. No. 3709, § 22, 5-28-86) 
(g)  Privately operated outdoor recreational facility, operated for profit, including riding stable, lake, swimming pool, tennis court and golf course on site of not less than five acres. 
(h)  Parking lot located immediately adjacent to or directly across the street from a C or M district. 
(i)  Public building erected by any governmental agency. 
(j)  Private club, fraternity, sorority, or lodge, except when the chief activity of which is a service customarily carried on as a business. 
(k)  Private recreational facility where buildings do not occupy more than 10 percent of the site area. 
(l)  Bowling alley, billiard parlor, recreation center and arcade. 
(Ord. No. 3709, § 22, 5-28-96) 
(m)  Expansion of existing mobile home parks pursuant to the provisions of Section 4B(6)(c). 
(Ord. No. 3790, § 4, 6-23-97) 
Access Requirements: 
All entrances to public streets and roads shall be hard surfaced with Portland concrete or hot-mixed asphalt, which shall include the area extending from existing public street black top, or back of existing curb, to the public street right-of-way line. All entrances shall be designed with a minimum radius of three feet. If the street is improved with barrier type curb and gutter, then the existing curb and gutter shall be removed and replaced with a five foot wide entrance slab including three feet curbed radii. All developed parcels shall provide ingress and egress at both ends of each parking bay or parking lot with a provision for circulation of vehicles. Parking areas that utilize a portion of public street right-of-way shall be paved with Portland cement or hot-mixed asphalt, and if the public street is improved with curb and gutter, then curb and gutter shall be continuous around perimeter of parking area. These access requirements shall apply to permits issued after the effective date of this ordinance. 
All entrances to public streets and roads and all parking areas using a portion of the public right-of-way shall be maintained by the private property owner or other person responsible. 
(Ord. No. 3709, § 1, 5-28-96) 
Site Design Requirements: 
Surface or underground storm drainage facilities shall be provided for all roads and drives and parking areas. All storm drainage shall be directed into established surface and underground storm drainage facilities. Stormwater retention structures shall be provided if, in the opinion of the City Engineer, unrestricted runoff will cause increased drainage problems downstream. A structurally-sound wall, curb or other abutment shall be installed around each side of the parking area to insure that no part of any motor vehicle either extends or is capable of accidentally rolling across the property line of the parking area. 
(Ord. No. 3709, § 3(a), 5-28-96) 
    Maximum Height (See Section 5 for exceptions.) 
(a)  35 feet. 
    Minimum Yards (See Section 6 for exceptions.) 
(a)  Front-50 feet. 
(b)  Side-20 feet. 
(c)  Rear-50 feet. 
    Minimum Lot Area and Width (See Section 7 for exceptions.) 
(a)  Lot Width-150 feet. 
(b)  Lot Area-43,560 square feet. 
(c)  Lot Area Per Family-43,560 square feet. 
    Minimum Required Parking Spaces (See Section 8.) 
(Ord. No. 3709, § 19, 5-28-96) 
(2)  RU-2 Rural 
    Permissive Uses: 
(a)  Cemetery. Must be state standards and requirements. 
    Conditional Uses: 
    None 
    Access Requirements: 
All entrances to public streets and roads shall be hard surfaced with Portland concrete or hot-mixed asphalt, which shall include the area extending from existing public street black top, or back of existing curb, to the public street right-of-way line. All entrances shall be designed with a minimum radius of three feet. If the street is improved with barrier type curb and gutter, then the existing curb and gutter shall be removed and replaced with a five foot wide entrance slab including three feet curbed radii. All developed parcels shall provide ingress and egress at both ends of each parking bay or parking lot with a provision for circulation of vehicles. Parking areas that utilize a portion of public street right-of-way shall be paved with Portland cement or hot-mixed asphalt, and if the public street is improved with curb and gutter, then curb and gutter shall be continuous around perimeter of parking area. These access requirements shall apply to permits issued after the effective date of this ordinance. 
All entrances to public streets and roads and all parking areas using a portion of the public right-of-way shall be maintained by the private property owner or other person responsible. 
(Ord. No. 3709, § 1, 5-28-96) 
    Site Design Requirements: 
Surface or underground storm drainage facilities shall be provided for all roads and drives and parking areas. All storm drainage shall be directed into established surface and underground storm drainage facilities. Stormwater retention structures shall be provided if, in the opinion of the City Engineer, unrestricted runoff will cause increased drainage problems downstream. A structurally-sound wall, curb or other abutment shall be installed around each side of the parking area to insure that no part of any motor vehicle either extends or is capable of accidentally rolling across the property line of the parking area. 
(Ord. No. 3709, § 3(a), 5-28-96) 
(3)  RS-1 Residential District 
    Permissive Uses: 
(a)  Single-family dwelling. 
(b)  Public park or publicly-operated recreational facility. 
(c)  Church. 
(d)  Public school, elementary and high, or private school having a curriculum equivalent to a public elementary or public high school and having no rooms regularly used for housing or sleeping purposes. 
(e)  Golf course, except miniature course and tees operated for commercial purposes. 
    Conditional Uses: 
(a)  Country club or clubhouse. 
(b)  Day care home. 
(c)  Privately operated lake, swimming pool, or tennis court on site of not less than five acres. 
(d)  Public building erected by any governmental agency. 
(e)  Hospital, nursing home and educational, religious and charitable institution on sites of not less than five acres, provided not more than 50 percent of the site area may be occupied by buildings, and provided further that the building shall be set back from all required yard lines an additional foot for each foot of building height. 
(f)  Modular home on a single lot or lots. 
(g)  Parking lot located immediately adjacent to or directly across the street from a C or M district. 
(h)  Bowling alley, billiard parlor, recreation center and arcade. 
(Ord. No. 3709, § 23, 5-28-96) 
(i)  Two-family homes in those locations where on the effective date of this ordinance more than 40 percent of the frontage on one side of a street between two intersecting streets is used for two-family homes or two-family homes and multiple dwellings. 
(j)  Private recreational facility where buildings do not occupy more than 10 percent of the site area. 
(k)  Commercial greenhouse or plant nursery. 
    Access Requirements: 
    All entrances to public streets and roads shall be hard surfaced with Portland concrete or hot-mixed asphalt, which shall include the area extending from existing public street black top, or back of existing curb, to the public street right-of-way line. All entrances shall be designed with a minimum radius of three feet. If the street is improved with barrier type curb and gutter, then the existing curb and gutter shall be removed and replaced with a five foot wide entrance slab including three feet curbed radii. All developed parcels shall provide ingress and egress at both ends of each parking bay or parking lot with a provision for circulation of vehicles. Parking areas that utilize a portion of public street right-of-way shall be paved with Portland cement or hot-mixed asphalt, and if the public street is improved with curb and gutter, then curb and gutter shall be continuous around perimeter of parking area. These access requirements shall apply to permits issued after the effective date of this ordinance. 
All entrances to public streets and roads and all parking areas using a portion of the public right-of-way shall be maintained by the private property owner or other person responsible. 
(Ord. No. 3709, § 1, 5-28-96) 
    Site Design Requirements: 
Surface or underground storm drainage facilities shall be provided for all roads and drives and parking areas. All storm drainage shall be directed into established surface and underground storm drainage facilities. Stormwater retention structures shall be provided if, in the opinion of the City Engineer, unrestricted runoff will cause increased drainage problems downstream. A structurally-sound wall, curb or other abutment shall be installed around each side of the parking area to insure that no part of any motor vehicle either extends or is capable of accidentally rolling across the property line of the parking area. 
(Ord. No. 3709, § 3(a), 5-28-96)

In reviewing the site design, the Commission shall consider all factors it deems relevant including the use of the adjoining property and the district classification of the adjoining property. No notice or hearing shall be required and the Commission shall review the site design and make its requirements, if any, as a part of the permit application procedure.

(5)  RS-3 Residential, Class A 
(a)  Purpose. It is the purpose and intent of this subsection to allow the placement of manufactured homes within this district to increase the options available for low to moderate income households in select residential areas of the City of Lebanon. The placement of manufactured homes will be permitted subject to the requirements and procedures set forth herein. Manufactured homes that do not conform to the requirements of this subsection shall only be permitted in RS-4 Residential, subject to the provisions of (5.1) RS-4, Class B, or mobile home parks subject to the provisions of Section 4.B(6) of the zoning ordinance of the Lebanon Code. The owner of a lot in this district must demonstrate that he/she/it either owns or will own the manufactured home which is to be placed on the lot before a building permit will be issued and in no case shall a manufactured home site or lot be rented out in this district. 
(b)  Preliminary Procedure and Lot Size Restrictions. Manufactured homes shall not be placed or occupied in the City of Lebanon, Missouri, until such time as the proposed location has been zoned RS-3, the provisions of Chapter 23 of the Lebanon Code have been complied with, and a building permit issued pursuant to the provisions of Chapter 6 of the Lebanon Code; each lot in the said district shall conform to the lot area and width requirements of Section 7A of the zoning ordinance of the Lebanon Code. No area shall be considered for RS-3 Residential zoning unless the size of the area to be developed will accommodate a minimum of 20 lots. 
(c)  Use and Siting Requirements. Each manufactured home placed on an individual lot: 
(1)  Shall be occupied only as a single-family dwelling. 
(2)  Shall conform to the setback requirements of Section 6A of Appendix A-Zoning Code of Laws of the City of Lebanon, Missouri. 
(d)  Maximum Height. No manufactured home shall exceed 35 feet in height. 
(e)  Minimum Living Space Requirements. Each home shall be at least 24 feet wide and shall consist of at least 960 square feet of living space. This standard is intended to require homes to consist of multisections which are brought to the site in parts. 
(f)  Construction Requirements. 
(1)  The roof of each home must be a gable or hip roof type and covered with material that is residential in appearance, including but not limited to, approved wood, asphalt composition or fiberglass shingles, but excluding corrugated aluminum; corrugated fiberglass or metal roofs. Except for permitted deck areas, all roof structures shall provide an eave projection including guttering of not less than 6 inches but no greater than 30 inches. 
(2)  The exterior siding, covering and window treatments of each home shall be of a type, quality and appearance that is customarily used on conventionally built residential homes in the area and shall be architecturally compatible with those of neighboring properties. 
(3)  Each manufactured home shall be set up according to the manufactures set up manual and tied down per state laws and shall meet all manufacturer's specifications for support. The perimeter must be of continuous concrete block, brick, or poured concrete in lieu of skirting. 
(4)  Each home shall have a minimum of 18 inches of crawl space under the entire living area of the home and the tongue and running gear including axles shall be removed. 
(5)  Each home shall have permanent steps or decks set at all exits. 
(6)  The owner of each manufactured home is required to declare the home as real estate pursuant to the provisions of Section 700.110, V.A.M.S. 
(g)  Nothing in this Subsection (5) shall be deemed to preclude the construction and occupation of conventionally built single-family dwellings but such homes shall conform to the applicable use, siting, height, living space, construction and design requirements of this subsection. 
(Ord. No. 3626, § 6, 4-10-95; Ord. No. 3826, §§ 1, 2, 12-29-97; Ord. No. 3830, § 2, 1-26-98; Ord. No. 3980, § 1, 12-27-99) 
(5.1)  RS-4 Residential, Class B 
(a)  Purpose. It is the purpose and intent of this subsection to allow the placement of manufactured homes, within a manufactured home subdivision. The placement of manufactured homes will be permitted subject to the requirements and procedures set forth herein. 
(b)  Preliminary Procedure. Manufactured homes, shall not be placed or occupied in the City of Lebanon, Missouri, until such time as the proposed location has been zoned RS-4, the provisions of Chapter 23, Subdivision Regulations, of the Lebanon Code have been complied with, and a building permit issued pursuant to the provisions of Chapter 6 of the Lebanon Code. No area less than 20 acres in size shall be considered for RS-4 Residential zoning. 
(c)  Use Regulations. All buildings and land within a RS-4 district shall be limited to the following uses: 
(1)  Each manufactured home shall be occupied only as a single family dwelling. 
(2)  Each manufactured home shall be at least eight body feet wide and at least forty body feet long. 
(3)  Accessory buildings customarily incidental and subordinate to the use of manufactured homes. Buildings housing such facilities as laundromats, nurseries, etc., and only when such facilities are intended for the use of persons residing within the district. 
(d)  District Design Standards. 
(1)  A manufactured home district shall consist of no less than twenty contiguous acres. A manufactured home district may be developed in phases, however, each phase shall consist of no less than twenty manufactured home spaces. 
(2)  Each manufactured home in a manufactured home district shall occupy a designated space having at least 5,250 square feet of lot area. 
(3)  Each manufactured home space shall have a width of at least fifty feet. 
(4)  Each manufactured home shall have two off street parking spaces of asphalt or concrete with a minimum size of 18'×25'. 
(5)  At least 200 square feet of recreation space for each manufactured home shall be reserved within each manufactured home district, as common recreation space for the residents of the district. 
(6)  No manufactured home or other structure within a manufactured home district shall be closer to each other than 25 feet, except that a storage or other auxiliary structures for the exclusive use of the manufactured home may be no closer to another home than 15 feet. 
(7)  Each manufactured home shall be set back a distance of at least 12.5 feet from the street in the district. 
(8)  Each manufactured home shall be set back a distance of at least 12.5 feet from the rear property line. 
(9)  No manufactured home shall be located closer than 30 feet to the exterior boundary of the district or an exterior bounding street right of way. Buildings used for laundry or recreation purposes shall be located no closer than 40 feet to the exterior boundary of the district or an exterior bounding street right of way. 
(10)  The manufactured home district must conform to the City's subdivision ordinance. Plats must be approved by the Zoning and Planning Commission and City Council. All lots within the district must be owned by the owner of the manufactured home district. All streets within the manufactured home district must be dedicated to the City. 
(11)  At least 100 square feet of fenced storage area for each manufactured home shall be reserved within each manufactured home district to accommodate storage for boats, RV's, etc. 
(12)  All manufactured homes shall be skirted with non-combustible material. 
(13)  All manufactured homes must be located in an RS-4 district that has been approved by the City. 
(14)  All utilities must be underground from the main transmission line to the manufactured home. 
(15)  All manufactured homes shall be manufactured or constructed under the authority of 42 United States Code Sec. 5401, and bear a seal used by the Public Service Commission in compliance with the provisions of Section 700.015, R.S.Mo. 
(16)  All manufactured homes shall be anchored and tied down in accordance with and otherwise comply with the standards promulgated by the Missouri State Public Service Commission pursuant to the provisions of Sections 700.010 to 700.115, R.S.Mo. 
(e)  Nothing in this Subsection (5.1) shall be deemed to preclude the construction and occupation of conventionally built single-family dwellings but such homes shall conform to the applicable use, siting, height, living space, construction and design requirements of this subsection. 
(Ord. No. 3830, § 3, 1-26-98; Ord. No. 3980, § 2, 12-27-99) 
(5.2)  NC Neighborhood Commercial District 
    Permissive Uses : 
(a)  Single Family Residential. 
(b)  Bakery. 
(c)  Bed and Breakfast. 
(d)  Dressmaking, tailoring, shoe repairing, catering and bakery with sale of bakery products on the premises and other uses of a similar character. 
(e)  Health care clinic or office. 
(f)  Office or office building. 
(g)  Personal service uses including barber shop, beauty parlor, photographic or art studio, printing, messenger. No laundry or dry-cleaning uses shall be allowed. 
(h)  Specialty Retail store; such as jewelry, furniture, computers, high-fashion clothing, and others. 
(i)  Eatery such as Bistro, Deli/Sandwich shop, Tea Room, Coffee House, and others of this type. NO DRIVE-THRUS ALLOWED. 
(j)  Museum or Art Gallery. 
    Conditional Uses: 
(a)  Church. 
(b)  Conversion of single-family dwelling, two-family dwellings or other buildings to multiple-family dwellings. 
(c)  New multifamily housing. 
(d)  Restaurant. 
(e)  Residential Care Facility with no more than 10 residents. 
(f)  Private school, day care center, day care home. 
(g)  Pizza for delivery or carry out only. 
    No Open Storage of Materials: 
No part of any lot shall be used for the open and/or unenclosed display and storage of commercial materials, equipment, merchandise or supplies. This restriction shall apply to both permissive and conditional uses of lots in NC Neighborhood Commercial District. 
    Hours of Operation: 
Hours of Operation for all businesses permissive and conditional shall be between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m., except for Bed and Breakfast. 
    Access and Parking Lot Requirements: 
All commercial parking shall only be allowed behind the required front set-back line. Parking can be in the required rear set-back and extend on the sides up to the front of the building. There shall be no on-street parking without a variance. 
(a)  All entrances to public streets and roads shall be hard surfaced with Portland cement concrete or hot-mixed asphalt, which shall include the area extending from existing public street black top, or back of existing curb, to the public street right-of-way line. All entrances shall be designed with a minimum radius of three feet. If the street is improved with barrier-type curb and gutter, then the existing curb and gutter shall be removed and replaced with a five-foot wide entrance slab including three feet curbed radii. 
(b)  All developed parcels shall provide ingress and egress with a provision for circulation of vehicles. All parking areas and parking lots shall have Portland cement concrete curbs and guttering built according to city specifications and continuous around the perimeter thereof. All parking areas and parking lots shall be hard surfaced with Portland cement concrete, hot-mix asphalt, or permanently installed pavers. 
(c)  All entrances to public streets and roads and all parking areas using a portion of the public right-of-way shall be maintained by the private property owner or other person responsible. 
    Site Design Requirements: 
(a)  The front yard distances as required hereunder, such distance being a minimum of 15 feet must be a mandatory green space. 
(b)  All utilities shall be underground. 
(c)  Surface or underground storm drainage facilities shall be provided for all roads and drives and parking areas. All storm drainage shall be directed into established surface and underground storm drainage facilities. Stormwater retention structures shall be provided if, in the opinion of the City Engineer, unrestricted runoff will cause increased drainage problems downstream. A structurally sound wall, curb or other abutment shall be installed around each side of the parking area to insure that no part of any motor vehicle extends over or is capable of accidentally rolling across the property line of the parking area. 
(d)  All conditional uses must be submitted to the Commission as provided in Section 9(F). 
(e)  No reduction in access or site design requirements shall be allowed except as follows: 
1)  On-street parking may be counted in the required number of parking spaces if the Board of Appeals grants a variance as provided in Appendix A of the Zoning Ordinance. 
2)  Parking on an adjoining vacant lot under the same ownership can be granted upon a variance being issued by the Board of Appeals and the parking shall be behind the required front setback which is 15 feet. 
    Signs: 
Signs must be property specific. 
    Permanent Detached Signs: 
(a)  Each premise shall be allowed one permanent detached sign. 
1)  The detached sign shall be of monument style, not exceeding 30 square feet nor more than 6 feet in overall height. 
2)  The detached sign cannot be located on the public right of way or extend over the public right of way and must be a minimum of 6 feet from the property line. 
3)  The detached sign shall have no flashing lights, animation, no search lights or strobe lights attached. 
4)  Sign Illumination shall be designed, located, and constructed to eliminate or significantly reduce glare and shall not increase the lighting intensity upon adjoining premises not under the same ownership and control. 
5)  The premise must be utilized as a business location in order to have one permanent detached sign. Residential uses, single family and duplex, shall not be allowed a detached sign. An apartment complex, 3 or more units will be allowed one detached sign per complex. 
    Attached Signs: 
Any sign substantially and permanently attached to, applied on, structurally connected to, painted on, engraved in, etched on, or supported by, any part of a building including being connected to an electrical outlet shall be considered an "attached sign". 
(a)  Each business shall be allowed wall signs on any wall. 
(b)  Wall signs shall not extend beyond the wall edge. 
(c)  Wall signs shall not do any advertising beyond merely identifying the business and giving the times it is open. 
(d)  The total effective area of all wall signs allowed for a business shall 16 square feet. 
(e)  Sign illumination shall be designed, located, and constructed to eliminate or significantly reduce glare and shall not increase the lighting intensity upon adjoining premises not under the same ownership and control. 
(f)  Wall signs shall have no flashing lights, animation, no search lights or strobe lights. 
(g)  Residential uses, single family and duplex, shall not be allowed wall signs other than those for addresses or name identification or identification of a home occupation per the City of Lebanon Zoning Ordinance. 
(h)  No attached signs shall be located on the roof. 
    Temporary Signs: 
There shall be no temporary signs allowed. 
    Maximum Building Height: (See Section 5 for exceptions.) 
(a)  45 feet. 
    Minimum Yards: (See Section 6 for exceptions.) 
(a)  Front-15 feet. 
(b)  Side-10 feet. 
(c)  Rear-25 feet. 
    Minimum Lot Area and Width: 
(a)  Lot Width - 50 feet on existing platted lots of record 
75 feet on newly platted and/or subdivided lots 
(b)  Lot Area - 5000 square feet on existing platted lots of record 
7500 square feet on newly platted and/or subdivided lots 
    Minimum Required Parking Spaces: (See Section 8.) 
    Minimum Lot Area Per Family for Residential: 
Single-family dwelling - 7,500 square feet 
Two-family dwelling - 3,750 square feet 
Multiple dwelling - 1,500 square feet. 
    Minimum Living Space Requirements for Residential: 
Single-family dwelling - 960 square feet per family 
Two-family dwelling - 480 square feet per family 
Multiple dwelling - 240 square feet per family 
(Ord. No. 4453, §§ 2-8, 12-11-06)

    Access Requirements: 
All entrances to public streets and roads shall be hard surfaced with Portland concrete or hot-mixed asphalt, which shall include the area extending from existing public street black top, or back of existing curb, to the public street right-of-way line. All entrances shall be designed with a minimum radius of three feet. If the street is improved with barrier type curb and gutter, then the existing curb and gutter shall be removed and replaced with a five foot wide entrance slab including three feet curbed radii. All developed parcels shall provide ingress and egress at both ends of each parking bay or parking lot with a provision for circulation of vehicles. Parking areas that utilize a portion of public street right-of-way shall be paved with Portland cement or hot-mixed asphalt, and if the public street is improved with curb and gutter, then curb and gutter shall be continuous around perimeter of parking area. These access requirements shall apply to permits issued after the effective date of this ordinance. 
All entrances to public streets and roads and all parking areas using a portion of the public right-of-way shall be maintained by the private property owner or other person responsible. 
(Ord. No. 3709, § 1, 5-28-96) 
    Site Design Requirements: 
(a)  Where any parcel within the district abuts any residential district, a 10-foot wide landscaped buffer shall be provided along all property lines of the parcel where it abuts a residential district. 
(b)  Surface or underground storm drainage facilities shall be provided for all roads and drives and parking areas. All storm drainage shall be directed into established surface and underground storm drainage facilities. Stormwater retention structures shall be provided if, in the opinion of the City Engineer, unrestricted runoff will cause increased drainage problems downstream. A structurally sound wall, curb or other abutment shall be installed around each side of the parking area to insure that no part of any motor vehicle extends over or is capable of accidentally rolling across the property line of the parking area. 
(c)  Site designs which pertain to the construction of new improvements or an addition to an existing improvement shall be submitted to the City for its review and approval before issuance of the building permit. The site plan will be submitted to the Building and Zoning Administrator. If it is determined, by the Building and Zoning Administrator that the site plan meets all the rules, regulations, and ordinances of the City of Lebanon and that no variances or conditional use is required, then the Building and Zoning Administrator along with the City Administrator and Public Works Director may approve the site plan. The site plan will be forwarded to the Chairman of the Planning and Zoning Commission for approval. The City will notify the owner within 5 working days if the site plan has been approved or if the site plan must go before the Planning and Zoning Commission at their regular monthly meeting. The Building and Zoning Administrator will report each month to the Planning and Zoning Commission, by mail, all site plans that have been approved, or by report at the next regularly scheduled meeting, which meeting is held the second Thursday of each month. The Commission shall have the power to require additional setback requirements (not to exceed 50 percent of the otherwise required setback for the district), construction of fencing, planting of trees and/or other similar requirements in order to reduce any harmful effects on the adjoining property. In reviewing the site design, the Commission shall consider all factors it deems relevant including the use of the adjoining property and the district classification of the adjoining property. No notice or hearing shall be required and the Commission shall review the site design and make its requirements, if any, as a part of the permit application procedure. The approval of the site plan by the Commission shall be void after a twelve-month period if no permit is issued and in the event a change in the code requirements occurs during the said twelve-month period, the site plan must be modified to conform to the new rules and resubmitted to the Commission. 
(Ord. No. 4298, § 1, 11-29-04) 
(d)  All conditional uses must be submitted to the Commission as provided in Section 9(F). 
(e)  Any reduction in access or site design requirements must be submitted to the Board of Appeals provided for in Section 9(A).

(Ord. No. 3709, § 19, 5-28-96) 
    Minimum Required Loading Spaces (See Section 8 for exceptions.) 
(a)  Retail or Service Establishment or Wholesale Commercial Use- One space for each 2,000 to 20,000 square feet of gross floor area; two spaces for each 20,000 to 100,000 square feet of gross floor area; one additional space for each 75,000 square feet of gross floor area above 100,000 square feet. 
(b)  Manufacturing or Industrial Use- One space for each 10,000 square feet of floor area or fraction thereof in excess of 5,000 square feet. 
(c)  In all cases where the off-street loading space is located in a manner that a truck must back directly from a major street into a loading space, a maneuvering space of not less than 50 feet shall be provided on the lot on which the industrial use is located. 
(Ord. No. 3626, § 5, 4-10-95) 
(7)  C-2 Downtown Commercial District 
    Permissive Uses: 
(a)  Any permissive use of the RS-2 District, except residential and church uses. 
(b)  Automotive parking lot or storage or parking garage. 
(c)  Automobile or trailer display and salesroom. 
(d)  Automobile service station. 
(e)  Bakery. 
(f)  Bank or financial institution. 
(g)  Bowling alley or billiard parlor. 
(h)  Business or commercial school. 
(i)  Dancing or music academy. 
(j)  Display and salesroom. 
(k)  Dressmaking, tailoring, shoe repairing, repair of household appliances and bicycles, catering and bakery with sale of bakery products on the premises and other uses of a similar character. 
(l)  Drive-in establishment. 
(m)  Dyeing, cleaning, laundry, printing, painting, plumbing, tinsmithing, tire sales and service, upholstering and other general service or repair establishment of similar character. Not more than ten percent of the lot or tract occupied by such establishment shall be used for the open and unenclosed storage of materials or equipment. 
(n)  Farm store. 
(o)  Frozen food locker. 
(p)  General service and repair establishments, including dyeing or cleaning works or laundry, plumbing and heating, printing, painting, upholstering, or appliance repair. 
(q)  Mortuary. 
(r)  Office or office building. 
(s)  Personal service uses including barber shop, beauty parlor, photographic or art studio, messenger, taxicab, laundry or dry cleaning receiving station, restaurant, and other uses of a similar character. 
(t)  Public garage, filling station and automobile repair shop, or parking lot. 
(u)  Radio or television broadcasting station or studio. 
(v)  Retail store, in connection with which there shall be no slaughtering of animals or poultry, nor commercial fish cleaning and processing on the premises. 
(w)  Self-service laundry or cleaning establishment. 
(x)  Theatre, not including drive-in theatre. 
(y)  Wholesale establishment. 
(Ord. No. 4427, § 2, 10-16-06)

(aa)  Apartment. 
(bb)  Apartment-loft. 
(Ord. No. 4753, § 1, 8-16-10) 
    Conditional Uses: 
(a)  New multifamily housing. No new single-family dwellings or two-family dwellings shall be allowed. 
(b)  Conversion of single-family dwellings, two-family dwellings or other buildings to multiple-family dwellings. 
(c)  Day care center. 
(d)  Drive-in facility added to an existing structure. 
(e)  Farm implements, sale and repair. 
(f)  Feed store, including accessory storage of liquid or solid fertilizer. 
(g)  Public building erected by any governmental agency. 
(h)  Hotel or motel. 
(i)  Laboratory research, experimental or testing. 
(j)  Lounge or bar as a part of a restaurant hotel or motel. 
(k)  Mini-storage. 
(l)  Private school. 
(m)  Church. 
(n)  Existing residential uses may continue as a nonconforming use, and structural alterations may be made to the residence, as provided in Section 4B(6). Structures within the C-2 District may be converted to a residential use as a conditional use. The yard and lot requirements for such a conversion are the same as the RS-2 District. 
(o)  Light manufacturing including but not limited to the following: (1) wholesale merchandising or storage warehousing; (2) manufacture of rugs, mattresses, pillows, quilts, millinery, hosiery, clothing and fabrics, and printing and finishing of textiles and fibers into fabric goods; (3) compounding of cosmetics, toiletries, drugs and pharmaceutical products; (4) manufacture or assembly of boats, bolts, nuts, screws, rivets, ornamental iron products, firearms, electrical appliances, tools, dies, machinery and hardware products, sheet metal products and vitreous enameled metal products; (5) manufacture or assembly of medical and dental equipment, drafting, optical and musical instruments, watches, clocks, toys, games and electrical apparatus; (6) manufacture or storage of food products, including beverage blending or bottling, bakery products, candy manufacture, fruit and vegetable processing and canning, packing and processing of meat and poultry products, but not distilling of beverages or slaughtering of poultry or animals; and (7) manufacture of boxes, crates, furniture, baskets and other wood products of a similar nature. 
(p)  Bowling alley, billiard parlor, recreation center and arcade. 
(q)  Warehouse in completely enclosed buildings. 
(r)  Mini-Storage. 
(Ord. No. 3709, § 25, 5-28-96; Ord. No. 4427, § 3, 10-16-06) 
    Access Requirements: 
All entrances to public streets and roads shall be hard surfaced with Portland concrete or hot-mixed asphalt, which shall include the area extending from existing public street black top, or back of existing curb, to the public street right-of-way line. All entrances shall be designed with a minimum radius of three feet. If the street is improved with barrier type curb and gutter, then the existing curb and gutter shall be removed and replaced with a five foot wide entrance slab including three feet curbed radii. All developed parcels shall provide ingress and egress at both ends of each parking bay or parking lot with a provision for circulation of vehicles. Parking areas that utilize a portion of public street right-of-way shall be paved with Portland cement or hot-mixed asphalt, and if the public street is improved with curb and gutter, then curb and gutter shall be continuous around perimeter of parking area. These access requirements shall apply to permits issued after the effective date of this ordinance. 
All entrances to public streets and roads and all parking areas using a portion of the public right-of-way shall be maintained by the private property owner or other person responsible. 
(Ord. No. 3709, § 1, 5-28-96) 
    Site Design Requirements: 
(a)  Where any parcel within the district abuts any residential district, a 10-foot wide landscaped buffer shall be provided along all property lines of the parcel where it abuts a residential district. 
(b)  Surface or underground storm drainage facilities shall be provided for all roads and drives and parking areas. All storm drainage shall be directed into established surface and underground storm drainage facilities. Stormwater retention structures shall be provided if, in the opinion of the City Engineer, unrestricted runoff will cause increased drainage problems downstream. A structurally sound wall, curb or other abutment shall be installed around each side of the parking area to insure that no part of any motor vehicle extends over or is capable of accidentally rolling across the property line of the parking area. 
(c)  Site designs which pertain to the construction of new improvements or an addition to an existing improvement shall be submitted to the City for its review and approval before issuance of the building permit. The site plan will be submitted to the Building and Zoning Administrator. If it is determined, by the Building and Zoning Administrator that the site plan meets all the rules, regulations, and ordinances of the City of Lebanon and that no variances or conditional use is required, then the Building and Zoning Administrator along with the City Administrator and Public Works Director may approve the site plan. The site plan will be forwarded to the Chairman of the Planning and Zoning Commission for approval. The City will notify the owner within 5 working days if the site plan has been approved or if the site plan must go before the Planning and Zoning Commission at their regular monthly meeting. The Building and Zoning Administrator will report each month to the Planning and Zoning Commission, by mail, all site plans that have been approved, or by report at the next regularly scheduled meeting, which meeting is held the second Thursday of each month. The Commission shall have the power to require additional setback requirements (not to exceed 50 percent of the otherwise required setback for the district), construction of fencing, planting of trees and/or other similar requirements in order to reduce any harmful effects on the adjoining property. In reviewing the site design, the Commission shall consider all factors it deems relevant including the use of the adjoining property and the district classification of the adjoining property. No notice or hearing shall be required and the Commission shall review the site design and make its requirements, if any, as a part of the permit application procedure. The approval of the site plan by the Commission shall be void after a twelve-month period if no permit is issued and in the event a change in the code requirements occurs during the said twelve-month period, the site plan must be modified to conform to the new rules and resubmitted to the Commission. 
(Ord. No. 4298, § 1, 11-29-04) 
(d)  All conditional uses must be submitted to the Commission as provided in Section 9(F). 
(e)  Any reduction in access or site design requirements must be submitted to the Board of Appeals provided for in Section 9(A).

Any such addition that is 30 percent or less of the original building or structure may be submitted to and approved by the City Administrator and the Building Administrator so long as all other requirements of the code are complied with. The site design must show compliance with all requirements of this C-L Limited Commercial District, including, but not limited to, the following: 
(1)  The location and size of all utilities on the site; 
(2)  The location of all parking areas; 
(3)  The location of all buildings and structures.
